Sea of Thieves I think is best described as a platform for guided player interaction, I don't think the game would be nearly as fun as it is if you could play it singleplayer or in an empty server with your own crew, this however of-course comes with the downside of player interaction dictating how enjoyable the bulk of your experience is.
The game itself is easy to explain, you're a fantasy pirate in a fantasy world exploring for fantasy treasure, the game plays like the glorified pirates of children stories and in media where it's a grand adventure of treasure and loot, with betrayal and all the glory of shooting yourself out of a cannon onto a enemy ship to anchor their ship and set it ablaze all while you're fighting the enemy crew 4v1, there is a lot you can do in this giant sandbox of a game and plenty of cool and flashy tricks you can pull off.
Funnily enough, in Sea of Thieves the gold and treasure doesn't really matter, no matter if you have 10 hours or 100, you will start in the same state as everyone else as far as other people are concerned, the only thing you can upgrade is your cosmetics and factions, which factions only offer you cosmetics and more rewarding missions to go on. which while can be understandably disappointing to some, I think it lends well to the player interaction. There is no upgrading your tools or boat outside of weapons which means everyone is on a even playing field, which makes your decision to run or fight a lot more interesting as it hinges on if you think you're better than your opponent.
Player interaction in this game can be intimidating, tense or just humorous depending on who you run into, since you're on a even playing field you don't know if that ship coming towards you is just passing by or looking to sink you and steal your loot, everyone is weary of other people and I really enjoy the ways people have come to make their intention clear, when we run reapers, which exist to pirate other players, one of us usually swims over to their boat to see if they're worth sinking and looting before using our resources, and the responses to "hey you got any loot we can take?" as one of our crew climbs aboard their ship and takes a look at their stash are really fun, though of course it can be really frustrating dealing with people who want to waste your time
While there's a lot of ways you can cause a ship to come to a stand-still, this game tends to give you a lot of ways out to either avoid encounters or just waste your time, for instance, if you want to run you can just sail against the wind which makes it very difficult for someone to catch up, we've had players who were spiteful enough to sail into out of bounds instead of actually fighting back. And on the other side, it's not uncommon to get your ship sunk for sport while the assailants gain nothing from it which coming from my friend who has been fishing for 200 hours of this game, tends to be a bit frustrating especially when you have no loot to give. Not to mention there's always the option that, if a player is confident enough, they can spawn trap you on your boat making your only option to scuttle your ship and start again.
Fortunately you don't lose anything when you die but potential gold and achievements/commendations which doesn't set you back, there is very little risk to dying and sinking which is fine personally so these problems are only frustrations rather than big game issues.

tl;dr first paragraph, game good.

This game is, by far the best open adventure sea game. whether you want to hunt for gold, slay skeletons, be a merchant or you simply just want to have a laugh with your friends, this game has the potential to do it. the boat mechanics are very good and the graphics, although cartoony have a good impact in the game. i have played for quite a while now and have found little to none bugs,. the combat in this game in my opinion is much funner than the other aspects because while your racing your opponents at sea, you can fire cannonballs at them and claim their loot and sell it for yourself

Be very aware that this is a completely open PVP realm; other players can attack you at will.  There is also no overarching story that keeps you coming back and on track with things.  You have to stumble across these as you navigate across the open map.  If other players find and kill you, then you risk losing all your progress on many of these.  Some of these quests do have checkpoints, but the checkpoints don't mean anything if your key items get stolen or destroyed, then you have to start all over again.  Due to this, most players jump right into PVP and treat this place like it's Fortnite.  The fighting mechanics are a little tough to get used to, as there are simple combat basics that are taught in the tutorial, however there are some players out there who have expertly honed how to do long distance strikes using a power strike/block/jump combo, that the game itself doesn't teach you about.  All this game really consists of is island hopping and other players ramming into you and then simply chucking firebomb cannonballs at the helm of your ship and running away.  If you are on a island grabbing a treasure and you have no one else in your crew, you're done.  The 30-45 mins it took to get to that island and find those treasures after obtaining your mission leads and setting up your ship can turn into a complete waste of time, particularly if you were not interested in the PVP part, and just wanted to gather some gold and purchase a new vanity piece.  Speaking of which, its all vanity items.  There are no level/damage progressions here.  
I honestly do hate bashing at it like this, the game itself is incredibly beautiful and I really do like the engine it runs on, plus the sailing and social interaction can be quite enjoyable at times, but so can a lot of other games that don't make me want to pull my hair out the other 60% of the time I'm actually trying to earn gold and interact with the main content.  I tried the matchmaking feature a couple times, but you either get teamed up with a couple idiots who don't know how to use a microphone, or some obnoxious jerk who just wants to go and harass other ships.  Many of my gaming friends who are interested in these types of games are turned off by the inability operate this game in Third Person.  Which honestly makes no sense considering that most of the items you buy with gold are vanity items for your player.  The only time you get to see any of those items is when you do an emote or when you are looking down at yourself as your soul leaves your body after you get merc'd.
A few things that could help change my mind here:
-Turn off the ability to throw cannonballs; or at the very least, prevent the fireballs from exploding when thrown and add molotov cocktails that are much harder to find.  ...Seriously, it's all people ever really do.
-Add new content to tutorial; advanced fighting mechanics
-Recruitable Bots - to be part of your crew
-Third Person view

Best pirate game you will ever find.

I would say the main goal of the game is to reach the Pirate Legend Status by getting level 50 in 3 alliances, then you can start the really special voyages.

This game is truly what you make of it. You just set sail and decide how you want to play it 

I have had some of the most memorable moments in this game that cannot be compared to any other game.

Even after all of the time since release, the game feels as empty as the sea around which it revolves. All you do is bounty after bounty like everyone's errand boy. That is all there is to do: bounties for gold to buy cosmetics. There is no actual loot in this game. Nothing makes your ship sturdier or faster, nothing makes your swords hit harder or your guns hold more shots, nothing makes you run or swim faster. Nothing gives you actual in game advantages; it's all just cosmetic. The chase is non-existent and the gameplay loop gets stale asf real quick. 

The only fun to be had is getting your friends together to grief other players. Even that is easier said than done, since finding other people in your instance is a chore. There is no tracker on the HUD, so you have to scan the map to find anybody, and they're usually many miles away, which means sailing for 20+ minutes. Even when you kill them, they respawn in seconds as long as their ship is standing, and sinking it takes forever. 

With that said, you will quickly realize that combat in this game is just as shallow as the rest of it. There's only one sword, and it lets you block, swing, or charged stab. There's 3 guns, all of which hold 5 shots max before you have to stop fighting and look for an ammo create for 5 more shots. And there's some throwable bombs/molotovs. That's it. It's ridiculously bare bones. 

The only real "content" the devs seem to care about adding is just more lazy cosmetic skins to "chase," as if anyone gives a flying f*ck what color your pirate's crap is when it all does the same damn thing as the default. This game is going nowhere until the devs realize they need to GIVE US A REASON TO PLAY THE GAME- GIVE US REAL LOOT. Make the combat mechanics deeper. Put more living things in the environments so it doesn't feel like a dead sandbox. Do something besides add more stupid skins ffs.
This game is fun for the first few weeks but then there is nothing else to do everything is all cosmetics and a waste of money TBH

In other words, it's a cool free 2 play game, that for some reason MC is selling for 40 bucks. Avoid if you don't have friends or don't wanna get new ones.

[i]Sea of Thieves[/i] and I have a bit of a love/hate relationship with each other.
The game is great overall, beautiful maps, textures and atmosphere and pretty decent gameplay to boot. The UI is a bit clunky on PC (until you get used to it) seeing that it originally released for Xbox.

[b]Solo/Co-op[/b]
The game is do-able solo, although you really have to know your stuff to survive long enough in a session to make any real progress. The game, however, is fantastic if you get a crew to adventure with. 

This does not have to be friends (although that is advised) since you can drop into a random Open Crew and play with other people. There is in-game voice chat available in case you need it (which you will).

[b]PvE or PvP[/b]
The game has PvE elements to it (fighting skeletons, story missions, npc's, forts etc.), but mostly it's the PvP that either makes or breaks this game for most people.

There is no way to avoid PvP, unless you spawn on an empty server or the people you encounter are nice enough not to attack you on sight. Be warned, you will get ganked, a lot.

[i]Advice[/i]: Stash/Turn in your loot at every chance you get, otherwise it will be lost.

There is an in-game alliance system of sorts, but personally I've rarely seen people use it.

[b]Saved Progress[/b]
The missions system also does not save all of your progress, so be sure to complete a mission before you log off otherwise you'll have to redo whatever it is that you did before.

[b]Micro Transactions[/b]
The game allows you spend real money in-game, but they are purely cosmetic, there is no pay-to-win in this game so it all comes down to skill (which is a plus).

Overall I really do like it, but if you are the sort of person looking to explore a world by yourself, this might not be the game for you. However, if you are prepared to die (a lot), and take precautions against thieves, you should do fairly well and have a fantastically fun time.

Sea of Thieves is one of the most polished games I have experienced in recent memory. Its environment, immersive sailing and beautiful graphics made this game a pure joy to play, explore and experience. The campaign stories (called "Tall Tales") are intriguing, inventive and curious to play-through.

When it comes to combat regarding the melee strikes with the sword or guns, it feels a bit lackluster and basic. Battling enemies head-on lacks challenge and is relatively simple. That said, the ship battles against Skeleton Ships, Ghost Ships, Kraken, Megalodon or other players is very satisfying and unique. The amount of ways to mess around with your opponent, blow their ship while also repairing and steering your own creates a frantic scene of cooperation among you and your crewmates each and every time. Moments where you T-Bone an enemy ship, grapple their hull and then proceed to invade their deck to release the anchor to prevent them from moving as your allies rain down a variety of cannonballs that inflict different effects and damage is exciting that I have yet to see matched in other games. To add, depending on the size of your crew from 2 players to 4, you will be provided larger ships from a single-said Sloop to a massive Galleon, all with their own benefits and short-comings, making battles incredibly challenging.

Another key part of the game is the progression in the game. For some players, the lack of progression detracts motivation to continue playing. However, if you are someone who enjoys the experience of games more so than rewards, this may be the game for you. In Sea of Thieves, what you start with is what everyone else has and there is no additional unlocks, access to better weaponry/ships or other in the game. The quests, currencies and rewards are all related to cosmetics to improve the look and feel of yourself and your ship.

Appended review after logging a hundred+ hours in game.

tl;dr - Good game when you have friends with you.  Worst part is the toxic part of the community that enjoy camping / griefing for no loot / gain, just the sake of being toxic. And that there is little-to-no 'spawn' protection or anti-griefing methods from the Devs.  But you'll get that in a lot of Online games.

6 / 10.  Will play with friends, but will have a hard time recommending it to new friends unless they enjoy Toxic PvPers as opposed to genuine enjoyable PvP.

Pros: 
- Beautiful game. Some of the best water graphics out there and over all a very visually pleasing game.
- Can be great with friends. Especially with recent additions to events and things to do, you can go for hours and have a great time.
- Fun encounters. Rare does seem to do a decent job of balancing things too, as Bosses / Encounters (I.e the Megaladon) scale to your ship size and things like that.
- Solid progression system and plenty of different reputations and rewards to grind, without high-level players getting 'Super Power Ups' from their rep levels.

Cons:
- No anti-griefing protection from the Devs.
- Too much 'forcing' people into PvP (Fort of the Damned Markers, Etc).
- 2-man Arena is a joke 75% of the time in which one or two crews just camp others for no gain other than griefing.
- The RNG on events working is wonky.  Sometimes you'll have no weather events / boss events / encounters for ages, sometimes you'll have three at once.
- About 50% of the community is very unwelcoming to new players and can be rather toxic (in our experiences).
- Rare's Matchmaking servers and Friends system is not great.  Sometimes your Arena matchmkaing will take you out of your pre-formed party and throw you into a random party.  And Rare refuses to integrate with Steam's friends & invite system, instead forcing connection through Xbox on the PC apps... which is often down.

Definetly a fantastic pirate game, I played this with game pass for maybe 100 hours before it came out on Steam and I can easily recommend this game to anyone wanting some fun pirate adventures. However, be aware that this game requires you to have 2-3 hours of free time to do anything in a game session. Travel times take up most of your time on the seas and that's assuming you don't get attacked by other players or from the random PvE spawns. Naval combat is fantastic and there's lots of skill involved in it, a 1-man sloop can still sink a 4-man galleon if they're good enough and that's insanely hard to pull off if the galleon crew is good. 

Although most of the game is PvE, don't forget that this is a pirate game, you WILL get sunk by some filthy pirate out there and lose your treasure even if it took you several hours to collect it all and that's fine, just remember [b]no treasure is truly yours until it is sold[/b]. You have to always be on alert for suspicious ships or sneaky pirates lurking around you somewhere. Even though there's an alliance system to buddy up with another ship, they can always betray you if they feel like it and that's up to you and your crew to trust them and being ready to open fire on them if they try to betray you. Also there will definetly be ToXiC gamers out there who will spam text or voice chat with insults if they ever fight you, that's unavoidable so just stay calm and humiliate them by sinking them.  

Overall, the game can be a fun casual pirate experience, though the game does have its problems, there are bugs of course and usually the devs don't fix them asap unless its a major bug that crashes the game/servers, you'll usually have to wait for the next major update to the game to get any bug fixes. Also I wouldn't recommend rushing to become a Pirate Legend, there's nothing new or exclusive to Pirate Legends that isn't cosmetics. The voyages you get from it are just a mix of the main quests you have to do from the 3 main factions before you can dig up the legendary treasure that isn't really worth it for gold, its only worth for leveling up the Pirate Legend faction just to unlock a new cosmetic to purchase. Just do whatever you want and you'll eventually hit Pirate Legend, you could also play with someone who's Pirate Legend to still level up the Pirate Legend faction whenever you turn in the legendary loot.

This game is one of the funnest multiplayer games I have ever played...

Playing solo on this game is fun. But when you have a whole crew full of your brothers or closest friends with you, it becomes a masterpiece. First thing I saw was how amazing the water looks on this game. Rare saved all the complexity of the graphics into the water and it looks absolutely stunning. When I play with my brothers and friends we discover something new about the game each session so far. (78 hrs on record so far). This game makes you feel like a real pirate while also implementing super fun fantasy elements that pique your interest instantly. When I want to get off for the night something almost always happens to where I have to stay on a little longer or I would miss out on a ton of loot. I also love how there is no level scaling in this game and so the PVP is totally balanced. While there isn't any level progression, there are so many cosmetics that motivate you to keep playing! Even if cosmetics aren't your thing. This is a game where the fun totally lies in the journey rather than the destination. I am so happy to have gotten this game, and I'm sure I and my brothers will keep playing for years because of the pure re-playable thrill of being a pirate on the Sea of Thieves.

-No progression system for characters besides reputation at factions. I get that this would break early players in an mmo setting but maybe have different servers based on player levels

So you use gold to buy cosmetics and more quests, and you level up in the different factions so you can take on quests that give more gold as a reward. But we already established that gold does virtually nothing. So why even play the game?

Because sailing around and trying to dock you ship but crashing into islands is fun. Like really fun. Fighting other players in ship battles is thrilling. This is a good game to play with friends and drink some grog both in game and irl (if you're into that) and dance around the ship acting like a true pirate. That's where I would lay my "in between" review

What really sucks is that this feels like such a great base of a game. The amount of potential is absolutely insane but the game feels like it's missing integral parts for players to come back consistently. I wanna grow with the game and with my character beyond putting on a cool hat.
Really fun game if you're into pvp or general grind. Some amazing visuals which means I'm constantly taking screenshots! Is doable solo but much better experience with a mate.

I cant recommend it overall.

Well after reaching Pirate Legend and Athena's fortune Champion titles,
I'm finally able to make a review of this game, I hope it will help you decide if this game is worth it :)

Pros :
-Cool graphics and simulation of a pirate life.
-It's a game where you either get addicted or hate it in the first hours.
-Funnier with friends or randoms, but you'll learn so much faster in solo trust me.
-Satisfying sensation when you sink ennemies boats and grab their loot.
-Good game if you want to chill and kill time (but sometimes it can be stressful especially if you have a lot of loots and you're getting focused by a reaper or red flag emissaries).
-Active developer team (monthly updates, quick reactivity on problems in-game through their tweeter, so I would recommend to follow them there to not miss a thing and to always be aware of what's happening).

Cons:
-Intensive grind.
-Boring after a while.
-Lack of content eventhough it was way worse back when it came out in 2018.
-FPS optimization is a joke on islands (At full ultra I go from 120fps to 55 fps on big islands).
-PVP mechanic is old and boring (idk maybe they need to add some new guns or mechanics).
-Bugs after new updates are not even a surprise anymore.
-Servers issues is normal and the community is used to it (so an advice would be to never do an event the day it comes out because you probably won't receive your loot's coins, XP and achievements).
-Some events are only visible on their website and not in-game so sometimes you can miss them (Just stop it, we are lazy and hate to go through google to see our fck in-game event progression, just put it in game already ffs it's 2020).

Overall the game has a lot of problems but I still love the concept it does represent otherwise I wouldn't have reach one of the highest titles you can earn and I hope this game will continue to get the support it deserves. I haven't played such a great game in a while, so if you like intensive farming, bugs, coop and pvp but also the big map you're in the right place. We'll be waiting for you on the ocean :)

PS: If you're a veteran please help new players and don't bully them, that's what I do and I would have loved to be helped too when I started, so please do so they will always remember you, thanks fellow Legends.


Edit: The game is still awesome, probably one of the best open world in multiplayer that I've played in a while. Nothing better but to fish with friends during late nights x)

Well, edit update: If you get angry easily, don't play. If you can cope with the game, where you run the risk of griefers, and _that is intentionally part of the game_, then you will have great fun with strangers from across the globe. I can recommend using the official Discord to find crews and to use the voice comms, it makes life much easier and you can better specify which strangers you wish to crew with. 
You will be hunted. You will be chased. You will lose loot. But considering all the loot can buy is cosmetics, it's not a problem, really.
This is the definition of a game where you play to enjoy the scenery and the experience. You will win some, you'll lose lots (when you're new) but there's no pay to win and your skill is all that matters. You can learn to be good, you can learn to play better, and the community is generally welcoming to new players (esp. on Discord), but all this leads to a better sense of satisfaction when you get that loot sold. Get it. Pretend to float about a bit, and keep a weather eye on the horizon, sailor!

So now that I've played more of this game, I feel like I can make a better review. The game in essence is a mile wide but an inch deep. It suffers from a lack of pve only servers and developers that don't know what they're doing. This game has MASSIVE potential, I'm talking Destiny 2 potential, it's sad to see it be as shallow as it is. It's good to say that with firewall you can make your own pve server though it is trickery. I'm unsure if it's allowed but it's not like they can notice it anyway. 

All the fun cosmetic stuff is sadly locked away by a pay wall eg; pets. There is no way to buy a pet with gold, you could grind the premium currency or so they say, in my 8 hours I've accumulated 0 of said currency. The game is incredibly shallow as I said before, the only thing you do in it is cruise and slay skeletons with quick-time animations. There is 0 skill involved. Guns only have like 5 bullets and the gunplay is just plain bad. 

What would need to change?: This game could be the Destiny of Sea's; the Battlefield of Sea's. Think about it. PVE / PVP servers, not set in stone but the option to switch,. PVP modes; such as infantry, prep up some islands and create some fun pvp modes like I dunno capture the flag. For that to happen though we need more and better guns; so add guns; levels; perks maybe even. Than how about some big ship warfare. 20 vs 20 galeon ships with 4 man crews each! Do it, just do it already! As for PVE, dungeons, bosses, more dungeons and even more bosses, guns, and guns and even more guns, epic story adventures that you can go on with your friends, instead of this boring grind that they have now. Just take a look at Borderlands or Destiny and translate it to pirates, they'll figure something out.

Would not recommend for any price, since the fun is locked behind a paywall this game is clearly meant to be f2p / gamepass subs who don't pay anything for it. Also playing solo is a nightmare, the extremely poor game design choices make it a hell.

Really hard to say to recommend or not.  Love the game for myself, but I can't really say I would recommend it to anyone else.  The game is fun with friends, but punishing for new solo players.  Most veteran players seem to target new players constantly.  I have 25 hours into the game and still learning a lot from some of my friends who are veteran players.  I solo a few games myself and got constantly targeted by other veteran players.  I had little to no treasure of value to them, but was still a target.  I am still in the learning stage of the game and spent most of my time learning about quests, treasure hunting, and sailing.  While learning to do all this, some players seem to just want to target me for my seafarer chest which are low value chest.  Most of the people that sink and plunder my chests are veteran players with Legendary Titles.  I am pretty sure they know I am a new player with the gear and state of my ship.  With this, I can say I can't recommend this to new players who don't have the patience to learn the game and constantly get sunk by veteran players.

This is a fun and exciting game to play both solo and with friends. The graphics are beautiful, and the game play is really smooth. This is of course dependant on your PC specs. 

There is one little problem I would like to point out... For those that want to experience what this game can look like in maximum graphics... Don't bother. 
When you try and put the graphics to max (if your computer can handle it - which mine most definitely can), the game continues to play smooth, until it crashes without warning. This happens sometimes within seconds or minutes of loading into a server. When this game crashes, it is the worst thing that could happen because you lose all quest progress and booty obtained. This game isn't worth playing on it's maximum graphical setting anyways as there is limited differences between max and the next tier down.

As long as you don't play this game with maximum graphical settings, it plays really smooth. Much better than other pirate games I have played. Would recommend 8/10

I absolutely love this game. From the PvP to the NPCs. We activated Fort of the Damned one night and had two player ships try to kill us. While we were trying to sink them a galley loot ship and meg spawned that we had to fight off as well. There's a lot to do in this game and there's never a dull moment.

3 of us spent all day about 10 hours into getting a lot of treasure and solving a puzzle to summon a rare boss from a rare chest to fight wave after wave of combination-intense skeletons, dying a ton of times in the process, finally killing the boss and opening the vault, just so a player can kill our ship, take all that loot, then kill us to raid that ultra rare vault all to himself. We grinded a whole day of work and a lot of rare items just to be pirated of it by another player.

This game is about pirating, you cheat, cheapskate, low blow, betray, and screw others for the fun of the game and it just has you throwing your arms up going, "why should I even play anymore?"

Don't get me wrong, it's all tons of fun, until someone literally robs it from you.

I'm gonna play some more though because it's still addicting, but rewarding depending on the next A-hole waiting for you to do all the dirty work for him.

The title is a little misleading - the seas are in fact made of water (not people with criminal records). I was expecting a bit more crunch to my sail.

Opinion from a new player:

Sailing the sea is very satisfying and it is easy to get lost in the vast world of Sea of Thieves but my issue with this game is just that: A vast open world that is as wide as it is shallow. At first glance the things you can do in SoT seem overwhelming. I started playing solo for a few hours and the novelty of sailing had me smiling from ear to ear until I met my first galleon crew that completely ripped me... I then started playing online with randoms which made me realize that this game is meant to be played with a crew (preferably friends). After 6 hours I quickly found that every objective is for one sole purpose: Gold, and you need a lot of it. All for cosmetic gear that looks neat but offer nothing more than vanity. There is no character progression, no linear story line, and it almost feels like there is no purpose. 

Score: 6/10 - A beautiful game that is as wide as the ocean but as shallow as a puddle.

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
UPDATED - 25 hours and a solid crew of scurvy pirates later...

I am glad I gave Sea of Thieves a chance, although some of the things I said in my original post still hold true, I found myself going back over and over again because it's actually fun. Playing with friends turns this game into a completely different experience than playing solo or with randoms. 

Updated score: 8/10 - Better with friends.

Got an error: 'LavenderBeard' which blocked me from playing SoT for about 2 days.

This error is described on the support site from sea of thieves which indicated a network error and a hint that a firewall may be blocking the application. However the firewall rule was adjusted to let the game communicate through the firewall. 

After doing some more research i had 'just' to verify my microsoft account. Without verifying the account I was blocked without notice. Not even via mail.  After verifying everything worked again... 

Well this is the last time i bought a microsoft product.

This game is pure adventure. Think of everything that makes the modern day action movie pirate. It's here. Adventure, Action, Mystery, Companionship, Betrayal, etc. Every time I log in it is like a new day of adventure where I don't know what I will find. The game asks you how you want to be a pirate. There is no wrong answer. Every game is an open world with real players also upon the waves. This very element gives the game it's entire draw. These other ships can be worthy foes, valuable allies, or simple passing ships that cause paranoia. It's a simply amazing experience that is unmatched. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is willing to play a game for it's story, but not the story that is written, but instead the story you create. (Also the written story is pretty decent too.) Keep in mind the game is a lot of trial and error. There are risks and rewards to certain actions in handling other players on the sea. Just keep in mind that tall that loot you have isn't yours until you turn it in and get the cash prize for it. Until then its anyone's game! Good sailing. Maybe if you're lucky some day we shall sail together.

Great game, great sailing and wave mechanics. Feels realistic. Highly suggested to play with friends, otherwise it might get bland. That might have been the point, so get to know many and sail away.

When I first logged into the game I was amazed at how beautifull the game was, especially when I saw the water, and started sailing with the rocks and a sea monster nearby, I was thinking there is so much potential in this game. But then as I progressed and did a few voyages I learned that you earn gold and reputation, and the currency is used to buy you skins.

You can choose your boat and sail without having to earn or buy them, you can equip any gun as soon as you log into the game as well as tools and musical instruments, 

You can buy a bunch of cool skins for your weapons, for your ship, tools and instruments. The skins you can get do not improve your items, its is purely visual.

The game is good fun to play with friends and chill, but as solo you must really love the game because its either hard to fight some bosses or fight skeletons ships and repair at the same time while driving the boat.

I do recommend the game because its visually beautiful and fun with friends to adventure.

I would have liked to earn some special items that give me some kind of advantage after doing more content during more time then new players. But its still good fun and that way theres no overpowered weapons in pvp that you cant use yourself.
Love it

I really tried giving this game a shot. I was hyped when it was announced, then I heard it didn't live up to the marketing machine, then after a few years my friends were playing it a lot, so I figured I would try it out. Maybe after all this time they would have addressed the criticisms at launch. Maybe they did, but after putting in my hours here, it just feels like one tiresome slog after another. The gameplay mechanics are flat and repetitive, the random events feel more punishing than exciting, and the joy of exploration isn't even there because all the islands look almost exactly the same. I'm getting too old to want to spend days or weeks of my life waiting for a game to get to the good part. And all this is on top of the numerous technical issues I feel like should have been dealt with a very long time ago. It really seems like the studio is just content to bank on the good publicity they got when the game was announced, and maybe the player base is content to get a dozen more flavors of fetch quests, but this really isn't the game for me.

Updated after playing for a week (on and off):  

This gaming community is just plain toxic. They are a lot of trolls. However, in the moments, which are very few to none, having a good time on Adventure which some close friends is possible just don't expect much from this game or its community. Bummer that there is no option for a steam controller on this game. I'm thrilled there is a custom server to just have fun in the world. 

Maybe you could allow the option to customize a server to fight ghost ships only, no gold, no reputation. It will muster some confidence and slight skill for newbies. I say this because the Maiden Voyage doesn't really teach you how to fight unless you play the whole thing like fifty million times because there is only one fight with a ship and it ends really quick. While there is a learning curve, people who want live fighting can hop in Adventure or even Arena. 

Other than that, it's an okay game, I probably won't sink anymore real money into it.

Too many late nights have I played Sea of Thieves. 
The first experience guided me to the tutorials - called the "Maiden Voyage".
There was little to discover at first until a friend explained to me that there was treasures and secrets on the tutorial island.
Like a pirate and a scavenger hunt, both are similar.

Until I got into the servers and played solo on a small boat (sloop), I practically did what any explorer has done - grab a map (quest) and just sail! The water effects and textures are too amazing and it does feel I could throw up due to motion sickness, but I love the game and realism adds the charm. 

Play along with friends or randoms, sail from small to long ships (3 types for selections) and plunder the islands for the gold it holds. Fight the foes from the living and dead and uncover the mysteries that lie in the tall tales texts.

A quote from the Pirate Lord (Maiden Voyage) - "There’s far more to being a pirate than a blade in your hand and a love of other people’s money. It’s about finding your way through ancient caverns by lamplight, digging up long-lost treasures…
… and raising a frothing great tankard of grog when you live to tell the tale!"

The Game is great, I love it, graphics/visuals make it a beautiful game to look at and a great concept of piracy games, excellent gameplay, I've already dropped 83 hours in it at the time of this review and had it for less than a week.

However it shoud be called Sea of A**holes Rather than Sea of Thieves, THERE NEEDS TO BE PVE servers or PVP designated regions in the map in this game. After hours of grinding work wether it is fishing to collect the varieties needed to unlock new rods, or a quest that took hours, to have someone just pull up to your ship while it's anchored and unatended and start unloading cannon fire while you're in the island questing about, sinking your ship for the hell of sinking your ship and not having an honest combat fight, just all out of being oportunistc and not an ethical gamer and making you loose HOURS you've put into the the gameplay, HOURS work and hard-earned plunder and resetting whatever grinding you've done to zero.

PEOPLE USE HACKING SOFTWARE ON THIS GAME TO ALLOW THEM TO FIRE CANNONS LIKE A SEMI-AUTO, AUTO-AIM CANNONS, TELEPORT TO YOU, DISPLAY EVERY SHIP ON THE MAP AND THEIR DISTANCE. EASILY OBTAINABLE FREE TO DOWNLOAD CHEATWARE.

You can drop hundreds of hours into a game, if among those 100's of hours is just replayability of an objective you've been trying to complete for days because other players can just decide to trash your entire progress. Those hours are not worth the money you've put into the game, IT'S WASTING YOUR MONEY AND TIME OVER A MECHANIC THE GAME HAS NO CONTROL OF. AT THE MOMENT. You end up feeling just discouraged to continue and start from scratch all over again and rage-quit from the time you've put in to progress being lost.

Again, it's not the game itself what makes this game suck (THIS GAME IS A MASERTPIECE), it's the people that play it who suck big time and go about doing all kinds of lows because they can and there's no repercussions. I'm a huge fan of ship combat games, Guns of Icarus was the game that got me hooked, followed by Blackwake, so I do like an honest fight against an opponent that will make me work for whatever loot his/her ship has, but not to have low-life unethical piece of sh*t gamers come trash all my progress.

This game is for people who have 2-3 friends to constantly play, learn the game, and get good at the game with. Matchmaking throws you+1 onto a 4-man ship, then sits there idly for 20-30 minutes without adding the other two bodies necessary to run this boat. The PvP community is utter toxic "ez pz lol" trash that sinks your ship when you have 0 loot - they are just so bored out of their right minds to a point where a 4-man assault on a 2-man parked ship is the highlight of their session. Oh yes, and they're proud of themselves for doing it - extremely so, too, and they'll let you know, you just wait. 

Also, massive amount of hiccups and glitches for a game that's been out for that much time, from random "teleport 2-3 m sideways" to "your sound is now gone since you dived into the water," and don't even get me started on the UI glitches (players leaving/joining, loot hand-in, voyage progress, etc. not displayed to you at all until you've re-started the game). 

All in all, this is some streamer sh*t game - go in with your mates, make some funny videos, get wrecked by PvP wh*res, get some likes on YouTube. If you're solo, don't expect to enjoy the experience.

So before writing this I had a look through some of the negative reviews and I hope this will be of some help to people who would have heard things from others who may have played 1.7 hours and then said it is awful and you just get camped blahh blah all of this . I'll try and address a few of the biggies :)

New players/Playing solo/being COMPLETELY Fresh:

I was gaming when the CDs or the Cartridge in a box came with a manual you could have a nice read of when sitting on the throne but we don't live like this now you have to take a little bit of initiative, you don't have a little manual but you have the power of mister Interwebs which after scratching the surface you will find there is a Sea of Thieves Discord community. Now as in real life communities there are the village idiots and there are the helpful people. No community is perfect in any game and in fact there are a hell of a lot of worse ones but there is a thread specifically created for new people and its constantly full of others willing to help / teach. Youtube now has become the manual for games so as long as you can put up with an ear bleeding American voice (sorry pondies) there is a lot of information to be gained.

Now I don't know where this expectation for instantly being incredible at a game has come from but I personally understand completely that when you start anything , specifically a new game in this instance you will be awful at it. lots of reviews come from playing less than 2 hours or something similar. I feel this is hardly a fair assessment to be able to make a rounded view of a game. We learn from our mistakes and you will learn lots here.  Accept and learn, this is the path to enjoyment. Most of my journey to Pirate legend was done Solo and ohhh so much of it I was being chased and sunk but after each time you learn things , tips tricks to make dealing with this easier.  This can be to the point where you will then get good enough to then take on almost any of the world events Solo and then once you realise what is what you can communicate effectively to make friends (yes this does happen and quite a lot actually) learn how to flee bigger ships using the wind or going straight into it, leading them into dangers you can deal with better as a smaller ship. You will get killed and sunk a lot but you will learn. As is the same with any game PvE or PvP  (assuming you play PvE games on a challenging setting)   You can even have chill nights playing Solo and fishing once you realise how to sail safely away from the busy shipping lanes. It all comes with experience. Any craft takes time to master and once you do it becomes incredible. And as a new player you have exactly the same equipment as every other player...

Concerning some people's negative reviews on not being able to "upgrade" things:

 Now I have seen this complained about "there is no progression" etc but it honestly think it is incredible that the ONLY thing that others crews will have as an advantage over you is skill from time played (they have accepted and learned too) and maybe more people. (If you wanted to fight 4 people in the street on your own would you expect to win unless you were very talented?)  The progression comes from showing off your appearance, title, skins earned from things you have conquered and people that know the game will notice this. Its a hard life but ultimately a VERY fun and rewarding one. One review in fact said that the tutorial is PVP , It isn't and I can only assume the in-game tips for new players were mistaken for an actual tutorial when there is a whole little scenario called Maiden Voyage for you to do.

"lack of content" / "Nothing to do"

Its very hard to review something based on other peoples opinions without being insulting to other people. I say this because in this game if you are struggling for things to do then I feel that you are not a creative person and think in a very linear way. There is a HUGE amount of lore and story quests for you to do that have checkpoints specifically so if you happen to get sunk then you can crack on where you left off. I've even typed/spoken to other crews saying i'm only doing tall tales (story quests) so there is nothing aboard. A seasoned player will realise there is nothing to gain from sinking you upon hearing this. you will always have bloodthirsty semi new people that unfortunatlely Mr Waye, just want to watch the world burn. The beauty of this game comes from the fact that no two play sessions are the same, you create your own fun here so it does disappoint me hearing others say there is nothing to do. I guess its almost pity based on the fact there are so many games that tell you where to go and what to do and how to do it now , it becomes an expectation for titles like this. 

My experiences:

I have sworn at his game (and other players to my shame) many times, felt like my world has ended after losing 6 figures worth of loot, made stupid mistakes, had huge amounts stolen from me, been sunk by completely new players and all sorts of other things. but i've also laughed more than any other game I have played, been in Awe of its beauty , made friends, taught new people and even encouraged a friend to take it up. Rare entered my life with Goldeneye, banjo Kazooie, DKR a whole host of others and its Quality of game does not feel influenced by its owners at all. Microtransactions have become part and parcel of how gaming has evolved from a passion to businesses. This game feels to me like 98% passion and 2% Business. I've mentioned that every player has the same equipment.. so you would only purchase other skins or a pet if you loved the game enough to include thhat in your experience. you are not pushed you are tempted.

My personal view on the "we need pvp servers and PVE servers"

there is a very strong case for this and I fully sympathise for the people that just want to pirate on without trouble, and I also understand the people who just respond with a popular reference to the game's name. I even think now there are private servers where this is a reality but I feel this is the extent it should be. your experience and fun in this game comes from the thrill of knowing there are other people out there and I would not change it for anything, despite my huge amounts of rage quits insults and being insulted this has to remain as it is to maintain the game's core ethos and feel

So what is Sea of Thieves?

You get to be a pirate sailing the seas by yourself or with a group. It can be the most relaxing game on earth or an incredibly chaotic one. You can get on a boat and sail around the seas with no objective, just enjoying the sound of the ocean and exploring islands for random treasure. You can find or piece together maps to find buried treasure, hunt skeleton captains, find long lost vaults, solve riddles, progress through fascinating tales, hunt huge sea creatures, engage in PVP,  deal with volcano's, or just chillax with fishing, cooking, music and good ale.

When it comes to visuals it has hands down the best looking water in a video game, and at sunrise/sunset it is just jaw droppingly beautiful.
I didn't like the look of the pirates themselves at first but the style has grown on me, and there are tons of cosmetics to change your look, many of which involve you having to pull off some commendation (achievement) or another to unlock the privilege of getting.

Sailing your ship is fantastic once you get the hang of it. Melee and ranged combat is serviceable at best, and it would be nice if they tightened it up but it's not a deal breaker. Using cannons and grapplehooks and all of the things you can fire and do with them is really great.

Are you after frenetic fast paced relentless action with no downtime? This isn't it.
There will be quiet times just sailing the seas between islands and if you're with people you can chat and play music and have a laugh. There will be times when out of no where pirates or a sea creature will descend upon your vessel and you'll need to just make the most of the situation. Overall it's a game you can do at your own pace, and I appreciate that a lot.

If you can find like minded other people to do it with, this game can be something truly special.

This game is good, graphics are okay, gameplay are quite okay, the content is good enough.

Graphics 8/10
You will be finding yourself lost in awe because of scenery with beautiful graphics, or lost in fear because of the thalassophobia that you have. Like seriously, i find the sea is quite soothing will musical instrument playing in your hand, Such a good time.

PvE Content 8/10
If you like to explore, like to solve riddle, and it burn your curiosity to finish the quest, the hint, and everything about adventure, i tell ya, this is good game. There is tons of quest or story line that you can enjoy with your friends, lover maybe and this game require you to play with others.

Gameplay 5/10
If you are newbie, come to this game because of these beautiful ads or whatsoever, then you need to do a lot of homework by searching about "How To Sea of Theives" because helllllllllllllllll man, game wont tell you what to do, whats the purpose, how to do, and everything, you will need to solve or find it by yourself by reading the wikis, watching hours of videos and everything and then you will find yourself practicing in the ship or in the island, just to get killed by some skeleton or players.

PvP Content 3/10
As i mentioned above, this game require you to play with others, this is what comes into your play time. As you progress with the quest, the riddle, or whatsoever, you will be forced to sail with others player, and you cant choose to not to stay friendly because 80% the others will turn HOSTILE towards you, either just for annoy you, or they just want to loot your 5 hours worth of hardwork. So you forced to get bullied by someone else in the game if youre not good enough with running away.

Dont get me wrong, i love Sea of Thieves, but not the community, i live in ASIA which is pretty much is either cheat, or toxic. 
I enjoy crashing with other people, but not gonna enjoy after doing hardworking quest and killing enemies just to get looted by the end by some 4 people hiding/"tucking" in your ship just to come out later exploding bomb, or they guy with explosion swim from across the island just to destroy you.

I get it, this is called Sea of "Thieves" so yeah, there you have it. Honestly if "Raft" has a lot of content, i would be playing that game for long hours.

I am on my way to Pirate Legend, with 55 Gold Hoarder, 30 Mechant Alliance, 42 Order of Soul but meh, im just gonna give up. That 90 Hours of my gameplay is the "Me" that doesnt give up.

tl;dr 
- If you like pvp, this game is for you
- if you like pve, you better stay away from this game and save your money for something else


- If you dont have friends to play with, man just stay away or you will be doomed.

I've already put hours into my XBOX account previously with this game. 

I believe it's definitely worth it, the best experiences are with friends-- and for those who enjoy sailing alone you won't have a problem either. 

This game, as they have proven-- is constantly being updated with new content to explore and more fun ways to act in PVP and PVE- more and more enemies are added, events, quests, and factions- I'm doubtful that you'll become bored-- and if you ever do, come back in a week or two and you'll have more stuff to do. 

We all get burnt out sometimes. 

I'll leave a much more detailed review down the line, but for now- I believe this simple review is good enough for people wondering what you can experience in this unique and fun game.

This is everything I've dreamed of for a pirate video game! Sailing ships feels authentic with all the tasks you have to keep them afloat and moving. Cannons are easy to use and have a variety of different ammo to make things even more interesting in combat. Crossing swords and firing guns is simple enough to get the hang of quickly. Plenty of adventures to go on with the constant updates coming out. Lots of treasure to find. Lots of lore to uncover. Plenty of customization, most of which can simply be unlocked with the gold you find in game (there are premium currency things like pets, but what I've seen so far hasn't been overpriced compared to most games I've played that have microtransactions).

TL;DR It's the pirate game you've been looking for if you're a fan of pirates like I am.

It’s important to understand that even though Sea of Thieves is a shared-world online adventure game, it’s not actually an MMO with a persistent world. This means that each and every time you log into Sea of Thieves you’re given a brand-new ship in one of three classes based on the size of your crew– Sloop (up to two players), Brigantine (up to three players), or Galleon (up to four players) – and everything except your long-term progression goals are reset. All of the supplies you accumulated last time, the row boat you found, the storage chests you saved – all of it’s gone.
easy to blow up your own ship

Sea of Thieves had a rocky launch with barely any content in 2018. However, after the last big updates this is a hidden gem of games. First monthly major updates get the community going a lot tons of quests voyages and story-based adventures. 

Sea of Thieves is about as free-form of an experience as you can get, which is both a blessing and a curse. On the one hand, you could probably spend close to a dozen hours having fun sailing around without ever realizing there is a proper campaign to follow. And that’s when I discovered that even though its free-roaming gameplay is enjoyable enough. And on the other hand, you can chase the campaign missions "Tall Tales" which includes lots of sailing, solving puzzles and fighting (since you are sailing a lot the chances that you are going to fight while sailing is very high).
 
 Progression in Sea of Thieves, like its overall structure, is pretty loose. Rather than gaining experience points to level up a character, you increase your reputation with five different Companies by completing voyages, finishing Commendations (similar to achievements), or turning in specific items. 

 Almost everything you unlock is purely cosmetic. If you’ve got a good group of two or three friends to play with, it’s hard to find a game as entertaining as this one!

Final Verdict: [b] 7.5/10 [/b]

This game is so weird because the aspects of the game involving playing solo, like the missions and sailing are really fun and casual, yet the aspects of playing against other people, like the ship combat are stressful and obscenely unfun. You really can't play the game solo and have fun without being a total loser, and if you try to play solo it's just like, what's the point? You can't focus on the missions because someone always shows up to destroy your ship. It's like the game was designed around taking joy in ruining the fun for other people.

Zero reprieve from PvP makes learning the game a miserable experience. Most people that are still playing don't care if you are worth nothing, they will shit on you, and if you run, they'll chase you to the ends of the map. On foot combat is as clunky as I've ever seen in a game. The UI is awful, and there's zero progression at all. Which means all that's left is hunting people down.

Also, the game isn't worth playing solo.

I liked the graphics and exploring. If other players were something you could opt in to dealing with, it might be worth recommending. The store tagline is "With no set roles, you have complete freedom to approach the world, and other players, however you choose." What this should say is: You will PvP. The game, and player-base, allows nothing else.

This review is hard for me. on one hand i really enjoy alot that this game has to offer. The sailing feels great, and with freinds we all enjoy the antics we get up to when sailing and getting treasure. the word puzzles are entertaining as everyone i play with is Incompetent, and we find ourselves spending way too much time screwing around. The problem comes when we are sailing back with our loot. The game is about pirates, and even has a faction dedicated to such debauchery. However, not being of that ilk, I find the looting and being hunted rather annoying. I love this game. I have been playing Sea of Thieves now for over two years, I own it on my xbox as well as on steam. If you like having the freedom of choice, that open world sandbox feel, SoT is for you. The game has a great community, with devs who are constantly adding content every month. The game is a little big to download, and there are some issues involving Hit registration, but these are ever evolving topics as each update comes out. Along with that open world aspect, you can do whatever you want in the game. You want, a story, they got story. You want a fight, sail to the nearest ship or maybe try out Arena. There's even fishing. I will say this game is much more enjoyable with friends, and it can get a little confusing at times, so I recommend looking up a guide. One final thing, you WILL lose in this game, and you have to be willing to lose or you will hate this game, as the saying goes, You win some, and you lose some.

Let me tell you a tale. A tale of my first few passings within the Sea of Thieves.


When I first awoke to the Maiden Voyage I in fact dared to claim that unlike most that went beofe me, I was likely much more well versed in the arts of sailing than they that came before me. For I informed myself quite thoroughly and waited a LONG time until I even considered the fabled Sea of Thieves. For I made a vow in this regard, not to repeat past mistakes when it came to my hard earned money.

Yet there I was. And I must say that happy does barely describe the feeling of me actually experiencing the wonderfull sights for my own. Sights I so far only ever could ponder about through others. Immideately I realized though, that my knowledge, well prepared as it was, still lacked ... much to even dare call it well versed. Yet now, I had the true ability to learn. And so I did. For quite a long time, and BOY did I enjoy every second of it. From stearing my first rowboat over cooking my first meal up to setting my first sail. Memorys I will treasure.

And yet ... that is but the beginning of my tale!
For when I then arrived in the actual Sea of Thieves I felt completely lost once again. It is hard to even think about something to compare this sea to. So the first thing to do was obviously to search for another crew. A crew to take me in for a while, grant me a cut of their treasure but most importantly, allow me to mirror their knowledge. And I did not have to search for long haha. More precise to say I did not have to search at all.

When we first set sail on our Brigantine I had no real idea what we were actually doing. And while the other mate wasn't exactly what I'd call magnificent, after all one simply cannot expect to get along with everyone, the Helmsman though was especially nice. Furthermore he seemed quite the seasoned sailor aswell. He told me that I was very lucky indeed and that after this journey I would have more Gold than most of my status can even dream of! And by now I can say, that was NOT an empty claim.

The voyage was long. We were sailing from island to island following some weird key compass which I initially could not understand even a bit. Yet after but a few strides on said islands I managed to use it just fine, though I still did not really understand what we were searching for even though the Helmsman tried to explain. At that time, though now I do well understand, all I could make out from it at that point, was 'Vault Run'.

We came to a great stone cliff painted with boars. The Helmsman gathered us and said: Behind this wall there is imense treasure, but we only have a very limited time to carry as much out of its hall as possible so we should hurry and not bother to carry it directly to the ship. And when he opened the wall like door within the cliff, with some kind of riddled key which appearently was our previous goal, I stood in awe!

Yet I controlled myself and focused on carrying as much treasure as possible infront of the enormous door, knowing that it would close soon. So much treasure there was within this hall of stone, I would indeed not have dreamt of it. The hall itself though was obviously more than just a simple hall of a culture that long since abbandoned it. It was also some kind of riddle. And as I later realized a gateway to a deeper, even more secured chamber.

Yet my glimpses at it remained fractued at best for I was fully focused on carrying as many treasure chests out of the hall as possible and that as quickly as possible. Indeed by now I have to confess that then, greed came upon me, greed that should be punished.

Though, through the fact that I was not alone, solid progress was made in completely clearing out the hall, I could not help but wonder why suddenly the Helmsman stopped his carrying and instead fiddeled around with some ancient pillars. Yet I trusted him and dared not disturb, still focusing on my own treasure hunting. Then, another stone wall opened, and behind it ... a single chest that obviously, was the true treasure within this ancient place. And I had the honor of carrying it to safety.
A glorious moment indeed. Yet our time within these walls was comming to an end.

The Helmsman made it clear that NOW we had to leave but there was still so much treasure to save! I thought to myself. ONE more chest! I succeeded. ANOTHER one! I succeeded. AND THAT BIG PILE OF GOLD OVER THERE!

Before I could even lay hand on it, the great wall that was the entrance closed and I found myself trapped inside the hall, that was, to my great shock, with VERY great speed, completely filling up with water. Immediately I had the most terrible regrets and asumed that I had not only lost the treasure but my life to go with it. And relativly quick, I did indeed drown in the hall out of which I could find no escape.
With only the gold still within giving me some kind of comfort.

When I woke up I found myself in an ethereal form. I instantly remembered that I had already seen this in the shape of a man only named the 'Pirate Lord' back when I first started my Maiden Voyage. And much more importantly that I had read about this within the Pirate Lords very own journals and that they stated we were somehow protected within the sea of thieves.

During my Maiden Voyage I paied fairly little attention to this. Yet after what I can by now truly call my "first" death, I thought differently about that indeed! I looked around and recalled upon my knowledge about religion. This was obviously the passing afterlife and I was on the ship to cross over. Calling it Ghostship would be an understatement yet what most caught my attention was the hovering man steering it.

I walked up to him and spoke. And he spoke to me aswell.
And before I could say anything else I remembered once more a passage of the Pirate Lords journals.
Speaking about this very Ferryman and that for us in the Sea of Thieves he should be seen with great respect. It honestly seemed like a sad existence this beeing had to endure yet also, he seemed selfless on a different plane indeed.

Then, after but a short time, a portal appeared. And I knew that this was my way back to the living. I hesitated not and a few seconds later I could see the sun again! Standing next to the nice Helmsman on the ship that brought us to the vault in the first place. He already expected me and didn't even seem surprised. I for my part though, was happy indeed, not only to not have failed this adventure but also, and I say that with a tiny bit of greed here aswell, haha ... to see all of the magnificent treasure still just waiting to be loaded onboard!
And so we did :D

Back at the Outpost we sold it all to a price that, so I was told, and once again I was told the truth, was in fact excellent yet even if it hadn't ... I felt like the richest sailor there is for a moment.
In the end we raised a Grog and made sure to remain friends even though this particular adventure came to an end. And thus I was free to go on another. Though much richer and, perhaps even more importantly, quite a bit wiser.

And while this tale ends here. My tale did in fact not. Just the next day I signed up for a Cargo run for the buisnessminded Mearchants guild during whitch me and my crew were attacked by a rivaling crew when in the middle of nowhere a Skeleton Galleon attacked! The fact that we made it out of there alive and even victorious over the other crew could probably make me tell a tale twice as long as the one I already told. And oh great GODS! The next day in fact makes these previous tales BOTH seem almost miniscule in comparison!

For I was taken onboard a Galleon by a crew of Pirate Legends! And boy the journey was LEGENDARY indeed!
Let's just say it ended with a treasure whiches core rightfully bears the name 'Chest of Legends'.

But why simply imagine it ?!
I say grab a Grog and then join in with the shanty!
For not since my adventures back at Monkey Island have I ever seen such glorious Horizons!

Each session is it's own little adventure and i can guarantee you that you'll have tons of fun.

This game is really awesome! From the stunning graphics, to the amazing storytelling, to the action packed PvP. Sea Of Thieves is definitely a game I would recommend to others. Just watch out for enemy ships when you're bringing back your loot!

This game uses graphic design similar to World of Warcraft. Sailing ships FEELS like sailing ships.  Not just turn left or right, but turn the wheel several turns, watching your compass heading.  Trim the sails or angle them to catch the wind.  The seas are beautiful.  Combat is exciting ship to ship or on land.  The choices for choosing your avatar are very limited as to body type/look.  But, you can buy multiple choices for hats, pants, shirts, coats, etc.  Also you can buy cosmetic upgrades to your ship and purchase pets.  There is no leveling up as all players are created equal.  You can play various tunes on instruments, cook you food. Perform various kinds of sailing missions...kill skeletons for gold or other treasure,  find can capture wildlife to bring back to one of several guilds.  I played first time yesterday with my son and grandson.  We played 8 hrs straight.  This game, tho no longer a new one, is SUPER FUN.  My only complaint:  No 3rd person view except when you use an emote, such as dance or point.  Otherwise.  LOVE IT.

It's a husk of a game. It might be fun to spend time with your friends, but it's by no means a well made game. Constant crashes, bugs, clunkyness, etc, piled on top of a bizarre "Session refresh" so that every time you boot the game you start over, keeping only cosmetics. I'll play it with my friends for the social aspect, but running into other players means you'll be griefed until you quit or switch lobbies. Bad community, shallow gameplay, gimmicky mechanics and no polish. Don't expect much, but get it on sale and sail with friends for a few hours.

First hour into playing I matched with a random and we set sail, within twenty minutes we found a man with purple hair sitting in a life raft. All he had was his monkey named Monaram and a box of exotic spices he claimed was his happy smoke. He only spoke in rhymes, and whenever we asked where he came from he would growl at us. The three of us went off and met another batch of Sailors who took my new self under their wing as our crews joined together to find epic fat loot. There was romance, suspense, horror, and a deep hatred for Randal the cat. As we were hauling our fat loot out of a vault we were descended upon by another group of pirates. The magic rhyme man was slain instantly along with his monkey. The other experienced crew left me and the random for dead as we ran across the island carrying the last few chests we had. The random was shot dead like an animal... his body turning to green mist as our treasure was lost to those pirates. As my broken body climbed aboard our ship with the last piece of treasure, Randal sat there licking himself as they set my ship ablaze with all my loot. As I laid there, dying from my injuries and my ship with all the treasure sinking to the bottom of the ocean, Randal the cat just sat there, licking himself.         10/10 you can throw up on your friends and sing Sea Shanties.
Other than being murdered all the time and constantly losing all your shit, it's very enjoyable.

Despite having a laundry list of accessibility options, you can't disable or reduce the agonisingly bright bloom or the eye-watering HDR.
You get gimped if you try to do most of the content solo.

WARNING:  IF YOU CONSIDER YOURSELF AS PVE ONLY PERSON AND HATE ANY SORT OF PVP DO NOT BUY. YOU WILL GET KILLED/LOOTED.

So, if you are still here, and don't mind pvpve gameplay, then listen up. I myself am a more pve person then pvp, but this game is not as bad as some reviews and community posts make. Yes, there is always that chance of being stalked by another crew, getting in a fight and getting sunken and all of your treasure taken by other people. Yes, as my experience showed me, 95% of close range ships will start a fight and will try to catch you, sink you, board you, kill you, take your loot, burn your ship and what not, but..

There is a thing. You can go for hours and won't even see another ship up close. They may stay at horizon or you won't even see them at all. And when you see them coming at your general direction, if you don't want a fight, you can always run. In most cases they wont even chase or if they do, you still can run and in most cases they will give up.

I myself have played sessions without any pvp encounters, and if you think that someone is after you, stalking and what not, you can always restart the session, which will put you in a different server. I mean, you may get unlucky or lucky sessions, depending on what you want from the game.

So the pvp aspect being out of way, i can say that the game visually looks great, if somewhat cartoony. Also sound design is top quality. Almost every action in the game has a sound clue. From successful hits on enemy ships to full blown wind in your sails. Gameplay mechanics itself are straightforward, yet somewhat not so well explained, such as ship speeds, sail position according to wind and ect. But after you have played and seen the basics, you can look for additional information online, like youtube or steam community. 

Overall games pve or pvp elements on its own are somewhat boring. Get in a few ship fights and you may as well have seen them all. Same thing goes for pve, in itself is very repetitive and boring. You mostly gonna do samish things in sameish locations over and over. And that's where the pvpve aspect of the game shines. Having that real sense of danger over your hand while doing 100th quest for gold hoarders will spice things up. And what a great feeling  when you manage to sell loot worth 200k after being chased across the map by 2 ships and still managed to outsmart/outplay them. Every time  I sell loot in this game is like victory to me. 

So, what can you do in this game you ask? Well, first of all, SoT are sandoxy game, there are no “you must” or “you have” to do things here. If you want you may just sail around and fish out treasures from sea, or trap pigs and chickens in crates. However game have various factions with their reputations. So that would be your “progresion”. Do gold hoarder quests and rise their reputation, put their emissary flag on and have even more gold/reputation from their voyages. And if its your thing You can just sail around under Reapers flag and hunt other players for their hard earned loot. Its all up to you and your skill. Game also have skelington forts, kraken, megalodon, skelington ships and ghost ships and some other world events to take part to. Or you can yust dock your ship at some small trading post, catch fish, cook it and sell to the Hunter faction.
Your rewards in game are gold and cosmetics. With gold you can buy mre cosmetics. So no pay to win stuff. All what others have you can have. Everyone has access to all 3 ships, all 4 weapons, all cannon balls and ect. So by sinking you lose only your loot=gold= some cosmetics what you can buy. And even as noob as i'm myself, i can easily make 100k in a session, and some nice skins can cost as much as 250k. Just be smart, dont sail around for multiple hours gathering loot. If you sink you will lose all, so if your pvp skills are not up to task, then sell quickly, cose all what you turn in is yours and you dont lose gold when you die. I have a rule that if I play solo I go for an outpost as  soon as I have 10ish chests or I spot a ship coming in my general direction. 

And for bad stuff.. Controls feel like a bad port from console to pc, some keys just dont make sense. Game can get buggy. Sometimes i will lose all feedback for treasures sold and reputation gained and sometimes some shops bug out so i can't see my character at the preview window and it may crush me on the desktop.

First review, going to keep it short. 

Great game with a crew, used Discord to find other newbs to play with and was lucky enough to find a few good people to befriend and cooperate with.  If you are playing with others that aren't team players, it isn't much fun.  

Graphics are beautiful, especially the water physics.  Sailing is a lot of fun whether it's on any of the three types of ships.  Lots of weather events, random sunken ships to explore, and islands.  There's even a Kraken that you could be unfortunate enough to encounter.  

The music is really well done, excellent high quality acoustic instruments, no synths.  Music changes often and always fits the mood of what is happening.  

This game is a blast to play, if you're into pirating and sailing.

The ONLY gripe I have about the game is that there isn't much of a reason to play except for making gold to buy cosmetic and aesthetic improvements for your avatar or ship.  That's it.  No upgraded guns, cannons, sails, speed... nothing.  You just sail around to find gold and plunder with friends.  And you know what?  At the end of the day, that's alright with me.  Because this game is pretty freaking fun.

TL;DR :: It took 10 hours to get a good amount of coordination with my friends. Learning how to manage steering, the sails, repairs, and combat all at the same time was a challenge, but a rewarding one. Early game, solo especially is slow and boring, but once you find a good group of friends and find what you enjoy doing; the game definitely gets more fun. 8/10

Sailing is fairly simple; manage the sails, steer the ship, use the anchor as needed. With practice the Sloop can easily be used solo or with two players. The Mid-sized ship works decently with three or four players and offers some decent benefits for the extra size in the form of additional cannons and storage space.

The game is fairly risk/reward based. You can loot and do quests and have a good haul; but a few too many fights with other players and AI can sink your ship and you'll lose everything. Figuring out what is the best amount for you and your crew is very important for getting good money.

PvP is fun if your winning, not so fun if you're losing. Getting out numbered happens a lot playing with only two players or using a smaller ship. Getting used to the cannons is very crucial to the game play and being effective with the special cannonballs is vital.

Quests are varied enough to give some replay value to each kind; but they mostly boil down to go to X island and do a thing. Fight some skeletons, search for the X on a map, do a riddle and dig up some treasure, move X cargo to X island, etc.

Raids are a challenge worth doing. Sail to the spot on the map where you spot the skull, tornado, etc. Fight waves of enemies until you win. They give good rewards of gold and doubloons at the end, but do have the risk of getting attacked and losing everything on way to port. as with any other time.

Cosmetics are decently varied but not vast. A handful of items for each slot, hats, coats, pants, etc. Weapons and items have the same for them as well. They don't provide any kind of boost to damage or HP; meaning everyone is on a fairly level playing field in combat. The art style is cartoony and highly detailed leading to a distinct, vibrant pallet during the day and a darkened, subdued one at night.

Overall; Sea of Thieves is a fun co-op game with enough to do for players to continue sailing for a very long time. Visually and mechanically this is a fantastic pirate game I'd totally recommend. 8/10

Some people hate themselves and the world, they are only having fun when other people are miserable.  A game like this gives those people a medium to go wild, and that is exactly what you are signing up for with this game.  The PVE aspects are only there to distract you to allow other players that only care about PVP to get the drop on you.

A couple days ago I started to feel pretty sick with respiratory symptoms, so I went to get tested for Covid-19. And thus began self-quarantine & the super exciting wait to receive the test results, yay! NOT exactly my favorite way to end the week... So yesterday, I'm browsing my Steam Library searching for a game that will do the trick to get my mind off me being sick & anxious waiting for Covid-19 results. Perhaps some Deep Rock Galactic again? After putting in 300+ hours, my mouse cursor decided it might be time to try something else & made its way to the Steam Store.

I just started Sea of Thieves. There's too many reasons why I like it, & I have only one thing I wish was different/better: it's really annoying & terrible how you are forced to use a Microsoft/Xbox Live account to log in/play. Figuring out how to add/play with Steam friends or anyone that's not on your Xbox Live account friends list is a nightmare.

But going through all that Xbox Live hassle/frustration was so worth it. For me, this game offers a profoundly unique experience I never had before. It's exactly what I was looking for to keep my spirits up & mind occupied during an unpleasant time I'm having to spend sick in isolation.
