One of the best Open PVP games I have ever played in my life. Not since World of Warcraft have I been so in love with a game. The people begging for private servers are missing the point of the game. The point is anything can happen. Maybe that galleon is friendly, maybe and more likely, it's an enemy who wants to sink your ship and steal your treasure. A paranoid pirate is a happy pirate. Private servers would only ruin this game for me. Putting PVPers with the PVE grinders is what the game is all about. You need wits and cunning to get away with the goods. If you're constantly getting sunk and losing your hauls it's not the game's fault. It's your fault.

10/10 would Yo-Ho again.

Not what i had hoped, it's just fetch quests packaged in different "companies"-clothing, without a thorough tutorial. The game does not even hide it, even the ancient world of warcraft hid it in a somewhat interesting way (stories of the quest givers) but not Sea of thieves. The world is extremely sparsely populated by NPC-enemies and i've yet not seen a single human player. Everything "resets" when you log off, so your gathered supplies and chests are deleted when you log back on - all that work is completely meaningless. 

I tried to get a refund, but apparently not since i had to look for 5 hours to NOT find the entertainment i looked for - funny enough, i bought Deep Rock Galactic, which is REALLY good (i also solo in that one) so it's not the solo-playing-aspect that is the problem. 

I am actually quite disappointed by Sea of Thieves, it was more expensive, takes up 42 GB of Harddrive (and deep rock galactic just 1,5gb!) and provides far less entertainment.

Is sea of thieves worth having access to and playing? 100000% yes. Should you buy the game? Debatable, unless its on sale then go for it!

What I would recommend doing is picking up Gamepass. It will give you access to TONS of good games (including Sea of Thieves) and it isn't all that expensive considering what you get. Personally, I think this is a better option than just buying Sea of Thieves.

That being said, do whatever is financially feasible for your situation. Gamepass is more expensive overall than just buying the one game, it just gives you more overall value imo.

Either way, get your hands on some Sea of Thieves and don't be afraid to play with strangers. The seas are much less forgiving to lone pirates and it could put a sour taste in your mouth for what really is a fantastic game.

Whatever bugs you might encounter are offset by the PvP, PvE, PvHimself and every other part of this game. The player to player interactions themselves are just incredible. Just to summarize: I had to sail a 4 man ship with only one other crewmember, we sailed through rocks as if we were on a hoverboard, sold a literal boatload of loot, made friends with another ship, stole the ship and sailed it into a PvE event against what seemed like 50 AI ghost ships, battling both the ghost ship armada and the captain of the ship we were on who kept respawning since it was his ship, meanwhile we had to think of course, ammo, wind, the other ships, ALL AT THE SAME TIME.

After every 2h+ session (and there will be plenty, you don't play sea of thieves for 15 minutes) you can write a book about your adventure. I have never played a game like this before.

Context: I've played this game on the Microsoft Store, that's why I have so few hours on Steam.

Sea of Thieves is an absolute amazing game, that most people can play and have tons of fun. To start off, it has 2 big modes called "Adventure", and "Arena". Now, if you enjoy the beauty of sailing the vast Sea of Thieves, without having to fight much, adventure is for you. Now Arena on the other hand, is a more limited map where multiple ships battle for the iron, which in the end determines who wins the game and gets the most rewards. The game itself in all modes is beautiful, the graphics are great, and the overall feel of the game just makes it in my opinion the best pirate, or even ship game ever made. Definitely worth the price, but if you catch it on sale, its even better!

I love how realistic all the various functions are. Don't be fooled by the cartoony looks, this game has some very cool realistic areas. Just lots of little things. Like, when you want to cook something, like chicken (which you have to kill), you have to place it on the woodstove and wait for it to cook all the way through before it's safe to eat. If you don't pick it up when it's done, it will burn. Another small thing, is when you go up the ladder to the Crows Nest, you move at an average pace. On the way down, you move a lot faster. You can adjust the sail direction to catch the best breeze. If you partially raise the sail, you move slower. When you lower the anchor, you don't stop instantly, it drags on the bottom of the sea for a second. Reloading guns takes time and it shows you put the ball in the end and cock it, and then you're ready to fire another shot. When your ship takes damage, the damage is exactly where you thought it was, and you have to go and grab wood to repair those holes, and then use a bucket to bail out the water. 
I could go on and on, but I think you get the idea. I'm only 4 hours in and I'm loving this game. Only Con so far is that if another player sees you, you're gonna fight, almost guaranteed. So you better hope you can fight under pressure against their higher level gear. So I mostly just avoid other people, at least for now until I'm a little better at the game.

"The Breath of the Wild of Naval-Exploration"

Hyperbole aside, with the right crew you can turn this game into one of the greatest road trip experiences you can find. There's seemingly always something to do between looting, fighting and treasure chest hunting; from a very nicely designed musician mechanic to drinking 'till you and the crew have covered the poop deck in vom. 

The water design is gorgeous, and the orchestra is phenomenal. 

Bought on sale, but at this point I think it's worth the full price if you have enough FOMO from seeing what your friends can get up to.

For those with 2-3 other friends who have a thirst for adventure, this is one of the best recommendations I can make.

I love this game, it is a bit dull after some time, but even after 150 hours, I still get amazed how good the sea looks and how beautiful this game is in general.
This is not one of those games that you play 8 hours a day, it is more like one of those that you play one or twice a week and for a few hours.
I am not an aggressive player, but I like that that it is a multiplayer game, it always keeps you on the heels and alert. You can not zone our for 5 minutes because by that time someone might have come and sunk your ship and taken your loot. It is possible to create alliances as well, then there is this awkward situation where on both sides you have introverted gamers who want to show that they are friendly but do not speak much. It is fun to meet other people and do some quests together. 

This game is not for everyone, all the in game currency that you earn you can spend only on cosmetics and the quests are not that interesting, but if you want to just chill and spend time in a beautiful environment this one is for you.

Hey you. Yes you. Have you ever wanted to be a pirate as a kid? Yes? Alright then I recommend this.
This game It's fine as a single player with randomly getting sunk by a overzealous brigantine.

Can it be great fun? Yes.
Can it be a horrible nightmare? Yes.
Would I still recommend this to anyone who has The Pirates of the Caribbean. Yes.
Would I recommend to anyone who everyone who wanted to be a pirate as a little kid (minus the jail time?) Yes.

I have a lot hours coming from the microsoft store version of the game, game is fun maybe for the 1st week or so, where everything is a mystery to you. Most of the fun comes from interaction with other players. Though this is a problem at times cause sometimes you'll be in servers where it feels absolutely empty and there is no one around to engage in battle with, or interact with. I feel it definitely needs a increase in amount of players per server, but I know a lot of people won't agree with this. You'll definitely be needing a friend though for this game, especially if you're new to the game. There's always the option to sail with randoms, but sometimes you could end up with trolls who will ruin your experience. I do enjoy this game though despite the negative review, but it's just something I'll come to play maybe once in a while to see what new updates they've added.

This is a game I enjoy playing with my girlfriend.  It's fun to sail, fish, and hunt for treasure together.  The mandated PvP is infuriating, though.

[i]Sea of Thieves[/i] is a pirate-themed multiplayer action-adventure game taking place on a broad sea with dozens of islands to explore.

The game uses a character creation system that allows players to generate pirates until they find the suitable one for themselves. This feature does not let the players to customize the appearance of their pirates and can be a bit disappointing for some people.

The players can easily understand the basic mechanics of the game by beginning their journey in Maiden Voyage, a well-designed tutorial starting on an island full of secrets.

The game is played as teams by two to four players. It is also possible to play the game alone; however, it will make the game quite challenging. Sloops are easy to control and hard to target, making them a suitable option for a solo adventure.

The players can choose from a decent number of trading companies to work with and become the pirate they want. The quests requiring the player to visit the same islands to accomplish the same objectives repeatedly cause the game to become less entertaining after a while.

The mechanics are quite realistic in terms of naval combat and ship controls. Fighting across the sea can be so much fun, especially if there are some friends on the deck.

The high standard sound design and visuals create a beautiful atmosphere. Traveling the seas while playing your favorite soundtrack with a musical instrument during the sunset is a unique experience.

The game is constantly changing with regular updates. These changes keep the game fresh. It is highly recommended for the players who are interested in experiencing a pirate life.

Sea of Thieves is a pay $40 up front to lose Battle Royale. The coding and hitreg is so terrible, the game breaking bugs are part of the meta. The game was released so incomplete and the servers are so laggy, its an unplayable mess. But you won't find out until 40 hours in and it is impossible to return.

I will never trust Rare Ltd. again despite a childhood of fond memories with them. This was an actual scam. And it is riddled with hundreds of in-game purchases.

Finally, you could bother offering feedback on the game in the forums. But you will be trolled and harassed for any negative feedback. Then the forum staff will ban you from the forums and ignore your tickets. That's the kind of community Rare keeps in 2020. So you don't have to wonder why they don't even bother trying to police and improve their game servers.

Oh man, Sea of Thieves. I spent $1 for a month of Xbox Game Pass to give Sea of Thieves a try, and I fell in love. I jumped on it on Steam in July despite the game not even being on sale at the time, just because I wanted to keep playing it.

The biggest gripe I have with Sea of Thieves is, like many others, the other players who choose to do PvP battle with you. I've gotten frustrated a lot simply because other players felt like engaging and they either have a better grasp of PvP than my crew does or their internet sucks. It can be, and is, very demoralizing to spend half an hour or an hour on one voyage and lose all of that progress.

However, thankfully, the majority of Sea of Thieves players do not fall into that category. Most players want to do their own thing and not make the gamble to lose all of their progress, so usually you won't even come into contact with other players, or you might end up finding friendly players. If you're aiming for PvP, the Arena game mode exists to provide PvP players the matches they're looking for. In fact, there are communities dedicated to setting up PvE servers, and having joined them a couple of times, they can be well-organized and very rewarding.

New PvE content is being added to the game almost monthly. New treasure hunts, new story quests, new world events, and more, all with unique gameplay mechanics that will keep you on your toes. Some players complain about "all enemies are skeletons" but honestly there's a lot of variety in both the skeleton types and the special skeletons like Captains and Ashen Lords. There's genuine feedback to be made about boss enemies being bullet sponges, but other than that the fights are honestly very fun.

It's also really great to have the game put everyone at an equal skill level in terms of weapons and ships. There's no way to upgrade anything for more power. All of the loot goes towards more cosmetics, which is risky because that means the developers put their entire stock in the gameplay loop being fun enough for players to keep coming back, and it definitely paid off because the gameplay loop is definitely really fun.

While other players can be a nuisance at times, I'm always coming back to Sea of Thieves, so much so that I easily paid real money for a pet dog. I definitely recommend everyone gives Sea of Thieves a try by using the Xbox Game Pass for $1 for a month, and then making a decision from there.

The experience is better with more people, The graphics are Beautiful, The bosses are fun for the most part, Great cosmetics, and in the new update dogs among other pets. It's not a pay to win game, because the in-game currency along with real money only gets you cosmetics, which in my eyes is a good thing.  but the game also has flaws. There are many people out there who don't like the PVP aspect of the game and that's fine. Be warned, people who dislike PVP, this game has quite a bit of it. There are glitches and bugs, but they can be overlooked and sometimes funny. Some players are also very aggressive and think it's okay to say overly nasty things towards other pirates. Despite all of that this game is great! Overall it's super addicting and fun with friends.

Sea of Thieves was just the change of pace I neededAs I'm sure many are already aware, there's not many other multiplayer games out at the moment that aren't Battle Royal or a FPS 15 min matches. If you're like me, you got bored of that same repetitive formula after 2018. Sea of Thieves managed to give me a new experience, where team work is key, and boring moments are rare. You could play this game by yourself of course, but I can't imagine this game being a fun single player experience. This is definitely something to do with a friend or more. That's where it strives as simply getting from point A to point B is a whole thing instead of just holding down 'W'. If you want to have success, you need to make sure you and your crew are doing each persons part. Somebody steering, somebody working the sails, someone making sure you don't crash into anything up ahead, somebody navigating on the map below deck as there's no minimaps. That's simple getting from point A to point B, I will admit that it can become a little tiresome sometimes, but I have found after being on land for a little while, solving puzzles, finding treasure, that resets it for me and I can appreciate the calm of the sea. Also playing along side other players you've never met, this game has a strong social aspect, and a good community too, you'll get some assholes sure, but it's a pirate game after all, you could be attacked, you could just find someone random and chat to them and share a drink. This game absolutely strives in it's social aspect.However, no game is without fault, of course the sword combat, I'm not particularly a fan of, but that's just my personal preference as I feel it a bit clunky, and somehow too slow and fast at the same time. But my biggest issue; The only progression is cosmetic. Sure to start with you'll look all through the store seeing all these amazing things you can get, but once you have an outfit you like, there's not too much of a point to continue. That ever lasting hope for gold leaves, finding a bunch of loot not as exciting as it once was. But I do still love playing, as the experience is far better than the goal.TL;DRBrilliant with friends, but no progression, still fun tho.

If you are expecting this game to hold your hand, not likely. Being polite and friendly is a surefire way to get a cannon ball to your broadside. Everyone is looking to kill and rob each other. You spend hours trying to complete a mission only to have someone swoop in, stalk you, and take it all away. Unless you are very patient and don't mind keeping your head on a swivel you can play solo. Otherwise, I refer you to a discord to recruit some crewmates. But even then you are most likely to be paired up with other players who enjoy griefing and will most likely shoot you in the back. Don't try to get your friends to sink money into this as well. BUT EVEN IF you manage to accumulate a hoard of treasure and max reputations and become a PIRATE LEGEND!...there's no point because you just get more of the same missions. There are no special events or rare drops or gear that gives you an advantage and the general community is so controller-breaking-toxic. The game itself may have its good parts, but it doesn't balance out the players and the mundane grind.

Toxic players, dismissive support, and glitchy game play all equal a title that isn't worth anyones time or money. For anyone who likes to play solo mode in games, AVOID THIS TITLE AT ALL COSTS. You will be attacked by larger ships/crews on a regular basis all while they scream "IT'S A PIRATE GAME!! YARR!!!". The Code of Conduct is a joke and only enforced at the developers leisure and pretty much never enforced on toxic players who have figured out how to cheat the system (either by actually cheating or by vocally abusing others over in-game voice chat; the latter of which isn't policed). And on the rare instances that a player is banned, it's often on mistake (search YouTube for "Sea of Thieves banned" to see what I mean), but Rare Ltd doesn't admit to its short comings and those accounts stay banned. 

In the end, this game is admittedly a good concept. However, the developers choice to leave the whole world as a "play it your way" environment without uniformly enforcing their own lacking rules and regulations only leads to a horrible player base which, in turn, results in frustration for those who would rather not enter into what amounts to little more than yet another PvP "shot `em up" game.

It's a beautiful game and could be a lot of fun, but there's so much busy work and the servers are full of jerks who get off on ruining other peoples' day. If you want to do anything substantial you have to spend so much time stocking up your ship, only to have it sunk shortly after because somebody saw your ship's outline from miles away and decided to hunt you down. It's awesome having your ship shot up while you're off trying to solve a vault riddle, or are exploring an island.

There are so many things the developers could do to streamline the experience, or make it more enjoyable for people who just want a chill pirate adventure with friends, but they have no desire to.

Only recommended if you have more time on your hands than you know what to do with, and have either sadistic or masochistic tendencies. Both types will find plenty of opportunity for their favorite type of fun.

This game had great potential. I've been playing before Beta and all I can say is this game has lost its vision when it came to rewarding skill. That was the original selling point for not having gear progression. "Progression is a veteran player's ability to do a 360 no scope" that shit was on a trailer before the game launched officially lmao. Well now there's 0 skill, hit registration for every fucking bullet you shoot, and multiple bugs with naval combat, such as cannon bugs. I originally said that this was a good game with flaws, but that was before Rare made it clear that this isn't supposed to be anything but a "Mommy and me" type game.

TLDR: If you are competitive and like being rewarded for skill, avoid this trash. If you like casual shit, this game might be for you. Fuck you, Rare.

★★★★☆

Pros:
Amazing graphics and sea-faring mechanics. 
Lots of contents, which includes but not limited to, treasure hunt, raid, PvP, and Quests. 
Devs take feedback and provide constant bug-fix and content update. 
No pay-to-win aspect. 

Cons: 
At disadvantage if playing solo. 
Buggy X-Box Live integration.
Lack of personal weapon choices. 
You can be attacked and looted by players for no reason, losing all your stuff
(well, not really a con because it says right there in the name "Sea of Thieves," but some people really hates it)
Limited to 4 crew members per ship.

Overall, great game. I would recommend it.

So I'm going to put a small review up for those getting excited about the cross platform bit. That's all I'm reviewing since I've barely experienced the game (and it's been really fun ngl) ...would be Great if I could play with friends. Unfortunately, anytime you try to join your xboxy friends from your lil xbox socials ex dee it sends you...to the windows store. You accept a game invite and it...does nothing. We tried every solution online dating back to almost two years ago and it's just broken, it's buggy, it's not working. Buy this game for solo. I played four hours and had a great time! Same platform friends? Sick, get it. Cross platform? Just punch yourself in the nuts. It'd be a less grueling experience then what we had to go through. I hope this saved someone from making a mistake because boy I wish someone had told me about this before I bought the game. Now I'm just sad. This pretty game with scary giant fish made me sad. 

It also doesn't use Steam for inviting friends. Because, you know. That makes sense. Obviously. 

Unless I see a fix for this soon, I'm just going to be in my sad squidward corner watching spongebobs and patricks have fun in crews. Sob. 

Thanks Microsoft. Ex Dee.

Amazing game. No, it's not a full-fledged MMORPG, and if you go in expecting that, you're probably in for disappointment. At all times, it's your ship (with between 1-6 players aboard) and 5 other ships - there can never be more on a server. So sometimes you'll bump into tons of other (typically very hostile) pirates, and other times you won't see another soul for 2-3 hours.

The thing is, the experience is so immersive - even solo - that I'm not sure it really matters. Honestly, SoT reminds me a lot of a tropical version of The Long Dark: there's a great deal of exploration, eating, seeking supplies, and defeating AI threats (of varying difficulty, though most are pretty much cake). Still, it's so damned atmospheric that I cannot put the thing down. The behavior of the sea, the sky, and they way your ship glides between the two is almost heavenly (and very, VERY reflective of real life sailing, albeit simplified). And, for me, that experience makes SoT one of the most rewarding games I have ever played.

But if you're looking for constant WoW-style raids, or ceaseless PvP, this probably isn't going to satisfy you much. Like sailing under crystal blue skies, with your ship skipping from wave to wave over turquoise waters? Buy this.

Love this game so much. Been playin' with some friends for about 2 months now and i am not dissapointed. One time, we did an Athena's Run (we were 3 guys on a brig) and after we got the last chest we tried to head for the closest outpost. While doing so, we passed by an island which had a galleon anchored next to it, the crew ashore and skulls, gold, chests, you name it scattered across the island from an earlier event which we didn't notice before.
We sunk their ship, killed them and stole every single piece of loot we could find. We tried to head out to the outpost when we realised the enemy crew respawned at the exact same outpost. We changed course, sailed almost half the map only to have them follow us. We tried to lose them near some volcanoes in the Devil's Roar (1 molten rock hit one of their masts and we gained some distance), we had been chased by 3 Megalodons, 1 Kraken encounter and 2 other small sloops. Then, we managed to throw a powder keg overboard which managed to slow them down a little. When we were almost out of hope we saw a ghost fleet in the distance. We rushed through the fleet (taking a bit of damage), then the fleet changed focus on them. We did some turns and managed to lose them after an hour. Best f* gameplay. Best atmosphere. Good story. I'll recommend it to everyone.

One Important thing about this game is it is better with FRIENDS. If you have a group of 3/4, this game comes alive as you go on your great pirate journey. 

I recommend it, but a thing to note is, that the game loop is centered around going to different places on your ship. The Seafarer journey is the core and for some, it could quickly get tiresome. And once you have earned enough to beautify your ship and have gotten your pirate swagged up, the only thing left is high level PvE and PvP.  For some it would be fun, for others it would be tiresome.

There are no builds, just 4 weapons with no upgrades, no skills. Nothing. It makes you play as a pirate, but the RPG factor is quite low, so don't go expecting too much out of it. Just simply going about the world, looting and pimping out your ship and character. Thats it.

Its a fun game, a lovely concept and the Seas are so good! If you want to try, get it on the 1$ Game Pass 1 Month Deal.

Great game!!! I'm having lots of fun playing it so far. Every night is a different adventure, which keeps things from getting repetitive.

There is a lot of content, and big monthly patches with loads of new content continuously coming out, which keeps the game play fresh. I've met loads of people that have been playing the game since it's release. I'm guessing because of this reason. 

No P2W which is a huge plus, considering most games now a'days. But if you do want to spend real money, it's purely for cosmetics. 

PvP is extremely fun! There's no better feeling than sinking another players ship, and taking all their hard earned loot that probably took them hours to accumulate. Yet, there is probably no worse feeling when it happens to you lol.  

Extremely fun if you have 1-3 close friends to play with. However, you can always join the SoT discord to find a crew that knows what they are doing, instead of using the random crew finder.

Game crashes every time I try to enter the vanity chest or clothing chest. I've tried every single suggestion that I found online to try and fix it, but no luck. Ended up asking for a refund, but although I only played through the tutorial, I had been in the game for too long to get any refund :( 

I spent hours in the character selection, and even left the game on while in the character selection. And when I was finally done with that, I played the tutorial and then went straight to change my clothes. Aaaand it crashed.. Sooo I started the whole process again and selected a new character (thought I had lost my old one), so it took even longer. And same thing happened again, entered a chest and the game crashed. After that I started looking for solutions online and tried everything I could find, and even got a friend to help me make sure everything on my end was up to date etc. But no luck.. 

So I recommend people who buy this, to not spend a lot of time making a character.. pick one, and then hurry though the tutorial, and then try changing clothes etc.. If you can and it doesn't crash or anything, you can just delete your pirate (if you're not happy with it) and then take your time picking the one you want. Don't make the same mistake I did and end up with a game you can't play and no help or refund :( 

If anyone has solutions for me, feel free to comment though. Tyvm!

>Be me.
>Proud veteran of the Pirate Vs Ninja wars from dark ages of the internet. 
>Play lots of pirate games over the years. 
>Log into Sea of Thieves for first time.
>Play through Maiden Voyage and then join a crew. 
>"Hey guys, I'm brand new to the game, is that cool?"
>Everybody leaves crew. 
>MFW when suddenly alone on galleon and see sails on the horizon. 
>Frantically try to steer and run around adjusting all three sails into the wind. 
>The sloop can't keep up! I made it!  Perfectly safe! Safe forever!
>Random pops up onto deck.  I can haz fren!
>Get on mic, "Hey man, everybody else just left.  This is my first day playing."
>He jumps around then runs below deck.  Crashing and booming comes from down below.  The ship is now on fire!
>He runs back up, also on fire. 
>Pulls out gun.  Shoots me dead.  Screen goes red. 
>I guess he wasn't on my crew, and that other ship must have gotten closer than I thought. 
>Looking up at him as he stands over me. He gets on mic, "Welcome to Sea of Thieves."  
>It's a pirate's life for me! Drink up me hearties, yo-ho!

I never review games but this one is just too good to ignore. Sea of Thieves has become one of my favorite games ever whether I'm solo or with my buddies. This game has a lot to offer and a bright future ahead of it. The community for this game is amazing except for a few bad apples, but that's with every game. The PvP has a learning curve since no other game has PvP like it which is not a bad thing, I actually enjoyed learning how to PvP and shoot cannons. The PvE is also great but the bosses can be a little annoying since they are just bullet sponges and they often just repeat attacks, but that aside it's always a good change of pace switching from PvP to PvE. If you're on the fence about buying this game don't worry you'll enjoy it, there's people to shoot, treasure to find, and adventure to be had.

This is a bloody phenomenal game. The ship mechanics are great. The naval combat is thrilling. And exploring is exciting. Not to mention the fantastic graphics, with the best water I've ever seen in a game. They do monthly updates that always add new and exciting content. And to all the people who say that they shouldn't be being robbed. It is called sea of thieves for a reason. And you only get robbed once in a blue moon. Or if you're dumb enough to get caught. So I JUST updated this review and now my ping will never go lower than 340.

I'm finding it really hard to enjoy a game when I have to sit there for 30 seconds loading my respawn but for some reason it prioritizes loading audio first so I could hear everything going on up until my ship sank, while still loading.

This game would be extremely immersive and fun if it weren't for a few problems that make it feel like an early access game. At first I was so immersed with the game that I was blown away, but as I played more I noticed more issues with trying to play this game solo. I tried playing with crews but having a conversation  ruins some of the immersion so I decided to continue playing solo, to my demise.  I have a low end pc and a low end wifi connection, but it's good enough to play most other games at 30 fps with ~50 ping on my server region, yet the way the servers on SoT works is that the more players, the higher the ping, so my average ping is 70-90 on any server. I also noticed that there are constant lag spikes that are game breaking for solo players like myself. These lag spikes don't work like any other lag spikes where your last input is repeated for a few seconds then you see where you ended up after the spike is gone, no, during the lag spike the game registers that nothing else exists, no boat, no water, only the sea floor, so when you come out of it and get to see where you ended up, you're off your ship and hundreds of feet underwater AND you take fall damage. But those random lag spikes aren't the only lag you're gonna experience in this game, every time an enemy ship gets within the right distance, it loads the entire thing in at once (it should load in loot, and different ship details at different distances to make multiple smaller bumps instead of one large spike) so you get a guaranteed lag spike if you have a low-end pc. I've also noticed that there are problems with repairing your ship, like the fact that the rocking of your ship can bring the wall far enough away that it resets your repair timer. There's also other interaction options blocking your ability to repair holes, the repairing should have priority over picking up a chest. I'm also experiencing extreme frustration every time I fight a skeleton ship solo, because their aim is way too good and they can move faster than max speed forcing me to fight. they have killed me on my ship, with their cannons, without damaging the ship. They have kept me from shooting a single cannon shot for the entire fight because every time I get on the cannon they've already shot a cannonball straight at my cannon. All in all, the only reason I'm motivated enough to write a review this long is because I fucking love this game, and I want it to be fun for solo players to sail the seas and be completely immersed in the experience of feeling like a genuine pirate.  The only improvements I believe this game needs are: 1. change the way the servers work because they feel like they belong to some niche title made mostly for it's story, which this game is the exact opposite of, a billion dollar mmorpg so you could and should invest in more stable servers. 2. separate what is loaded in at what distance instead of having everything load in at once (have multiple small bumps instead of one big lag spike to reduce crashes), sometimes the lag spike of nearing or seeing another ship will crash my game at the worst time possible. 3. simply make skeleton ships less accurate but shoot a bit more frequently, that will make fights far more intense with more cannonballs flying, while also balancing them out, making more holes on galleons and less direct hits on solo players, it also lowers the chance that a skeleton ship will hit a player with multiple of the same cursed ball in a row (permanent sleep/drunk/raised sails is something that solo players can do nothing about, and you don't want moments that force a player to lose no matter how skilled). Sorry for the bad review, I don't believe this game deserves it, but I definitely won't give it a good review until it feels like I'm playing on high-end servers, without moments where I feel powerless to fight or run and I just have to accept my fate.

ps: I am hitting shots that should never hit because, with the way that the servers work, your view of an enemy player's position is just a very close estimate of where they actually are in-game. As a result you can do no damage on a direct hit and deal damage when hardly missing an enemy. how do you expect players to get good at your game if their understanding of how to play is getting mixed up by inconsistent game mechanics. fix your game already, 15 MILLION PLAYERS x $50 = $750M + MICROTRANSACTIONS, you can't say money is a problem, and if no one knows how to program better servers then it's time to hire new programmers.

Yet another side note: The lag is getting worse and worse the more players playing this game. New players beware the fucking 99999 ping. I keep trying my best to ignore the issues because the game play is fun but It's still a struggle to play the fucking game.

I like this game very much. Before it came out, and after it did, I would talk about how great it was to my friends and my family, and my brother, being the intelligent guy he is told me I probably liked the idea of the game more than the game itself. I've realized over time that he was right. The game came out to a horrible start. It truly was wide as an ocean and shallow as a puddle. I didn't care though. When I saw how the developers talked about the game in the videos they released regularly, I knew that their enthusiasm about the game was sincere. They really gave a shit about the project. So, instead of giving up right there, they kept working on it, and they fed off all of the hope and enthusiasm, people like me and the people who were still playing the game had and were sharing. It really was a terrible game, but I wouldn't let myself tell me that, because I knew that the developers had a drive to make the game great and that the game had a future.
They made a smart move and didn't release it on steam until it was a finished product (well not really finished, they're still going at it, but you know what i mean.) They basically got a second chance for a review, and instead of getting the 6 out of 10 review they started with and couldn't repair, now they have a 9/10 score on the platform people actually look at. I saw the hope in this game, and they carried through, buy the game.

TL;dr The game was bad, now its good. It was always supposed to be good in the end. The developers did care and they still care. They listen to the players, and they're not afraid to admit when they f'd up.

It's not a BAD game. I think it would have been better off (as an experience overall) if it were targeted for VR use. It's got many of the elements you'd find in a VR experience, including a slower pace and moving objects around, but it's an endless grind. What's nicest about it is also the worst part: everything you work for is cosmetic. That said, your focus becomes the gameplay itself a bit more easily than in other games, but it's not very rewarding.

Personally, I get bored very quickly with this game and only bother with it when I have relatives that are already playing on their consoles and want me along. What is there to do, exactly? Steer the ship, fish along the way, look at a map or read a riddle, find a few boxes on an island, gradually fight skeletons, and sell your findings.

The game has a competitive mode of some kind, but I don't know why it exists. Every single thing you do has an atrocious cooldown time, and that includes something as simple as swinging your sword. Weapons need to reload after one shot, and that takes a terrible amount of time. It may not feel as bad for console users, but that in itself is kinda the problem for PC users.

All in all, this really isn't a bad game. It's just remarkably monotonous, and the sluggish gameplay doesn't help.

I would recommend the game but there are a couple issues as of writing this.
1: The only consistent way to spend your coin is cosmetics. Once you run out that's it, nothing left to spend money on.
2: There is no point to make it to pirate legend. Mostly because you'll only get more pointless work for cosmetics. Pirate legends have no special privilege. If you could get access to stuff like the ability to buy a storage crate with like 50 planks, 50 canon balls and ten of five different fruit for a decent fee at the start of every game, and maybe you could buy a rowboat at the start of every game too, being pirate legend would be worth it not because it's an advantage, but a PRIVILEGE. So unfortunately there is little to do other than mindlessly gather and sell treasure. But a solution could be...

Solution 1: Add special privileges like make the black market archives exclusive to legends. The ability to buy previously limited-time cosmetics shouldn't be for just anyone!
Solution 2: Add alternatives to selling treasure for gold. Perhaps instead certain treasure can earn you certain privileges if you don't sell them.
Solution 3: Add more ways to spend gold that are also optional but very useful if you have the coin. These wouldn't be crazy advantages but instead worthwhile privileges.
And so on and so fourth...

But the game is still fun despite these problems, it just gets really repetitive and could use a little more stuff to do. All in all though, a good game.

It's a pirate game. Thats everything you need to know. If a pirate can do it, you can do it. Whether it be sailing a ship, hunting for treasure, or simply just fishing, Sea of Thieves does it all masterfully. Theres content for every type of player, if you just want to chill out on the open waters, feel free to do so! If you want to engage in combat with other pirates and fight over loot, that is always an option as well! 

Customization is also a huge part of this game, so there's tons of cosmetics to unlock as you journey across the seas. If you're more of a story kind of person, there's plenty of that too! Personally, I think this is the perfect game if you're looking to find the most interactive pirate experience. The community is friendly for the most part, but keep in mind everyone is a pirate, so don't let your guard down.

This game could be so good, but has several issues so I recommend not to buy.

In general, the co-op elements and the sailing work very well. Some people complain about the PvP, I didn't find it too bad, but sometimes you will find your ship sunk when on an island for a quest. Most players are not friendly in my experience. 

The main issue I have is that all the quests and main activity within the game revolves around repetitive fetch quests. The tall tales are essentially multi-step fetch quests, the guild progression is extremely repetitive. There are no interesting items to find or unlock, just cosmetic skins for everything. 

So overall I might play occasionally with friends as i've already bought it, but i'd recommend you buy something else.

Once you get past the clunky WoW-like graphics and get out to sea, it's a fun experience.  I was blown away by the water, motion, lighting, and controls in a ship.  You can solo, but it's much better to play with others.

I can't recommend this game for it's current price (40 USD).  I wouldn't recommend it for more than 20 USD.  I'd say definitely get it if it ever gets down to 10.

In my opinion, there are a lot of features that could be done better -- design choices, not bugs -- which could make this game worth $40.  Right now, the only real draw is the immersive feeling of being out to sea with friends and encountering other players.  I was pretty bored with it after the novelty wore off after about 15 hours of play or so (total).

Rare knocks it out of the park with pirate dress up.  The in-game PvE elements are a bit one-dimensional, but the PvP, Arena, and exploration are out of this world.  If you were like me and only ever wanted to be a pirate when you grew up, get this game.

pros:
- skill-based game
- noteworthy lighting, shading, and sound effects
- arena mode
- confining those who refuse to use nautical terms

cons:
- low FPS drop with multiple skeletons
- overlays displaying mission/reward info are often missing
- losing the chat system and loot between merging servers
- swapping ships requires starting a new game
- PVE story missions coincide with PVP events

this was a positive review but the low-FPS-skeletons-on-the-steam-version issue pretty much turns adventure mode into an overpriced fishing/cooking simulator.

Just an amazing game. I waited for long to buy it because I kept hearing that it had no purpose. I love the current game and don't think I'll get bored easily. I keep playing with strangers and so far it was really fun. Only cons are server issues and some bugs. Sometimes me or my crew has to restart due to minor but annoying bugs or sudden dcs but we can't join back. It seems this problem is around for years now, I wish they would fix it already. If you are in mid of delivering an item, prey to god that you don't dc.
Other than that It's perfect. I'm addicted to steering my ship.

My advice to new players:
This is the Sea of Thieves, don't trust anyone. Even if you form an alliance don't let anyone near your ship. 
Don't expect people to be friendly or forgiving. You gotta learn how to avoid fights and play defensive. 
If you don't have enough friends, don't rush to sail with bigger ships, Sloop is godlike. Sloop is life.
There are no skillpoints in this game, you get better yourself and that's what I love. So every battle will teach you something new or show you what you have been doing wrong. You will sink a lot.
You can learn it all by yourself but there is no harm on watching and learning some tips. I learned so many stuff by watching players like PhuzzyBond everytime I'm in bathroom.

I can say after a short playtime that I've had more fun with Sea of Thieves than I've had with a lot of other games. There are so many moments in this game that make me genuinely smile. The game is not by any means complicated, but it doesn't hold your hand and tell you what to do or how to go about it. You end up discovering little things that make it so much better.
Pros:
- Easy to get into gameplay that has a lot of tricks you will discover along the way
- Pretty immersive, you really feel like a sailor when you adjust the rigging on your ship
- Lends itself well to playing with friends, good teamwork game
- Gorgeous graphics and cartoony art style that will age well
- Lots of exploration, however I will come back to this point
- All navigation is done by hand with a map in your ship, sometimes you get a picture of an island and you have to go find that island. It seemed clunky but I actually enjoy the lack of any kind of quest markers or anything
- Permanent progression in the form of being able to ante up and take bigger, higher-paying jobs
- PvP is purely skill and teamwork based as there are no upgraded weapons or ships, only cosmetic skins to unlock (however if you're looking for an RPG with character power progression this may not be for you)
Cons: 
- This game does have a cosmetic-only cash shop. From what I have seen so far, Pets (which are just cute little companions that can follow you around) are exclusive to the cash shop. 
- 90% of the time if you see a player ship, especially a bigger one, your best bet is to just run away. This isn't the game's fault, obviously, but kind of a bummer none the less
- Quests are not persistent between play sessions. Not a huge deal, but the level 4 ones have been taking me roughly an hour to complete (by myself) and it would be nice to be able to take a break more frequently than that. 
- (From what I have seen so far) fixed map. So once you've seen every island, that's it. Not a big deal though because the non-story quests are randomly generated and a bit different every time.

[h1]Sea of Thieves is a pirate themed multiplayer experience[/h1]

Sea of Thieves is an engaging "Rust" themed game made for people who prefer the pirate life of "riches" over the survivor life of "dominance". The core of the game is to collect various items and bring them to various merchants residing on Outposts. In return the player receives rewards ranging from Gold all the way to Reaper coins. As it is centered around "piracy" and sea, a ship is your best friend and controlling one, while defending yourself from enemies, is close to impossible on your own. A crew of friends is, while not mandatory, [b]highly recommended[/b], as playing with random people may not always work out.

[b]Positives:[/b]
+ Vast and incredibly detailed open world, the sea, islands, waves, sun are all incredibly well-made. The world does a fantastic job of "sucking" you in, from making you feel calm and relaxed while sailing in quiet seas, to keeping you on your toes during heavy thunderstorms and ocean full of waves in the middle of the dark, cold "unwelcoming" night.
+ In-Game events ranging from deep sea battles with Flameheart's endless platoon of Ghost ships, to a mad fight for survival in inky territory with the ancient creature known as "The Kraken", these events give out the most amount of rewards for those daring to complete them.
+ Talltales serve as a sort of "Story" mode for Sea of Thieves. They are easier than previously mentioned events, however they do pay out less and usually take longer to complete. I still recommend doing them though, as they do form a relatively interesing story.
+ Great element of freedom, as soon as you log in you are free to sail the endless Sea of Thieves and explore at your own will.
+ Features Cross-play between PC and Xbox, thus unifying a bigger player base together.
+ Beautiful art style that doesn't require a monster PC, while still looking extremely solid even in 2020.

[b]Negatives:[/b]
- Completing a hard, frustrating event and collecting the treasure doesn't mean keeping it, you are in constant danger of enemy ships. They can attack at anytime and just like that steal all the loot you have potentially spent a long time collecting. That's where the "Rust" feel comes from.
- Bosses of events and talltales can be quite "annoying" sometimes, as they have a [b]huge[/b] amount of health and it can very well take you 30+ minutes to defeat them.
- The close quarters combat is very "primitive", you either swing your sword in light and heavy attack or use one of your firearms to shoot at enemy players.

[b]Neutral:[/b]
* The Steam version of the game still requires a Microsoft account in order to sign in. Many people report that the "Xbox app" on Windows 10 is required when playing Sea of Thieves, but that is not actually true, it seems like the game uses it, but if you have deleted the app from your OS like me, you would be surprised that the game actually works completely fine without it. You still log in to a MS account but that's it, afterwards you play as normal, you just invite your friends via their MS account names, not via Steam's invite system.
* Microtransactions are also a thing in this game, you use the currency you buy with real money to purchase cosmetics like emotes, pets etc. The reason I classify this as a neutral feature is because I personally prefer these types of games to be completely equal in terms of ships, weapons, upgrades etc. This game has no upgrade system, nor special weapons and ships everything you buy with real money is cosmetics. Many people like that, many dislike it. Up to you to decide.

[b]Opinion:[/b]
Sea of Thieves is the type of game you play for fun, while chatting with friends. No competitive vibes here, just sailing in a beautiful open world that can be as easy and friendly as you want, or as hard and tedious as you want. My final score is [b]8/10[/b], as for me the pros far outweigh the cons. It's even more worth it if you buy the game on sale !

Honestly, i tried. Again and Again. My Father and both brothers got it so we may all play it. And we tried. Played a few nights together. And I think its because it was a more expensive game we were too stubborn to admit we weren't having fun.

But we were not. It is not fun. Im not going to sit here and complain about every little thing. Thats not the point. This is a warning to players like me.

Does the game do good? Of course it does. However, it does only enough good to smooth out the rest of the bad stuff to leave you with just a feeling of a disappointing waste of time and a bad taste in your mouth.

The game is stressful, the community is toxic, and we are constantly enticed and incentivized to PvE which is immediately dashed by another player for no significant reason other than "its a PvP game". 

Then this game needs to stop pretending that it is something that it is not. There is a PvP zone. There is a PvE zone. And the PvE zone has more PvP in it than PvE. Its a game that breeds and encourages trolls. Its not a fun environment at all unless you have that mentality. Which is not a good mentality to have in life really. The developers claim to encourage a "pirates code", but its literally a piece of paper on the wall of the tavern. There is nothing to encourage any kind of behavior other than being an intolerable prick that is willing to attack small ships, that are doing story quests, with all of the "community approved" signs of peace, just because you can. The thought of fighting off other players is fun. The ship battles are dynamic and exciting. But not when they happen every ten minutes. Even when you do everything to show you dont want to fight.

I bought this game because i wanted to have fun. But i made the mistake of buying a "mainstream" game yet again.

So with that said, the four of us are never going to play this again. not unless this game makes a huge push to allow for strict PvE content as well as its PvP. (which can be fun at times.) we had a long and calm discussion of the pros and cons this evening after we initially quit out of frustration.

This is probably the first refund on Steam i can think of for a game i have ever requested. I know i am way beyond the time, but i wanted to at least try. It truly was that bad of an experience for us.

So, as i said, this is a warning. If you like PvE, Doing quests uninterrupted, or have a 'general' distaste for PvP, you will not enjoy this game.

EDIT: 9/5/2020:
While my review for the main game remains the same and unchanged, i have found small beacons of hope for players like me. I found a PvE focused Discord group that sets up entire fleets to work together in PvE content. They are called Athena's Vanguard. They are polite, well organized and i have had good experiences with everyone i have played with. While this helps me, and players like me, my view of the main game remains as i feel these are things the official game should be able to allow for this a little better.

SoT is a rage-quiters nightmare.

The game itself, esp the water / sailing effects are beautiful. The problem arises in 2 areas...

1. Other players: Now, the player count (ATM) is low; your chance of encountering another player is slim. But. (9 /10 times) the other player will be hostile. WHY?? I dont know. And dont care.

2. The "save" system is, in a word, re-tarded.

See, in order to get to these 'NEW" areas one must do the Shoudbreaker quest. The quest itself is fine and fun but....there's a catch...


See...once you have the "shroudbreaker" if you get disconnected or log off...it goes *POOF* and you have to complete the ( I assume) last subquest to get it again.

This is just stupid.


SoT is a fantastic idea that is poorly implemented.


Final Rivscore - 66 / 100

Me and 3 of my friends are sitting on our Galleon minding our own business
We spot a Sloop in the distance, which hasn't moved in a while 
We decide to leave it alone for now, since it isn't doing us any harm
Suddenly, we spot a mermaid in the water, which means players are far from their own ship
We check our ladders, and sure enough, on both sides, 2 dudes are clinged on
We start fighting and manage to kill them
The dudes try to come back again, and are really toxic, so we chase their ship for a bit
The Galleon is much slower than the Sloop because of its size, so its hard to catch up
I come up with a plan to launch 1 person at a time in attempt to try to get onto their ship and lower the anchor
After a few failed attempts, I finally manage to lower the anchor and we fight
We sink their ship after a long battle (The dudes were more experienced but we had the numbers)
They are incredibly mad at us for fighting in a group of 4, despite them provoking us first
We go back to farming stuff via quests and minding our own business, when we spot a Sloop in the distance
We are near an island, so we brace for impact
The ship collides with ours and sure enough its the same dudes screaming through their mics
I decide to distract them by lobbing fire bombs at their ship, so instead of attacking us they go to put it out
They are too late, and their ship sinks, but not before they can get a few more insults at us through their mics
We never saw them again, but it was incredibly funny and intense, and made the game worth it for me

Spent the better part of a month repeatedly downloading and reinstalling this game following a myriad of troubleshooting steps to get this game to work; has not once launched successfully.  Even followed the steps that no respectable company would try to force on Users by so badly designing their application's compatibility (disabling antivirus to play, only installing on C drive because their internal file paths are probably absolute instead of relative, etc).

When none of that worked, raised the issue with Support, and the ticket was marked as "Solved" before they even contacted me.  They used the resolution mechanic of their ticketing system to send me the email with what they wanted me to try.  Of course nothing they sent worked, some of it was even pulled from the list of troubleshooting steps I told them I'd already tried, but at least I got the pleasure of downloading the 50GB install for a 6th time.

I've turned one last ticket in to their Support Site, and if it works, fine; if not, also fine, as long as I can get refunded.  I'm kinda past the point of marking this as something I'd recommend, even to my enemies, but if they do at least get it working I'll update this with a slightly less negative tilt.

EDIT:  Second ticket marked "solved" before they contacted me again, but this was expected.  Half of the recommended troubleshooting steps they sent in the "how was the support you received?" email were steps they had recommended on the previous ticket (gave them the first ticket number in the second ticket, but of course why would they even glance at that), and the other half of the troubleshooting steps were to fix download errors in the Microsoft Store downloading process....unfortunately for me, this is neither a download error, nor from the Microsoft Store.

Going after a refund, but Steam policy did mention that refunds are usually not granted after 14 days; sorry, but if the thing is 50GB and they tell you to reinstall it 6 different ways to try to address the issue, it'll take some people more than 14 days to try to make it work...fingers crossed...

FINAL EDIT:  But of course!  No refunds after 14 days, no matter that it takes a month just to run through the recommended troubleshooting including 6 repeated downloads of the 50GB of game files, or that the game not once successfully launched.  Maybe it's like the "line ride" at the crappiest state fair ever, and all that garbage I was doing with support WAS the game?  Regardless, well played Microsoft.  You can crap in a box, call it a game, charge 40 bucks, and as long as the game files are so massive you're safe from refund requests from people unfortunate enough not to have fiber optic internet service.  Recommendation?  Run away.  Screaming.

PROS:
Sea of Thieves is visually appealing.  You'll never find better looking water, nor a ship that handles quite as wonderfully.  Sound design is professionally handled, from thrumb of your cannons right down to the smallest insect chirping.  It's a world you can easily become immersed in.  Even if you don't get to design the starting look of your pirate, there is more than enough customization to truly make your character feel like your own, even if they are just "borrowed."  If I was IGN this game would get a 10 from the sole fact that it was gorgeous to look at and brilliant to live in...

CONS:
...But I'm not IGN, and this game has issues.  Lots of them.  Sea of Thieves is the ultimate time waster in a number of ways.  Since PVP isn't something you can opt into/out of, your average experience will be investing hours of time hunting for treasure, tackling bosses, raiding fortresses, only for another band of players to skulk along after you've done all the hard work and take it all away in seconds. This is a REGULARLY OCCURING thing, and in my opinion hurts the game far more than it helps.  I understand that this is a core concept of the game, but it doesn't change the fact that no matter what kind of gamer you are, having your time investment amount to absolutely nothing is just not fun.

Aside from the glaring pvp issue, the game has numerous technical issues.  Frames skip regularly, rubber-banding and teleporting are common occurances.  The game looks amazing, but it clearly can't handle its own beauty.  

CONCLUSION:
The game is in dire need of some work under the hood, as well as the option to opt out of open world pvp.  I'd feel more comfortable recommending this game if it didn't have such an astounding knack for wasting precious time and energy.  But as it stands it takes far too much effort to have a fun time in Sea of Thieves, compared to how little effort it takes for that fun to be ruined.  Seek yer pirate kicks on brighter shores me hearties.

Initially bought this game for my 12 yr old daughter. We both absolutely love Sea of Thieves now.  Mainly for the sense of exploration and how detailed it is when sailing your ship across the ocean.  Working together on the ship while keeping an eye out for other players, the actual ship combat, and pvp is freakin great and so much fun.  LOVE the sound effects, weather and storms, the night and day change, the music is so well done and matches every situation you find yourself in.  Graphically I think the game is gorgeous especially when out in the ocean.  LOVE the use of all the equipment (compass, maps, spyglass, bucket, mugs) and love how you can grab an instrument and play.

The only "complaint" I would have is...  treasure you find seems to be ONLY to hand in and gain reputation points (which is definitely fun BUT) - would be nice if we could also find an occasional vanity related item (rare skin for example) OR making SLIGHT changes to pvp and allowing padded armor (to raise protection from gun fire or swords just a bit) or maybe weapons that do just a bit more damage than normal.  Nothing crazy.  I'm talking like 5% at the most?  Decorative items for the ship maybe?  Just to make treasure hunting a bit more fun and hopeful.  Definitely NOT a real complaint at all.  Just adding my two sense.  Regardless, we are having a great time with this!

Let me tell you a tale; a tale of old that sea dogs told 'bout an accidental alliance between pirates at sea, and a fleet that came forth worthy enough to challenge Flameheart himself.

The tale begins with two adventurers, in this case two crews allied with each other since long ago. The alliance consisted of two ships full of honest pirates, both commanded by officers who knew not of what they were doing. Commodore T. William of the [i]Sea Dragon[/i], a formidable Brigantine crewed only by the finest men; Ensigns G. Kitsu and K. Sikil. The other mighty vessel was the [i]Roaring Anglerfish[/i], a sloop agile and hardy enough to out-maneuver any vessels who dare to get in its way; commanded by Captain I. Kristofer and his first-mate M. Reccing.

Our alliance traveled across the Sea of Thieves in search for adventure and treasures of left behind long ago by pirate legends long before us. For nights and days we sailed across the seas. Then one day, there it was! A dark, mysterious cloud in the sky in resemblance of a ship. The two ships set course for the mysterious cloud and stood by waiting for whoever, or whatever, is waiting for them. Waves splish and splash across the hull of both ships, water poured in through the top deck, the Wilds was no happy and peaceful place! It's waves almost felt like they were about to tear the ships to pieces and leave our pirates to meet their fates on the Ferry of the Damned.

Then there it was before them, a lone sloop sailing in the middle of sea just where they needed to go. Hesitation arisen and many believed that this sloop would be filled with cut-throat pirates! But before anyone could take action, there it was, monstrous vessels of legend, vessels with the appearance of death, ships began rising up from the sea below as if ships sunken from years past were spat back out from the locker. Never have they seen anything like this. Ships emerging from the depths below, crewed by what seems to be a skeleton crew. No, not a skeleton crew as in a minimum amount of personnel needed to run a ship, but a literal crew of cursed, walking, living and breathing rags and bones, nasty things. Maybe not the last two, though. 

The battle was gruesome. Cannonballs exchanged left and right, holes were placed across their ships. How can you possibly sink something that [i]came[/i] from the waters? The skeleton sloops were easy to dispatch due to their nimble and fragile hulls, however the large skeleton galleon? There's absolutely no way they could take that out! They were outnumbered and outgunned. Then it happened, the brave commodore and captain orchestrated a plan to take out the final galleon one last pathetic barrage of cannonballs pointed towards the galleon, they only needed to put at least one or two holes in it for this to work. heroicly, they both jumped off their respective command ships and boarded the hostile galleon. It was absolutely horrific. Skeletons emerged from the floorboards, bones rattling, swords slicing, and blunderbusts blundering. The two pirates fought bravely against the horde of seemingly never-ending skeletons on the galleon and finally they only needed one more hole to finally sink the damned ship. The Dragon and the Anglerfish were both far too far away to do anything effective, and the time it'll take for them to get in range could mean life or death. Then the unexpected happened, cannonballs shot coming in from the starboard of the galleon. It was them, the sloop from before with its sails dropped down and displaying a large, gaping maw of a shark. The final shot needed to take out the wretched ship from the depths, and there it went down back into the abyss where it game from. While it sunk, it left behind mystical treasures and mysterious skulls. Gems taken from the cursed merfolk, skulls of the captains who used to serve on-board, and good old gold and doubloons. 

The sloop introduced themselves, they were the Gaping Maw, hunters of the legendary Shrouded Ghost; a great, giant shark only told in legends, whether it exists or not still left a mystery to most. Our initial alliance offered them to join, they needed fine pirates to travel in their journeys. Once offered, the crew of the Gaping Maw agreed to ally themselves. There, a mighty fleet was formed.

It wasn't over. At a nearby island not far from where they were, the skies turned red and the winds turned warm. They saw a tower of ash and wind looming over them. What did our adventurers do, you ask? They did what any rational pirate would do. Set sail towards the obviously dangerous threat! Arriving at the island that sourced the ashen winds they meet a man. But he was no man, nor was he merfolk. Dead he was not, neither was he alive. He donned a large overcoat and a mighty fine cutlass, his red skeleton structure radiated heat around him. His name was Captain Grimm. Is he why the undead emerged with their ships before? Doesn't matter. The time for talk is none, the skeleton captain was in no mood to talk. The battle was heated, figuratively and literally, and our pirates feared that this may be their last. Captain Grimm was a talkative one, said something about Ashen Lords or whatever, dunno. He took no notice, didn't even flinch, to any damage done to him. Cutlass slashes were shrugged off, so were bullets from flintlocks.

However, hope was not yet lost. Our pirates continued to fight and strive for victory against this evil foe. Could this have been an Ashen Lord? They thought that was merely a legend. The crews fought tooth and nail against the evil skeleton captain and his hordes of undead. Finally, Commodore William dealt the final blow on Captain Grimm with his trusty cutlass. He was defeated, however not killed. The skeleton captain vanished into thin ash to not be seen again. Our pirates won the battle, but something told them that this was not yet over. What of Flameheart? 

Unfortunately that is where this action-filled tale ends. The Sea of Thieves is a wonderful place full of excitement, adventure, and stories to tell. Take on the pirate's life and set course for the Sea of Thieves, where rare treasure and riches are vast, from pirate legends in the past. Share a voyage with a faithful crew, and call to sail the ocean blue.

This game is amazing, the graphics are beautiful, and the tasks available are very entertaining.

It was night, and I was heading to a nearby outpost, with my first booty. I come across a brig, behind a rock. My heart jumps, I start to panic, but, then in chat the captain says;

"ahoy there"

"all ok?"

"all good" I reply. 

I feel so relieved, We head into the same outpost together, and hand in our booty. Then, without goodbye, they leave as quickly as they came. 

What I love about this game is that everyone/ thing is balanced, everybody can access the same weapon, the same ship etc. the only thing different is cosmetics. 

By completing adventures and handing in chests/ items, you level up your reputation with the three guilds (which allows you to earn more gold and cosmetics). With gold, you can also buy new quests, that earn you more money, and also give an interesting adventure. (I have not tried these out, I just noticed them). There is also free adventures available, but they earn you very little amounts of money and are relatively bland after some time goes by.

 The graphics are aced, and the time it takes to cross to areas on the map are not to long, and not to short. I wish you could hold more ammo, but that would take inventory space, and maybe more food. (you can hold 10 cannon balls but only 5 bananas?)

My first experience was amazing and I love it. my only 2 complaints is the inventory wheel which you press, which then allows you to hold your weapons/ equipment. It feels strange to use. I have never used something like it, and I will probably learn quickly., and also the anchor time, it takes way to long to drop Anchor (not raise it that is aced). Perhaps, the time it takes to drop anchor could be dependent on the depth of the water. 
Also, seeing graphics for the chain and anchor in the water would be nice (it is the little details that count).

Edit: People are only reading the first part of this review thinking I'm upset. But clearly I recommended the game, and had an absolute blast. Which they'd know if they bothered to read.

It's a great game, and its really fun, especially if you have friends to play it with, however; the toxicity can be a struggle, but thats just pvp for you. Once I got into the game after the tutorial, it was just me on a little sloop only had 30 minutes at the time, immediately being hunted down by a Brig, and a Galleon. I didn't have treasure, I had just started the game, I didn't know what I was doing, or how to do it. Yet these people chased me across the map, yet I had the wind in my sales, and was faster than them. 

Suddenly, the wind changed direction, I had lost the speed, there were ghost ships ahead of me, and I was still being chased; I tried to escape around a large rock, but was cut off by the galleon. They boarded my ship, two started attacking me, while the other two were lighting my ship on fire, and firing the cannons. I had no treasure, and I was alone, I didn't understand why they were after me. Thats when they finally spoke up.

"You're trash at this game, ___!" - "I bet your mom is a ______." - "Killing noobs like you is the best part of this game!" - You get the point.

They were clearly suffering from mental issues, so I didn't use my mic to talk back, I just let myself go down with the ship, as a good captain does. However, I vowed to get my revenge, even if I must do it from the depths of Davy Jones Locker. I respawned with my ship, and immediately got to work, I hunted down loot with a stranger that joined me, and together we made some money. I bought an outfit, because I needed to look the part.

I had seen the same Galleon hunting down one of the new Ashen Winds skeleton lords. Together with my shipmate, we sailed towards them, and found their ship undefended, as they were fighting. We waited for a while, out of sight, our ship hidden behind an outcropping of some rocks. We let the fight go on for a while, before we lit their Galleon on fire, and sunk it to the depths like they had done to me. Once they had all died from the Lord, and respawned wherever their ship was. We went in and finished off the lord, and took all the loot to the furthest outpost we could find on the map, to lower the risk of the Galleon finding us. 

We got plenty of good loot, and made lots of money. All in all, for my first 4 hours of pirate adventures, I'd say it was absolutely amazing. You should get this game, and maybe we'll sail the seas together, or I'll sink you to the depths of Davy Jones with my Sloop.

Applicable alternate name, Pirate Simulator. Who knew getting a ship ready to set sail would be more fun than just jumping on the wheel and going? There's plenty to do, whether it's deciphering riddles to find treasure or running bounty missions or even just sailing around and looking for visual clues to sunken treasure. It's all about getting that loot. The cartoony visuals are refreshing and fun and the sea itself looks amazing. 
My only issue is how hostile the in game playerbase is. Yeah i know it's a game about Pirates, murder and theft but even then you'd expect to meet another player at a outpost and be able to share a grog and do a jig. 22 hours in and every player i've came across is instantly hostile, whether it's a group that's spotted your ship then chases after you for 10 straight minutes who then go on to linger around your ship to keep killing you when you respawn to having players sneak up behind you at outposts and blast you to death for no other reason than that they can. 

It's definitely a great game and even though i have my frustrations i personally chose to sail alone. For those of you that are abit more sociably comfortable I'd definitely 100% advise you find a crew otherwise you may end up uninstalling from the large amount of trolls when you're just trying to explore or ferry your spoils back.

Sea of Thieves is truly a wonderful game. I've played the game for 2 days so far and have already accumulated 15 hours. Whether it's solo, or with a big group, you will always have fun. The game does have a sharp learning curve, not only on the way to make money, but also on how many small mechanics work, but playing with a toxic player for 5 minutes should help you learn them.

The majority of the people I've met so far are very positive and peaceful, with very few exceptions.

Overall, I would recommend this game if you either want a game to relax and explore, or be a parasite and steal the loot of other ships.

Sea of Thieves has easily become one of my most played games in its short amount of time being on steam. The two main modes in this game are adventure and arena. Adventure is the main mode of the game which has open world while arena is a mainly pvp mode. All my time was spent in adventure and I have only played one or two rounds of arena because no one plays it. It took me about two months of playing to hit pirate legend, which is the main goal in the game that you achieve by hitting level 50 with the three main factions, the gold hoarders, the order of souls, and the trade merchants. This can be achieved much faster if you wanted to grind. Although I focused on the Tall Tales and just having fun, I barely had to grind to hit pirate legend.

This game primarily shines with friends although there is a way you can play with a random crew, which often either puts you with a crew without mics who are all doing different things or a crew who has mics and will be a good time playing with. Being an online game you are going to meet some toxic people, especially with there being pvp and voice chat. The toxicity in this game isn't as bad as others but can still get bad. With that being said the experiences in this game are like no other. Such as the time my crew were going to sink a sloop with another brigantine there but all forming an alliance and getting onto one ship to practically from an 8 man crew. Or the time my crew and another brigantine that we had an alliance with got a toxic galleon almost sandwiched between us and blasted away at them until they sank, which felt like a scene straight out of the Pirates of the Caribbean movies.

I highly recommend this game especially with friends. The memories you make and experiences you have together are well worth the $40 price tag. There is also monthly updates so I have no doubt that I will continue to play this game for years to come and it will stay as one of my most played games on steam.

One of the best PvPvE games I've ever played. Already have over 400 hours on it combined when I had this game via the Microsoft Store, and Rare has really put their heart and soul into this. It had a rough beginning, I mean a rough beginning, but it's come such a long way since then, making this game truly a hidden gem.

Not the best game to play solo, but an amazing game to play if you have 1-3 other friends that can join in!
Love it!

pros
Pretty to look at.

The gear you start with is the gear you end with. No pay to win or veteran advantage in gear.

There are plenty of different things to do.

Great when you have a few friends to play with.

Cons
Can be grindy if you care about being a pirate legend.

The skeleton ships can have absurd agility, speed, and insane accuracy making facing a galleon damn near impossible alone.

You need to restock your ship every time you start playing making the first 10 to 20 minutes just annoying.

Can't continue missions when you log back in. ( I understand it can mean some people exploiting it to avoid losing treasure, but I feel like there can be a compromise somewhere.)

It doesn't look like there is really any reason to become a pirate legend. Like you can have rewards that don't provide unfair advantages like an Island where you can store stuff for your ship.

You have to leave the game if you want to change ships losing all progress you have done that session and needing to restock your ship.

Overall a fun game,. I just hate that game companies can't release a complete game at launch and instead need to do this live serves crap that trickle game features that should be in the game on day one.
