Sea of Thieves is overwhelmed with PvP at the moment. If you're planning on buying the game to enjoy its PvE content, you'll soon realize many players have played the game for so long they are only looking for PvP at this point. And they will lead you into a fight no matter what your intent is. They can't take no for an answer, so you will be insulted countless times just because you're here when they are. They will be very creative at making your experience terrible for their own enjoyment, it's pretty rare that they'll just take your loot (if any) then leave without pushing it further for 15+ minutes. Most likely they'll sink your ship and kill you repeatedly, even though it serves no purpose besides wasting your time. The community is toxic beyond belief and their "debate" over private servers is yet another proof.

The game itself is very immersive, with gorgeous graphics and ambiences, awesome characters & ships design, and most of the PvE content is enjoyable even in solo... It's not too casual yet not too hard, though you'll definitely need a good team to unlock what this game has to offer. Menus are confusing at first but you get used to them pretty quickly. To be honest I'd be 100% recommending this game if the players base was not so despicable. I've not met anyone friendly in 40+ hours of gameplay (and I truly mean NOT ONCE), despite what some people might say. I don't mind PvP every now and then but I despise toxic communities, and this one is the worst I've seen by far, over nearly 25 years of gaming. I cannot recommend this game to new players: mixing PvP and PvE together isn't a terrible idea, but right now people are playing this game as if it was just another team-based competitive FPS, and you can't really enjoy PvE with that many bullies and trolls around...

I've given this game a chance (twice), and I still enjoy its content and gameplay very much, yet I uninstalled it again and I'm considering asking for a refund because toxic players can't even understand when they're going too far. I feel like people are asking for private servers mostly to avoid toxic players at this point (not just for roleplay with rewards disabled), and I cannot blame them for asking that much. This shouldn't happen. What a shame for such an amazing game...

EDIT: Anyone complaining about toxic PvP players in their review are receiving tons of judgemental comments, which (again) proves how toxic this community is. Just browse through negative reviews (sometimes even positive ones) and see for yourself! Besides trolls and fake reviews this topic is present in almost every single review. The same guys that are bullying players in the game are finding cheap excuses for their toxic behavior in the comments around here. No good will ever come from such community until PvP is somehow restricted, and toxic players are effectively removed. I don't believe this is happening anytime soon, I've watched pro players streaming SoT ever since release and even though they're nearly unbeatable at the game, they're still annoyed by all these toxic behaviors. No online game should ever come to this!

The NPCs are sometimes hilarious and the hidden environment "Easter eggs" are cute and add an extra layer of enjoyment when you stumble across them. This is a great game... Really it is. But don't try to start playing it solo. EVER. Playing solo works some of the time, and only if you know mostly what you're doing. Everything about Sea of Thieves screams team play. Looting an island? have someone stand watch. Sailing through a difficult storm? have others work the sails so you can stay on the helm. Getting holes blown into your ship for the sixth time by that same stupid galleon that just wont leave you alone? Hire a crew to go and blow it to smithereens. Honestly I have a lot of fun playing this game. But very rarely will I say that after playing solo. Find a few people you like who have it and play it with them. You'll have a better time.

[h1]A Pirate themed "Rust"[/h1]

Sea of Thieves is a multiplayer game where you join a crew that's normally 3-4 players in size. 

You do a variety of quests although the large majority are "Go to this island, dig on the X, get a treasure chest, and bring it back to sell"  Every other crew is doing the exact same thing, so whether you attack other ships and steal their loot or you find loot yourself is up to you. 

[b]Keep in mind you can spend over an hour finding loot only to be attacked and lose it all in an instant *feels like Rust*[/b]

[b]The Good:[/b]
+ Very social game, everyone is expected to talk in-game and communicate with one another 
+ Cross-play between Xbox
+ Team-oriented and great fun co-op gameplay
+ BEAUTIFUL world, they did an absolutely wonderful job on creating an amazing sea with a variety of tides
+ Open world and somewhat of a "create your own adventure" as you and your crew set out at your own pace
+ The voyages (Quests) allow the players to figure things out on their own. I particularly like that it doesn't "hand-hold" the player when it comes to directions and figuring out what to do or where to find buried treasure. You actually have to map out your surroundings, use the compass to orientate yourself, and coordinate where your ship is going.
+ The ship battles are pretty fun, shooting cannon balls across the water trying to sink another ship before they sink you. Bailing out water, patching holes, etc. All in real-time with multiple people working together on your ship.
+ Interesting world events and more elaborate quests


[b]The Bad:[/b]
- VERY Poor integration with Steam. You can NOT invite friends on steam to join you. You must use the "Xbox Companion App" and create an Xbox Live account and add friends. 
- No in-game "friends-list" or messaging system. Again it just makes it very hard to add people  or message people when its all done through Xbox and not through Steam.
- Can-be "Toxic" community. Sometimes a huge ship with a larger group of players will just circle around blowing up every ship it sees. Sometimes people will just hide out and wait at ports so when you come back to sell your stuff they ambush you and steal all your hard earned loot. (again like "Rust" you sometimes lose A LOT of progress, especially considering this game can take hours to gather loot and complete quests)
- The close-combat system is pretty lame, mainly just swinging a short sword willy-nilly hoping you hit them more than they hit you.
- To make things fair, the gold you earn is only used for cosmetic purchases. This leads to a feeling of "what's the point" or "why am I doing this?" I would have liked to have seen some sort of upgrade system or a more meaningful progression system, 
- Microtransactions... On a $40 game....    


[b]Overall:[/b]
Definitely a great game to play with friends or other people who want more social interaction. Its the type of game where you can EASILY sink 4+ hours into in a single day and feel like time just flew by. The world is beautiful, and theres always a sense of danger with enemy players around which adds to the "thrill".  I do think $40 is way too high for a game like this though, so I would recommend waiting for a sale.

The game has so much to do that it's staggering. Fighting players, battling it out with NPC skeletons, captains, and their ships, Captain Flameheart and his massive ghost ship fleet, there's the fleet with several skeleton ships to fight with plenty of rewarding loot (when you have the time to grab it), megalodons, the Kraken, ashen lords, tall tales, reaper's chests (you'll find some player combat surely if you have one aboard), skeleton forts, and more. Not to mention the fact that you can become an emissary for pretty much all factions for more rewards from doing voyages and digging up loot on the islands on the massive map. The player interactions are, four times out of five, more toxic than botulinum toxin, but that makes the game more interesting.

From a solo standpoint, the game is difficult, as it should be, a solo pirate should not get too far without a crew. With a full Galleon, however, I got 70k coins from just messing around with my friends and destroying player ships, the fleet, and getting reaper chests, all gained within a few hours (IN AN OPEN CREW, NO LESS!). I didn't even get too angry when we lost a ship with an estimated 20k coins worth of loot, because the coins don't buy much except for cosmetics, and it was fun getting the loot in the first place. (We ended up taking the loot back from the people that stole it from us but still, I wasn't even mad at the time.)

Overall, a great game with more toxic than wholesome players, and I wouldn't have it any other way. The occasional wholesome friendly group or solo slooper is heartwarming, and toxic encounters are engaging and give the game character.

This is the first game I spent money on in an in-game purchase, (for a pet because why not), and sure it was a waste of ten bucks, but now I have a cute little birdy boy on my adventures.

Did I mention how stunning the graphics are and how confused I am at how even the brickest of PCs that I've used can render them?

UPDATE ~ I have nearly 300 hours in this game now, and I still love it just the same!

Sea of Thieves is a satisfying adrenaline rush and surprisingly balanced if you enjoy PvP.

I'm always on the lookout for new co-op games on Steam. When Sea of Thieves popped up, I mentioned it to a few friends and one of them was ecstatic. He insisted that I get it ASAP so we could play together. I'm so glad I did. Within the first 10 hours, this became one of my favorite co-op games.

Things started out a bit rocky. My boyfriend and I simultaneously booted up the tutorial. After I beached and un-beached my ship, I shambled through the rest of the tutorial on my end, a little concerned about whether or not I'd ever handle the multitasking that's required to be an effective pirate in this game. Soon after, our good friend joined us and I went into full-on panic mode. There are other players? Right now?! All around us?!!?! I knew there was a PvP element, but I thought we were playing a private game and that we'd be able to do that in the future.

It wasn't long until we were raided by another ship, and it was definitely just for lulz. The three of us were at an outpost with zero loot. It wasn't long until it was over, however, and as we watched their ship sink and I came down from the stress, I grinned. [i]That felt amazing.[/i]

I never envisioned getting so hyped about PvP. I avoid most PvP anymore because of cheating and toxic communities, but Sea of Thieves does it quite well and I've had, so far, a very fair experience. While I've lost some battles, I've never felt that something was unreasonable. I've had people cuss me out for swiping their loot, killing them, etc. If I could offer any advice to a new player, it's [b]learn to pay attention to your surroundings as much as possible.[/b]

This isn't a game where absolutely anyone can easily sneak up on you without you having ample time to do something about it, and this isn't a game where people are required to leave you alone. If you decide to stop at an outpost to sell your loot when you see a player ship in the distance, then you're setting yourself up as a target. If you truly feel a player is harassing you, scuttle your ship and spawn somewhere else. With almost 60 hours in this game now (now well over 100 as of June 30. 2020), though, I really have a hard time wrapping my head around just how people feel like they can't get away from other players. The only thing I can conclude is that they're just not paying enough attention to what's around them.

I've played on all three ships now by myself and with a team of friends. If you're solo, the sloop is fast enough to outrun any ship against the wind. It's actually very easy to completely avoid other players on it if that's your jam. The brig and galleon add the thrill of teamwork and communication. As with any PvP game, Sea of Thieves is not without its toxic players. This is honestly why I primarily play solo or with friends because I just don't personally enjoy teaming up with random people. I've met nice players, trolls, and jerks, and it's really nothing different from any other PvP experience in my opinion.

The rewards for completing anything in this game are purely cosmetic. While I was lukewarm about that at first, I appreciate how it levels out the playing field for players of any skill set. Even with micro-transactions, there's no pay-to-win mechanic.

While players are certainly a threat, there are plenty of other things that can sink your ship, from The Kraken to a rainstorm, from ghost ships to a poorly placed gunpowder barrel (a good place for them is in the crow's nest, FYI). It's difficult to deal with some of the PvE threats when you're solo, but it's very possible with practice and patience!

Sea of Thieves is also graphically and musically beautiful. It easily has the nicest looking water I've [i]ever[/i] seen in a video game. I'm normally a little thalassophobic when it comes to large bodies of water in video games, but it's just so darn gorgeous that I'm always ready to jump in and swim around. Further, I knew I recognized the composition style from [i]somewhere[/i], and it's none other than Robin Beanland! That's just another plus for me as a gaming music nerd.

There are a variety of bugs that seemed to have been fixed (at least for me) in the most recent update: ship compass freezing, wind not showing up, not being able to interact with things and having to die or find a mermaid to "reset" ... Rare seems really set on making this a polished experience, however, and it's given me even more incentive to stick around and keep playing!

I do not know what drugs the SoT moderation is on these days, but I found out the only person I crew with has gotten banned, with no reason stated, and no reliable way to dispute. This game is an open ocean adventure. Emphasis on open.

There are no roles.
There are no rules.
It is up to you how you wish to go about it.

Today you can decide to move some cargo for the Merchants Alliance, raising their flag, and carefully transporting goods across the sea, avoiding what conflict you can.

The next you can be a mercenary for the Order of Souls, going from island to island, killing skeleton captains and their crew for their heads. Defending your loot from the sea and players alike.

Or, you could go all in, raising the Reapers Bones, your crew skillfully sinking every ship you encounter, and sending every player you meet to the Ferry of the Damned!

But, sometimes, you will be yourself, whoever you are, another soul on the Sea of Thieves, exploring with your friends, approaching other ships with your Alliance flag raised, recruiting other crews to the sea police, using your amplified words through your megaphone to convince others to help one another, and simply go digging for treasure together.

These are the open waves. Bring a friend, where I may be kind, I will gladly wait for you to leave your ship, hijack it into the ocean, and leave a piece of Snake Meat on your ships stove, simply to watch it catch ablaze. A reminder of the choices you make, and the consequences that may follow for being a rude dude.

I am sure you have already read plenty of material about the Sea of Thieves.  And overall it is a great game, A game that I really love and one that I am going to keep playing.  Now, why with that would I rank it negatively and tell you to run from this title?   Well let me try to explain my love/hate relationship with this title.

Ahh, yes this incredible game, it really is a fantastic experience UNTIL you run into another person.  Wait, Mikey, you say its great until you run into another person?  Isn't this game full of other people?  Ding Ding, Why yes it is Johnny.  It is full of the most awful despicable people you will ever meet.  There will be those that say well you should get Gud, or play better, but the facts of the case are these.  

A game really should be something enjoyable and if someone in this game wants to make your life hell for a few hours, that is doable and really easy to accomplish.  For example, lets say you are playing for an hour, have done a few small missions, played around and have a few pieces of treasure and along comes someone else who wants to take it away from you.  Well if you play solo, odds are you are already outmatched and are about to get 2v1 and thats if you are lucky.  Because it can be 3v1 or 4v1.  Sound fun yet?  Perhaps to you this is challenging but delightful.

Perchance you will flee from those horrible odds except that getting away in this game is not possible unless your opponent gives up on chasing you and completely turns away from you.  You see if you are in the 2 man sloop you are the slowest ship in the game unless you go into the wind.  The 4 manned galleon and 3 manned Brig are FASTER than the 2 or 1 man ship with the wind.  However in the case of our 2 man sloop you are supposedly the fastest going into the wind, but since the wind shifts eventually the guy behind you can literally track you and follow at a distance.  If someone wants you and continues to follow you around, you aren't going to be able to play the game.  You can't run ashore and do a mission because the second you do, here they come to blow you up. You can't fight because they outnumber you or are just better than you in general because this game doesn't have a rank system of any kind and they lump everyone together.  
As an example:  So you have been playing for 2 days?  Meet Mikey who has played for 400 days and knows all sorts of tricks like the "Hide" emote where you can hide on a persons ship and you can't see their name plate.  Well I am sure there is gameplay that explains that right?  Nope.  And he knows that if you stop at one island over he can use his rowboat to row over an explosive and prep to blow up your ship so when his friend comes over your ship is blown to pieces before you even get back.   In essence If you don't read up on these things you are gonna be awfully surprised the first time it happens.  Well now that you read it, you won't, but I hope you can see where I am going with this.  

Perhaps you say to yourself well I have very little treasure on my ship at a time so it won't be a problem.  Well other players don't know that, and they won't know until they have killed you and sunk your ship.  So they are going to sink you and all that time you spent collecting things for your ship are now gone.  But hey, my mama didn't raise no fool, I am not gonna  just let them steal my stuff  so I will out sail them.  Good on you for making the smart choice to run away from someone better or perhaps there are more people than you but did I mention they can chase you down for your entire game time and not bat an eye about it? No?  Well they can, there is no where that is safe and fog and storms only hide you so well.  
So your next choice is Well I will turn and fight and I will stop their ship so they won't pursue me.  Well odds are, they know all the tricks you know because there aren't a heck of a lot of them to employ to begin with. The most common are Hitting their anchor, setting them on fire, and hitting them with an explosive barrel.  That's what you got, and if one person is watching the water/ladders, you are not going to succeed in any of those.  Sure, you will hear the odd story of someone not paying attention and able to stop a ship, well there is a problem with it.   I have tested this in pursuit of someone, and they did the anchor thing a couple of times, (I had lost fair and square to two of the worst people I have ever met in gaming and I pursued them for quite some time)  and No matter how many times they stopped my ship, I was up and moving again very quickly and still after a few minutes of expert sailing I still caught up to them to fight.

If someone does not choose to break off and go do something else you are in for a miserable play experience because you are literally trying to bore the other team into leaving you alone. 
When someone chooses to do this the experience is not enjoyable and it happens VERY OFTEN.  It is harrowing if you just spent 60 minutes playing and now someone comes along to render that time spent moot.  It makes for a great story to tell people for sure, but the reality is, Being chased and blown up when you don't want or feel like fighting horrible odds 1 vs 2  or worse is an awful experience.  Imagine being chased for 3 hrs, yes it has happened to me, it was Horrendous.

But Mikey, you must really suck at this game and should just get better or make some friends that play.  Sure, I could get better at the game, better at distrusting anyone that comes near me is more like.  Rank Paranoia is what this game causes.  You will come across nice players that will ally with you.  Ahh yes, the alliance.  So, remember those two people I called horrible beings above?  You see, I took a 10k piece of treasure off a ship, which shows your location at all times, and I was delivering it,  They came sailing up and asked for an alliance.  I said sure, why not.  I used to be fairly trusting early on thinking my allies won't hurt me.  I bet you didn't know that allies in this game can shoot and hurt one another so if they decide to betray you, like in this case you, like me will decide to never trust anyone.  So to continue the allies' names appear in purple, but they can screw you over at will and in this case, they did.  They waited for me to pull up to the Reaper's hideout and walk to the entrance and they threw 4 bombs in my face and stole the chest and blew my ship to pieces while I was dead. 

Which also brings me  to another negative about the game.  You see, if you play more than 40 hours and die here and there you will learn where on a ship you will spawn.  there are literally SET points.  And if you stand in the right spot, and for a sloop that would be the roof, they can continue to throw bombs at you and you can't do anything.  Oh, and did I mention that you spawn 1-2 seconds before you get control of your character?  That means the boarder has the advantage. and can kill you before you get your weapon out.

Are you Excited about the sea of thieves yet!?!

Truly I have enjoyed some epic and great battles but at the end of them, if you lose and I have lost some and won some.  Winning feels great but I have been on the side of losing, so guess what? I don't do it to other people unless they come looking for trouble and then I will give it to them.  But think about it for a moment, do you like someone stealing your things?  Well guess what, they built a simulator for it, the Sea of Thieves.  I mean its in the name, but if you read the cute signs they have posted in the taverns the company that made it asks you to be nice to fellow players.  HAHAHAHA, Have these developers met a single human being?  If you can be mean to someone and its part of the game, its highly likely going to happen and this game is literally geared for it.  The plot of the game: Steal from your neighbors, Don't be nice, be a pirate, and be hated for it.  No I mean it people are going to really hate you.

Now that I have played the game for 100+ hours I gotta say its fun. the treasure hunting and ship combat is amazing and fun there is a story and a few bonuses for through exploring. Best part is that the game dose not hold your hand all the way through the game it dose give you some tips here and there on how to lvl rep up and not die but that's about it. when hunting for some treasures instead of "you go here dig here take chest back to outpost get gold" you get a map or riddle telling you an island and a vague area to look and rely on land marks and NESW.

However to every good thing there is a bad, the pvp is a touch...broken. people spawn camp the hell out of you if they board and your unable to do squat until they leave or you sink and hand to hand combat is dull and repetitive. That and some players just don't die you can blast and slash them to your hearts content and they somehow don't die people say its cheats some say its the that pc players have an advantage (oh and quick note THIS GAME IS CROSS PLATFORM WITH XBOX) and others say its ping/western and eastern players playing on eachother's servers and becoming almost impossible to hit even though you hitmarker them to hell.

all in all the game is fun ship combat and treasure hunting is fun pvp can be fun if you don't get spawn camped or face an oddly immortal player and hand to hand combat is fine most of the positives outweigh the negatives and the negatives are very minor things that are most likely to get fixed in the future and if they don't? hey I ain't giving up this game since I find it fun.

I do recommend the game, there are micro transactions just its all purely cosmetic items. Xbox players are a touch toxic but hey pc is master race and mouse and keyboard will out aim and shoot controller users almost any day...if your a good shot.

Sea of Thieves is an Adventure Game in a PVP game's body

Pros
-Sailing is Fun
-Gives a real sense of Adventure
-Fighting off random events can be rewarding.
-The atmosphere of the open ocean
-Conquered my Thalassophobia 

Cons
-Hyper aggressive players
-Lack of progression
-Clunky combat
-Imprecise controls
-NPCs are very forgettable

Notes:
-The tall tales were fun. The adventure was the best part of the game.
-You sail to accumulate money, but you don't ever get to spend it on anything that will make the game more easy/fun. So what is the point of doing it all?
-Players are always hostile. 100% of the time. Some will even chase you beyond when it would be profitable to them. They waste your time and you waste theirs. There is no tangible reward for PVP. The game does not even keep track of boats that you've sunk. Why even do it? And yet players will chase you across the entirety of the playable map just to get some shots at you. Players will chase after you for no reason. If you see a player in the horizon, the best course of action is to change course. PVP becomes a barrier to you enjoying the game. An annoyance to plague your experience of the game. I know its a game about pirates, but not even real pirates were this nonsenically violent.

They made some fundamental errors in the design of the game (primarily that they forgot to design the game). There's no progression, griefing is terrible because nobody has anything to lose (because no progression), all the outposts look the same.

Things I want and this game doesn't have:
- Let me own a ship and upgrade it. Maybe ship ownership is more like a roguelike where if you lose the ship, it's just gone. That way I'm very nervous about engaging in a PVP battle.
- Have way more player ships in a world and let there be default alliances. Like by default everyone affiliated with merchants are on the same "team", so to speak. So you can always have at least some backup if need be, etc.
- There's a sign in the bar that says "all crew members are equal" or something. That's a load of crap. Give us Captains, and first mates, and let us mutiny. 
- Let us parlay with other OTHER captains and strike deals, etc. Huge missed opportunity on not adding in a "pirate code" or something.

There's no way that Rare is completely oblivious to the issues with this non-game.

As may come as a surprise, this is with the caveat that it is fun with friends. Several. 3+, which can be a tall ask with today's wealth of games. VERY much a sideways thumb.

It CAN be fun without them and, in fact, they have a boat specifically for single-players, but it's near impossible to play as all any crew wants to do is PvP and grief. There's fishing and cooking and treasure hunting and shipwrecks to explore and sea monsters to hunt and a story and entire alliances devoted to these things, but the content is essentially locked off as people will camp outposts or chase any smaller crew to the end of the earth regardless of whether they're hostile, have goods, etc. so it's extremely difficult to actually cash anything in. This is exacerbated by the fact that there are in-game alliances incentivizing it, which is honestly very confusing as it should be it's own ample reward to have a sweet back-and-forth before looting the wreck. Everything is rendered superfluous by the Reaper's Bones since you get everything for the other alliances from it. None of this is a problem with a decent crew, but they'll just want to be aggressors too so I guess it is all unnecessary background in the end. Even with a crew, trying anything else will likely just get you blindsided and, "that advantage makes the battle," as they say.

Also confusing is their focus on arena-specific events. Yes, there is an arena mode in this. It's hard to utilize it because it's seemingly pretty sparse, but it's there. Everyone wants to PvP, but not in the specific mode. Ironic.

Ship battles between two competent crews are exhilarating if not sparse and sailing the high seas with just your compass and a map or spotting a ship on the horizon with your spyglass and deciding if they're worth it based on the flag their waving is great. Landing that long-distance as a ship is getting away with the chainshot is priceless. Hell, skeleton raids are super fun when other players aren't just camping them in a big-ass galleon. When it's hits, it hits on the head.

tl'dr it's half a game because it shoots itself in the foot on every step but open-world PvP and that half is only accessible with a handful of friends, but boy, what a half a game that is. I just wanted to fish for God's sake.

Just started playing Sea of Thieves...
So... I'm on a one-man crew.
I'm getting harried by this 2-man crew, who I killed twice each before the popped my ship.
I spawn back in... and strangely... they're on my map.
So... what do -I- do...
That's right... full tilt toward them, ramming speed...
I creep on them for a few miles, and then dart around this mountain to cut them off... and then BAM... right into the front-right of their ship.
I sprint down the steps, up the bow of MY ship, and jump onto theirs. Mine keeps going because... no anchor was set, and I have no crew...
Proceed to set fire to their ship with a few more bombs I'm carrying, kill them both with my sword, and turn THEIR ship toward some rocks before bailing out in THEIR rowboat. XD
I have no idea what became of them, or their ship... or even mine... but I feel like a high seas psychopath. ^_^

If there's one thing you [b]NEED[/b] to know about this game, it's that there's no meaningful progression.

Every ship is available from the start & every treasure, delivery, beaten player, or killed skeleton is done for the simple sake of cosmetics. Whether that be a different hat for your character or a burgundy sail for your ship. 
There's different 'factions' which you can sail as an emissary for, level up, earn greater rewards, and get better cosmetics, but that's it.

That'll put many people off, but depending on how you look at it, it's also a good thing.
It means that the only real difference between you and someone who sunk (pun intended) 1k hours into this game is skill and mechanical understanding. There's no OP weapons, or stat-boosting apparel.

The real fun to be had is playing with friends. Whether that be killing a megladon, experiencing the ever-expanding story-driven events, completing challenges, or hunting other players on the seas. Sea of Thieves is a game for creating your own story.

1st time I played a game like this and I love it!

Highly entertaining game! It's easy to learn the PVE/PVP & ship mechanics but hard to master some of them.

Open Crews can be a bit frustrating due to lack of gameplay experience or bad comms from your crew mates, although there's always a good chance you may queue up with a decent crew. 

There are many things to do in this game: Arena (sloop arena is easier to queue vs galleon arena unless if you have a premade crew), Events, Emissary runs, Emissary hunts, Tall Tales, Commendations/Achievements, go guns blazing/sneak in Forts being completed by another player crew and take their loot etc... 

This is the kind of game where you do whatever you feel like (that's what I enjoy the most about it)!

Feels good to sail the seas for a change! Roll tide! :)

[h1]A review a short one and a long one for mah readers. [/h1]

[b] Short Review [/b]
This game is simply beautiful and alluring. If you like pirates, loot, group or adventure games then you should already have this on your wishlist if not in your cart already. 

[b] Long Review [/b]
When this game had first came out I wanted it but I didn't own an XBox, I enjoy looting games and the graphics were simply eye gasims. I was sold when I had seen gameplay;  [spoiler] of someone getting sucked into a tentacles of a kraken. [/spoiler] I just wasn't sold on buying an Xbox for one game.

When this had recently come out for Steam I won't lie, I was hyped as my want for the game had subsided after a year and a few months.  But me being me I didn't want to pay full price, I rarely ever pay full price for a game, I want wait as I have for two years for this game, but low and behold my gf seen me on the store page of it during the Summer sale and I told her that I was going to pick it up but that it wasn't on sale, low and behold spending x amount resulted in a discount so that's what I did after she pointed it out. So as I was installing it I decided to read up on the game... I learned a lot but with you have to do it to live it.

My first day out I went alone and didn't know what to expect and people would randomly join in and out of my game.
Second day out I went out alone on my sloop and alas this has been the way it has been for me as I have now countless salty sea dog tales. 

This game has reminded me many key points in life.
1. You start with nothing.
2. Everything can be taken away.
3. Friend or foe, don't trust anyone you don't know.
4. The greater the risk, the greater the reward!
5. Megalodons are not real, but sharks are.

There is a stigma about this game. i.e. Solo/group/pvp/pve

First and foremost yes you can solo in this game, I do it all the time with plenty of screenshots and loots to prove it. I have heard that it's the game on "hard" mode. To some extent yes to some extent no. The sloop is the weakest out of all the ships, but the fastest. Yes 3 pirates vs 1 you may seem kind of bad but they are on one ship and you can take them down I promise, as I have. My worse encounter has been while battling a megalodon, one player trys to get credit for the kill as well as sink me in the process, while that is all going on another ship was on fire coming toward us and had 2 skeleton ships chasing that which added on to the chaos... long story short I killed the meg, down a skeleton ship and let the other 3 play with each other while I got away with a meg kill and a few chests from the skeleton ship. It was the most chaos that I have seen all one area at one time. Most other times I will randomly come across other players. 80% of the time they are hostile. I do randomly meet other friendly sailors but always be weary as a few of them have tried to sink me while not watching as well. lol #Piratelife

There are two modes of game play.
The first being of open world, quests, voyages, tall tales, etc.
The second is more of an Arena where it's 15min matches, up to 5 ships compete for silver, and a Chest buried on an island that all the ships are after.

I highly like this as I can jump in and out of the arena for quick matchs or I can burn a day away hunting megalodons as it is my new favorite thing to do.

In conclusion, I rarely ever write reviews, but this one deserved not only my praise but my kudos as well, may they continue to make great things in this game as it has plenty of content and gameplay to keep a salty sea dog busy for hours.... I have played toooo many games that there's consent trolling... I can throw this game on set sails... I seen no flames... unless I am setting them upon skeleton ships. I see no trolls.... unless they are pretending to be a friend then then jump off my ship with a chest. 

If you like or love anything to do with pirates. Buy this game now, come join us!

Also if you're just looking for a shipmate let me know!

Base game is fun. But cannot play solo or generally with random people. so unless you have a group to play with EVERY time you play then its not worth playing. People are either salty or always on the hunt. So forget doing anything PvE related like the many world quests and such since someone else will show up 99% of the time to kill you and take what you just worked an hour or more for. Only way to really see if someone is sailing around attacking people on the map is if they voluntarily put up a reaper flag, so that's a useless system...all in all, game is very well designed, PvP system poorly designed, making it annoying/frustrating to just play if you just want to jump in and casually play. There really needs to be a bounty system that marks pirates attacking/killing other players and rewards anyone who sinks them. Not saying there should be no PvP, but it really needs work to make things balanced.

This might possibly be one of the greatest MMORPGs ever made.
The reason is simple; unlike most MMORPGs those games put gimmicks and tricks into the player experience to keep them playing and paying a monthly subscription.
Those MMORPGs such as WoW put you on mindless quests, fed Ex quests, and needless grinds for EVERYTHING.
Its like going to a 2nd job.
Then there are the Free To Play MMORPGs that bait you into playing for Free, then frustrate you into buying a subscription for yet another endless grind of an MMORPG.

Sea of Thieves CHANGES everything and BREAKS the WoW model all MMORPGs imitate and cram down our throats.
Sea of Thieves does this by providing a rich, beautiful, totally immersive gaming experience that holds your interest so well you can't wait to play it again.
You will not wake up thinking as you do in other MMORPGs "oh my I have to play just to keep up and not lose the race".
YES, all those OTHER MMORPGs are one big race to get ahead of everyone else and accomplish everything fast fast fast and then grind over and over and over.

In Sea of Thieves, just hopping into your ship and going for a joy ride is always an interesting experience.
You contend with storms, rough seas, occassional nasty critters that pop up out of the water when you least expect it. This unlike other MMOPRGs where MOBS just stand there grazing and waiting for you to kill them.
The quests are so rich and varied, with everything from riddles, puzzles, to stories, you name it.
So many different types of quests its varied and REFRESHING.
The graphics although at first seem cartoony, especially the pirates and NPC's;  HOWEVER, you will be amazed at the beautiful and epic vistas so much you will wear out the Steam "Screenshot" key.
I hate cartoony graphics, yet somehow this game seems to blend them into something beautiful to the point where if someone walks by your PC while you are playing they will stop and say "WOW!".

The quests are fun and challenging and you are not forced to take ones you do not like.
For example, I have a hard time with riddles, but the community is so vibrant there is always an answer somewhere if you cannot figure it out yourself.
Unfortunately, many of the Tall Tale quests are bugged and the games design does a POOR job of deciding when to keep or discard your progress.

There are mobile companion applications, guides, and videos to help you if needed.

PvP in Adventure mode is exciting, don't whine if a player ruins your day.
To quote Captain Jack Sparrow when accused of playing unfair: "Pirate..."
Like the game "EVE" its a cruel world, but in Sea of Thieves you dont lose anything except "time".

Please remember, when you first play do not blow off the Maiden Voyage quest, even if you do not like the art style, etc., just DO IT to learn the game.
Then be amazed as you progress thru it.

Don't worry about real money, thats all just for cosmetic items, emotes and stuff like that.
The $39 was well worth spending and as a whole this game is better than most if not all anything I have played recently, if ever.

Keep in mind this is mostly a sandbox MMORPG, and you will not get much hand holding.
Which is a GOOD THING!

All is not peaches and cream, as you will die many times trying to do a quest, and lose all your stuff that you found, but with the exception of quest items that can be obtained again by just repeating the quest or any quest other stuff can be found all over the place: Food, Ammo etc etc.
However, unlike other MMORPGS you can go back to the spot say where your ship sank and pick up floating debris from it. Been finding alot of that lately, some mine some others (?).
Regardless, loot is so amble its not a big thing.

***BAD***
And now, the BIG BAD of this game...The game does a horrible job of maintaining your quest progress. Thus, you will find that for whatever reason the next time you log on your quest state is gone unless reaching a certain milepost or chapter within it. But sometimes even that 
 DOES NOT WORK AS INTENDED. 

Also, Tall Tale quests are BUGGED. 
Good example of this I completed the very hard and long Shroud Breaker quest, started Cursed Rogue, only to find the next time I logged in the Cursed Rogue quest was gone and so was the path I needed to restart it.
In fact, the Shroud Breaker quest was back, despite having already finishing it and getting the Accomplishment for it etc. and rewards.

As a result, if you can deal with these GAME BREAKING quest bugs, then by all means play this game.

If you cannot deal with such stupid bugs or poor game design of how quests are handled, then this GAME IS NOT FOR YOU.

I've played 74 hours so far. I love this very enjoyable game but there is [b]1 fact[/b] that makes me HATE this game.

[h1] GRIEFERS [/h1]

After 2-3 hours of hard work, lot's of loot you get as a reward. Some bastards will show up and start to hit your ship. Ah you guys will say, WELL CAN'T YOU FLEE OR FIGHT BACK? We're 2 people in fucking sloop(SLOWEST SHIP). And we're basically noobs. Also we're mostly being tired after all that world events or voyages so just want to sell and quit. But you know what you CAN'T. They will chase you for HOURS. They will scream you 'GIVE ME YOUR LOOT'. And eventually we will ALT+F4. 
We know, we know this is a pirate game, yes. But it is a GAME. We're paying for this and playing for to ENJOY. You cannot force people to PvP.

That's it! If PvE server's will be a thing in the near feature I'll change my review to YES.

[table][tr][th]Genre[/th][td]Action-adventure game[/td][/tr][tr][th]Campaign[/th][td]Yes But online only [/td][/tr][tr][th]Game length[/th][td]N/A Only online[/td][/tr][tr][th]Difficulty modes[/th][td]normal[/td][/tr][tr][th]Gamepedia Page[/th][td][url=https://seaofthieves.gamepedia.com/Sea_of_Thieves_Wiki] Link [/url][/td][/tr]


[b][h1]Overview[/h1][/b]

Sea of ​​Thieves is one of the best multiplayer coop experience you can currently get. It highly depends on your crew, you and up to your 3 friends can join to have your own adventure. The beauty of this game is that it does not have any progress in developing your character. At first it may seem pretty repetitive and boring. There is no way to make your ship stronger, or character do more damage. This makes every encounter on the seas challenging. The only progress that you can make is by knowing the core mechanics better, and use them to your advantage. By smart managing your ship and using all variety of different cannonballs it is deffinietly possible to sink a 4 person galleon while flying 2 person sloop. The only things that you can buy for money are clothes and different skins to your weapons and equipment, but you won’t get any benefits by using endgame and rare varieties of this skins. You can look whatever you like fitting in many different sets of clothes not losing any stats. Game had a pretty rough start in 2018 by a lack of content but now Rare took a good care of their masterpiece by adding regularly new content and even new core mechanics such as fire. Rare is one of the most transparent and connected to community companies I’ve ever seen. They love their game and care about community. The updates are well thought out and makes changes that make me go back every time the new update is released. However this is not a game for everyone. Its mainly for people that have lots of free time to spare. Quick in-and-out voyages can become a long hours of traveling thru seas collenting more and more loot just to the point that other crew will decide to attack you and steal all the loot. Yes this game is PVP ONLY. That doesn’t necessarily mean that everyday you would find someone so desperate to kill you, that he will chase you thru all map and eventually get you in confrontation. BUT loosing your hard earned progress just a few minutes away from outpost in with u would cash in your loot is a part of the game. I literally have a THIEV word in the title so by setting sail be sure that you will eventually lose many thousands of cash by other players. It is in my opinion a great test whether you really like this game. If you would sail for like a 4/5 hours on duo sloop with your friend just to be downed by a galleon of reapers bones, and after a break to chill after this loss you would still want to play and maybe make up what your lost . Trust me you won’t regret.

well its certainly a good game, though ive got some mixed feelings. i feel like the whole "no safe areas" thing is a bit much. i get that its supposed to be the most like a pirate's life in some sort of way but when you spawn in to 3 or 4 people spawn camping you just to troll it gets old and very discouraging. there also comes a point where you need to be able to kick people from a 2 man crew. 2 men crews for the sloops are the most troll infested matchmaking ive seen since i last played COD. and on top of it all, THE FREAKING ROWBOAT DOCKING IS SOME OF THE MOST FRUSTRATING THINGS IVE EVER EXPERIENCED! ever tried going on it to get some random floating loot from the ocean because it's easier? yeah well the whole "hold to dock" thing is dumb enough but then add the whole 80ft waves that push and pull you up and down so far from your ship that its out of range to dock. then you account for the incline glitches where my guy can climb stairs and ramps like a pro but you try to walk up a rock that isnt completely flat and my dude slides straight to davy jone's locker. also, i think there could be alot of improvements in ship design. specifically storage placements. the sloop, the ammo box is almost directly on top of the stairs so trying to get in and out quickly for repairs or emptying water from your hull is pretty frustrating. then there's the cannon ball storages on bligintine and galleon. oh boy yall might wanna sprint your butts down below deck for some of them sweet cannon balls in the middle of battle because you no have the ability to just drop to stockpile them in place. also, this is just my OCD but i really hate the cracked lens on your rifle as being the way you aim. a semi-seethrough paint dot or something more prominant for that time would be so much better for some of the other skins. also, the continued spawns of skeleton ships while youre docked at islands is especially frustrating when youre doing a voyage and all the sudden once youre completed you notice your ship sank and all your other treasure despawned because skeleton ships will relentlessly attack your ship whether you are on it or not. its fine for the ship to draw agro when youre driving it but damn man, im like a mile into an island underground and some boney bois strawhat luffy my ship to the sea floor. there should also be a thing to where you could crouch or at the very least stable yourself on a ship during storms and high waves because my god as a marksman this game is pretty annoying like "hey this skele ship keeps hitting us but every time i get on the cannon the waves decide to take me out of shot way under us." i also think the amount of planks you should be able to hold at a time should both be increased by 5 because man, a megladon and a I think I'm two months into playing this game and I'm pretty obsessed. I love the skill based fights and the feeling you get sailing across the water. Its a Gorgeous game and I enjoy the ranking system. I do have a lot of Wants for this game though. I have 10 friends who play this game, and we're forced to separate into groups and never see each other in game. Kind of a bummer. I so desperately wish there was a place for a lot of players to gravitate together and share a pint and just goof around with other pirates. That being said, all of my wants come from the excitement of the game. It inspires me for whats to come in the game and what could be. I think it could very well become one of the best online games ever, if it keeps expanding its world and working for the players. Rare did a great job. I love this game and highly recommend you come sail with me!

Sea of Thieves is an open-world, sail-the-high-seas pirate game. Easy to learn and hard to master, there's not much bad I can say about it; the graphics are beautiful, there's always something to do, and unlike MMORPGs, there's no real difference between a new player and an old salt beyond raw skill and game knowledge. Every person loads in the same.

When you load in, you are given the option of a sloop (1-2 players), a brigantine (1-3 players), or a galleon (1-4 players). You are then given the option to play by yourself/with friends or with other players online. Playing with others is the heart of this game - whether with friends or strangers - however, it may be difficult to decide on what to do. When you load in, there is an active "event" on dictated by the clouds in the sky, visible across the entire sea. For example, if you see a skull in the sky, there is an active skeleton fort to take on, and if there is no cloud, that means the kraken is on the prowl! If you get tired of fighting, there is lore to be discovered in "The Shores of Gold" quests, and plenty of other things to find if you search...

The game has monthly updates full of content, with stories progressing if you're watching closely - as I type this, the Ashen Winds update has been released, and Flameheart's generals are unleashed upon the seas. Things change all the time, giving the game a fresh feel each month. Very few games can do this.

I often play solo, which is only recommended if you have a stomach for unfairness; commonly, my ship will get taken down by a 4-man Galleon who just feels like causing trouble. I understand that this is part of the game, however it takes some patience and often if I am tired I'll just give up. There's a lot of patience in general required for the other members of the community - there are some toxic people who will find new players and spawn camp them until they quit, will chase you all the way around the map, and will keep coming back even after they've been sunk multiple times. This can be exhausting, but don't lose hope! This is only a small part of the experience. Most of the time, other players will either offer an alliance, or sink you/be sunk and go on their way, unless you steal their loot.

TL;DR: I have over 300 hours on the Xbox version and I can heartily say that there isn't a game like this anywhere else. Unforgettable graphics, in-depth and out-of-sight story that makes you feel like you earnt it, and monthly updates make this game feel completely unlike anything else. Throw in some friends, and you're in for a night of fun. Definitely worth the $50.

Sea of Thieves has huge potential, but ultimately I don't recommend this game at the current time (August 2020).

This is a negative review, so let's start with the bad:

- The game is quite pricey. It's greedily priced by the developers for what it offers compared to other games.
- Combat mechanics are very basic for person-to-person, the cannon combat seems more fun, however.
- No personal/coop PvE only mode available. This is probably the strangest problem. For some reason the developers are hell bent on not having/keeping more players. If the developers wanted  more success, players who want PvP would play in the normal area, and then a completely separate gold/rep/quests etc area/instance would be available for casual players to play at their leisure. No crossover of gold/rep etc. between the two. I see a lot of complaints that this would "split" the player base, but this is false. The people who would play PvE would simply not exist because PvP isn't much fun for them and they would just quit. If they quit they aren't part of the player base anyway. Ergo, having two modes means you get casual players, plus the sweaty PvP people. The only reason I can think of to not split things is if the developers are worried that more sweaty PvPers will quit if they have no noobs to grief than the number of PvE players who will quit. Surely the developers want more people to play??
- Lack of PvE only mode also means the game really misses its potential in terms of RPG/leveling/experience. Because the game is pure PvP, it has to be balanced with zero leveling or upgrades or experience. A PvE side of things would allow a much richer experience where you could upgrade cannons/weapons/ships. This may potentially take up too much developer resource time, so I can partially understand why they wouldn't bother, but it seems like you would bring in a huge amount of players who'd like the coop RPG side of things without sweaty PvPers ruining a chilled out experience.

Ok let's look at some good things, despite the developer's insistence on having fewer players than potential:

- The game environment is beautiful to look at. The engine for the water and weather is great, everything looks really good.
- The sailing experience is quite fun solo on a smaller boat, or with friends on a larger boat. Not too complicated, but you still need to take account of wind direction and such.
- Quests and riddles are basic, but fun.

So the TLDR here is, the game has potential to be great if a PvE mode is added, but is overpriced and essentially unplayable solo. This may be fixed in the future if the developer discovers that more players = potentially more money. Until then, avoid this one.

Last thought: The PvP only mode with no solo play realistically available (current game) is maaaybe worth 50% of the purchase price right now, so if this is ever on sale at least 50% then it may be worthwhile.

Great game, I read a lot of reviews saying that it's not a solo game but I find it a great experience to go at without any friends. Admittedly, the whole thing improves substantially with a couple of crew mates.

This is a very unique game. I wouldn't recommend it for every person, but there are plenty out there that'll enjoy it.
As for myself, i disliked the game at first. I owe that to being so new and just getting frustrated with the mechanics and running in to enemy players that were better than me and slaughter me. However, SoT grew on me and there are way more positives than negatives.
Positives-- Great music, interesting storytelling, beautiful graphics, smooth combat, rewarding, humorous, and there's plenty to do.
Negatives-- Takes time to get used to everything which could lead to frustration, community can be toxic, and could use some QoL updates (like holding more resources while at an Outpost or something of that nature).

TLDR: Great game to get sunk in to, plenty of content, hard to get bored. Can be difficult to get into at first and not the best game for casuals in my opinion.

101 час за ~полтора месяц. Пару минут назад я сдал Легендарным Пиратом, что далеко не предел, ведь мне открылась новая фракция, на которую я должен буду потратить в три раза больше. Но тем не менее считаю, что имею достаточно игрового опыта и наигранных часов для рецензии, так что сейчас я расскажу, почему я потратил на нее больше тысячи рублей и остался доволен:

- Полная свобода действий. Игра не загоняет тебя в рамки. Зайдя в игру ты можешь заняться тем, что тебе по душе. Хочешь лампово посидеть в дискорде с другом попутно выполняя задания фракций? Вперед. Хочешь немного экшена? Ивенты на сервере не дадут тебя заскучать: захват форта скелетов, сражение с Призрачной Флотилией, Флотилией Скелетов, убийство Пепельных лордов (которые сделаны, по моему мнению, очень хорошо: обладают таким количеством разнообразных атак, что схватка с этим боссом не выглядит скучной и монотонной) - эти ивенты идут друг за другом и поучаствовав в одном ты сразу же можешь направляться к другому. Не говоря уже о случайных ивентах, таких как нападение Мегалодрона, Кракена или корабля скелетов, выплывшего из глубин океана прямо на ваших глазах. Ну или ты можешь отходнуть от всей этой суеты, остановившись где-то в укромном месте, чтобы порыбачить. 
- Отсутствие РПГ составляющей и доната, влияющего на игровые механики. Вам может показаться, что раз уж в игре нет прокачки персонажа и корабля, то она скучная и неинтересная. Эта мысль у меня развеялась после того, как я наиграв 10-15 часов со своим другом уже мог спокойно противостоять довольно опытным игрокам, которые в ином случае просто задушили бы нас, будь у них сильнее корабль/больше хп/больше урона и так далее. Мне очень нравится эта игра за то, что видя перед собой корабль, ты беспокоишься только о том, чтобы в бочках было достаточно ядер и досок, чтобы стрелять и чиниться, а не о том, насколько прокачанные там игроки. Сражаясь непосредственно с игроком 1 на 1 у тебя абсолютно равные шансы, ведь оружие нельзя прокачать и сделать его сильнее.
- Нет сейв зон. Для меня это именно плюс. Игра не простит тебе, если ты, заполучив огромную гору лута, довольный и расслабленный пойдешь сдавать его на ближайщий фортпост, ведь там тебя могут ждать другие игроки(или проследив за тобой, подплывут за спиной, пока ты сдаешь свой лут). Хоть и звучит это довольно сложно, но стоит отметить, что на сервере ограничение: максимум 6 корбалей любого типа + большая карта + много фортпостов и встретить на фортпостах другой корабль довольно маловероятно.
- Наверное стоило бы отметить этот пункт как один из первых. Управление кораблем. Оно довольно продуманное и многофункциональное: якорь/штурвал/паруса/гарпун/ветер влияет на скорость. В бою тебе могут отбить мачту и твой корабль будет фактически обездвижен, ведь паруса упадут. Гарпуном ты можешь на скорости стрелять к скале, таким образом изменив свою траекторию. Так же гарпуном можно притягиваться к другим кораблям, притягивать лут с пола и даже людей.
- Мелочи, которые я все объединю в один пункт. В игре есть различные музыкальные инстументы, на которых вы можете наигрывать разные мелодии(в игре их больше 10-ти) как самостоятельно, так и со своим товарищем на разных инструментах. Довольно лампово и может скрасить долгое плавание. Алкоголь. Куда же без него в игре про пиратов? Тут все просто: у тебя есть кружка и бесконечные запасы алкоголя на корабле. Только не пейте перед битвой, эффект опьянения в этой игре довольно неприятный и затрудняет любое действие. Можно стрелять собой из пушек! Вы гонитесь за какой-то командой но никак не можете догнать? Пульните своим корешем и, если повезет, он попадет к ним на корабль и сбросит якорь. Так же есть проктялые ядра, которые дают разные эффекты кораблю в который они попадают. Довольно много разнообразных скинов на корабль. оружие, персонажа. Все из них(кроме донатных) можно купить не напрягаясь.  Вам не нужно донатить и покупать золото ради того, чтобы купить носовую фигуру. Вы спокойно можете заработать на это сами.

В общем, хоть я и описал многое и в голову особо ничего не лезет, но я уверен, что это не все. Попробуйте сами. Возможно напишу еще один обзор, когда достигну 10-го уровня Сокровищ Афины, так что встретимся через пол года +-

[h1]Short review:[/h1]
An immersive pirate sandbox where interacting with other players is dangerous and exciting, scary and hilarious. Sailing the ship with your crew is lots of fun, and progression comes from finding new adventure opportunities and learning new strategies, instead of unlocking skills and gear. Highly recommend playing with friends, and I think playing with voice chat is essential. 

Overall if you enjoy player-led, openworld, gameplay, and the mayhem ships filled with gunpowder can offer, then Sea of Thieves is for you. 

[h1]Longer review:[/h1]
I remember when I started to get tired of mmorpgs. I loved the player interaction and the feeling of exploring worlds, but I found they didn't seem to evolve much over the years. I wished for a new gen mmo that placed a lot more emphasis on adventuring and exploring. I feel like Sea of Thieves is in some ways what I was hoping for. 

There's 2 modes to choose from, Arena and Adventure. Arena is a pretty straight forward PVP mode, where crews of pirates attempt to sink each other for ingame currency. Pretty straight forward. Adventure is the openworld, sandbox aspect to the game, and in my eyes the main attraction.

Adventures start on an Island, with a ship waiting at dock. Players can suggest a quest at a captain's table or just set sail. Quests can be ones designed by the developers (Tall Tales from NPCs, messages in bottles etc), or something you just come up with as a crew. The sense of freedom is impressive. We've often chose to sail to an island we like to look of, and proceeded to get tangled up in all sorts of madness. The game has a way of turning a fetch quest into Homer's Odyssey. 

Most things are totally player driven. You're required to use your compass to tell the direction, hold your lamp up to read things in the dark, gather around the map to make a plan, pay attention to the wind to set the sails accordingly. There's no HUD markers to highlight objectives, in fact HUD in general is pretty minimal. I don't suppose there's much competition, but this has to be the most immersive pirate game ever made. 

I think it's worth pointing out that nearly all of my experiences with this game have been playing with friends over voice chat. There's always a possibility you get matched with some tool that messes with your experience. 

As for major criticisms, I can't find many. I think the login process is a bit tedious, and the fact that you can't chat whilst in a lobby seems a bit silly (although I suspect that is to reduce the likelihood of people dropping out of parties due to toxicity). One criticism that I've heard is the lack of power progression for your character. Sea of thieves only offers tangible progression in the form of cosmetics: outfits, weapon skins, ship decorations etc. For some RPG players I imagine this feels unsatisfying or shallow. But as I said in the short review: progression comes from finding new adventure opportunities and learning new strategies, instead of unlocking skills and gear. It's brave from Rare, but I think it makes for a very unique, fair and immersive experience.

Overall, I'm really enjoying Sea of Thieves. I never thought I'd get to feel like a pirate, but somehow it's happened. Avast! Log in and let me steal your shit!

Was pretty excited to play the game but the lack of indian servers spoilt the experience. Playing 200+ ping every single time literally made the games pvp extremely difficult. Pve and missions were stuil fun but pvp is a integral part of the game so not being able to do that part is a big thumbs down.

**The gameplay is very satisfying -- especially with friends.** Unfortunately this game has a very glaring downside... I completely understand that this game has a cycle that more or less depends on other players/squads coming up to you and pirating your vessel -- it is in the damn name of the game! I've had about 33% of my games ending with this outcome and still finding myself having a blast. Yet this games player base leans itself to the noxious halo kiddies of old who will come up on you while shouting obscenities and homophobic and racial slurs. Some things never change.. Sure, I could turn off my local audio settings, but then I would have missed out on some really special encounters with friendlies that were really fun! It was these toxic few that have ruined the game for me completely after encountering them multiple sessions in a row. If this game ever implements a reporting or blocking system, then I MIGHT consider re-installing. Until then I'm sure you can find some other co-op exploration game that is better worth your time.

Update: 
Still a lot of bugs. I've encountered floating megs, gotten glitched in many trees, swam on land, glitched through the boat, etc. 

The hit reg is still pretty terrible despite some reworking and you have to get used to the fighting style in this game. I come from CS:GO and there's no advanced movement in SOT  like strafing etc. I haven't noticed much inaccuracy while moving as well. Most people I've seen in this game just jump around with blunders like maniacs. The guns are also really easy to learn how to use which is a plus for casual players. 

However, there really isn't much to do in the game. Without friends, the game gets boring quickly. There is no real progression in this game; once you hit Pirate Legend, you just end up doing the same old voyages over and over again. 

The game is also targeted towards casual players in my opinion, but some of the voyages like thieves haven runs can take a while. If you don't have much time to play, I wouldn't buy this game.

TLDR:
First off, it's a really easy chill game as far as controls go and understanding the game. So it's a nice game to play with casual and competitive friends alike. This review covers all the details that you won't typically see in game-play videos of the game. It's not a perfect game, and if you are solo or with a partner is SUPER easy to get pooped on by a group or an Alliance that REALLY wants to sink your ship. There are many who will follow you for quite awhile. All-in-all, It's a fun game with dedicated friends who can sit down and play it for longer than a couple of hours at a time..


*Deeply Impacting Negatives*

1) Need committed friends to play with you "just to make the game playable!" Without that, and you will be hit with so much time lost and wasted effort. 

2) The Cross platform play makes communication with randoms impossible. 

3) You are unable to quickly and efficiently send friend requests to console players "just so you can communicate with them."

4) The glitches and lag turn high difficulty situations (when involving enemy players, which is often) into near impossible situations to get out of.
Example 1: Lag makes players unkillable.
Example 2: Be sailing while being chased by other players and "POOF" you can no longer see wind streams to help you get away from your pursuers.
Example 3: The Faster connection will always win. i.e. blunderbuss, sword strikes, and ranged attacks.

5) SERVER TRANSFERS mid game "Constantly":
- This will royally bone you so bad. 
Ex: Imagine sailing for almost "2 hours" constantly against the wind, resulting in even slower speeds, FINALLY find a clear Sea Post to turn in and sell all your loot from adventuring, and right as your docking... "BAM" a 4 man Team/ship spawns in RIGHT NEXT TO YOU... but it's okay, you manage to turn your ship away just fast enough to start to get away- only to have a Kraken show up, LOCK YOU IN PLACE!!! Thus allowing that 4 player team, who just spawned, enough time to swim out to you, Spawn kill you over and over because you constantly spawn in the SAME PLACE on your ship- and them reaping the rewards of YOUR 6 hours in total (which includes constantly traveling around to find a safe place to offload your loot.
((NOTE: This little scenario, just happened to me 30 minutes ago, which is enough to push me over the fence to finally write a review for this game.))

6) Impossible to report people in game, almost as if to facilitate conduct that in other games is a bannable offense. i.e. horrific verbal outburst, speech, insults, racial slurs, team killing, team sabotaging of the ship or dropping your loot off the boat, or even swimming your loot out to enemy players.
7) PVP Area, Sloop Arena is pretty good if you don't have #6 of these negatives on your team. However, Galleon Arena is unplayable unless you have your own 4 man team of friends. You pretty much win at that point in Galleon automatically, you just have to go through the motions of getting some chests and turning them in during the match. The reason for this is the majority if not ALL of the other teams will be down a player, or even down "2 players" (making them absolute fodder and fun targets for your team to shoot. In the even there are other teams of 4, fear not, they will almost always have a player or two on their team that is addicted to playing music and not at all helping, or they LOVE to just drop your anchor constantly freezing you in-place to get shredded up by the enemy teams, or they like to shoot the harpoon gun at anything they can to make you turn off course to constantly miss your shots or get you to where you can go to actually get some points.

8) 90% of the clothing and character aesthetics from color/shading to the style of them, looks like an 8 year old thought them up. I don't have a nice short and concise way to put this, sorry devs.

Lastly, it's a game that is done with so much love and hard work that it's truly sad to see it wasted because of those impacting negatives.



*Positives* 

(only if you have "Committed Friends" to play this with, because there are no, "hey lets sit down for an hour- maybe 2 to play some sea of thieves..." No-no! This is a game that you have to be prepared to sit down for AT LEAST 2 to 3 hours to play, "IF" you REALLY want to turn in that loot!
((NOTE: There are too many positives if you have committed friends to play this with. It's a game that you can truly have a blast in. You just have to always keep the frame of mind that it's a game, and not your precious time being taken from you because of something beyond your control or cautious measures you take to ensure success.))

1) Breath taking world to sail around in from water physics, to how far you can see things all the way to beauty of the world itself. The Sounds are so perfect from ambiance to sound effects of every little thing... and the music, SPOT ON! The warning system with ALL the different types of music is insanely good.

2) SO MUCH content. UPDATED MONTHLY to boot.

3) Incredible replay value with endless hours of doing something you haven't done before in game.

4) Awesome lore.

5) SO, many things to do, many, MANY different types of NPC encounters.
ShadowLegion reaps what you sow!!

This is a review of Sea of Thieves. Here I will list the pros and cons of this game.

Good things about it:
Very interesting story.
Good music.
Insanely good optimization.
The sea and waves are beautiful.
Very cool quests and a lot of content.
Frequent updates.


Bad things about the game:
Not very beginner friendly in terms of PVP.
Can get annoying when you are constantly killed.
A bit overpriced.


Overall, this is a very good game and I would rate it 9/10. The beginning is a bit slow, but once you know what you are doing and have progressed a bit it's very fun, though it's much better to play with friends than with random people.

Graphics are beautiful at times
PVP can be fun at times, when the person doesn't run (they basically always will though)
Music is amazing!
Very fun with groups of friends

*Cons* - 

One of the least polished games I've ever played. Every single time you play you'll encounter an extremely annoying glitch that has a chance to ruin your gameplay. (Didn't expect it to be this glitchy considering it has a $40 price tag.. This game isn't finished whatsoever.)

Mermaids.... That's all I need to say. They never work, they're complete rng, half the time they swim away as soon as you get to them *if they even spawn*  and there have been MANY times when my boat is still up but I respawn on a random nearby island instead of my ship..

If you want pvp this community is not for you.. The learning process of the pvp is amazing and the more skilled player will almost always win, but that's if people actually fight. Players run 90% of the time and if they do fight, they usually try to guilt you into going away instead of truly fighting back.

Crossplay mixed with bad servers causes people to teleport a lot. I'm on the East Coast of America and I get servers with Chinese players that are stacking 3 galleons and teleporting around as they run.

*Glitches that I've encountered that haven't been fixed in at least 5 patches* - 

When jumping into water you have a chance for your audio to glitch and BLAST your headphones with bass that's so loud it's painful.

Worst hit registration I've ever seen in any game.. By far. You'll see a hitmarker but it does no damage to the player, or you won't see a hitmarker at all and they'll die. It makes no sense and I don't see how this hasn't been fixed since it kills MANY pvp fights.

Swords can literally hit you through walls at times. If someone is below deck and they swing at the roof it can hit a person above. 

Blackscreens when they make no sense. There's a mechanic that sends back to your ship if you get stuck in a place that you can't get out of, but I've had this happen while casually running on an island. If you're trying to be sneaky stay away from rocks because instead of making them so you can actually walk on them, they just made it so you sink in between them and blackscreen back to your ship..

Every single play session you will most likely run into a glitch, especially if you do any pvp... If you only PVE these will only be minor inconveniences (most of the time)

*Summary* - 

This game has so much potential and I LOVE the general idea. They just need to stop putting out updates before actually fixing their glitches. Every patch has been filled with more and more glitches and it's starting to kill the fun. I love active developers, but hate when they say they've fixed something in 2 different patch notes as it actually ends up getting worse.

My new favorite game. 
Graphics: the water is the most beautiful I've ever seen in any video game. The textures are a little cartoonish at first but you understand the necessity for that soon enough and it all merges and blends in together stylistically. And when it's night time and the sky is cloudless? Look up. This game is beautiful. 
Gameplay: It can be a tad frustrating getting attacked by another more skilled player for the first time, but at the end of the day you have to remind yourself that the game is literally called "Sea of THIEVES".  Learn the tricks of the trade, and in no time you'll be a Pirate Legend (or a happy-go-lucky gold hunter, like me :D). 
Updates: the dev team (Rare [yeah, THAT Rare]) releases updates to the game on a fairly regular interval, keeping the game fresh and exciting for veteran players while giving new players that much more to explore. The Ashen update that came out recently added some tough new enemies and items that make me wonder what they're gonna roll out next. 

Important to note: I was not aware of the difficulty of playing this game single player. Not to say that it can't be done, mind you; I've often set out solo into the wild blue yonder and returned with arms bursting with booty (alongside some cuts and burns, admittedly). I do confess the game is significantly more fun with at least one other on your ship, so invite your friends! 

10/10 game, though. It gives me the freedom I crave in an accessible and beautiful medium rife with adventure, discovery, and a satisfaction to that wanderlust inherent in the bosom of any who's caught even the subtlest whiff of sea spray.

Really fun pirate game with friends, playing solo is challenging. The game is  focused on teamwork so make sure you've got good friends with you to play. The best part for me about Sea of Thieves is that a higher level does not give you an unfair advantage to other low level players since most of the items in game are purely cosmetic.

This is one of the most open and fun games I have ever played. I have played since day one and recently purchased the game for a second time to play in the Steam ecosystem. Not only did I not mind having to pay again, I was happy to be able to support the developers. 

Sea of Thieves gives you a truly level playing field sandbox where you can live out your pirate dreams and dump countless hours into what is essentially a bottomless pit of game play that is always changing. 

The constant and quality content updates stand out as some of the best in the business and you can just tell that the developers are having fun and love the IP just as much as the community does.

Pros:  

1. It can be pretty. The sea is done well.
2. If you like to gank people this is your game.

Cons:

1. The character creator is a lazy gimmick. Its an exercise in ugly. 
2. They sell you real cash potions because they know you will hate the character you create, rather than fixing (1)
3. 16 players a map. Its basically a tiny multiplayer game where you end up hoping you dont meet other players when you solo and hoping you do when you have a group.. but totally random if you do.
4. No customization other than cosmetics. No skill  trees or character growth or any kind of RP functions. You are like everyone else - which should be good for balance but....
5. Experienced groups can just grief you as a new player. Nowhere is safe. It's a gankfest of the worst kind.
6. There is no end game. There's no point. Everything is the same. In the end you just play for useless cosmetics. 
7. It is really samey. All the islands are the same. Same monsters. Same pigs and chickens. No variation whatsoever. It reminds me of a game called Worlds Adrift: same lazy-ass approach to the game world where nothing stands out as unique. Its all cartoony skeletons and stuff. 

This game is a very superficial ripoff of archeage sea battles. Someone in Rare played that and thought "hey lets cut out all the interesting stuff like character building and just make a treasure hunting gank-fest". 

Untlimately it got very boring. When I played solo I was ganked. When I played with a few people I ganked. ^shrug^ After a day or 2 playing i struggle to find any motivation to continue. You see the whole game in the first 2 hours.

Currently my favorite game. If you have a couple of friends this game is an absolute blast but could still be enjoyed solo. There is a always action and its not always combat. Managing your ship in tough conditions and dealing with the many random events always keep you busy. You never know what to expect when you sail the seas. There is nothing more satisfying than cashing out all of your loot after the end of long voyage. Combat is not too diverse but is still really fun I'm not sure what else they could add to it and ship combat is a little weird to get used to but still fun. The emissaries are all diverse and let you play the game slightly differently and with a few updates you're not stuck grinding a emissary you don't enjoy. Sadly the money you make is only for cosmetics but that doesn't matter to me. The point of the game is the journey and the stories behind what got you the gold to get those outfits and ship parts.
