If adventure be what ye seek then look no further than Sea of Thieves.

Ye can set sail pleasantly alone or with friends, the quests and plunder ye find along the way be fun and ever changin' like the sea herself. 

Full of mystery and intrigue I've found myself quickly enamoured, but watch out for other pirates! I've found just as many to be pesky as friendly. 

With no gear to speak of the high seas are a level playing field, meaning the soul of adventure be what calls you back to the swell, a refreshing change of pace! no more grindin' for coin just to experience something locked behind a paywall! ye can play and earn yer cosmetics at yer own leisure.

If it be something that concerns ye, you'll be happy to know that yer pirate can be whoever ye like and wear whatever they like! man or woman, yer identities are safe here, we're all pirates and mateys on these here islands. 

If ye be lookin' for an escape from yer grind fests and yer season passes, climb aboard, raise anchor, lower yer main sails and set forth! 
We'll be waitin' for ya, grog in hand.

First thing i must admit about this game. Its beautiful has some very solid cartoon look to it. One of the best looking games. But other then that its very boring. The game doesn't really explain much to you. There is a short tutorial that introduces you very quickly. You learn about the items and tools how to setup a voyage which is a quest mission. Once your done with that you go into one of the games many random trade islands. This game is water world meets Zelda Wind Waker feel to it. So you start in this island and every island is different you look around for the 3 trade factions, one is delivering or trade goods, the other is a treasure hunter looking for chest. Then the third is a skeleton bounty collecting skulls.. You have to gain reputation with these factions and move up. There is also like a main adventure voyage guy who is in the inn and he starts this epic voyage line that is actually pretty tough and i thought was the most fun. You must play with friends or a group playing by yourself is boring and tedious because you have to run the ship yourself. The ships are not very complicated they have mechanics to them like dropping raising anchor sails, loading cannons repairing damage etc what you would expect from a pirate game. The game is full PVP once you start the voyages and collect loot, anyone else who comes across you if they choose can attack and steal your stuff. Sea of thieves. One thing i noticed is everything is cosmetic you always have the same items weapons but only make them different buying different looks. There are no stats in this game. I just can't recommend this game. Unless it goes on sale or something then give it a try.

I want to like Sea of Thieves, i really really do.  The graphics and most of the game play are really fun, particularly some of the riddles you need to solve to dig up treasure. I also really enjoy the randomly roaming NPC skeleton ships.  However I can't bring myself to keep this game installed. First off let me state that I appreciate that some people really enjoy PVP, and power to them! I fully encourage people who enjoy competing with other players to do so. Heck I even partake from time to time.  However I HATE open pvp with a passion the burns like a sun and it sucks all the fun out of a game for me especially when I'm in the middle of solving the aforementioned riddles and my ship is robbed and sunk. Every. Single. Time. It is 100% not fun for me.  If your into that I encourage you to get SoT as it is a very well made game but with no options for me to disable that aspect of the game it is a waste of time and effort for me to play it.

I want to start this review off by saying I have severe thalassophobia, so I play 99% of this game above water unless I'm forced off the boat to go to shore or am unfortunately knocked off by some very notable monsters.
As someone who screams and turns the game off the moment I'm knocked too far away from my boat, I 100% recommend this game to anyone who's interested in a pirate's adventure!

Graphics:
Just... look at the trailer. That trailer is accurate to what it looks like in game: it has that beautiful Rare style to it with a nice blend of realism when looking at the ocean. The light effects, the fog, the different types of oceans... 
There's very few things in this game that look off-putting or wrong, and usually it's just your pirate's face.

Sound Design:
Yes. Yes. Yes.
Do you love the sound of creaking wood? Water? Gun clicking? Sword swinging? How about when the music picks up because a kraken just spawned underneath your boat for the SECOND time in a single day? Then you'll love the ambiance in here!
Also, the cats purr directly in your ear. Highly recommend for anyone who loves cats!

Gameplay: 
Depending on your hardware and how high you have the graphics cranked up, the game can lag for you. If you tweak them, everything should RELATIVELY run smooth like butter.
Some people complain about the sword swinging: "Why is it only 3 times?" That's because of PVP my fellow plunderers! Everyone in the game can be killed in about 3 sword swings, AKA one solid combo on an unsuspecting pirate. With how health is managed and how respawn works (15 seconds in timeout before you're allowed to respawn back on your ship), this is purely for balancing the game and works quite well once you've played enough to realize the design nuances. Ocean fights with other players can be VERY intense because of this, so try to focus on sinking their ship as fast as possible!
Digging treasure out with your shovel is possibly one of the most satisfying things I've gotten to do, and fishing and cooking food is more entertaining in this game compared to others.
Sailing your ship is where you can tell most of the care went to though, even if the instruments and lantern and opening and closing your pocket watch is fun. The controls for each ship vary depending on how big it is, just like in real life: it's considerably easier to pilot a sloop than it is a galleon, but with enough practice, you'll get a feel for how each one sails in no time.

Everything is highly accurate in this game in terms of aiming, no janky hitboxes here! I main a sniper rifle and frequently practice my sharpshooting from the crow's nest if I'm not the captain for the day, and I can confirm that if you're in bullet distance, you CAN hit things as long as you aim and account for bullet travel, disruption from waves, enemy movement, etc. 

General Enjoyment:
Despite being a big chicken with my ass firmly planted on the boat, I REALLY enjoy this game! I'm hoping it'll eventually help calm my phobia of the ocean and the monsters in it over time. So far, I can't bring myself to even jump into the water to help my crew loot shipwrecks, but this has forced me to know how to pilot each and every boat perfectly.
I can't jump in the water? That's okay! I'll just gently ease the boat in place and just harpoon everything up myself.

So far, other players have tended to heed my warnings and I've only encountered 3-4 hostile ships. My friends (one of which is a high-ranking PVPer) warned me that people disable VC in this game and to not trust others, but most of the time when I pull my megaphone out, I get positive responses and people adjust their course, realizing we don't want to sink their ship for no reason.
I have yet to fully turn to the "kill on sight" mentality my friends possess and seek peaceful resolutions first... but if someone ignores my verbal and written warnings, then I'll happily participate in a brawl.

While there are lots of things I like about the game, I will just mention the cons since this is a somewhat negative review and I can't see myself continuing to play it any time soon.
[i]If none of the whining below strikes you as a problem, you might have just found a new favourite game.[/i]

[b]Purely from a solo adventuring standpoint, this game sucks[/b] if you want to play at your own leisure.
Also, roaming for random goodies (decent profit sometimes) or sidequests (abysmal money to begin with) feels like a waste of time when you realise [b]all the gold you make essentially gets you nothing but cosmetics which have no functional improvement whatsoever[/b].

While it is reasonably easy to escape bigger ships with 3+ players in it if you don't let them get too close, escaping is pointless when your quest target is an island in their "hunting grounds" since you either have to go back and get targeted yet again or lobby and rejoin the game to start again while hoping the quest target won't be near jerks this time.

That said, [b]the game is filled with jerks[/b]... Absolutely FILLED TO THE BRIM!!
I haven't had a single reasonable experience with another player in this game. To the point that if you die, you literally HAVE to scuttle your ship or they camp and repeat kill you which doesn't even give them any benefit.
As such, the emote system is useless, the alliance system is a sham, the open crew option is useless, etc...
[i]I know the game is literally about pirates and thieving, but there is a difference between taking everything someone has (which is usually next to nothing to begin with for a solo player just starting out) and completely forcing them to capsize their own ship and respawn across the map.[/i]


The straw that breaks the camels back for me is that [b]everything you've accumulated in your ship is trashed when you logout[/b].
All those storage containers filled with food, cannonballs, wood, etc... Gone...
Why pick them up in the first place? The ship's existing containers can hold more than you could ever hope to use to begin with and even they get emptied back to the starting amount.
The additional containers remain if your ship is sunk, you say? So what?! They've either been looted by the time you get back, are being used as bait by the crew that killed you or are so far away from your respawn point that you might as well loot the random barrels at your spawn point and move on.

The only things that permanently follow you are the cosmetics you buy but they don't provide any functional benefits so what is the point of anything in this game?
There is no real progress other than faction reputation which, in the end, only gives you more opportunities to gain gold and buy more useless cosmetics...

All in all, the aim of the game is to look pretty and barely have a fighting chance unless you can force your friends to buy a game they can only ever really play when you also have the time to play. (Definitely would not recommend this unless bought in bulk to play with a team)

Awesome pirate game with stunning visuals. There be no greater joy than trading cannonballs on the high seas and emerging victorious. You scurry to pick up the enemy players' loot and race to the nearest outpost to turn treasure into cash before another pirate can come claim your hard earned haul. There arrr some elements that are not enjoyable, like players camping you and sinking your ship over and over when playing solo, but other than that this is well worth the money.

Personally, everytime I get on with friends, we have a great time fighting and doing all kinds of things in the game. We goof, we play shanties, we raid, we loot, and just have a jolly time but it just seems to me that once a fight starts you run into a megalodon, sometimes a kraken, or a skeleton ship will join. We've come a long way in terms of alliances but its such a pain spending hours only to lose everything after destroying 9 skeleton ships, sometimes like 20 fireheart ships only to run into a player and a megaldon at the same time. There is no peace once you choose to be even remotely aggressive, chances are you won't make it with your 100k worth of loot from emissary looting, theres not satisfaction for that hard work.

____________________

The PROS. The visual of the water and the experience of the actual sailing is very well done. The water looks great, the feel of the ship riding over the shifting waves and through storms and all is very well done. The main graphics are cartoonish and a lot like Team Fortress (concerning character models and textures.). But as far as the water and the feel of sailing, it's very well done.

The ship-to-ship combat is a lot of fun. It's pretty simple, but it's an addicting experience to unload your cannons into the hull of another ship, or to screw them up with the ridiculous specialty cannon-balls that you can find and use.

There are some cool things in the game which make it interesting for a while. The fishing (which could be implemented better), using rowboats, trying to find different rare treasures to sell for a decent value. 

____________________

The CONS

The melee and gun combat is horrendous. The sword-fighting especially. It's very clunky, and feels more primitive and worse than the old Daggerfall game.. Unfortunately, there are a handful of very vocal and subjective fans to the game that instead of trying to better the game, act as purists and treat the game like the Holy Grail it isn't, and pretend it doesn't need to be improved upon. 

There isn't nearly enough variety in the weapons, or the fighting. You get four weapons to choose from (But you can only carry two at a time.) The Sword, Pistol, Sniper, and the Blunderbuss (shotgun). And each are quite underwhelming, especially the cumbersome sword.

This is more an opinion but one that is highly shared. The lack of any improvements to anything in the game. You can't purchase better cannons, better equipment, better weapons. Nothing. No matter how many hours you put into the game, you will never gain anything from it besides the purely cosmetic features for your ship, and your character - and different titles. The small group of subjective loyalists will scream like banshees that this is the purpose of the game. To keep "everyone on a level playing field". Which is fine as a concept, sure. But ultimately, it provides no incentive and it relishes in a boring long-term experience.

The biggest issue with the game, is its portrayal of itself as a full-fledged gaming experience. But after you put some time into it, you realize it's more a sandbox demo experience. It still feels like it is in early-access. It leaves you just wanting more. It delivers a salivating little experience which is all far too short and too shallow, and just leaves you wishing it were a better game with more depth.

Is the game worth it? Sure! If you can get it for free, or for a very cheap price. But the game definitely isn't worth any full price. I'd top it off at a $15 value at best.

It seems to be a fun concept, however, it didn't gave me a good first impression.
When you launch the game for the first time, it wants you to log in with Xbox Live, which is you know, unusual, but why not i guess.

I connected my accounts, picked my character, and started playing. The game was locked at 30 fps stable which i spend 15 minutes on fixing it - it was so confusing i dont even remember how i did it at this point -. I didn't also had a proper tutorial, just some texts that tell me which button does what, but thats it. 
Needless to say, usage of buttons were also bad, you had to press a button to climb stairs, etc. It could be a simple thing for new players but after playing lots of games unlike that, it was a challange to me.
Gravity seems to be broken. I instantly fell down and glitched out in a few situations without understanding whats going on. Animations didn't also impressed me all, they look like they are made by a 12 year old.

But other than that, graphics look cute, and i liked the particle effects, I think it could be more optimized though.
Doesn't worth the money, not sure if i'll play this again, maybe with friends.

Edit: I tried to play with one of my friends, and Xbox Live wasnt really helping us at this point. It felt like they made it confusing so users would spend too much time on it to decrease refund rates.. 

TL&DR: Everything is just too confusing. The UI, The game itself, the mechanics, etc. It's clearly not beginner friendly. Didn't give me a good first impression, not recommended.

Still just earning my sea legs, but here's a review of my experience so far.

Hours simply sail by. The tutorial is an incredible safe environment for you to learn the mechanics. From handling all the different pulleys on your boat, to how to sail a ship, how to hunt for treasure and all the good stuff. (If you are thorough, you can even leave the tutorial area w enough gold and doubloons to immediately get yourself a nice piraty look.)

Once you finally reach the Sea of Thieves you are treated to gorgeous environments, a neat small port where you quickly get acquainted with the different factions and shops, and from where you can start sailing.

I haven't had any PvP yet, so I'll focus on the PvE. Cannons feel great to fire. The sound, the way they move, having to lead your shots, everything adds to it. The sloop is extremely easy to solo sail, so you'll get a good feeling for what you have to do. Guns are incredibly powerful, but the ammo is limited, which is a good way to keep things balanced. Melee is simplistic. Some polish wouldn't hurt, as sometimes it's hard to proper block and counter, but it's something you can get used to, nonetheless.

Visually speaking, the game is stunning. Be it at the break of dawn, or the dark of night, the sea looks incredible, the sky reminds you of how small you are, and the tropical feel of the islands around you make you feel like you're back in the Caribbean. The audio is also quite immersive, helping you forget about the world around you as you sail the waves and run around the deck.

Navigating is pretty fun. Using the map for the quests, locating your destination and then setting sail there feels excellent. It can be tricky to find the right island in the cabin's map, but once you do there's a tingling feeling of wander and you just want to set sail.

Overall, if you want a game you can zone out to, if you want to explore gorgeous islands for booty, or even just take your sloop to high sea, salvage wreckage and fish for a while, this is the game for you.
You might not enjoy it if you're looking for a story-driven game, then you might want to look at Tempest or something like it, but I strongly recommend this game if you just want to enjoy a great experience.

Similar game mechanics to Fortnite, which leads me to believe that Fortnite stole from this game. I mean, look at it closely, the building, the healing mechanics, the concept of guns. Sea of Thieves invented these ideas and concepts and upon further inspection, it appears that Fortnite stole them. When in human history did guns become an idea and gain widespread use? March 20th, 2018. The exact date Sea of Thieves was released. The date is a well known and documented fact, but the instigator? Never once was the name "Sea of Thieves" uttered. People MUST know that Sea of Thieves invented guns, building and most importantly, food. Food is absolutely essential to human survival and without Sea of Thieves, we're as good as dead. I think this game deserves a SOLID 11/10 for not only its gameplay, but also the lives it has saved and the ideas it has introduced to the human species.

This game is very pretty and for whatever reason it's really enjoyable to sail around on a boat in the ocean, something i would hate to do irl. It's great to play with friends but playing solo is viable as well with a smaller ship. If it weren't for the PvP i wouldn't enjoy this game nearly as much, but it's cool that you can fire cannons at other players and sink them and take all their loot. It has a bit of a learning curve for some because a majority of the game is spent on the sea and not everyone is used to piloting a boat. 

The stuff you collect each time you play is lost after the session like cannon balls and food and wood, but when you sell the valuables to the traders you keep all the gold and get a fresh ship each time. The size of ship to choose depends on the number of people you are playing with. You can play with 1-2, 2-3, or 3-4 players and playing solo is not necessarily a disadvantage if you know what you are doing. I haven't really played a game like this before and i enjoy it. You can really lose track of time just sailing around to different islands and braving storms.

On my last adventure i was greeted by other players at an outpost with cannon balls, so i reciprocated and then managed to escape. Unfortunately in doing so i had ventured out to the location of a big chompy boi who did not hesitate to circle my ship and then take a couple bites. The second time knocked me off the ship which zoomed away and left me in the ocean. Big chompy boi seemed to have left but to smaller chompy bois had arrived for lunch.

You will get hit by lightning, and you will catch fire. Get to know your bucket well, because you'll need to scoop a lot of water, but also might want something to puke in so you can toss it on your friends. Have your wood in hand when holes appear from penetration.

Bring a friend if you're looking at this game.

Open World pirate goodness.  All the adventure and exploring you can ask for as a pirate enthusiast.  Definitely recommended but make sure you have a good graphics card.


(3 months of play so far):  I'm really liking this format for a pirate game so far.  Open world and lots of choice each time you play of what kind of adventure you want to play that day: could be a grand Tall Tale, a couple quests for various factions, hunt and loot other pirates, explore, or just casual fishing and scavenging... the choice yours.  And I like that idea a lot; especially because pirating is supposed to be about freedom and this game gives that freedom while having a very intriguing and interesting ever-evolving storyline / lore.


Lots of fun once you get into it.  Watching others on YouTube and Twitch helps a lot if you're new (or need tips).  Good way to learn; and it's really interesting how no one can 'buy their way' to more power in the game ..... you actually have to get better at the skills in the game .... what a concept!  It's about time we have a game like this.  Quickly becoming my favorite.
Is good stuff.
awesome game

I've only played 20 hours so far, but this game has got me craving to play more. 

Graphics: Absolutely gorgeous. 

Design: The only thing I that about the game is that the avatars are FUGLY. But you don't ever "see" your avatar so I forgot about it after a while. (and plus it is probably more realistic lol). Other than that, the rest of the game is downright wonderfully designed. If I explain too much it will take away from the game so I will just leave that there.

Social: This is pretty good. You can play by yourself or with other people (but its REALLY hard to play solo).  They have an in-game chat (both voice and text). You can also fight other people, but I'm the kind of person to run away. lol.

Game-play: When you play for the first time you are going to be confused out of your mind so follow every tutorial and REMEMBER them. HOWEVER, this is actually an allure of the game. You get to experience what it is really like to be a pirate. 

Mechanics: The mechanics of ship sailing is awesome. I feel like I learned a thing or two.

Price: To me its worth the $40 bucks. You can get infinite game play out of this one! DO IT. Join us. ARGGGG Matey. <3

This game is the top of the line, make your own adventure type game! I was a participant of the Closed Beta and it is amazing to see how far Sea of Thieves has progressed. 

I have been asked by some friends, "what do you even do in Sea of Thieves?" The answer is really, its up to you! When the game first released, there was:
-Gold Hoarders (Go out and find buried treasure by solving riddles and looking at maps)
-Order of Souls (Go out and fight skeletons)
-Merchants Alliance (Go and collect materials or animals to sell)

But now, they have added soooo much more:
-Skull forts (take on wave after wave of skelletons to try to take their loot)
-The Kraken and the Megaladon (frightening random encounters, which happen more often than you might want when cargoing loot)
-Skelleton ships (a worthy aponant from the depths of the seas)
-Ghost ships (equally as menacing)
-A battle royal mode to get you into some action quickly!
-The ability to team up with other ships using "Alliance Flags"
-The ability to stack/upgrade your gold intake by hoysting an "Emissary Flag" giving you a boost of one company for how much you work for them.

And that is all the stuff that you choose to do on your own, not to mention the "Tall Tales" which are basically like the games story mode, with some sweet items to get if you complete all the achievements!

Now, note before you buy:
-I have bought both the Windows 10 store version, and the steam version. For some reason, I have better quality gameplay on the Steam version. Faster frame-rate, better connectivity, less issues connecting to friends.

A couple things I wish were changed/added (If the Devs See this)
1. It would be amazing if you could change the type of ship you have from the outposts. If a new friend comes in, instead of having to re-start the crew, we should be able to change from a sloop to a brigantine or galleon in the game.
2. It would be awesome if we could hire/buy AI skeletons to run the ship like the ghost ship, especially on a Galleon, 4 people almost never feels like enough.
3. Kind of on the same note, it would be amazing if we could change how many people could be on a ship, even if that means seperate servers for "Double Crew", and have 4 people on a sloop, 6 on a Brig, and 8 on a galleon. I know I have more than a few friends who want to be on the same crew.
4. OR, if we cannot have that many on one ship, it would be amazing if MULTIPLE crews could join the same server easily. So, two brigs of friends could spawn in, make an alliance using the alliance flag, and then sail away with eachother.

I hope that the Devs see this, and for the players reading, I will see you on the Sea of Thieves!

Let me describe this game for you;
Three new trashy sailors buy their way into sailing their first voyage, and with excitement and minimal preparation they set of. as the captain looks upon the treasure map, he realises it is glowing with embers. he warns his fellow crewmates, but none of them becomes scared of the luring danger. the treasure is said to be great, and a great treasure is only alluring.
as the sails are set and the wind hits them, they fare of with great speed, towards the island described to them with nothing but a picture.
the first island was a piece of cake, so they venture forth to the 2nd island with courage and self-confidence. as they near this omnious island, they hit a thick fog - within seconds the ship hits shore and rams straight into a volcano, 2 fly of screaming, as the ship roars and crashes into this volcano, and the captains frantic efforts seems to no avail, as he is now left alone with 7 holes and water flowing into the ship. the ship gets fixed, and they nervously venture forward. 10 seconds later, another volcano erupts into flames and giant rocks of lava hurls down upon the ship, breaking the mast and setting everything on fire, while the ship sinks faster than you can think - the crewmates frantically screams and tries to fix the ship, while these gigantic balls of fire rains down upon them.
Jesus fucking christ - this game is amazing, so atmospheric and so god damn good.

Sea of Thieves provides some really intense moments.  You can go through long periods of relative easy exploration and looting... mostly PVE fun.  This provides you with a lot of loot to put on your ship.  However, you have to make it back to an Outpost to sell most of this loot.  This is when the pirates come for you.  Do you fight them off?  Or try to outrun them and make it back to the Outpost and sell?

You can also go the more PVP style where you strictly attack other pirates for their loot.  One of the more popular activities is hiding on another players ship (tucking) and relaying their position to your mates so you can plan to steal all their hard earned loot.

If none of that sounds fun, then perhaps the fishing might grab your interest.  All in all, I have been having a lot of fun with this game.  I wish that they had a better match making system and perhaps a PVE server as an option.  I can see myself sailing many more hours on the Sea of Thieves!

if the griefing were to be stopped somehow, this game is a solid 10/10 from me. otherwise. the risk of griefers makes it a 2.

They nailed the sailing and the sea mechanics. I've never seen a game that renders water so well in different weather and conditions. Ships sail with believable physics and they are fun to operate, from the wheel and sails to the cannons and ship-on-ship combat. 
The sound design is brilliant, with contextual music and great sound effects. Overall the atmosphere of sailing the ocean is unlike anything you've played in another game, and is enough to recommend Sea of Thieves.
There are a few things that could be improved. Melee combat, which feels a bit floaty and disconnected. More enemies, island styles and themes would also be interesting. The megalodon and kraken are so intimidating and interesting, it would be nice to see more sea leviathan style enemies and dangers in the ocean. 
Overall SoT is a very original and innovative game and it deserves credit for that. As long as they keep adding content it should be well worth your money and time.

The core gameplay loop is great, fantastic even. The combat feels weighty and scavenging for supplies to boost your performance in a fight is a fun little mini-game to play alongside the core pirate swords and sails gameplay. However, until they fix these two critical issues this game is a waste of your money and your time.

1. No progression. There is literally no progression in the game. Every gameplay element is either unlocked from the start or available to find in the world. The only thing gold is good for is buying cosmetic items. Can't purchase supplies, can't unlock upgrades, just cosmetics. Other than the gameplay itself there is literally no point to play and no point to even care about the loot.

2. Respawning. Currently, if your ship is sunk you and your crew will respawn a short distance away with the bare essentials by way of supplies. I played four hours today and two of them were spent fighting another ship that we had defeated fairly the first time... and then again, and then again, and then again, because they would keep rushing back to fight. And a barebones ship is still a threat, make no mistake. You have to stop and address them. We didn't even get the loot because they'd managed to suicide bomb our ship with a powder keg they'd found, which caused us to dump the loot in the water, thus queuing a mutual zerg rush to lose ship after ship on the beach next to the loot repeatedly.

The devs don't and won't read this, but until they implement this single simple fix this game is practically unplayable:
Sunk ships respawn on a new server. Simple fix that prevents the zerg rush, and while it won't make the loot worth a gnat's fart it at least will stop fighting over loot from being a soul-crushing, frustrating, tedious slog.

A quite challenging pirate adventure simulator with unique graphic, many kinds of treasures and secrets and amazing mysterious fantasy stories, in it's vast and very beautiful world. You can decorate your ships and there are many type cosmetics for your character and outfits. Learn how to sail a ship similar to real life but simplified. Go anywhere you want in the Sea of Thieves alone or with your crew (friends), find treasures on islands, find secrets in the depth of the ocean, be a fisherman who plays music, get fames and reputation in every towns, but also be aware there are exciting dangers out there from skeleton, ghost ships, big big shark, and huge kraken, and don't forget other pirates (players) may hunt you to get your precious treasures. This game might give you the best beatiful and challenging pirate life fantasy experience you ever want.
Very good

Sea of Thieves is a really fun game and is quite enjoyable. I do recommend playing it with friends as it not only gets easier to manage everything but also becomes a lot more fun. 

In Sea of Thieves you cannot play offline and grind for fun you automatically play online on servers with other players. With my experience and how I encountered the game the more players you have the more players there will be on the server (that was my experience and how my friends and I encountered it). Playing alone puts you on a tiny ship where another player can be. When you are on a 3 man the boat gets bigger and harder to manage I do not know whether it changes again with 4 people I played in a 3 man group. The 2 man boat is the easiest to not just control but also to manage but it isn't as fast as the 3 man ship.

It has a fairly nice grinding mechanic to it. You find an island, plunder the stuff that is there (if you don't have a mission) and leave. If you have missions you find the island you are suppose to go to and do either solve the riddle or dig up the treasure from the treasure map that you will receive.

The game do have events which are showed in the sky (you'll know what I mean when you see it) which all players can see and go to.

The game can have people that try and just kill you and your boat which is a bit annoying but it is to be expected when the game is literally just "plunder all you can". If you go into the game and play it when you see another ship you can expect it to either see you and go for you or not see you and just go away. There is some players that will ally up for some time so they can complete what they have and then just sail off.

Overall the game is really fun and puts you somewhat into the shoes of a pirate and how it technically could be. Super fun game really beautiful to look at as well and is definitely recommended to play but mostly only with friends as it becomes even more fun. More so when you bully them a bit :)

I think that this game is honestly one of microsoft's more memorable games, and my god the graphics are great, I have never seen better ocean graphics. With monthly content updates, there is always something to do. I recommend playing this with friends though as the open crew just matches you with Xbox players with no mics. PvP is unpredictable  and PvE is fun! I recommend this if you like open world games. I will admit though, I did kinda lose the sense  of progression but that is only because there is a lot of grinding. AND IT IS WORTH IT! 9/10 would recommend

Sea of Thieves is a really unique experience. 

While the gameplay itself is relaxing and simplistic, the game does not respect your time. A lot of time is spent navigating the seas, uncovering treasure, and having it all taken away in a minute by a stranger. While this might be the intended playstyle, a pirates life, it isn't conductive for good gameplay. Spending an hour scouring the beaches for loot to have it your boat sunk in a matter of moments is a night-ender. 

There are also many infrastructure issues in the game, and I have not played for more than an hour without annoying lag, or unresponsive systems.

On the positive, the game oozes style and beauty. It really is a marvel of a game visually, and scratches that Pirates of the Caribbean itch.

I am giving this one a negative review based on the poor servers as it makes everything in the game, especially fighting, tedious and annoying.

Sea of Thieves can be a blast with friends, but you will likely find yourself getting bored with trying to complete the more challenging things in the game, due to the only reward being cosmetics for your character/ship. This game is really what you make it, and it is very hard to “make” fun without playing with a group of friends. Ultimately, I would not recommend people to buy Sea of Thieves unless you know you will have a group of friends that will commit to playing with you. Otherwise this game may just end up another game of the day within your friend group.

At 5 hours in I left a negative review and requested a refund. Let me now tell a tale that summarizes this game in full for me, at 100 hours, with a memory I will likely keep for the rest of my life.

[b]A day like any other[/b]
While heading to an island for a bog standard treasure hunt on a bog standard evening sail, my brother and I complained that the hunt would be difficult in the fog that had unfortunately spawned around it. As we gathered closer the newest event also spawned at that very island, meaning we were so close we had a chance to take it for our own before the rest of the server arrived to challenge us for the newest loot.
Being the skeptical pirate, I rested our Sloop at the rear of the island that backed onto the map edge, meaning anyone approaching the isle would not see we were there. The fog only aided this more.
We begin this event fighting a skeleton pirate lord, a multiple stage fire breathing pve nightmare vs two lads and their swords in one hand and their bananas in the other. With such a large health pool we had been kidding ourselves thinking we had time to complete this solo!
In the final stage of the fight, another Sloop arrived who sat just off shore without approaching. The two aboard did not fire on us, but they did not assist either. That’s fine, we can fight them off later or share the loot to make things easy. We did not expect a 4 per Galleon to arrive not long after who were also friendly but assisted us in completing the event. With the boss down and loot spawning all around, we returned to our Sloop to bring around the rowboat and divvy the loot. 

[b]Mistaken Identity[/b]
Unfortunately this is when the other sloop entered the island in our place, and split the loot with the Galleon. By the time we had brought around the rowboat the Galleon was anchor up and sails down, heading towards the nearest outpost to sell. Gadzooks, I hid the Sloop too well. They didn’t realize there was a 3rd crew!
I jumped from our rowboat into the waters, stealthy boarding the Sloop who was following the Galleon. While clinging to the rope ladder hanging from the side as the two aboard organized the ship, I found a moment they were both below deck and sprinted and climbed to the crows nest to hide unnoticed. Success!
A few minutes later, the Galleon ahead had the misfortune of running into a Kraken, who’s inky surroundings halts a ship in place. Karmic laughter from my brother and I over discord, we were keen to see how this played out. As the Sloop approached the Kraken to assist it’s demise, I call out over in-game chat that “I don’t trust these guys, shoot them!” to which both ships knew they were not the ones calling out.

[b]Mistaken Identity 2: Electric Boogaloo[/b]
One misplaced shot at the Kraken that hits the Galleon later and war broke out. Boarding, cannon fire, firebombs. Within seconds a cannon hits the crows nest and I’m sent flying back into the waters. Eating my last banana while swimming back to the surface, I find that the Galleon is set to sail directly overhead! Adjusting for turning and speed, I grab the rope ladder hanging from the side and catch a ride to see how this plays out. Again waiting to hear all footsteps below deck I chance a moment to sprint to the back of ship to hide again.
But, what’s this? The loot from the island is still on the rowboat strapped to the back of the ship! Without hesitation I jump in and detach, calling over discord for a ride home. 

[b]Great Escape[/b]
Rowing away from the fight I noticed another ship had approached the Kraken laden Galleon to strike opportunity. This had become a three way fight, of which I was leaving the victor.
This entire time my brother had been keeping our Sloop close but not engaged to support a quick getaway, and one masterful hand brake turn at full speed while I attached the rowboat meant just that. We’re away and sailing directly into the wind. We know the Galleon is the fastest ship on the seas with tailwind, but the Sloop is the fastest with headwind. They give up after a couple of minutes and we’re safely disengaged with the brand new, rare skeleton lord skull.

tl;dr: convinced two crews to start a fight, stole the good loot while they’re both distracted

The Positive: Extremely fun game to play with friends! Beautiful graphics and performance.

I remember watching game play of this back around when it was new, once I seen it on steam me and my bro decided to give it a try. The graphics are beautiful! Doing the quests feel exciting and rewarding, It's not pay to win or anything like that, everything in the shops and what you can buy with the in game currency is cosmetic only; so your on even footing with every other player out there. You can play the game however you want, you can hunt for other players and steal from them and believe me they can and will steal from you eventually. Figuring out what to do for the quests involving riddles is very fun, I usually can figure them out but there's been a few I had to look up. Controlling a ship with a crew is some of the most fun Iv'e had playing online, there's so many little things that Sea of Thieves just nails to give you the feeling of being a pirate on the open seas. 

The Negative: Toxic Players, xbox account is required (don't need xbox live), players can hide on your boat and be near impossible to spot

The game is doable Solo, although it's so much harder to deal with an enemy team who is dead set on getting your loot. The players I have encountered while solo have been some of the most toxic people I have ever had the displeasure of playing with. I'm still pretty new so I don't know how everything works, Iv'e been chased all the way across the map while putting up a good fight, keeping my ship afloat and killing the enemy players pursuing me as they try and board my boat.  I'm not sure yet how to deal with a scenario described above but I do know there is built in matchmaking so playing solo is a choice.

Conclusion: Sea of Thieves is a fun game that offers some high risk high reward pirate like adventures with friends and foes on the open seas. I'd give it an 8/10 overall and would recommend anyone that was on the edge of buying this game to give it a try with some friends.

Game starts off really well, gets you hooked on the pirate and background aesthetics real fast. Colorful environment with a good variety of wildlife. A lot of attention to detail can be seen in all items. 

The core mechanics run smoothly and feel just right, there are bugs from time to time, mostly audio related, however, they are easily fixable.

The lore, main quests and voyages are quite addictive and can keep you on a single server for hours, especially if you represent a faction/company.

The PVP in this game is fun and engaging, sometimes enraging. The bullet shots are not hitscan and there is a bit of a learning curve, however, there is no weapon bloom if aimed downsight. Bear in mind that there are other factors that would change the trajectory of the shot bullet (shooting after being launched from a cannon; shooting while in a moving ship etc.). Losing your loot to another crew would be demotivating and rage inducing at first but you get used to it eventually and git gud. There is also an Arena game mode where you can practice your PvP skills.

Overall a great sandbox game! It might become bland from time to time but Rare amps it up with a new update including different activities, new items, loot and cosmetics

dogshit game

What's that? You don't care? Apparently neither do Rare.

What initially posed itself as a game i've been waiting a long time for, from a company I regarded as one of the best in the business, has now for me become an emblem of the failures of modern day gaming.

Image and hype generates more profit than quality or substance. That's because rather than people having to work to earn money, and then decide how they're going to invest it, they are instead being given money, for doing nothing, by either mommy and daddy or the state, and spend it frugally on anything shiny waved in their face.

Why does my opinion matter at all? I've been playing videogames since I was 4. I was a big RARE fan, played kameo, enjoyed viva pinata a lot, and loved BK Nuts and Bolts. I'm a massive pirate fan (not historical, but fantasy piracy), and I love experience-centric, immersive, non-grindy games. I'm a game designer of about 7 years experience and i've played many games across many genres and formats and cultures.

The concept of sea of thieves is very close to the exact concept I'd use if I was given an experienced games development team and 4 years to build a game. The core design would be pretty much identical.

So to be honest, if the game doesn't appeal to me, it has failed to appeal to the very people it should be tailored towards. Instead it seems to be tailored half towards office workers who don't see the outside world very often, and half towards bored fortnite players who want to stream footage of themselves being pirates for the views and lulz.

The kraken was a dissapointment. Rank 50 with the guilds was a dissapointment. The firt pirate legends was a dissapointment. 50% of the voyages where you sail for 10 minutes, search an island for poorly written riddles or fight awkward enemies for 15 minutes, sail to an outpost for 5 minutes and then get 80 - 200 gold as a reward is a dissappointment. The sailing is exactly the same everytime. The pvp is exactly same 90% of the time.

A worst of all, worse than the poor quality design, the lag, bugs, glicthes, pc / xbox combat disparity, lack of content and lack of variety, is the community. A spattering of logical, sensible individuals attempting to constructively critiscize the game in order to improve it being drowned out by waves of loyalists and zealots, mindless defending the game and defaming any opposition without even a single logical point or relevant argument in sight. Moderators that close entire threads rather than ban offending individuals. A tolerance of opinions and users who are clearly not interested in discussion or debate on a DISCUSSION FORUM, but who are more than happy to tote their opinion as evidence of the game's merits.

And this game they claimed 'isn't COD or PUBG, it's unique and revoutionary and doing it's own thing'. Meh, being unique is dandy, but being unique and lazy and complacent is no more commendable than being a high quality, committed clone of another product. If Sea of Thieves being 'unique' and somewhat unusual is the only merit you need to enjoy this game, you're standards are exceptionally low.

Okami was unique. Pikmin was unique. Journey. Fable 1. Rock of Ages. Limbo. Undertale. Makai Kingdom. Viva Pinata. Banjo Kazooie Nuts and Bolts. Spyro. Metal Arms: Glitch in the System. Pirates: Legend of Black Cat. Overboard! Brutal Legend. Left 4 Dead.

All games I could argue are good for reasons other than 'because I like them'. All games released with a variety of content. Narrative / progression of some sort, not necessarily vertical, or even horizontal. Consistancy of design (if a shotgun to the face kills you, so does a pistol round. Quality across the entire experience.

Sea of thieves lack ALL of these things. There are two way this goes now. We continue with this culture of false respect, hype and over promotion compensating for lack of sustance or quality, and find the games we're playing becoming ever more dissappointing and worthless investments of time and money. OR, we stop supporting trash beyond the point of sticking with it through years of deveopment, tens sometimes hundreds of hours of design and suggesiton, and force them to improve their attitudes, approach and commitment by the only means they understand, money.

When the money stops pouring in for trash and starts moving towards quality games and quality developers, we'll all start seeing more games like what Sea of thieves should have been, and less like what Sea of Thieves actually is.

Quite frankly, if you're going to spend £50 / $60 on a game based purely on what they tell you you're getting, you're a fool. And fools don't do the playing, they get played. Play demos. Read reviews. Listen to freinds. Watch footage. Don't pay until it's been earnt. I've put 80 ish hours into this game, for virtually no reward, and fairly hollow memories when compared to actually leaving the house and meeting real people. I've not paid a penny to play it. And that's the way it should be.

This is my last thread anyway. After 50+ detailed suggestions for the game and what I guess is around 400 - 500 responses to other threads, "I wash my hands of this madness". "Doldrums, sir, has the entire crew on edge."

As you may guess from my playtime, I do like, and sail, the Sea of Thieves quite a lot.
So why the negative review?
Simple, some people shouldn't touch this booty with a ten foot shovel.

At its core this is a bastard simulator.
There is pve, where you are going to find treasures, battle Kraken or deliver plants that die unless watered(Yarrrr).
But in a true pirate fashion, pirates, as in other players can, and will attack you.

And here the problem lies.
You are going on your first journey, spending 10 minutes sailing, an hour on the quest, and then, when you are sailing to a port, to cash in your reward, you are boarded.
You did not see or hear the boarding, as you are up against players who have 2000+ hours in the game. They know tricks.
Or they just sail up to you, as there is no tutorial explaining how to effectively sail, and you suck at it.

You are now repeatedly killed. 
The games tutorial is a bad joke, created for old players going archievement hunting, no one told you that shotguns are useless unless you aim with the right mouse button.
You do not know how the sword works, and you do not know that cooked food passively regenerates your health.
You are up against people, who do know that, and every other trick.
So why do they kill you over and over again?
To loot your ships supplies if you are lucky. Because they are "real pirates" if you are unlucky. 
They are going to tell you in the latter case.
Of course you can scuttle your ship, to avoid respawning into renewed rounds of humiliation.
But that option is hidden away in an options menu under "my crew", so as a new player, you don't know of it.

This deliberate crippling of new players seems to be by design, new players are supposed to be "EZ LOOT... jk", as the loving moniker for steamplayers in official communication is.
This is best shown by a range of emotes that, while some are free, must be purchased in the real-money store.
The emotes in question are the "hide" emotes, that also hide a players name.
A new player will not know that this is possible.
Veteran players use it routinely to "tuck" on ships, and then spring the trap after the ship in question got loot, or is vulnerable.
Which is fun, If you know of the possibility.
Not so much if you don't.

If you do not like pvp, if you do not like to lose hours of playtime, without a chance to prevent it, or retaliate, then stay away.
If you do not like to be helpless prey for the first many, many hours in game, then turn around and never return.

If you can laugh that away, then this game might be for you, and then all the nice stuff everyone else writes is going to come true.

In any case: Before you buy, you should watch lets-plays. 
And remember: You are going to be the butt of that joke.

Edit, to clarify, after reading the comments: 
I wrote this review shortly after reaching pirate legend(the first big grind) at around 200 hours. I am still playing, mostly as a reaper(the pvp faction). 
If you think I wrote this because I am bad at the game, or don't like pvp, you missed the point entirely.
I would choose pvp-servers, should they decide to add pve-servers.
I do however think it fair, that people should know that pure pve is not viable, and that hey are going to be at the complete mercy of a certain kind of people. 
On that note: A big thank you to everyone commenting, much appreciated.
I also wanted to give some hints to new players.
All the stuff I wrote, that I did not know? 
If you read about  it, and still decide to buy the game, you are much more prepared for what is to come.

One of the best multiplayer PVP games I have ever played with some minor issues.  

Gameplay:
Interesting and fun PVE adventure game play, awesome character and ship customization. 

PVP gameplay is both thrilling and exciting, everybody has the same stats so the playing field is level, however, although rare, aimbot cheaters still exist on the server.

Graphics:
Probably this is the game with the best water simulation and the sceneries are simply stunning.  

Server issues:
Previously there was a server issue that caused players losing all of their progress on that day, the bug existed since two years ago and they still haven't found a solution to that yet. 

Occasionally, you will be disconnected from the server which is pretty annoying .

The game can be a bit buggy at times, but has an otherwise enjoyable arsenal of features, such as the unique sailing mechanic, the seeking out and plundering of various islands, and the combat with many different randomly spawning creatures and monsters. I would strongly recommend this game to anyone seeking a unique open-world adventure. I hope this is helpful to anyone on the line about whether or not to get this game.

Often times reviews include subjective opinions about the game. Look around online for content related to this game, whether it be YouTube videos or Reddit posts; get a feel for what the game is like, rather than looking for someone else's opinion. This game appeals to a very specific type of person, a person with very specific interests and etc. So have a gander at it, and maybe buy it and try it out, if you don't like the game then you can refund it always, as long as you have played it for less than two hours.

What isn't subjective is the developer presence in this game. The game gets monthly content updates, not only that, but the developers are very in tune with the community and keep a constant line of communication between themselves and the community.

An outstanding game for both people who want to go it alone or as a group. But you will get the most fun out of it if you have friends to play with. Or you can join the always friendly discord groups and sail the high seas with total strangers who I have never had a bad experience with.

Alright you little wanna be pirate king's, I've felt that I've wasted enough of my life on this game that I should tell you all how I feel about it.

This game itself is AMAZING... at first.
Graphics are astonishing, it runs smoothly, the controls are very fluid, and the some-what story line is very engaging.

Anything else after that is just revolving around repetition.

Going to the same islands, fighting the same monsters, completing the same events, obtaining the same items, reselling them to the same merchants. Naturally, that's going to be boring, BUT that's not the main issue here.

The issue occurs when you have a ton of loot and have to carry it onto your ship ONE by ONE whilst being UNABLE TO SPRINT so you have to walk from point A to point B. You could be holding something as small as a key and still have to walk at the speed of a broken leg and to me personally, this is a literal joke.

Another major issue is the imbalance between players. See, as a single player with a 2 man ship, you could complete one of the skull events and get completely screwed over by some losers waiting in the distance with a 4 man ship, and the fact that there is no safezones, even at major locations such as the ports or harbors adds onto the fact that you've wasted a few hours of your life farming loot just for people to take it from you and there is LITERALLY NOTHING you can do about it. 

Well...  at least on the bright side you won't have to spend another hour or two putting it onto your ship AND another hour or two taking it off to sell to merchants.

6/10 from me.

Some thing's I'd highly recommend to improve the game's QOL.

1. Monster variants. I'm tired of fighting skeletons that run away from you and sharks that swim around in circles around your boat.

2. Safezones. I don't want to have to add another 2 hours onto the 2-3 that I've invested running from User5849872 cause he saw me comming from the direction in which he was headed.

3. Allow people to run or speed walk while holding items. I can understand that not being able to run with a chest is logical but bro, you telling me that the key I gotta use TO OPEN the chest is almost as heavy as the chest itself? C'mon man, get it together.

I'll add things over time as I find necessary but right now it's 3:46pm, I just woke up and wanna finish my pancakes.

Game is immensely fun and easy to understand.

Pros: 
- You don't need a strong PC to run it.
- A LOT of achievements to collect. 
- Game is extremely beautiful to look at.
- It's not a pay to win game.
- The cosmetics does't help you in any shape or form.
- Campaign is fun and satisfying to do.
- It's a simple grinding game, you need gold for everything. 
- Game will take at least 600 hours to have done every main mission and unlocked every cosmetic. 
- Friends can join your crew without leaving the server.
- Game isn't difficult, you just need to understand riddles and figure out traps and puzzles. 
- There is no fast travel, so it's a race to the chest and fight till you survive. 
- Fishing is fun, more then I can say for other games. 

Cons:
- You WILL struggle to play this game alone, most people play a party of 3. It's not impossible to play alone, it's just when you are alone and have chests or other treasure to give in and someone attacks you, you have almost no chance to win, because you will sale a Sloop (max 2-person that is the slowest ship) and fight against a Brigantine (max 3-person), and the Galleon (max 4- person).
- If your ping is over 200 vs a player with 90, you will lose sword fights.
- People can attack you anytime, anywhere! There are no safe zones.
- You can't save anything you collect, when you leave the game, all the stuff you horded on your ship will disappear. 

All in all I give this game 8.2/10 Try it and have fun!

This game is not nearly as hard as people seem to think it is. sure, there may be infuriating players who come and steal the fruits of your hard work...
But if you aren't expecting opposition from other players (especially in a game about pirates)  you don't need to be playing video games.

and to those that whine about soloing, there's open crews, also it's not that fucking hard to make a friend unless you really are just a completely unapproachable person, even online.

(Hoo Boy, this'a long 'un!)

You don't specifically need friends to play this game, as you can access open crews and be matched with random players across the globe.
The world is beautifully crafted with a well built lore surrounding it, the graphics look great even on lower end settings.
The quest system is fantastic and fun, each step of the journeys upon which you may embark have their own little jovial tune, making the adventure much more memorable.
The core gameplay loop of "buy voyage, sail to island, perform required task, sell task item" may sound droning, however with the variety of chests to dig up, the number of skeletons to fight, and however many times you'll meet the Ferryman all add to the overall adventure, making each journey unique in their own little ways.
Each trading company has their own unique types of voyages, allowing you to pick your favorite!

So what are you waiting for? Get a voyage from a trading company, fill your sails with the roaring wind and embark on your adventure!

And remember!
[spoiler] [i] [b]"It's not about the gold... It's about the glory!"[/b] [/i] [/spoiler]

You get to be a pirate. 'Nuff said. Well, it should be. Alright, if you're reading this, then I assume you're trying to decide whether to play Sea of Thieves. I played it on Xbox One originally and now I'm excited to find it's on Steam. I'm going to do an honest break down:

Reasons to Play:
(1) Lots to do! There's literally something to do all the time and a large variety.
(2) Fun to play together! Random people to play with can be hit or miss, but regular friends to play with makes it oh so much better.
(3) Beautiful scenery! The game is stylish and beautiful. This is down to the different styles across the game including customizable outfits, weapons, ships, and more. Not to mention the literal scenery around you.
(4) Anything can happen! At any moment, you could run into another player ship, a ghost ship, the Kraken, a giant shark, and more. Every time you set out on an adventure, you never know what you will find.
(5) Unravel mysteries! There's a deeper lore than most people realize to this game. You just have to find it!
(6) Play music! Together or alone while your shipmates sail, the mood is set by your own instrumental choice.

Reasons NOT to play?
(1) You don't like dying occasionally! If you're going to get easily frustrated by setbacks, then either suck it up or drop anchor and play a game that doesn't have other players in it. Oh, and its not just the players that can kill you. The ocean is dangerous!
(2) You don't like pirates! If so, then why are you reading this anyway or considering this game?
(3) You don't like playing with others! Well, you don't HAVE to play with others in this game, but it's bound to happen eventually. Or go play a single player game.

All in all, jump in the blood-tainted ocean with us and go on an adventure! SEA YOU THAR, MATEY!

I absolutely recommend this game.  It is played best I think if you have a solid crew of three that you can coordinate well with where everyone has different strengths. As long as one person is good with player vs player hand to hand combat you're golden.  The game has a nice pacing where it goes between relaxing and just enjoying the sailing of the seas, to intense moments where "all hands on deck" is necessary and you have to strategize as a crew to survive.   I do think there is room for a lot more content in this game and it has further potential it could live up to.  But even still, where it's at allows me to happily play 6 or 7 hour sessions with my crew and we don't get bored.  
to sum up. graphics, while cartoonish, are beautiful.  the battle mechanics for fighting ships is pretty flawless and fun.  the range of content available i'd give a good 8.5 out of 10.   and the thievery is a 10/10.  one of my favorite games to spend time in.

AWESOME GAME !!!!!
If you and your friends want some fun by exploring the pirate world , buy this game. The gameplay will be explained during the tutoral which last only about 10-15 minutes. Afterwards you know every important item and its use in the game. I would recommand to play the game with friends since playing it alone is not so funny and really difficult. It is an open world where everybody can attack you (players and NPCs). You are a pirat which means you can steal from other players , attack other players/NPCs and explore the world. You can go on an adventure( tall tales) or simly sail with your ship around the world and search for a fight. 

One of the best points in this game is that a player who has played this game for 100 hours has no advantage towards new players. There are treasures in the game which you can sell to receive in-game money but this money can only be used to buy skins for your ships or your character. These skins will give you no adantages in a fight. You can also use real money but only to buy pets (only cute and funny but have no real function) /emotions/special skins which again will give no advantage to the player. The game is fair since every time you start your game , everybody starts with the same conditions. The canons, foods and planks you collected the day before disappears when you finish your game. 

The game will give you no instructions what you should do. The point of this game is living a pirates life, do whatever you want to do. 

P.S RESPECT THE PIRATES CODE : THERE ARE NO RULES !!!!!!!!

So I've watched this game for many months, thinking it seemed very fun and was excited I could now play it on my new computer.

Loaded in and had a cool tutorial setup.  Wasn't an issue to grasp, had very pretty visuals and good musical cues.  I do know it will take me a bit of time to get acclimated to the inventory wheel system and hotkeys.  Unfortunately, as I was trying to get my feet under me and follow the tutorial, an NPC skeleton sloop spawned next to me within maybe 1-3 minutes of the voyage, killed me twice with cannons, and then sank me.  Respawned, brushed it off and set off on a new heading.  Was nearly at my first destination for my first castaway chest dig-up when another sloop came up and over the span of three to five minutes, killed, boarded, killed, and then sank my sloop.  Irritated, I tried again, got on the ship, headed for the isle, got there, dug up my first chest, started for the nearest outpost and another skeleton vessel spawned.  I managed to outrun it.  Okay, fine, but then between me and the nearest outpost was this glowing ship i think called a 'reaver?' that came up.  Tried to wave and avoid but they chased me down, killed me, and took my chest.

Overall just a really unpleasant, oppressive feeling start to the game.  I barely know where my wood, food, and sword buttons are and I'm getting roflstomped repeatedly.  It'd be nice if there was a way to flag your ship as "New Player" or "Less than 10, 25, 50 hrs" to try and promote a more pleasant experience where people don't just kill off potential new community members.  

Tempted to refund it.  Only reason I won't is due to the chance to play with friends.  If that doesn't happen soon or the same thing happens while with others I will likely do so.

Absolutely gorgeous and enjoyable controls  and game mechanics around sailing that, in itself is sufficient to have a lot of fun.
The game is some kind of sandbox where there are tons of things that could randomly happen, between missions you can request to kick off your journey, random encounters or parchments and journals laying around.
And the great thing is that you'll have to balance your greed and safe playing. Globally, roughly 16 players will be playing in teams, most probably against you but hopefuly, the map is huge.
It's pretty probable that a PvP encounter leads in catastrophic consequences and you lose everything so think twice before taking that new mission while you could head back and sell your precious loot.

So many things happen:
- Meet the Kraken
- Skeleton crew ships floating back from the deaths in the middle of your trip
- Megalodon that enjoys the wood of your tasty sloop
- Tough Skeleton captains which skull is valuable
- Treasure chests hidden under the X or behind a well thought riddle concept.
- Mermaids gem stones
- Ship wrecks
- cursed chests that will either burn or flood your ship
- Terrible storms that you wish you didn't underestimate.

The commands of the ship are simple but very fun to use:
Anchor, sail length and angle, navigation wheel, canons and balista. You may even manage to outrun your tail with a bit of skill.
Use fire or holes to sink your opponents so that they can't respawn, chop down their mast, board their ship.

Over all a super fun game that may only be slightly tainted by its PvP side.
It's possible to get away from most players but at some point, you will be hit by them and it could be frustrating.
And even if this is possible, I do not recommend playing this game alone.

So the game is great, the gameplay is amazing, and the community is amazing. That's a lot of amazing things to still warrant a thumbs down. After 200 hours of gameplay I've experienced rampant game bugs, out of a 30 day period nearly 8 of them had annoying bugs. Everything from serverlag for the entire EU servers, to an event that caused non of your progress to be recorded. See, even when that bug was active I still played because the devs and the community were claiming that even if my progress isn't showing up it is still being recorded. About 5 days later, with constant updates everyday from the devs on their progress to restore the progress, they dropped the bomb. The progress wasn't recorded and we were given a useless compensation that wasn't worth the while at all. 

Their support is rubbish, utter rubbish. If you buy this game and enjoy the content like I did, remember to log out and not play when it's buggy which is 2 out of 7 days a week, that's what I should have done.

Updated Review, older impressions below:

The game is just beautiful, honestly I wish there was more content in it, because I feel like I'm playing an openworld Windwaker, but the game is still incredibly shallow. I know it's a PVP game mostly, but the PVE stuff in it, is incredibly shallow. Game looks big as an ocean, but is shallow as a puddle. Other than that, PVP shenanigans are fantastic, the game just needs a lot more depth to it. Can I recommend a full price purchase? Only if you're like me and know it's a game where you make your own fun, the game will not help give you any fun after raising the water level to your toes, you'll have to find ways to have fun. 


Old impression: Wow, wow, and WOW. The closest I had to this game on PC was Blackwake, which is already amazing, but Sea of Thieves has literally blown me away. How does this game run on max settings on my pc at 1440p above 60 fps easily and my PC doesn't even break a sweat not even when I start recording, the fans don't come on, I don't get weird overheating framerate drops, my cpu remains steady and the game is super stable at high frame rates, but a 2D game with some 3d effects like Darkwood causes my graphics card and CPU to go into overdrive and I have to turn the jet engines on to cool my pc, and if I even think about turning on recording, the game has random freezes, especially Hunt: Showdown.

I will update this review as I play more of the game, but honestly, the first ten minutes just looking around and enjoying that classic RARE artstyle, it's the next best thing to Viva Pinata, AND sailing around with a friend, you feel like you're playing COOP Windwaker or something, the art style is gooooooorrgeous. I hope the gameplay lives up to these graphics, I'm all about looking to troll and be trolled by piracy in this game, I'll never moan about losing or dying in a game like this, it's all about the experience, especially in coop sailing. This game should scratch my DayZ style gameplay itch.

This review is going to be harsh yet honest. If you play solo this game is going to make you hate yourself and thank steam and sweet baby Jesus that there is a refund button. So this was my experience with the game, I started up the game and was greeted with a half ass attempt of a tutorial and was given a ship and told to sail to a nearby island. Steering a ship solo in this game is not fun because it feels like the night before Thanksgivining and your mom told you that the annoying grandma is coming and you now need to focus on cleaning every damn thing for the next 24 hours. So you start off by raising the anchor, dropping the sails, and steering the ship in a general direction. By the way when the sails are you literally cant see anything. You might as well get in your car throw on a off brand, off white pillow case on your head and drive around your neighborhood yelling you are a pirate while destroying every fucking mailbox along the way. So to remedy this, i  had to run up to the front of the ship look around and pretend i knew what to do, run back to the map room and realize i know fuck all, then finally run up to the steering wheel and frantically turn because that is a rock and i am a naked pirate. i finally got to this island and it felt like i landed in fucking Oklahoma. There was nothing there but empty land, skeletons, and my will to live which was rapidly depleting each minute i endured this. I slapped a fish, slapped a statue and realized it hurt me so i started swinging faster but it broke before i could end my misery. I finally found out i had a shovel and started looking for my will to live but instead i found a chest... wo. I yeeted it onto my ship and did everything on the ship like a crack fueled sailor until i literally slammed onto the island i needed to be on. i turned it in and got enough gold to buy a gun that looked like it came out of a great value fallout. So i was like hey maybe playing online is better. I joined a random crew and was immediately locked in the brig and couldn't do a damn thing which forced me to leave the game. My friend then told me he also makes poor life decisions and bought the game as well. We joined up and realized YOU CANT USE YOUR STEAM FRIENDS LIST! I literally had to go to the damn xbox website add him manually and then visit my local priest to cleanse me cause... xbox. After an hour of fighting microsoft we finally managed to join up. 5 minutes later we were attacked by a galleon of 4 players and had to start over. I said fuck it and started drinking. The next day i tried again i joined up on a new crew and it was actually going ok until we decided to chase down some schooners. We chased them for over an hour and couldn't do a damn thing. The people on said schooner kept jumping of and boarding our ship and dropping anchor. Why is this a big deal? Because raising a galleon anchor take like 30 to 45 seconds dropping it however, is instantaneous! Does this track in real life yes it does but nonetheless it was insanely annoying. The entire crew rage quit so i was like eh i'm going to join up on my friend and join a bunch of other people you like to waste money. We all got into a galleon and set off. Our team was communicating and everything was going amazingly and we stumbled upon an enemy galleon we decided to fight them and ill admit an intense 30 minutes ensued as we blew each others ships to pieces followed by the most bullshit hour i have ever seen in my life. It all started when we got close together and started to board each others ships. i went over to the enemies ship and stole all their supplies but they somehow magically got all of their materials and ammo (cannonballs and throwables) back. Over the course of the fight however, both sides died and we waited in the respawn area to come back however, the enemy team just jumped in and jumped out while my crew sat there for over minute waiting like we are in the damn DMV. We came back to our ship which was now on fire, sinking which symbolically represented my aforementioned will to live while their ship which keep in mind was in worse shape then ours 30 minutes ago magically repaired itself and went to therapy or some shit. So we fought as hard as we could but they just died and immediately came back like the second coming of Christ himself. We all died broken and beaten like the brave 300 even though they were all killed at least 20 times. To celebrate their lack of morals, they proceeded to dance on our corpses and brag that they were better at cheating. Oh yeah by the way you can hear your enemies talking and you cant mute your own team members this game forces communication down your throat and does not give the courtesy of buying you dinner or altering the settings. So to put it plainly, the best part of this game, was me pressing the refund button if you love yourself, wait for skull and bones.

A game where you'll actually have your own adventures to be told.

Even though I'm still new to this game, I've had many memories that are so fun and interesting, I've actually felt like I'm having real life adventures. You never know what your next play session will take you. Fighting sea monsters? Making alliances with other ships? Raiding other players, perhaps? The balance between how you can play vs what you can do in this game is unlike any other I've played.

However, I don't think this game is perfect, far from it. Under all that pirate glory, Sea of Thieves still have a lot of potential to be dug up. Swordfights are sort of bland, islands should have more in it, territories could be added, etc. That being said, Sea of Thieves is way more fun with friends, playing solo is doable but you'll feel that more manpower is needed and it gets boring faster.

The game is unique and mixes things up well. The quests are exciting as it nonchalantly reveals a story of magic, thievery and fellowship. Some of them straight-up challenge your intelligence, which i do appreciate. The competitive aspect for me is stealing from other online pirates and, my god, it is loads of fun.

The game still has some bugs but they don't hinder you from having a great time. 

9/10 would recommend

Very chill game, perfect if you want to have an entire afternoon running around and looting islands with treasure chests.

Although i haven't really met a lot of people in multiplayer, most of them are really chill and might help you out. I never really got to speak to them properly and none of them used their mics so the experience could be better for me at least if there was more of that. 

As for PVP in the game i have only encountered 1 person that attacked me and my friend even though we were on an outpost. It didn't go well for that person as we barely shot our cannons so we had too many cannonballs to spare and sunk his ship lol.

Riddles can be super confusing and working them out can be pretty frustrating at times depending on the riddle you got, plus there are still unsolved riddles so if you are stuck on one there might not even be a guide on how to solve it.

Pet system is cute and all but i wish there was a way to earn your pet and not though my wallet, i know its all cosmetic but i wish you could earn it though gameplay.

tl;dr Fun chill game, grab a friend or if youre as lonely as me grab a body pillow. And set sail in the open ocean with lots of shenanigans to be had like crashing into the same rock 50 different times, battling krakens , megalodons , raiding fortresses, ghost ships, skeleton ships or pvp. Its a thrill ride if you want it to be or a chill time.
