At first I was very reticent about purchasing this game. I heard and read many differing opinions on whether or not this game was worth the commitment; it's certainly worth the money, I wouldn't argue that, but more so the time sink.  

I also had a very unpleasant experience with trying to purchase this on the Windows Store before coming to Steam. I had both store and xbox companion app issues with my computer, and even being tech supported through it via remote access, no one was able to fix the issue...and I never got the game and said 'fooey' to Microsoft. 

Fast-forward to the Steam launch, and my son's willingness to jump in with me, and here I am 25 hours later enjoying the hell out of it. Even as a solo-rolling lone-wolf I enjoy myself. Truth be told, there are moments when I'm alone that are more immersive than when I'm with someone. This is because the truly immersive environments that this open world creates. Regardless the playful artstyle, the detail in the world and the sound design, play to a truly captivating experience. When I'm alone, and I stare off at the massive hulking supercell a few miles off, slowly encroaching on me, I'm honestly terrified. Hearing the far off thunder-claps succeed each potentially damaging lighting strike, gives me the chills. And that's just from a mile off. I honestly don't have the gamer guts to just sail off willy-nilly into a supercell...heck no. I had the displeasure of being caught in a storm once, with the high velocity winds, massive waves, pelting rain, and lighting strikes which can and will harm you...it's nerve-racking. But...inspired. I respect those storms...and I stay away from them at all costs.

Let's briefly talk about water. It's a pirate game, so it goes without saying that there will be a lot of water. I think this game should teach a master class on how to create water and physical waves in a 3d medium. The water is absolutely beautiful. No other game comes close to the fidelity of this undulating water. The movement, the complex shaders and myriad different looks and feel depending on the surrounding environments time of day or weather....it's astonishing. Again, the immersion aspect here is so successful. When I stare out at this ocean, I feel small. I fear what can not be seen, lurking below the surface--this could be the Kraken, a Ghost Ship, a Megalodon...or who knows what else. The same fears and reservations I have about the real world ocean, I share with Sea of Thieves. It successfully puts the fear of the ocean (and ocean floor) in me. How deep is it? What's down there? It works. And the tension is palpable. 

In terms of gameplay and loop, I'm still such a newbie pirate. But from what I've scratched, to watching streamers and tips and tricks videos, I can see that I have a myriad content to play through. Months and years to mull about with. 

I realize this review isn't in typical format, nor does it go over much of the game and mechanics...but I wanted to write this to share my experience with the world and its immersion. I get the same tension from this game as I do with Alien Isolation, Outlast or Deadspace. It's true! Sailing the ocean alone in Sea of Thieves provokes the same adrenaline and tension as those aforementioned horror survival games. Of course you could be a min-max gamer, plunder till your hearts content and ignore all the immersive elements...but I choose to get lost in them, and that is WHY Sea of Thieves shines for me.

As far as sailing mechanics: I'll briefly just say that they are very satisfying. I feel like a sailor. I feel like the rotating of the mast to catch the wind, or the raising or lowering of the sail to control my speed is all very intuitive and just feels good.

In terms of PVP and PVE: in the few dozen hours I've sailed around in 'Adventure Mode', I've only run into a handful of try-hard murderous human pirates. So far it's been the perfect sprinkle of PVP in a pretty vast PVE world. There are plenty of baddies and bosses to fight and find, and occasionally you will run into another human on the open seas. Sometimes they will be friendly, but always prepare for a fight.  

Is it worth $40? Absolutely. I urge you to go read more reviews, but I can say if you are into sailing, pirates, the open seas, mythical creatures and locations...this game will deliver in spades. I've got no major bones to pick, and I can say a pirates life is for me.

Sea of Thieves is a fun romp on the Sea digging up treasure, fighting skeletons, Ships piloted by skeletons, fighting Krakens and megalodons, as well as several in game events and a good amount of story missions in the form of Tall Tales.

This game is fun, the art style is beautiful, and there is a lot to enjoy in the game. 

You might be wondering why I don't recommend the game. Why is that? Well there is another feature in the game that I failed to mention. Specifically the fact you are not sailing the seas alone. This is not inherently a bad thing, in fact I have had some good experiences involving random players. I do not advocate for changing the base game, but the toxicity of the community is really off putting and I feel that a mode similar to the PVP arena mode should be created to allow players to enjoy the game with friends without being harassed in PVP. Basically a PVE adventure mode, that focuses on doing voyages, tall tales, and PVE fighting and events.

A PVE only mode would not affect people who enjoy the base game, and I feel there are plenty of ways to enable its functionality. Like increase the amount of PVE events, cause more skeleton spawns etc. Sometimes you don't want to deal with other players, and a mode should be there to allow people to enjoy the game a bit more casually.

The main game mode is fine, but sometimes a few bad apples can really ruin an experience for people. The amount of toxic responses people who ask for some kind of PVE mode receive from others just proves a point of the toxic nature of some people.

Do not get into this game expecting a good time if you do not have a group of friends to play with, and even if you do people who only play this game to prey on you and make you miserable  may show up to ruin your day.

This game is good, but it has some major flaws that need addressing.

Sea of Thieves is a great game. The graphics are so uiniquely atmospheric, and the world is very harsh and leaves you to your own devices. What really makes or breaks SoT is if you have friends willing to play with you. The game is very focused on having friends to make life on the Sea easier. Playing in a one player ship has huge advantages as you have to simultaneously control the wheel, the sails, and the cannons alone. While it is definately a chore, it's still possible and even fun at times.


What really sucks is it's nearly impossible to do the harder activites by yourself. Doing Skull Forts is a day long chore, as you get overwhelmed with bodybuilder-esque skellys. Fighting Megalodons is quite easy, as you only have to sail in a circle and shoot him while maintaining your hull.

These things being said, when you find a group to help you out with you quests, the game gets immensely more fun. Sailing the sea gets less lonely, and major schenannegans ensue. Be it getting drunk and fighting a Kraken with your crew, or Chasing Captain Flameheart across the Sea of Thieves, the game is a serious PVP (Pirate v Pirate) extravoganza.
Fun if you play with friends, or queue with randoms and find new friends :-)

Save your time and money, avoid the headache, and stick with PUBG, Rocket League, or Fortnite.

I was really excited for this game and the first impression was great. I enjoyed the well-crafted tutorial and was stunned by the beautiful water graphics and physics.

However, this first amazement didn't last long and unfortunately I cannot recommend this game.

I hoped for an open-world pirate game with cool quests and some RPG mechanics where I could level up my avatar and my ship. Maybe something similar to EVE Online, but much less complex and more beginner-friendly of course.

However, this game offers nothing of that:

The "quests" are boring and repetitive. The only reward is gold that can be used to buy cosmetics. And this game is all about cosmetics. You cannot level any skills, there is no character progression, and you cannot even really customise the physical appearance of your character to your liking, just buy new clothes, hair styles etc.

And, what I find most curious for a pirate game: you can neither buy new ships nor weapons, nor can you upgrade them. You just select one of three standard ships when starting a new game. And when your vessel get's destroyed, you just receive a new one for free.

All you can do is grind lots of money and buy various cosmetics that give your character, ship, or weapons a different appearance. That's all there is.

Furthermore, most progress is not saved when you quit the game. You can loot all kinds of stuff like wood (to repair your ship), and you can even cook food after you e.g. hunted animals. But you neither have to learn certain crafting skills to do so, nor does it make sense to stock up on any of these things because they disappear the moment you log out anyway.

Overall, after a couple of hours one has seen most of the game and there is not much left except from grinding lots of gold to buy lots of useless cosmetics...

Bought this game on a whim, thinking it'll be a little fun side game while stuck inside.

Boy, was I wrong. Ended up getting sucked into the immersion, hours pass by like mere seconds in this game.

Managed to get my irl friend to get this game, $40 honestly seems like a steal considering this is the most fun I've ever had in years.

We had our great pile of loot stolen from us by some more experienced players; they sunk our ship and headed to the nearest outpost with our stash. Feeling not quite defeated, I stated we should try and return where we were, get our stuff back or die trying. We looked at the map and set sail for the island near where we were sunk.

Ended up seeing their ship docking in the distance, I grabbed a TNT barrel they tried to kill us with, and suicide bombed their deck, sinking them in the process. My fellow crewmate picked up the treasure we had been robbed of moments before.

Nothing has ever felt as epic as that, and I'm sure you'll have similar experiences. 10/10, easily up there with MHW in terms of graphics, teamwork and fun.

Sea of Thieves is an online adventure game where players take on the role as lovable rogues traversing the mystical and eponymous Sea of Thieves, in search of treasure and glory. Gameplay is focused on taking on voyages for one of the many companies that have established themselves in the region, each with their own goals, emphasis, and mission style.

The Merchant’s Alliance wants to build a civilization in the Sea of Thieves, and to that end they task pirates with gathering resource parcels, herding animals into cages, and making deliveries.

Many crates for the Merchant’s Alliance have some gimmick associated with them to compensate for their missions being less adventurous than the others. Crates of plants need water, jumping with a crate of rum bottles can cause them to break, and pigs herded into cages need to be fed.

The Order of Souls is interested in the esoteric history of the Sea of Thieves, and wants to put the sea’s roaming skeletons to rest. The Order tasks pirates with hunting down skeletal captains who hide on islands and spawn in waves, or engage in battle with ghostly fleets that haunt larger islands.
So far I love this game. It's very fun to play with friends and relaxing to play alone. Would recommend.

I would like to counter many false reviews I've discoverd. 

One of the reasons this game shines is because everything purchasable is purely cosmetic. Therefore, just about anything is purely skill based. Different gun types, different gun skins and assecories have no legitimate gameplay advantage (except minor sight changes on flintlocks). 

If your thinking of buying it, keep in mind it is P-V-E-V-P meaning you can encounter both AI and legitimate players. That's the way it is, and it will stay that way. Do not buy if your just  going to complain about "toxicity." 

Thurethuremore, if playing with friends, the invite system is very simple. Just make sure to have X-BOX console companion. 

Make sure to read every review with a grain of salt, and also, with a game of this cost, DO YOUR RESEARCH! All of this should be common knowledge to a person shilling $40 on a game, yet half the reviews I've found are incredibly ill-written and from a bias point of view.

Sea of Thieves feels almost as a spiritual sequel to Sid Meier's Pirates, and that is possibly the best praise I can give it. The game is rewarding, challenging, and most of all captures the exact essence of what it means to be a pirate.

Nothing is sacred, your loot can be someone else's in a matter of moments, with them laughing as your ship sinks, only for you to do the same thing to someone else later. No one is ahead of you in weaponry, the only thing you can buy is cosmetics and the game's purely about who is the most skilled, [b] no pay to win [/b]. The tension you feel as you slowly start to play more and more close to the wire as your boat fills with loot, and you frantically check the horizon making sure no one is near to sink you and take it, can only be compared to that of a horror game. This game has the highest highs, and the lowest lows. Don't buy this game expecting to invincible. Don't buy this game expecting for others to leave you alone. Because, at the end of the day, you only have a boat, a crew, and some weapons keeping your loot from the hands of everyone else, and the sea itself.

SCORE: 7.5/10

Sea of Thieves is a clever sandbox multi-player "Fantasy\Pirate" action game. I did not bother with this title around it's original release because it got so much negative attention that I didn't want to waste my money\time on it. After several patches and added concepts and it's release on steam I 'rightly' decided to give this game a try and was not TOO disappointed. 

❤ Audience ❤
☑ Beginner
☑ Casual Gamer
☑ Normal Gamer
☑ Expert

Why?
Based on what I experienced during my time with Sea of Thieves it became clear to me that this game has something to offer a player of every skill level. With that said, depending on your skill level as a player may determine the amount of fun you have and how far you take your adventures. 

☼ Graphics ☼
☐ Bad
☐ Alright
☐ Good
☑ Beautiful
☐ Fantastic

Why?
Graphically the game is beautiful. The art style is very on theme with the game and like others before me have stated the water physics and effects are super immersive. There isn't quite a another title that can match the sailing experience in this game. It's cartoony, goofy and just a fun look and encapsulates exactly what the game is underneath. 

♬ Music ♬
☐ Bad
☐ Alright
☑ Good
☐ Beautiful
☐ Fantastic

Why?
It's exactly what you'd expect for a cartoony pirate game. It's right on theme from what I heard before quickly turning the music off because..immersion obviously. On top of the music you can play musical instruments while in game and it's pretty great. If playing with friends and playing different instruments you will all sync up with each other and play old classic pirate songs as a band.


☠ Difficulty ☠
☐ Easy
☑ Average
☑ Easy to learn / Hard to master
☑ Hard
☑ Unfair

Why?
With the addition of the tutorial this game is easy to learn. The tutorial is done well and explains the basics. Depending on where you choose to take your adventure will determine the difficulty of this game. (For the most part.) Danger is everywhere in this game. Sailing in the open water can be a bit nerve wracking because you never know if some other crew is going to pop out and wreck your day and jack your loot. Other players are probably the biggest threat in the game but besides that you could encounter sea monsters, skeletons, ghost ships and other dangers. Supplies in this game are abundant and you'll probably never run out of anything during a normal 1-2 hour session. The puzzle treasure quests are really cool too and require you to use your brain. I like that about this game. 


§ Bugs §
☐ Bugs destroy the game
☐ Lots of bugs
☐ Few Bugs
☑ Nothing encountered

why?
I haven't encountered any bugs so far. 

☯ Story ☯
☐ There is none
☐ Bad
☐ Alright
☐ Good
☐ Fantastic
☑ You make the story

Why?
I wouldn't say this game has a story but it definitely has lore that you uncover as you play the game. However there is no linear story mode to this game. It's all just sandbox and player driven. Whatever you choose to do is the story. 

⚔ Gameplay ⚔
☑ Frustrating
☑ Sleepy
☑ Boring
☑ Fun
☑ Challenging

Why?
Since there isn't a linear story guiding you through one part to the next, the game is about as fun or as boring as you make it depending on what you choose to do. The replay value from this game is based purely on the motivation to earn cosmetics. New costumes, hair, weapon and tool skins, ship skins. You buy these cosmetic upgrades with gold. You earn gold from turning in quests and treasure. You'll never encounter a sweaty player who is more powerful than you just because he's played more than you which I imagine some people probably love! The only things that are stacked against you in an encounter with another player is Crew size v Crew size which those odds can be overcome with skill. I think this progression system is risky and a little bit lazy to be honest. You could play the game for 1000s of hours and all you have to show for it is a costume you earned in the first 5-10 hours of gameplay and some title no one cares about. To me the time sink to reward isn't there to keep me playing every day which might be the intent of SoT. I like the idea of a leveling, unlocking, skill/perk system at the very least that to keep me engaged and wanting to develop my character. Truth be told I have no idea how i'd implement it in the game as it now and I doubt we'll ever see a progression system outside of cosmetics and titles and I think most of the players are probably okay with that. It keeps things casual for the most part and keeps people focused on just having fun as opposed to grinding for power. Another thing thats cool is there is an arena mode for purely PvP encounters.. although that doesn't satisfy the urge to grief does it?


۞ Game time / Length ۞
☑ Really short (0 - 3 hours)
☑ Short (4 - 8 hours)
☑ Meta (10 - 20 hours) [if you focus on the main story]
☑ Long (40-60 hours) [if you complete everything]
☑ Very Long (61-100 hours)
☑ Extremely Long (101+ hours)

Why?
This game doesn't require a set amount of play time. There's usually as much time or as little time to do whatever you're trying to do.

$ Price / Quality $
☑ Full price
☑ Wait for Sale
☐ Don't buy
☐ Refund it if you can

Why?
If this is the game you've been waiting for your whole life just buy it. If you're on the rocks about it, wait for a sale. If none of this game appeals to you whatsoever just don't buy it. I will say that it's a fun experience best enjoyed with friends. If you're planning on going it alone you're probably not going to have as much fun.

Quite a bizarre game it is!
On the one hand, the first few hours yield you little to no content.
On the other, as soon as you get your basic understanding, it showers you in so much to do that, quite honestly, it would seem like a terrible grind.
On the third hand (pretend you're a Kraken), you will find pure joy just from hanging out in the game - think of it as of a VERY PRETTY VR chat with ships and high-quality wave physics, I guess? Better yet, it does fulfill the fantasy of sailing with friends, and my best moments of the game were when my friends and I took a six hour long trip.
And yet if you play it long enough to go through the initial grind, you are only met with more grind. The rewards are cosmetic only, and even such are much easier achieved through microtransactions, and, beyond decorating the ship, there isn't really any endgame.


So, would I recommend it? Hell yes, I got one friend to buy it, and gifted it to another. It is a perfect way to waste half a day, and still feel satisfied. The problem is, it does not work for long. If you want to get something that will keep you company through the months, absolutely do, it is an endless supply of joy that will never end - but if you want to binge a game for a week straight, you will find yourself seasick.

Seasick, get it? Hire me, IGN.

Spent $40 on a buggy, broken game that seems to have been buggy and broken since day one. Every month there's an update and every update something breaks, whether it's gold rewards, reputation rewards, commendations, or important bits of gameplay like spawn mechanics or the menu just flat out not working. Criticisms of the game in the official discord are being removed after the most recent screwup where players lost many days of progress and got a paltry compensation.

It's a fun game that looks good and plays well when it works, but even leaving aside the crippling bugs there's always something that's broken which takes away from enjoyment of the game. It's not necessarily a bad title but not something I'd recommend spending $40 on unless you've got friends who like to play a lot.

Cannot recommend this game. It has tremendous potential but there are three things that just ruin it for me.

First, there's no actual character generation system in place worthy of the name, tho there are evidently quite many options on how your character COULD look. Instead it's a frickin dice-rolling system. You have to just be ready to spend a few hours rolling for frickin characters until you get one you can live with instead of just being able to create it yourself, and of course, they want money for further attempts (also in the "character selection menu" most of the characters shown do some sort of gesture or facial expression that heavily distort their looks so it's hard to tell if your character will actually look decent ingame or utterly ridiculous).

The second and even more annoying problem is one that way too many games have nowadays. Forced open world pvp. Honestly this game is one I'd like to play for a bit after coming home from work to relax a bit with a friend or two, however the way the game is set up you're going to invest hours and hours into accumulating loot... and it can all be taken away in just a few minutes by some griefer crew coming along just blowing up your ship while you're landed at an island somewhere faster than you can have any chance to defend yourself. 
Why in bloody hell does this game not have a frickin PvE Exclusive playmode? ... The way it is it just rewards griefing, is all I'm saying.

Last there's the annoying forced profanity filter for text chat. It is completely useless and very counter productive as most people in this game just insult you via VoIP anyway and it interferes heavily with text based conversations in ANY language other than english. Seriously I can understand people wanting a profanity filter, I can not understand it being forced on people tho.

Notes on the player experience: 
If you know how to fight and have friends to play with, this game will be a ton of fun. But if you can't do either then be ready to be run over by people who make it their priority 1 to ruin your day along with anyone else they come across. It's to be expected after all, because its basically in the name. If you really want to run into other people you can have some friendly banter with, then stick to the tactic of keeping your guard up and not attacking someone until the first shit has been fired.

This is the pirate game I dreamed about as a kid. The granular level of ship control is both easy to understand and difficult to master. With always-on multiplayer, every time you set sail it's a different adventure. I've made friends with strangers in pursuit of treasure, and vowed revenge against nemesis' for stealing my loot.

The game is harder when playing solo, but not impossible. However, playing with friends is where the game shines. The only limit to your shenanigans is your own imagination. 

All's fair in love and war though. Be prepared to spend hours gathering loot only to lose it all in an ambush by guys dressed like crab people. The open-ended nature of the game is either the best part about it, or the worst. There's not much structure to the experience, but that's all part of the charm of pirating. You never now what's going to happen.

[u]Sea of Thieves [/u]
A light, but romp on the seas with a healthy serving of total anarchy.

[list] The Good:
[*] Hands down the most satisfying sailing in a sea faring game you could find.
[*] Ship combat is absolutely brilliant.
[*] Story Mode is A+
[*] Rich in emergent gameplay and storytelling experiences. Every voyage feels like an adventure.
[*] Fabulous with friends
[*] The look and feel of this world is sublime, the Pirates of the Caribbean vibe is so rich and full of life. 
[/list]

[list] The Meh:
[*] Multiplayer is the main focus here, even though solo play is fun and tense, it's not for everyone. 
[*] Pvp is your biggest source of excitement, everything revolves around whether or not you're safe from prying eyes and bloodthirsty bandits. 
[*] Open Crews are a total toss up.
[*] New players are tossed into the thick of things pretty quickly. The tutorial is decently robust doesn't prepare players for pvp.
[*] Sword Combat is spammy, but has potential.
[*] Gun options range from very good to mostly ok. Nothing major to complain about outside of balance
[*] Lots of downtime is offset by the active sailing mechanics and constant lookout for player ships
[*] Gathering loot is time consuming and tedious, but constant vigilance for other players keeps this from being boring. 
[/list]

[list] The Bad:
[*] No real progression to speak of. Everything is in the cosmetics and what isn't is just the promise of quests with better loot.
[*] Quests and tasks are fairly same-y, its a lot of go here, do this, sell stuff. 
[*] There is not a lot of variety, there is lots to do to keep you busy, but session to session gameplay is largely the same with a few exceptions
[*] There is no end game. Reaching Pirate Legend is essentially status only and only promises longer, better paying quests. 
[/list]
    
Mid-Review Tl;dr
[i] 7/10 [/i]

Lots to do, little variety. If you can accept cosmetics as upgrades and play for gameplays sake, there's a lot on offer here that will keep you playing for a long time. However, make no mistake: other players and your interactions with them are the real core of this game. Be ready to protect yourself, kindness here is the exception, not the rule.

Review

I've got a feeling i'm going to stick with Sea of Thieves for a long time. Despite its flaws, the gameplay is just too compelling for me not to keep playing so i'm just gonna gush for a bit. There's a lot to love in Sea of Thieves and its come a long way since its release a few years ago. The devs have been incredibly active and gave this game a serious glow up. First of all the sailing is second to none, the moment to moment gameplay is honestly masterful, especially with a crew. Bailing water, fixing shit, firing cannons, boarding other ships, its all there and its all good. Sea of Thieves really has this secret sauce to it and that's the players. Love em or hate them, this game is pvp right to its core and it revels in that fact. Tasks might not be anything special, but nothing gives you quite the adrenaline rush that cashing in does after you've successfully defended your hoard. It takes run of the mill missions and amps up the energy tenfold. The pve events are also great fun. They don't change much but they offer a nice break in pace from the usual gameplay. Fort of the Damned, Skull forts, Flamehardt fleets, Skeleton Galleons, Krakens, Megalodons. Each one really pumps in a breath of fresh air especially when tensions are already high. Not even to mention the content that marks you right on the map, broadcasting your position to everyone. Reapers bounties and emissary flags just kick things up a notch. High risk, high reward, its fantastic. God damn, and every voyage feels so exciting, you just feel so plugged into the world. Everything just drips with flavor and its easy  to spend a few hours just getting lost in the grind.

This game isn't for everyone, it really isn't. Not everyone will appreciate the lack of progression, the limited variety, the grind, or the pvp, but if you're on the fence, i truly recommend it. Find a group of friends, or sail alone, sit down with a few drinks, find a few new friends, make even more enemies and just be a pirate for a little bit. To be honest, if you were sure you didn't want it already you probably didn't make it this far.

I'm only 10 hours in (feels like a bit more) but it's pretty awesome, if it's your thing.

In spite of the cartoony graphics (which are actually often-stunning) there's a real feel to actually being on the high-seas. It's crazy fun when you're feeling like an adventure. 

I can imagine though, that spending many hours doing the somewhat tedious tasks, only to be slaughtered by an experienced and mean crew (which is ultimately the major promotional point of the game) would be annoying.

Here's the catch though: Since everyone is essentially the same, there's no reason to get upset about it. It adds to the adventure that someone shows up when you least expects it and tries to take your loot. Suddenly you are in some fight with a bunch of randoms and if you're victorious, all the sweeter when you carry the loot into the sellers (another tedious task).. but if you lose.. what have you really lost? You had an adventure.. you didn't lose anything besides the ability to buy some pointless asthetic.. so don't worry about it! Have fun!

My only issue is the tedium.  There are lots of tasks that are annoying to undertake in large numbers. I am hopeful though that the monthly updates continue to bring more content, because this game has massive potential.

Points for aesthetics and musical score.  Demerits for toxic PVP, lack of separation between PVP and PVE, and shallow gameplay.  Definitely not recommended if you are a solo player; especially if you're a solo player who enjoys working with teams.

The endgame content of this title is literally "Go Ruin Other Peoples' Experience"

The core gameplay loop is very repetitive: Sail around either: 
1.) digging up treasure chests 
2.) shooting skeletons 
3.) playing UPS delivery driver.  
There is extra content, (giant sharks, krakkens, PVE raids) but in terms of progression, that's about it.  You learn very quickly that most side quests (random quests of the 3 varieties listed above that you can find in the world, via RNG) aren't worth that much, and you're better off doing the missions you buy at Outposts.  There are extra PVE quests with lore and fun characters, and they do attempt to expand (if ever so slightly) on the core gameplay.  Finishing these quests however, can be a bit more difficult, due to long runtime of the PVE quests, and the high chance of getting waylaid by another player crew.

The main problem arises with the PVP aspect of the game.  There is no distinction between PVP and PVE on the servers, so there's a very high chance another player (or group of players) will sink your boat, and nullify any progress you might have made toward a specific goal.  Unfortunately, when you have a niche-audience game that has been in release for multiple years, you wind up with these super-sweaty players that have literal hundreds of hours invested into this game, who are actively looking to ruin other peoples' play experience, since there's literally nothing else in the game for them to do.  There is also a high percentage of team-killing troll players who join open crews via the matchmaking feature just to cause mayhem.  Good luck trying to start, let alone finish, a PVE raid.  

It's pretty disheartening to attempt to unwind after work, and then have your entire play session feel pointless because of the toxicity of other players.  These are the same players who jump into messages boards going 'iTs sEA of ThIEVes, nOT sEa oF FriENdS!'

Good concept, pretty screenshots, amazing soundtrack, but unless you're tying to troll other people, your money and, more importantly, your time, is better spent elsewhere.

I want to start off by stating that I will revisit the game and plan on updating the review in the future. After 3ish hours this was my experience.

I played a duo sloop on adventure, we worked our way through the tutorial just fine and began our adventure. After spending multiple hours exploring a few islands and doing voyages with various riddles. We were attacked. Keep in mind, neither of us had even shot a cannon yet. Now an enemy with 8 or so people decide to raid and attack us. We were outgunned, outmaned, outleveled and, outmatched. The battle was over before it started. I marked an outpost on our map so we'd have the chance to sell our stuff before we were destroyed. We quickly discovered that they were much faster than us and they were tailing us to the outpost. We crashed the ship into the outpost and started gather our things. They rear ended us and immediately killed my friend. We tried respawning but eventually scuttled the ship. The PVP is so heavily imbalanced to whoever has more experience and friends that it's not even worth trying for a new player. We felt as if we had just lost all 3 hours of our progress with nothing to show for it but 1k gold. It was an extremely demoralizing experience and we decided to take a break. The tension we got from the fight was great but if we weren't so outmatched we would have actually had fun. How were we supposed to fight against them?

This game is a riot! While the main gameplay can be a little repetitive and the enemies (mostly the skellies and snakes and things) can sometimes be tedious or annoying, the true fun comes with interactions with player characters. There are only a few other players per server so you're not overrun and constantly fighting for your life, which I really appreciate. You can also ally with others and work together, or take them on and steal their plunders, which is fun depending on your mood. Plus playing with some pals is a really awesome way to hang out in this current climate. It'll suck your time away, be warned.

One thing I'd like to see are some kind of quality of life upgrades to the game. Not necessarily stronger guns or something where new players will just get pummeled but things like an better zoom on the rifle, a faster reload upgrade, or 2 more shots in your "magazine" just to give you a little edge but something that doesn't make you OP. As far as I can tell, all upgrades and items in the game are purely aesthetic. Maybe if the devs are responsive, they may consider something like this. I like the idea of keeping the playing field level, while at the same time offering up some little perks to give you a slight improvement.

I am also hugely grateful for the cross-play with Xbox players. Half my pals play on there and we link up with only minor issues revolving around the team chat settings, but there are work-arounds that are simple enough.

Lastly, I think the game visually is really really cool. The style is consistent, and there are little details that make it really fun to engage with and explore. The sound design is also AWESOME. You can hear cannonballs scream past you, feel like you're truly drowning if you fall off the ship in a storm, and experience the chaos when you're attacked by a Kraken! The ocean is really cool too, the shallows are rich with ocean plants and fish, but if you're out in the middle of the water and jump in, there is no bottom and it gives you that feeling of a deep dark ocean.

Overall I'd say highly worth picking up if:

- You have a few pals who will play with you.
- You're not too hung up on a story or progressing a character via upgrades.
- You have creative ways to engage with other players (befriend them, battle them etc)
- You enjoy the thrill of accruing treasure knowing it really doesn't lead to more than making your character more interesting to look at.

I really like it and have gotten a whole bunch of my friends hooked too. I could see this game kind of fizzling out over time, but for $40 it's worth playing around with for a while!

TLDR: Good game but don't buy this on Steam, get it on Microsoft store.

As someone else has said this game is horizontal in nature not vertical meaning you can do everything at the start of the game. This spooks some of the people who like grindy games to achieve a nice skin or new weapon but not I. The games core mechanics are very fun and I would definitely recommend the game if you are interested.

Only issues I've found with the game is that playing it from the Microsoft/Xbox application is a tad buggy and doesn't have ease of use features like choosing and SSD for an install path. There are also microtransations for currency that's used for skins which is a bit irritating in a game that already costs £35.

Getting this game on steam has no difference to getting it on Microsoft, for both you need to log in with your Microsoft account and you can't right click and "join friend" via steam - its honestly easier to do it through the crappy Xbox program.

I have now played this for some 46 hours and can honestly say I have enjoyed every minute of it. As a lone player it can be frustrating to gather some booty up and then have a galleon come bearing down on you and blow you out of  the water - but hey it's still great fun. Exploring the islands is great and the sea effects are wonderful and would do justice to a full blown serious sailing simulator. The quests are well balanced and once you have chosen a faction to sail for, the rewards are much better. Some of the other players are friendly and some are most decidely not - wanting nothing more than to sink you and steal your plunder, but it is called Sea of THIEVES - so the name does give the clue! It made me laugh on occasions, such as when I fought three skeletons and killed two of them, only to have the remaining one run away!! The cat I have as a pet on board is brilliantly done, someone obviously knows cats. At the end of the day I always think about a game like this - the cost is a few bottles of wine, they will be drunk and forgotten quickly - this will keep me happy  and amused for months to come - looked at like that it's a bargain. Great game, beautifully put together. If you are dithering then stop dithering and buy it - I seriously doubt you will regret it.

Great Game

Really good game. Really fun. However, very hard for new players like me to get started. You kinda just have to hope and pray your on a server with people that couldn't give a sh!t about plundering actual players. Basically, learn how to battle really fast. For me it's been 50/50. Your either in a server where every other player wants to kill you. Or your in a server where you never run into another player for hours. Right now I'm just trying to get more money to buy things so I don't look like a noob cos I feel like that's why I get targeted. No one appreciates new players, just takes advantage of that fact they are new and still learning the game. 

I do play this game alone. But only cos I'm trying to get more gold, and get far in the trading companies so that hopefully it's a bit better when I actually play with my crew. Game is WAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAY more fun with friends than it is on your own. But it is possible on your own. I actually defeated a fleet of ghost ships on my own.. Sure.. I lost my boat and was fighting from an island.... But I still did it. 

Ship battles are basically impossible on your own. While your repairing the ship they are still shooting at you. So, you have no time to shoot back at them. 
Also do be wary that I swear people teleport on your boat. Sometimes you will literally turn around and there is a person on your ship! 
Other than the awful PVP, I still recommend this game, mainly if you play with friends. You can play on your own, and if your okay with strangers, you can join a random crew. I did that once and got paired with a French man.. I can't speak French so I quit because this is the type of game where you need to be able to communicate. And this is why I wish I knew other languages but I can barely speak English sometimes.

The combat sucks. It's basically one of those mash the button if you've got a sword, and aiming a gun is stupid! I'm usually pretty good with aim in games, except games that DO NOT make it clear on where the gun is aiming..... Like this one... 
The quests can get frustrating at times. But they are still really fun. It's one of those frustrating moments that isn't necessarily bad, and it's probably your fault anyway. Like misreading the directions for example. I think in games it's okay to get frustrated. That's part of the fun. And I REALLY like games that it usually is your fault. I HATE games that glitch, or are just unfair and it usually isn't your fault. Those suck. But with this game, I always felt it was MY fault, and I think that's a good thing, cos the last thing you want in a game is for you to mess up and you KNOW it's not your fault. That is one of the worst things. But luckily, I've not encountered any of that with this game so far. 

Overall, really fun experience. Quests are fun. Better and easier with friends. Combat and pvp sucks. Some of the players suck. But I have seen some literally just ignore me before. Unless they just didn't see me. 
So yes, I recommend! But just be aware of the things I've said.

Sea of thieves is a game where quite literally anything can happen and in the blink of an eye you might get sunk if you're not paying attention. While grindy it is a good time mostly because each voyage you do or just random exploration can be different. A good example is I was trying to get a rare chest that is signaled to everyone in the game by fireworks or a marker on everyone's map. I was trying to get to the chest first and I was being followed by another player, but an AI enemy ship popped up so I shot a harpoon on the AI ship, the AI ship targeted the other player and so was I, since i was hooked and being led by said AI ship, I just focused on cannons and sunk the enemy. and in the blink of an eye, I entered the sea of the kraken and my tiny lil boat was dragged underwater. So quite literally, anything can happen and it is quite exciting.

I know i'll be boo'd for this but when the hype and novelty wears off you'll find this game is no more than that of a mobile game, its set up so you get a big ol dopamine hit every time you hand in a chest but other than that this game doesn't have much to offer. All the reviews im seeing are "HAHAHA funny le pirate game haha guys eat le banana" and no one wants to speak about the actual problems of the game.

The sword & gun gameplay is as flat and stale as a board and feels boring
you'll find yourself going from a to be to solve a riddle or find an x mark on your map to then return to a dock to hand everything in. Rinse and repeat & yes the "Tall Tales" are a more intricate version of what i just mentioned, you literally just go from a to b but it has uninteresting characters spewing dialogue & at times more fighting but it doesn't mean much when the combat is just woeful. This is literally it, too often you'll find yourself just mindlessly sailing going nowhere fast.

The ONLY progression in this game is cosmetics, so what is there to do when you've purchased the outfit you like best? i play with 3 friends and most of the time we were so bored we were forcing ourselves to make our own fun, we struggled to find many players & the arena lobby we joined failed to start after 30 minutes of us running around the starting lobby.
We defeated the "mighty" Kraken twice, both times we bombarded it with cannons and it just withered away into the water after a few minutes and left little to no reward. 

We all want to love this game but its nothing but a big yawn
after the novelty wares off you're left with a slow, tiresome game.

This game isn't for everyone, it does cater to a certain type of player and it is somewhat of an unusual beast, sitting in an odd place between casual and sometimes brutal, but always forgiving. The three main complaints I see for Sea of Thieves are it being boring solo, it's too grindy and the PvP aspects being too much. 

If you are the sort of player who likes to be given objectives and focus down, ignoring anything that isn't to do with your objective you are going to struggle with this game. Likewise, if you are the sort that enjoys grinding out max ranks as soon as you can and being rewarded with having the best stats in the game, you are unlikely to find much value in SoT. At the same time, if you were expecting a relaxing, sailing and sight seeing game and nothing more, you should think twice. 

Sea of Thieves is essentially a huge sandbox, with loads to do but nothing particularly telling you to go do it. The sort of player who can set their own goals and enjoys going and doing things because 'why not?' will find this game really rewarding. Sea of Thieves has so many little mechanics and very few restrictions or rules, it really encourages creative solutions to situations. If you enjoy this in a game and can accept that your rank and currency increasing is just a by-product of this and not something to obsess over, you will be right at home on Sea of Thieves. 

If you are expecting a persistent world where your actions change things long term you will probably be disappointed, there is a story and it is entwined with the landscape, characters and seasonal events, but it is never changed by a PvE event. For some people, this in a Sandbox PvPvE world is a deal breaker, but the PvE content serves a different purpose than usual. It is there to guide players toward interacting. This game really is about interacting with people, be it keeping well away from them or not. This game is the largest game of trust I have ever played. 

The game facilitates all kinds of interaction and it's why the blend of PvE and the PvP is perfect, because you find yourself making decisions and weighing up situations continually, which in turn gives you plenty of opportunity for creative problem solving. It's why there are no stats and why items are cosmetic, it levels the playing field and when it comes to PvP, having experience and not XP does pay off. This is where Sea of Thieves is fairly unique in the realm of Survival/Sandbox type games. You will learn that loot isn't anyone's until it's turned in, but at the same time losing it (and you will) to another crew or an angry sea monster isn't going to mean you are set back on levelling, unlocking gear and perks or upgrading something, there's no long term impact. That sort of penalty is eliminated here. 

The servers aren't persistent either so there's not the worry of having 'clans' or crews dominating a map or having people instantly gank you every time you try to play. The game is forgiving enough that it has lots of things in place to help you escape PvP situations too. The game is better with friends, as is most games. There's an auto-fill for your crew if you enjoy playing with randoms too, I have had mixed results with this. I still find this game very enjoyable solo, but it does change how you play depending on your crew. 

Lastly, I think it's really important to mention the way the DLC and seasonal content is handled. You can leave this game for months and still jump back in without any penalty. You never have to worry about log in bonuses and so far all the seasonal content, including map expansions, has been free. With the nature of the game, it kind of has to be. The only paid content is cosmetic/novelty such as pets which do nothing but look cute. You never need to feel locked into playing every day or worry that if you miss an event that you will be at a disadvantage and I think that from a game now days is rare. 

If you are the sort of player that enjoys, to coin a phrase, the journey and not the destination, you will find a lot of value in what Rare has done with SoT. If you can accept you will rank up by doing just stuff and you don't obsess over min maxing numbers, if you enjoy creative open game play and you enjoy the oddities of interacting with other players, you will hugely enjoy this game. It isn't for everyone and I can see why but I think there's value in a game like this and I can happily recommend that you give it a go at least.

I dont think I would recommend Sea of Thieves unless you for sure plan on playing the multiplayer aspect. It feels like a very aimless game where all you're doing is grinding to increase your rank with the trade unions, but there are zero upgrades for your characters, just tons and tons of achievements and challenges you're meant to work towards if you desire it. The only stuff you can purchase with in-game currency is cosmetics, so at the very least a new player is at the same playing field as someone who's played since day one.  Its definitely comparable to Elite Dangerous, but as opposed to a space ship galaxy mmo where its very wonder-filled and relaxing to journey through space, Sea of Thieves has lots of lore and stories to go through but leans more heavily on the journey rather than the destination. Its even built such that you can die and have your ship sink, but you still respawn with generic items for healing and shooting, and you can't keep items persistent between sessions, so unless you complete quests and purchase cosmetics, it feels like there's no unique loot for you to acquire and can get repetitive easily (which is why I dont recommend solo play).  Its sailing mechanics are also pretty great and top notch, if you have knowledge of real-life sailing practices you'll do well.

[b]My Review Score as of 7/16/2020:[/b]
 - Gameplay: [b]6/10[/b] (Open world multiplayer PvE/PvP, PvP is unregulated but PvE is decent)
 - Mechanics: [b]6/10[/b] (Easy to understand, moderately challenging to do)
 - Story: [b]4/10[/b] (Not really, but I get that's not the main point of the game)
 - Graphics: [b]8/10[/b] (Vibrant and toonish, yet enjoyable to watch. Surprisingly well animated)
 - Audio: [b]9/10[/b] (The sound and music in the game is pretty fantastic)
 - Community: [b]3/10[/b] (You may find some decent people, but best play this with a friend or two)

I don't think this is a play forever type of game, but certainly worth the money for the enjoyment to be had.

You can go solo or team up with a crew which will make things a little easier, as many tasks like manuevering. repairing, firing cannons are all called for simultaneously. 

The quests are fun, with treasure maps like X marks the spot or sometimes word puzzles. Missions from the merchants, bounties for skeleton captains, and gold hunting are all good pirate fun, as well as trophy fishing and ship combat or you can just sail of into the blue and see what adventure befalls you.

Loot is sold for dubloons which are used to purchase cosmetics only, so there is no pay to win, and indeed, it truly does not matter at all if you lose all your loot or not. 

A very fun and a little quirky, this is one of the best pirate games I have played.

So first off I want to say I absolutely love this game. Never bought it on Microsoft but I kept my eye out for a Steam release and when it finally came I waited till I had the time and funds to really sink my teeth into it (got injured from work so all I have is time right now) and I've had quite the experience so far.

The sailing is immensely fun. Being behind every single one of these ships is a pure delight and it feels just plain good to have control of either of the three ships provided. 

The non ship combat feels good to me at least and each weapon you get is well suited for their roles.

However, I do have a few negatives, but instead of bashing like I have seen before I thought I'd put my two cents in as constructively as possible.

The PvP has been fun at times and there's hardly been a time where I have even come close to getting upset with losing loot or something else. Now this comes from another highly loved game Elite Dangerous that I have played on and off since the beginning. 

Solo servers where you can only invite friends as well as open servers I think could be amazing, as the trailer does a very good job convincing you there IS a place in this game for solo players, and from what I have both heard and experienced first hand it can be, but is not always, a very tough task to accomplish. So here are a few things I have drummed up in my head while relaxing with a bit of fishing in game. 

1. NPC faction ships. This would be AMAZING as Elite Dangerous has random NPC ships you can encounter. Although the number of them in open servers would be minimal due to players currently playing and the size of the map. It could even go into you having an emissary flag on your ship and if you take down another NPC ship flying another flag you get a little bit of rep with your faction but ultimately not counting towards any multiplier.

2. Safe zones. I know I know, this probably rubs some people the wrong way, but in the instance of griefers and especially in the case of larger skeleton ships, there are some times where you are vastly outgunned by say a larger player/skeleton ship. Having an area where you are unable to sell anything or are unable to injure a player/damage a ship is almost like having a hub in MMOs where you are able to meet players and interact with them, and if done right giving an incredible social aspect. 

3. Ship scaling. There have been times where either solo sailing or with one other friend I have been decimated by a skeleton Galleon. It wouldn't be such a bad thing if the skeleton ships were proportional to what you were sailing especially since they are incredibly fast/accurate shots and love to use special rounds in their cannons. 

That's all I have really thought up in the amount of time I have played so far, and I just want to say I do not hate any part of this game nor do I think it is bad in any way. I genuinely love it and just wanted to say these few things as a means to maybe make this game even better. 

Again I absolutely love this game and haven't stopped playing since I have bought it and these are just plainly opinions and suggestions and honestly I have no clue how they'd implement these things. I tried to keep from sounding like I was complaining in the slightest and if it comes off that way I do apologize, because I've had a ton of fun so far and just wanted to say these few things as a means to maybe make this an even better experience not just for the PvP crowd or the PvE crowd, but for all types of players so that this playerbase can flourish and grow more and more as time goes on.

This game has the some of the highest highs and lowest lows I've experienced in multiplayer gaming. But all of them, every single experience I had - whether that be bad or good - was memorable. Whether that be taking revenge on a galleon that broadsided our ship as a spawn and sank us, or outrunning a brigantine for 50 minutes while forced to deal with literally every obstacle the world had to throw at us. You will play this game, and you will have a story. Maybe that story ends abruptly, from the business end of an enemy cannon. Maybe it's about the first time you ran into some of the world's obstacles. Or the time you soiled yourself mistaking a guard tower for an enemy ship on the horizon. Don't lie, we've all done it. But you will at the very least have one good story to tell your friends about the adventure you had in this silly little pirate game.  And one thing is for certain, it is absolutely meant to be played with friends. While it is doable by yourself, it's just so much better with other people. Because adventures, like stories, are best when shared.

We shall sail together.

This game had a rough start but its a diamond in the rough, and a VERY valuable diamond at that! A great game to play with friends, immersive sailing mechanics, and fun riddles to test your wits, and fun naval and island combat this game has a little something for everyone! Something that is quite refreshing is the game DOES NOT hold your hand! A game where you learn from your mistakes and become better for it!

The game is visually gorgeous, the music is top notch (every now and again giving sprinkles of nostalgia from classics like Banjo and Kazooie and DK64) 

Another plus is Xbox and PC players can play together!
The only downside I have is every now and again the servers do get a little laggy.

Sea of Thieves is overall a fun, relaxing and exciting game (especially with friends) and I hope it  grows from here!

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Good game just buy it.

[h1]Full review[/h1]
Good game just buy it.

[b]But seriously. I would recommend it, here's why.[/b] 

Most games i've played are quite linear or at some point start to give you an impression what you can expect the next time you play. This game is an unique experience every time you play. You can encounter other players that will go out of their way to make your ship sink. Or you meet people that will offer an alliance while downing a grog. Sometimes you won't see many people at all and you're busy getting some sweet loot and fighting off PvE enemies such as megalodons, krakens and skeleton fleets/ships. This randomness can make for great experiences thus making it one of the best story games out there since you write your own stories.

[u]Just be warned that Thieves is in the name, stealing loot or getting your loot stolen is part of the game as painful as that can be sometimes. But remember that it keeps it tense and fun, even if you disagree in the heat of the moment.[/u]

I think Rare did a great job saving this game and actually starting to turn it into a masterpiece.

Too tired to write an elaborate review after a 10h turbo grind, but this game is SO FUN. It's SO fun and SO addicting, even though it has it's issues WITHOUT A DOUBT. I'd say the two major issues are bugs and pirate legend being useless. Sometimes it feels like it lacks content and like the content is so one dimensional because, well, it honestly is if you don't make it fun yourself. PVP is probably the most fun thing to do, but sometimes athena quests and PVE (like grinding the FotD) are the thing you want to do most. It's a sandbox game and that really describes it well imo. It has one dimensional content which is maybe not the best game design, but it's a fucking playground. Go play and make it fun for yourself. Don't complain about silly things or things you can't change, but learn to accept them and then use them as fuel for your endeavors.

This game has many issues but overall I'd give a big fucking thumbs up for this game. I wholeheartedly recommend it, but you gotta know what you're getting into before buying it yourself. Don't cry about being killed multiple times or getting your loot stolen, it's a PIRATE GAME after all.

[h1] Prepare To Destroy Your Expectations... [/h1]
[i] ...in a positive way that is! [/i]

Sea of Thieves was one of my highlights since the time it was launched on Microsoft Store. Not being a big fan other platforms, I hesitated to purchase the game in order not to strict myself with Xbox and Microsoft's features and only particiapated a little in free trial of SoT. And those 30 minutes were the best moments and I cannot trade it with anything else. And now, Sea of Thieves is here alongside everything majestic it brings.

[list]
    [*]Gameplay
In Sea of Thieves, there is [b] vast adventure and experience [/b] awaiting for you and when I say vast, I mean it. Prepare yourself for continuous interruptions for your expectations. Are you planning to do a voyage? Expect countless PvE and PvP encounters. Planning to land on an island? Perhaps it will erupt. Sailing from one island to another? The things that are awaiting for you in the sea...

In Sea of Thieves, you have two dominant objectives. Exploring and earning. By exploring, you will experience various weather conditions that shape the gameplay (fogs, thunders, big waves), new locations that differ from eachother (volcanic islands, islands with PvE encounters). Your main tasks for gaining, however, has many ways. You can do voyages that require you to do a treasure hunt, fight, or package delivery. 

When you look through a narrow perspective, Sea of Thieves sounds like a "reputation farming" game. But the maing thing in Sea of Thieves is not just these quests but everything else you encounter throughout these voyages and quests.

For those who hate [b] Player-versus-Player [/b] experiences, I highly advise you to get your team of pirates together and dive into this experience. The community is always welcoming and you should take advantage of this to sail together to have the maximum experience.

[*]Design
I believe it is an obligation to create a sub-category for this in Sea of Thieves. The aesthetic of the sea is the highlight of this game. In all of the conditions, sea has a different role and an appearance and all of them are unique. Truly the "sea" in Sea of Thieves is one of the most aesthetic features in the game. Other than that, the game shares not-entirely "cartoonish" look from its character design to monsters. The ship cosmetics also provide no benefit, but surely they are one of the most beautiful things to explore between tons of varities.

[*]Soundtracks, Microtransactions, Final Note
The team behind music of Sea of Thieves crafted such beautiful components that you can feel each and every experience in the game in a different way. Got a massive shark attacking your ship? Here is your intense theme. Raiding a fort? Here is your sinister theme. Attacking an army of ships? Here, have another intense theme. The soundtrack is amazing.
Microtransactions in the game provide no gameplay benefit, so it is just cosmetics. Additionally, you can purchase pets that are only available with microtransactions. 

[/list]

[h1] Sea of Thieves is the game that we all needed for both PvE and PvP experience combined. It rewards you for your enthusiasm and participation in the game and keeps you playing. [/h1]

It's a pirate game. And it is great. As long as you know what to expect.

So let's summarize what to expect:
1. This is a [b]full online[/b] game. You will see other crews and they can attack you as well as you can attack them. You are not alone on the sea.
2. [b]Sailing[/b] a pirate ship [b]is not easy[/b]. Set Sail, retrieve anchor, turn sails in the ever turning wind, use the steering wheel and shoot with canons are individual stations. While you have to repair the ship under deck.
3. This is [b]mostly a coop/group game[/b]. While you can play the game solo, I would recommend to have at least 1 friend. The more the merrier! And it makes ship fights easier and even Captain Jack Sparrow had a crew most of the time. Your crew size is between 1 and 4 people with 3 different ship sizes (1-2, 1-3, 1-4) each having pros and cons.
4. [b]Expect to lose your loot[/b] at any time, especially in your first few hours. The Kraken whose weakness you dont know perfectly, other players stealing your stuff while you kill some skeletons on an island or losing to an enemy ship in an epic battle. 
5. There is [b]no "better weapon"[/b] or any think like that. In this game [b]you play for visual upgrades[/b] only. Your cannons wont have more damage if you get the epic Kraken skin on it. Battles are won by skill.
6. And yea. [b]You should know how to read maps and a compass[/b]. Or you will not find your target. Because [i]- you know -[/i] pirates have no minimap.

If you [b]know this, accept it[/b] and buy the game, you will [b]have a lot of fun[/b].

I've played Sea of Thieves for a few weeks now and there are both pros and cons to this game...

First of all, I highly recommend playing the game with friends! I've played both as a solo player and with a group, and the latter is a much more enjoyable experience. Don't get me wrong, playing solo is fun as well but you become easy prey for larger crews/ships who can overwhelm your one-man Sloop in literally seconds - meaning that your hard earned loot can be easily plundered - making the past hour of treasure hunting completely mute.

Pros:
- The game looks truly stunning! The stylised design keeps the game lighthearted and the environments/ocean look exceptional.

- Managing your ship is a lot of fun. Players have a choice between three types of ship: the Sloop, the Brigantine and the Galleon. Each ship is harder than the other meaning that you will require more hands on decks to help with the sails, look-out and cannons.

Players need to actively resupply their ships with food (to regain health) wood (to repair the ship) and various types of cannonball. 

- The supplies in this game are completely free. Each dock you start at has a number of supply barrels with the supplies you need. All you need to do is simply pick them up and store them in your hold. You can then find a great many supply barrels or chests throughout the world to stock up.

- Combat is fun! Especially with a crew! But watch your ammo - this can run out quickly if you've forgotten to resupply your cannonballs!

- Every player...and I mean EVERY player have the exact same weapons. There is absolutely ZERO play-to-play in this game! Player have limited ammo on their person but your ship has an ammo chest with unlimited ammo and a weapons chest where you can change your weapons loadout. Weapons CANNOT be upgraded with more powerful ammo, stopping power etc - winning a fight is purely a contest of either skill...or greater numbers.

The same goes for the ships. Although the bigger the ship - the more cannons - but the cannons, themselves, are all the same.

Sails cannot also be upgraded, nor can the hull. Unfortunately, the bigger the ship - the more sails - therefore; more speed!

- The puzzles for missions or random treasure hunts are really fun. It requires you and your crew to decipher clues which require tasks or just finding the spots that mark you to that all important 'X'.

- Navigating storms and coming across ghost ships or skeleton ships adds to the random events in the game. You could be sailing happily with your crew, playing a sea shanty with your instruments and then a ship will literally emerge from the ocean and start attacking.

The storms throw your all important compass off, meaning you or a member of your crew need to relay instructions from the interactive map, below deck, and the rain from the storm also floods your ship - which means someone also has to be on bailing duty! 


Cons:
- There is a severe lack of progression in the overall game. All money you earn in the game is only spent on cosmetics (which is fine) but it would be nice to add GTA V style businesses in the game i.e. owning your own docks, buying a pirate lair or a trade business and then trying to fend off rival pirate clans etc. This would add a lot more depth into the game.

- There is rarely a friendly player in the game! You are literally, constantly scanning the horizons or nearby islands for other sails.

Bigger ships tend to also prey on smaller ships for easy kills and loot. If you're in a Sloop and you spot a  Brigantine or a Galleon...you better sail like hell! 

- There are NO safe ports in Sea of Thieves! You and your crew can be docked at a port either buying cosmetics for your ship or character, finding a new mission or even getting drunk at the local tavern and then all hell brakes loose when another crew decides to attack your ship as it's docked, raid any supplies you have or even kill you.

- The servers are extremely odd and can make for some painful experiences!

You may log onto a server and be on for an hour or so, but there may only be you or another one or two crews - max - on the server. The server will then decide to migrate everyone onto a more populous server - however! It does not relocate you to another server within your region, but rather one where you will get the HIGHEST ping known on the seven seas! Meaning that you can expect regular disconnects, major lag and clipping.

This server issue is even more annoying as a player cannot just reconnect to another server from the in-game menu. To do so, one has to completely log out of the session (loosing all your supplies and or booty) and then reconnect and start from scratch! 

Conclusion:

All in all, the game is a lot of fun - especially when you're with friends. Graphically it looks amazing, the gameplay is fun and doesn't require a lot of practise and the sailing mechanics/ship management only adds to the pirate experience. 

Solving puzzles, taking on hordes of skeletons can be challenging and can often be rewarded with an ton of gold and or riches, however, with no real progression system the game can feel a little lack-lustre here and there. Trolling players can be a real pain in the ass and the servers REALLY DO NEED SORTING OUT!

This is an open world pirate game; there is really not much more you can say about this without playing. It allows you to sail the seven seas with an appearance of your choice. The combat is very symmetrical, and all of the progression is in cosmetic items and clout-titles. It is mostly a game about securing loot which can be turned in for rewards, but you have to be weary of other pirates who come to steal your loot before you can turn it in. 

The game has a pretty unique feel with a lot of attention to detail. This game is mostly made up of the little things like playing instruments in sync with your shipmates, finding buried treasure after solving a riddle, watching your enemies sink to the bottom of the seafloor. Most of the game is about learning new mechanics and you'll get a lot of enjoyment if you skip the wiki.

GREAT GAME (A review from a solo slooper)

This game reminds me of CSGO a bit. Hold up, keep reading.

The mechanics, and controls are unlike most other games you've ever played, especially if you've never played World of Warships, and don't know how to aim arms from a ship. You'll need to learn, even with a crew, to balance all 3 aspects of maintaining the vessel. Captaining, Shooting, and Bailing. CSGO like learning curve? Check.

The community gives no shits that its your first time playing. They dont care that you have no clue what your doing, and they don't care that you JUST spawned. Why would they? Aside from being a game about PIRACY, who would know how new you are? Just hurry up, clear out some barrels off the dock, drop that sail and get a move on! You can at least see possible enemies and strat your way out of danger. And if you do get sunk off the rip, who cares? Go fight the guy, die, and you'll respan with a fresh ship on a lonely a$$ island. Soooo CSGO like comunity toxicity? Check.

But once you get over the newbie starting line, figure out how to sail a bit, learn to read the ocean and the skies, all the mechanics BLAH BLAH BLAH...you suddenly realize you can hang. Once you realize you can hang, you start "gittin gud" and then you'll be just as well equipt as anyone else in the server. Even as a solo slooper. Sure as a solo I avoid fights like plagues, but it doesn't mean your toast because a Galleon rolled up on you. I've solo toasted a 3 man Galleon. It aint easy, but big ships are full of dummies that can't play together or communicate, so the fire of anarchy lights as soon as they take a round. CSGO like addiction rateing? As I'm writing this, my ENTIRE keyboard and moniter is swaying. I physically feel like I'm on the waves, despite only playing this game for a few days now. Check, yes, most DEFINITELY CHECK CHECK CHECK.

If your OK with a BLISTERINGLY challenging learning curve, keeping your wits on you at all times, and possibly setting up in your bathroom so you can continuously puke in the tub until you get your sea legs, get the game. Do the Maiden Voyage, at the start of the game, jump into an open matching on a Galleon, and refuse to captain it. Use the crew to help guide your learning curve, then try closed matching by yourself in a sloop to learn to sail like a boss. You'll get there.

Oh, a quick tip: NEVER, upon finding cursed cannon balls place them in the ships barrels. You sink, they sink. Keep them in your invin and you'll respawn with em after death.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME WITHOUT RESEARCH. RARE HAS LIED TO YOU ABOUT THE GAME.

Hopefully you paid attention to that intro.

The game is not PvP or PvE, the game is PURELY PvP and PvPvE. There is no pure PvE mode (hypocritical on Rare's part, there is a PvP mode)

If you are looking for a Rust style game based on the sea, then you get Rust in it's community glory. The PvP is ok, the people are garbage human beings, and it's all sweat all the way down.

If you are looking for family friendly fun time, easy sailing, or anything calming and enjoyable, (As the style and Rare would like you to believe is possible) DO NOT. BUY. THIS. GAME.

The intro alone means you can't refund the game due to the starting length based on steam's requirements.

I repeat, PVP is how the community sees the game. It may be a PvPvE game, as the mechanics show, but the community is Shoot and Kill first, be friendly so far to second that first died of old age.

To recap, if you spend 3 hours having fun with a friend, you WILL have your things stolen and all your hard work removed with no way to get it back.
There is no progression system, so you lose everything.

I can't recommend this game. I wish I could refund it.

First things first: I am not a big fan of pvp only games and since nobody of my friends was willing to buy the game, the first two hours I was alone on my sloop. 
In fear I just rotated in the crow's nest with the spyglasses in my hands, looking out for others players. 
I even took it that far, that I was searching for a pve only solution for the game.
After the third hour, without seeing any other player, I finally calmed down a bit and started to enjoy the unique style of the game.

Then in the fourth hour, of course with treasure in the hold, I met a crew of three players.
Anchoring in front of an island I ran back to my ship, of course frightening that they will just drown my sloop.
But instead I was lucky, they just waved and sailed along.

Then I realized, the pvp part is adding the thrill. 
Humans are interesting little unpredictable little fricktards.
A pve only game would become easy to predict after a while.

So all in all, it is nice to have a quick jump into the game, playing solo, enjoying the atmosphere and playing at my own pace, but obviously the game is meant to play with others.
So I tried the open crew feature choosing a sloop and met a really nice guy, who was willing to explain me the basics. 
The next day, hyped from the day before, I tried the feature again, this time for the three-master.
And hey, I can say, I really cannot recommend to do that :D
Four completely random persons on a big ship, two of them without a microphone, the third sounded like he was sitting in a meeting in homeoffice, playing SoT alongside.
It was a mess!

If you play solo or with a crew, I can just recommend to use a headset.
First part is to enjoy the great ambient noise, 
the second is about communicating with others, 
without typing mile-long sentences while the ship is sinking.

If you are new (like me) just try it solo on a sloop, I mean, there is nothing to loose at all, 
since all rewards are cosmetics only.
There are youtube channels from experienced players who are explaining 
what you should consider while playing alone.
There are also discord channels with other people looking for a crew.
And since I have no friends............ that are playing Sea of Thieves of course,
I am also happy about every invite to play SoT with you.

This review I am writing after 7 hours into the game.
Maybe I have to adjust it after a few more hours,
if I was just lucky so far and now I am approaching many more hours 
of toxic behaviour and seal clubbing :)
But I really hope it is the opposite!

A 7/10 game that would very easily be 9/10 if a few key problems were addressed.

Despite the developers' wishes, PvP should not be mandatory. The times when a long quest or world event are interrupted by an unruly player are disheartening and are pure feelbad moments, especially after spending several hours gathering treasure. I understand that this is a pirate game, but the current way PvP is handled leads to extremely unhappy play sessions.

With that out of the way, however, the game is a great time when all goes well, easily able to steal hours of free time as you sail from harrowing adventure to harrowing adventure. There is a serious sense of pride when besting a kraken encounter or taking down an ambush from rowdy skeleton pirates as you fill your hold with a literal boatload of loot. Environmental storytelling is also great, with deep lore easily accessible to those who would like to look for it. If you have a group of friends you can reliably play with, you can find yourself clocking in hundreds of hours sailing on the Sea of Thieves.
