TL;DR: Yarghh Harghhh, the seas be a cruel mistress but opportunity for glory be a foot! Errrr, rather, a peg there matey.

For someone who has been looking for a pirate game for a real long time, having played Sid Meier's Pirates, Black Flag, Atlas, and a few others, this game feels like a happy ending to my journey searching.

When you're on the ship, the water feels real, the sailing feels heavy, and aiming your cannons feels like it makes all the sense in the world. Are the quests a little repetitive by nature? Yes (each of the 3 main factions sports 2 types of quests). Is that what this game is about? No. As many YouTubers, Streamers, and people who play the game will tell you, it's not completing the quests that makes the game fun. When you're sailing from island to island completing the various quests, it is what happens during that time that makes the game fun. Your map will never be going from Point A to Point B and back to Point A again. Sure, it will be dead sometimes, but maybe another player shows up, a Kraken, a storm, skele galleon, or you accidentally sail into Flameheart. "Oh wait, is that a fort over there? FotD? Let's go." Maybe it's all of the above.

I've only played for around 60 hours and haven't really noticed any bugs. If there are any, I haven't really noticed them because I was too busy enjoying the game. Can sword and gun mechanics be a little wonky? Sure. Am I a pro? No. So I could very well be making mistakes. I also don't feel that my negative interactions with other sailors is worthy of if the game should be considered good or bad, solo slooping ain't easy, that ain't the games fault.

Whatever problems I've had with the game, have been blended in with all the good content that I've enjoyed. Highly recommend to those people who love a good Pirate RPG.

For the creators: I think an idea for future content could be 4-8 rare NPC pirates like Blackbeard or w.e. that rarely spawn on the map. Have their own faction as well with an island in the center of the map, maybe that island has a map that shows if there is a current NPC on the map and where but that would be the only place you could see their location unless you stumbled on them. After killing them 5-10 times, you could unlock their livery's. Their loot could be something different like a special flag like the emissary flags that you could sell to that centralized island for big money. Maybe make the initial wave like 2 of their captains on the map before they themselves spawn so you have to kill them first.

I'm writing this review, because at the time I bought the game for myself and my daughter, I had no idea that it was PVP only. And I think it's important that people know it's PVP only, and that Rare has no intention of adding PVE...EVER. So buyer beware before you invest in this at-times fun, but frequently frustrating time-sink of a game.

For all its piratey goodness, Sea of Thieves by Rare has a single wart...and it's a big, nasty one - there is no PVE mode and there are no PVE servers. Try as you might to enjoy the PVE aspects of the game, the PVP'ers will not leave you alone to quest and PVE in peace - it can mean literally hours of wasted time, since collecting and turning in your loot is a time-intensive process. This is doubly annoying because the game is so grindy when gaining coinage and reputation.

All of the PVP'ers are folks who have been playing for 100s of hours and have mastered the game - so when they prey on newbies like myself and my daughter, it really is indistinguishable from griefing. There have been dozens if not hundreds of requests for Rare to release PVE servers, and deep down inside the Rare devs must acknowledge there's a problem, and keep the PVE'ers from fleeing the game after more than a couple of hours. 

First, Rare released PVE-style Tall Tales, which are fun, but you will still be PVP'd while trying to complete them. Second, Rare released the Emissary system, which attempts to put a bandaid on the PVP / PVE situation, but all it really does is create bonuses for PVP'ers - it doesnt protect or disincentivize the PVP'ers from preying on the new and unskilled. Finally, Rare has gone to great lengths to ensure new ships that spawn into a server, spawn far away and isolated from the other ships that are already there. Rare is clearly aware of the issue but only bandaids the problem and doesn't deliver the real solution - PVE servers or PVE/PVP only flags.

Another tell here is that anytime someone requests a PVE mode or PVE server, the PVP trolls come out of the woodwork to try and shut down all discussion. Which makes you realize, the anti-PVE mantras of "its how the game was designed" and "its a PIRATE game" are just cover stories masking the truth: the PVP wolves need a steady supply easy-to-fleece sheep to maintain their egos and their loot supplies. They know that if Rare ever released PVE servers, the PVPers would be stuck to themselves - funny how they don't want THAT level of PVP challenge.

It's a mystery to me why Rare has its head in the sand regarding PVE and chooses to miss out on all the revenue the PVE community represents. In any case, once my daughter and I finish all the Tall Tales, we will be sailing on to better games that value PVE customers - I hear Deep Rock Galactic is pretty fun.
That will be perfect if we have PVE only server; fuck it if we don't.

Ok so first thing - this game is cool.  Great visuals, fun atmosphere, lots of well thought out attention to detail and such, the sailing mechanics are great fun with a friend.  It could be fantastic.  BUT - I haven't even been playing long and I see a major problem: what's the point?  The point seems to be pretty much entirely cosmetics.  That's really all you can do with gold besides purchase more contracts to get more gold. There are no real upgrades to speak of.  No better hulls, or weapons, or even things that you can trade off one thing for another to 'balance' it but still more attune to your playstyle.  Everything is the same except the way it looks. Sure, I like cosmetics - but not that much.  So where does that leave me?  What's the core gameplay loop that will keep me going?  PvP?  Well most PvP games you get to unlock some 'upgrades' which allow customization to fit your playstyle.  And lets be honest, if I want to run PvP there are other more robust options for me to choose from to scratch that itch.
Buy it if you like pvp.  Avoid it if you don't.  People will follow you and grief you while you just want to explore.

I've been playing video games for a long time and I've never experienced such a video game. It's incredibly unique. You get to sail the seas on either a small, medium, or large ship and simulate being a pirate. You can embark on voyages, and dig treasure, you can do Tall Tales, which are playable stories throughout the world. You can solve riddles, puzzles, etc. It is also a shared world, meaning you can come across other players, who more often than not are very hostile.

This is essentially an open world shared pirate experience, and it's amazing. However, this game is very much for the experiences. No progress is made whatsoever, you can embark on legendary quests and recieve tons of gold after completing them, but this gold is only spent on cosmetics. The game is about playing, earning money, and buying yourself some cool stuff essentially. There is absolutely no purchaseable items that progress you. I thought this was a little bland, I love the game but I would like to see atleast some unlockables.

Overall, this game is pretty amazing, I'd give it a 10/10, play it with friends and you'll have a great time.

Don't waste your time. This game takes all of the worst elements of End-Game-MMO's and makes it the core gameplay. There is no progression; no story progression, no weapons to buy, to upgrades for you ship, you are as powerfully at the start of the game as you will ever be. The only things you can actually buy are cosmetics for a ship you barely see as the game is entirely in first person. There are no classes so there are no different skills or play styles to choose from, only one type of enemy. All of the quests are procedurally generated fetch quests ; go to this island that's like all of the other and kill skeletons/collect animals/ dig up a box.

The blurb on the steam page says you can do the following :

Sailing : This is true...yay...

Fighting : you only have a sword and gun, one attack animation, and no upgrades. There isn't anything to fight except the same skeletons over and over and over again. Maybe you can fight other players but I haven't seen any, or seen a reason to fight them, especially since the game now has a dedicated PVP Arena.

Exploring : There's plenty to explore, but no reason to. The islands are all the same. Beach, a few trees, a cave with nothing in it. There is nothing to find except the occasional journal or piece of "treasure" if you're lucky. Because you start the game as powerful as you'll ever be, you can go anywhere from minute 1 and never feel like you're making progress through the world.

Looting : The only reason to kill other players or go exploring is to get gold. The only reason to get gold is to get cosmetics, That's literally all it is good for. You can't even buy consumables like food or cannon balls because those are found littering every island you go on.

Additionally, it seems the multiplayer aspect of this game is gank/grief oriented and Kill-On-Sight. Every player I've met so far has immediately rammed my ship, killed me and stuck around to kill me again when I respawned. Even when I'm off my ship on an island, they highjack the ship, with no treasure on it, run it aground, and kill me when I come back and spawn camp me afterwards. It's toxic and annoying and the community practically encourages the behavior. 

This game had a lot of potential but squandered it on lazy design, it's all of the tacked-on ignorable features from every other game lumped into one large disappointing pile of nothing. Hour 5 will be same as hour 500. If you want a good pirate game go play AC:Black Flag. If you want good naval combat go play Blackwake, if you want good story based island hopping go play The Raft. There's no real reason to play Sea of Thieves unless you like making ships look pretty.

Do i like Sea of Thevies. Hell yes
Do i recomend it though....ehhh
SOT is a very fun game, especially with friends and it certaintly has done a lot to fix the issues it had at launch, but there are a ton of issues that make me occasionally a bit mixed on it.
- Forced microsoft intergration. It does allow cross-platform but it is a pain to deal with. You cant even join friends over steam. Because of Microsofts crappy feedback and help and randomly locking accounts, i got locked out of this game for a good 2 weeks. Oh and by the way, once an account is locked to SoT, its locked to steam. If you lose it, tough.
- Glitches, my god. Minor stuff like constant t-posing to massive audio issues, loot despawning, teleporting and all sorts. Half of them have been unfixed since *launch*
- No bounty system makes pirating rather boring and doesnt give a good risk or reward to doing or fighting against it
- Tall tales are mostly very boring and repetivie, when the game asks you to beat each of them *five times*
- Server lag and performance issues, still very problematic
- Zero progression. Money is for cosmetics and nothing else. Progression though the emissaries gets more cosmetics. Pirate legend gets more cosmetics. Theres *nothing* tangable gained from your progress at all. 
- Impossible to join servers. Got more than 4 people looking to play? Tough.
- No saving at all. Your ship and all its contents are lost the moment you log out or sink.
SoT is a game thats very fun, dont get me wrong but there are so many issues that havent been addressed in its 2 year lifetime that its a little tricky to fully recomend. If Steam had a third "kinda" recomendation, id give it that
A really fun game with loads of adventures..
yee

Sea of thieves is an amazing game to play, solo or with friends.

Unfortunately it got a bad reputation at launch. People (correctly) called it out for a lack of content or things to do in it, and most people have stuck with that opinion regardless. The developers, much like No Mans Sky, have worked tirelessly to fill the game with plenty of content but that reputation remains. Only after buying the game for various friends did I manage to shake their perception!

The game has two states. It can be very peaceful, almost zen. Sailing the seas, hanging with friends, fishing off the deck while you wait for the wind to change and pick up speed.

It can also be brutal, attacked by a kraken while fending off another player, trapping you with them and low supplies while you desperately try to protect your treasure.

All in all, if you're on the fence, I say check it out. With steams refund system you can play the tutorial and do a mission or two before your two hours are up and decide if this game is for you. I was Pirate Legend before this ever came to steam, and I plan to play a lot more in my future.

While solo play is possible it is not practical. The current "meta" is boarding an enemy ship, so again something you can not do as a solo player. Boarding is way to simple. Just jump in the water or launch yourself from a cannon, if you miss the enemy ship don't worry you can re-spawn onto yours in 15 seconds for another try...
Decent with friends I suppose but it's all just a chase for cosmetics.
the grind is real, but isn't to bad. Keeps you in it until you reach your goal. overall a great game.
B
Heavily recommend playing with friends. Yes, you can play solo, but it's a bit bothersome managing a ship on your own.

A small tip: If you are the person to struggle starting the game, read through.
I have saw multiple comments that are complaining about the difficulty connecting to xbox sometimes, so I decided to help some people out.
If you have Windows 10, search for "xbox" in the search bar, and open Xbox Console Companion, and you have to make an account in the Xbox platform when you open the console companion, there will be short instructions on how to make an account (almost like making a google account). And after you made an account, and start the game it will ask you if you want to attach your steam account to the xbox account. Press "Yes". And then you will be able to proceed to the game!

Mark this comment helpful if it helped you out.

This is a game that gets repetitive pretty easily, go here, do some digging, go over there, do more digging, you get the point.. there are things to do in this game besides digging up treasure, like raiding forts, solving puzzles, random events that happen while sailing,  or fighting a.i ships ( including player ships ) , also there are stories called tall tales you can do which can be entertaining for a little while but can get bland and tedious after sometime. A lot of times the people you play with if they're random won't know what their doing, other times they'll know exactly what they're doing but wont do anything and make you do all the work. Which reminds me.. this game feels like work, as in a job sometimes. though it does have it's moments of being fun and entertaining, you will hit a point where you will feel nothing but fatigue and boredom as you progress, and the current fun factor of the game becomes less and more questionable. I think this game is interesting especially when you come across people who like to role-play, but that is a very rare sight to see sadly. If you were to buy this game I would wait for a sale, or get it on another platform where its potentially cheaper, because this game may or may not be for you, especially, if you aren't a patient person that can get bored or frustrated pretty easily.

Sea of Thieves,

This game is definitely worth the buy. This pirate game is about teamwork and plundering gold from islands and shipwrecks, sometimes if ships you've beaten yourself. In the game, you play between 3 different ships, each one of them being different from each other but is used by either 1/2, 3 or 4 crew members. You have to manage sailing through the tough seas of thieves as you try and build reputation with 5 different alliances. Each having an objective of their own.

I don't want to write a very large review so I'll try and conclude. This game is really fun with friends and even by yourself if you enjoy the pirate's life at sea. Due to it's style, modern computers will be able to run this game well and at good quality. 

So if you decide to get this game, then be prepared to fight to keep your treasure among the thieves that rule these seas!

Man... what to say about Sea of Thieves... This game is fun honestly and with a group of people its a blast and there's quite a bit of content to keep you and your friends playing for a while, but its got some major issues. Ill detail my thoughts on those.

When I say there is a lot of content, there is. There are different factions and lots of levels to grind and rep to grow and lots of add on's for the ships but the big major flaw here is its all almost the same. The factions have you do a few different mission types whether its killing skeletons or digging up treasure chests, but in the end its all the same. If you go to dig up chests, you will fight skeletons, if you go and deliver loot, you will most likely find some maps for treasure... and skeletons. It just ends up feeling all the same, go here kill some stuff, sell the loot. It's fun for a while sure, but its empty. The longer it goes on the quicker it wears out its welcome. 

The game is pretty risk free and you really start to notice, I have over a million gold and so nothing really matters if you die, the worst is that you will lose some loot on the boat and really this is only a big deal if you havent sold stuff in a few hours and if you are smart you can basically pass by outposts and sell a few things here and there and thats if someone is really REALLY chasing you. Most people just give up.
The risk free part makes fight worth a lot less and to be honest if someone really wants to get away from you, they pretty much can, unless you are able to catch someone sitting in the water or they have the anchor dropped, its hard to catch someone who is just focused on running away. I dont have a good solution to this but Ive had lots of time sitting in the boat sailing even pace with a boat in front of us, waiting for them to stop or turn or do something and then an hour has passed and we get bored and pull off.
I dont have the perfect solution to this, but it seems to many things are focused around the game being safe and honestly pretty easy. 
Give us a way to up the stakes.


I'll talk about a few positives before I talk about my biggest gripe.

The sea is amazing, it looks good, it feels real honestly this game is a boat sailing simulator with pirate stuff added in and thats a good thing, they did a great job. Skeleton forts are fun and can be a bit of a challenge from time to time. This game does a great job of adding a lot of value playing with more people, its honestly not to good alone but every time you add another person you really feel a different angle of play.

So on to my main issue. This game has so many bugs! Bugs that honestly really mess with the game play and are sometime game breaking and these reasons are the biggest reason I cannot recommend this game. 

1. The compass on the boat sometimes will just not work, its annoying having to let go to check your personal compass.
2. Music often wont play with instruments, but often times shipmates can hear it but I cant or vice versa. 
3. Sometimes me and my friends cant drive the dingy, it simply wont let us grab the oars and drive.
4. I experience a game breaking bug where my pause menu will open and will not close, I've tried closing it time and time again but the only thing that will work is closing the game, this is crazy detrimental to the game because I cant eat or grab wood, if this happens I pretty much have to close the game down instantly and reopen it.
5. The game often thinks you are stuck and will go dark and teleport you back to the boat for no reason?
6. You will get stuck in a rock or in a tree... and wont teleport you back to the boat.
7. Loot will constantly sink in the water, pretty much if you see seagulls in the sea above some loot, move fast because as soon as you get close it will drop. This use to happen once in a blue moon, but recently its about every time or more we go to loot in the water.


The game is fun and I dont regret my time put into the game, and I hopefully will keep playing but this game has been out for years. Fix the bugs. If the game continues to run in this state, I know I wont stay for long.

EDIT: I'm just adding on to this review. Its been another 20 hours or so since I wrote this review and the bugs are continuing to grow. Loot is dropping more rapidly and it seems about 1 out of 3 skeleton boats are not dropping loot, and I have taken a few screen shots of my boat floating into outer space.... How is this game getting worse?
I'd highly recommend this game. Sea of Thieves allows you to be as aggressive or evasive as you want to be. It's pretty much as sandbox as it gets while still having a lot to do. Big props Rare.

If you want some swashbuckling pirating adventure time, I feel there's no better game out there currently. Since Sid Meier's Pirates came out, I have been in need of some good action in this department, so me and a couple friends picked it up.

After completing the Maiden Voyage, I decided to hop into a sloop solo just to fart around and try to get used to things. I picked up a Hoarder's voyage just for fun. After plotting my course, I set out, thinking it would be all fun and games. Less than a minute after leaving the outpost, the sea turned nasty, with huge waves crashing around me, and the wind howling. The skies turned dark, and I became slightly alarmed. A deafening roar filled the air, and the fabled kraken rose from the depths and surrounded me. I knew it was in the game, but I didn't expect to see it on my first mission. Its sheer size filled me with dread, and I had no idea what to do, as its massive tentacles wrapped themselves around my puny boat. Leaks were springing around everywhere, as I feverishly ran two and fro trying to patch them up. It was to no avail. Soon, my ship was slipping under, into Davy Jones' Locker, with me inside. It went down so fast, I had no time to get out of the hold, and the water was so dark I didn't know which way was up and where to swim to escape. I accepted my fate as my lungs filled with water, and I faded out of existence......

My eyes blinked, and I saw light! I had escaped death it seemed! I got up on my feet on a sandy beach, and took a look around me. My faithful sloop was not far away from the shore, rocking gently in the breeze. I searched the tiny island for supplies, and thought, "Lets try this again". I left, heading for my original goal of buried treasure before the Kraken had its way with me. Suddenly, in the distance, A sail! I whipped out my spyglass, and determined a 3-4 man team was headed straight for me. I let down the sails, and headed with the wind at full speed. They soon gave up the chase, as the wind was on my side. I was now back on course. Suddenly, another storm arose, and a cannon shot slammed into my ship. A skeleton ship had risen from the depths, and was trying to make sharkbait of me. I feverishly patched holes while keeping on going, and eventually I escaped them too. As I came out of the storm, I emerged next to a beautiful mountain peak stretching into the sky. "What a beautiful yet intimidating island" I thought to myself. Suddenly, an earth shattering boom filled my ears, and the mountaintop exploded as truck sized boulders came flying out of the sky all around me. Let me tell you, being right at the base of an erupting volcano is no joke. I thought I was dead for sure, as a giant flaming rock flew straight down at my ship, only to have it narrowly miss me. I zigg zagged my way out of there, surviving some how, with deafening booms all around me. 

Afterwards that, I found the island i needed, found my treasure, and sold it back at an outpost. What an incredible journey. I feel I almost got the full rundown of what can happen in SoT, all crammed into my first mission.

The biggest problem with the game is how to play with friends. The game does not help you at all in getting set up with this. You have to download the xbox windows app manually, and add your friends on it to play with them. Simply linking your steam account does nothing, at least for me. When it looks for suggested friends, it can't find any of my steam buddies. It seems pretty stupid this isn't implemented, since you can open the steam overlay and everything in-game.

After you've added your buddies, and they've added you back in the xbox windows app, you can then create a party in-game, and invite them.

In the end, the price is definitely worth it, even at $50. It's fantastic fun, with friends.

Game doesn't hold your hand too much, but teaches you the basics of pirate life in a tutorial mission or your "Maiden Voyage". The world itself you need to experience and see yourself, so you know not to hit that ground on shallow water at that one outpost or know the location of those uncharted islands. You'll be able to learn more advanced maneuvers with ships, the worth of each type of treasure, and when to run from a skeleton ship fight as you play. Gameplay is more session-based, in that you should sell your loot and do any quests you want before ending your session. At the start of each session you should stock up on extra cannonballs, food, planks etc. with your crew before heading out.

All in all, about 18 hours in and with some guidance I have gotten my wife playing this as well, even though this is more challenging and more PVP oriented than what she usually plays, this has been fun for both of us.
Progression could be deeper, and is mostly just gold, cosmetics and levels for each faction.
This is the type of game that makes for some fun stories though.
Would recommend, especially if it is on sale.

The gameplay itself is potentially a bit limited, at least if you approach it with expectations from other games. There is no leveling, or buying better gear, or upgrading. This will be one of the best, if not the best pirate-themed games you've ever played. I'd not played any good pirate game for years but after getting my hands on this one, I immediately fell in love because this game is realistic in many aspects, from solving treasure riddles to sea battles and countless unexpected encounters you can get while sailing the seven seas. Beware of the clock because Sea of Thieves might suck a ton of time from you, as longer session means more gold and usually you want to keep playing forever because there are just so much to do in this game. And also, the graphics (especially the water) and ambient audio is incredibly good, which contribute to the realistic pirate experience you'll have when playing this game.
I cannot give it a perfect score yet, because there are still some issues in gameplay experience. Controls and item browsing can be messy sometimes since this game is also designed for consoles. Sensitivity for different items are not 1:1 and it is not adjustable, I don't know why. And personally I am stuck with a bug where the Y-axis of my mouse is inverted by default and I tried everything I could to fix this but nothing worked, so I had to find a workaround by enabling the Invert Y-axis option in order to look around normally, but it inverted other stuffs such as viewing the map table or using the harpoon/cannon.
This game is totally worth full price. You won't regret buying it, trust me. And as I mentioned above, beware of the clock!

The first and most important thing to know about this game is that it must be played with friends. Forget what you might have been told, viewed, or read about solo slooping; if you aren't playing with friends then there are simply no positives to owning this title. Two forms of DRM, a horrible character creator, microtransactions galore, and skinnerbox gameplay all cease to be relevant only once you and your crew are all playing instruments on your ship to make your pet monkey dance. This is absolutely a sale-only title, but there's fun to be had if you grab copies for friends as well; taking a skeleton fortress with friends is worth every penny. Just try to ignore Rare's seeming insistence that the Golden Age of Piracy was comprised mostly of fat women.

I initially didn't want to review this game because of my immense bias and love of anything that has to do with pirates... but I think anybody that's willing to purchase this game already has a closeted pirate niche. 

This game is a grind. An open world, multiplayer, do-whatever-you-want grind. The missions are repetitive (outside of Tall Tales) and the payoff can be quite infuriating compared to the effort you put into it. But this is a game about the journey not the destination.

You and your crew raise an emissary flag for another day of plundering on the high seas, stopping at nearby islands to dig up their treasure. On paper, this is the same monotonous task over and over again. Read a map, solve a riddle, force your shovel into the sand, repeat. But there are many dangers on the sea that make the journey incredible. Reapers tracking your emissary flag on their map attempting to steal your haul for themselves and their vile order. Krakens and megalodons waiting in the depths for an unlucky band of wretches to pass into their waters. Ships crewed by the undead sailing quickly underwater and surfacing at your port side, broadsiding you relentlessly with metal and curses. All of these devastating hazards bring the life (and the pirate) out of your crew and win the day, especially making your measly 5 captains chests seem much more earned in the end. 

Of course there are the world events as well like Skeleton Keeps and Fleets, Flameheart's Fleet, and the Fort of the Damned. All of these can be conquered by you and your crew. However you may opt to be more of a bandit figure in the Reaper's name and wait for another poor crew to complete the event and sink them to take their earnings for yourselves!

The concepts in this game are fantastic, and the implication is just trailing behind that. There are a few issues regarding hit-reg due to the game being incredibly complex with how the engine makes the ships solid objects while crashing on waves, loot objects and your player models being able to stick to those surfaces, and general rules of motion. But the issues don't show their colors unless you truly look for them or play somewhere over 100 hours, when you're sure that "that musket shot should have hit in that situation."

An easy 9/10 in my book, just make sure you have a group of 3 or 4 people total before you take on the treacherous waters of the Sea of Thieves. It's much more fun that way.
It will be much fun if you playing it with your friends ;)

Sea of Thieves had a lack luster launch back in 2016. Reviews and many different voices explaining their experience with footage put me off of it for awhile.

Recently it was recommended to me by a friend and while reluctant I said I'd give this game a solid chance and it delivered with a simple yet enjoyable pirating experience. Lore through detective work and Tall Tales, large scale battles on skeleton forts, amazing ship to ship combat, great faction aesthetics, and a swanky soundtrack that syncs up with actions from the player that not many other games have tried save Doom 2016. Getting full wind in the sails only to hear the same calming track wisp over you with the crashing waves doesn't ever get old.

Combat while simple is surprisingly nuanced. From keg rushes to sword lunging off your ship to get closer to the enemy without the use of a cannon. To burning a banana in an enemy ships frying pan with kegs next to the stove, the food catching fire blows up the entire lower deck, and chaos ensues. I don't want to touch further on this because first time experiences are important.

Cosmetics are great and easily earned with a little reaping or looting. You can buy things with actual money but everything is surprisingly cheap. The only major cosmetic complaint about this game I actually have is surrounding the pirate creation menu. Finding a good looking pirate is a test of endurance and patience since there is no slider or any form of customization option in the facial and bodily features your pirate has. You have to roll the dice a lot on a pirate generator. It took me roughly two hours and three 'Pirate Appearance Potions' to find the right pirate for me.

There is a lot I have left out but mainly because like I said in my combat segment, "-first time experiences are important." My input while valuable is going to ruin other things you should learn while playing the game because learning is fun and mastering something is even greater.

I'd recommend this to people that like a relaxing exploration game and to those that crave that PVP rush after beating an opponent into the ground.

A few final words on this title. You are a pirate so expect the unexpected from anyone, play with friends if possible because while challenging solo play is much more punishing, and most of all shanties with a full crew feels amazing.
This is the best pirate game since blag flag so take from that what you wish

I've played the same MMORPG exclusively for ~14 years now, mainly because I've never been able to find a game that interests me enough to play it in lieu of the other. Sea of Thieves is that first game that got me to branch out, in 14 years. 

You can navigate a ship, manipulate sails, change the angles to catch the wind, fight skeletons and skeleton bosses, do special events that allow you to shoot cannonballs at enemy ships, dig up treasure on islands the old-fashioned way with a bright red X on a map, farm gold, farm reputation, PvP, fight megalodon sharks, fight the kraken, find as many treasure chests as possible, and even sink another player's ship to steal their loot. It's the most fun with a group of 4 (imo), but you CAN play solo.

It took me a while to get into this game because the streams always looked relatively boring, but when you start playing and start figuring out how everything works, you realize it keeps you busy and you ALWAYS need to be on the lookout for other players' ships and the swimmers that sneak onto your boat. "A group of friends helplessly playing the[i] Happy Birthday [/i]song with their musical instruments while their ship is sinking due to insufferable damage caused by the Kraken, a Megalodon, and the Skeleton Pirates, simultaneously."

If that sounds fun to you, then you [i] arrrr [/i] going to enjoy Sea of Thieves!

Sea of Thieves is a game that puts you into a pirate's shoes (or rather, [i] peg legs[/i]). Which means, you get to do what pirates normally do! For example, getting killed by the Kraken,  searching for One Piece, dueling skeletons in a sword fight because apparently they have a [i] bone to pick [/i] with you! (They also eat bananas to regain HP, just like in real life), and FISHING! I guess..

My main point is, you have a lot to do in this game, such as the campaign a.k.a Tall Tales, sidequests, and you can do it at your own pace. Want to fish all day instead of sailing the seas? Sure, why not? Want to get pointlessly killed and robbed by other players? Sure, why not? Whatever [i] floats your boat. [/i]

At first, the game might be intimidating because of how overwhelming it is. Atleast to me. Trust me, initially i knew [i] jack [/i] shit about how the game works. Gave it some time and now i'm [i] hook[/i]ed. Heh, [i] sea [/i] what i did there? See what i did there again just now?

Graphic wise, the game looks beautiful. It's so vibrant and colorful, and i will never get tired of it. The most impressive part is the water graphic and animation. Seriously, it looks so good! If that Miiverse person who bought every game on Wii U and reviewed its water graphic still plays videogames until this day, then they'd be proud and crying [i] ocean [/i] of tears upon seeing Sea of Thieves.

So, [b] why should you buy Sea of Thieves? [/b] My answer would be "immersion". The game is very immersive and a blast to play with friends. I can't say anything for the solo players but i assure you, grab a friend or two and you'll see what i mean. You fight with the terror of the seas, explore, loot, duel with other pirates, and the game makes all that experience immersive and feel great. Not a lot of game can pull this off.  It's truly a [i] rare [/i] experience, heh. I'm sure i will [i] treasure [/i] all these moments because they're just [i] gold[/i].

If you're a solo player, please read other reviews and think twice before buying. But, if you're planning to play this with friends, then i strongly recommend Sea of Thieves. Do not miss out on this [i] gem[/i]. Heh.

Well, I guess this is OK if this is the kind of thing you are into. In concept it could be a great game; great graphics and sound, really cool quests and puzzles - just overall a really great feel. I bought this game to play with my kids as a crew and while the game could a lot of fun and very enjoyable the vast majority of the SoT community (in my experience) are no more than a bunch of schoolyard bullies taunting and constantly grieving new players simply for the joy they find in ruining someone else's experience.

Unfortunately servers seem to be filled with adolescents who do nothing but screw with other players. It seems that because of the limited progression (cosmetics only) folks get bored with actually playing the game after they have gotten all of the cosmetics they want. It has now   turned it into nothing more than screwing with other players as much as possible. Not only killing other players for no gain other than the sheer pleasure of it but disgusting mean-spirited taunts laced with foul language seems to be the norm. Not my idea of a great time.

Yeah, I get its PvP, but its pretty hard to enjoy the game (or even play it or do quests) when other players just hunt you down and kill you or simply camp out at the starting outpost and cut you down as soon as you enter the game. I'm not talking about attacking your ship, that is expected. But when a four man crew chases down a crew of two (or even one) after they have sunken their ship and taken all of their booty just to kill them, what is the point in that? Then rinse and repeat, over and over and over. It gets pretty old. The SoT community is rife with immature adolescents who make the entire point of the game to insult and harass new players.

How about some safe zones in and around the outposts so you can't be sunk while anchored at the harbor or cut down as soon as you enter the game? I was under the impression that the game was about sailing the high seas and completing quests and finding treasure and ship to ship battles. What it has turned into is 4 person crews simply screwing with smaller groups of players. This has nothing to do with sea battles and taking their booty (definitely expected) its just simply hunting down smaller groups so they never finish any quests or enjoy the game.

I probably have just scratched the surface of all of the cool things the Devs have put into this game. I have seen riddles for treasure maps, an island dungeon laden with traps, interesting and unique treasure chests, megladons, kraken, ghost ships just to name a few. Unfortunately, it has been next to impossible to actually experience any of this fully  because of what this game has become for a large number of players; an opportunity to bully others from the safety of their basements. 

I guess for some folks this kind of thing is fun. So if this is what you consider to be fun I say go for it. For me, however, I just want to enjoy the game and explore what it has to offer with family and friends. I was expecting a 'normal' PvP environment with a few safe areas (there are none) and encounters with other players resulting in someone losing their ship and treasure, not an environment where killing and ridiculing other players was the entire goal. I feel like I've wasted a lot of money.

This game turned out to be a lot more fun than I thought it would be. After seeing videos posted online for years, my son finally convinced me to give it a try. I'm glad I did. I have had some amazing adventures with him and other friends who also recently bought the game. For me, I enjoy a game that creates stories. What do I mean? When you're sitting around with friends later, do the memories of a voyage or a battle come back and is the tale told with the same enthusiasm as if you were actually there? If the experience was memorable and fun, the game is a success. Already, my son and I discuss voyages we've had together while eating dinner, and it's really incredible to have this shared experience. I've done the same with some friends as well.

Want to waste time? Play a regular FPS/MMO. Want to make memories, have a great time, and have your own sea stories to tell afterwards? Play Sea of Thieves.

I feel compelled to write a review for this game because it's simultaneously perfect and irredeemably flawed. When I launched the game I was floored by the look, feel, and flavor of the game. The visual design is inspired. Truly, they nailed the Disney pirate aesthetic. The sound design is far better than it has any business being. The feel of piloting a functioning pirate ship as you tack into the wind and brave inclement weather is jaw dropping. The core game engine reaches levels of perfection I have never experienced but have always wanted to. There is however a flaw in this game; a flaw so enormous it beggars belief. 

Money is worthless.

Yes the very thing that motivates people to be pirates in the first place is completely worthless. Suddenly you realize every single thing that you could possibly do in the game will get you no further and make you no more powerful than a person just launching the game for the first time. In one heartbreaking moment you realize the entire game is set on a hamster wheel, destined to take you nowhere. 

The most painful part of this game is how near to perfection they came without seizing it. I remain hopeful that the developers will realize what this game is missing and add it in, but considering the size of the flaw its hard to believe the oversight was NOT an intentional decision. 

In conclusion, if you want to roleplay as a pirate with your friends and just do pirate things then this game might be for you... but if you want to play a game that goes beyond the surface experience and truly motivates you to continue playing I doubt you will find that here.

[strike]Just finished tutorials and ready to set sail on my first quest. Right before I died I heard this word .. [b]Nihao[/b] . Two chinese were camping my ship and they kept killing me so I can't start my first voyage or do anything. Uninstalled and sent refund right away. PIRATES LIFE? Nah[/strike] (Wrote July 4, 2020)
-
[b]Update 07/08/20[/b] I decided to repurchase and reinstall the game to seek revenge. I watched alot of tutorials, highlights and tips about the game. My first voyage was peaceful so I managed to learn the basics. 
Then one fine day, There is this ship marked as wanted on the map I don't know what it's called but you can change your flag to hostile to everyone so I went to their location and noticed they were treasure hunting at Kraken's fall island.  I hid my ship behind a rock and saw that no one was guarding their ship so I swam all the way to their ship, raised their anchor, threw their treasures one by one and then this dude spawned right in front of me. He said something, and yes it was a Chinese so I didn't hesitated and shot his face. I crashed their ship to a random rock and jumped out and spawn to my ship. I felt victorious.
[b]BUT[/b] they were so pissed. I checked the map and they were heading towards my ship. So I ran and ran and the chase took almost half an hour. I was gonna fight but I remembered I had this chest called uhh [b]Ashen Chest[/b] or something that you needed a key for it so I had no intention on giving that up. Then I remembered watching some youtube guides as a solo player, that you can use the storm as your ally. (They were using sloop as well) So I went inside the storm and I was so scared but I had to keep going. I can still see their sail rushing towards me. They managed to close the gap and I heard their open mic saying some random stuff and I was so afraid (They were 3 of them) then I saw this pile of medium sized rocks and decided to take that call and hoping for a miracle. As I stirred the ship left and right to dodge the rocks, I heard a crash and I thought I was done for because I can't repair while leaving the ship at the storm then I heard another crash but this time there was a rage voice .. As I looked back and boi for sure that put a smile on my face .. They were sinking and I can hear their voices arguing. I don't know if they raged quit but after a few minutes their hostile mark on my map vanished. That was one of my best experience in my gaming life. Sea of Thieves has so much to offer and I can't wait to venture further! I only have 23hours playtime but I 100% recommend you to give this game a shot!

the ability to feel like a legit crew is an awesome feeling, and all of the islands are well spaced out and the different roles of the team and all of the sea shanties to play means that there is always something to do.

There is a lot of talk of this game having long bouts of nothingness which make it semi-unenjoyable, but I can say without  a doubt it is worth every penny. Even while solo the game is very entertaining both when you have a plan and when you don't. There is always the risk of getting into fights with other people but you just have to breathe and keep going because it is worth it to just not give up. Being with friends is an interesting experience and will definitely test your patience with them! I think I'm kinda done with this game for now. For multiple reasons, i really don't want to return to this game unless it gets updated.

The first reason being what you work for, the vanity. 
Vanity is the only thing you can spend your money on. even the wiki says 'It has no skill based advantages, only cosmetics.'
So you might think 'damn, those vanity items must be epic is that's the only thing you can buy in this game!' Well, No. 

It just feels creatively bankrupt. Everything is bland, not to mention all around the same price. Some cost a little more than others, but those are usually a recolor of a cheaper vanity item. You don't work your way up to a wicked outfit/ship vanity, its all just the same price. So you play the game for 15 hours grinding to your favorite vanity set, and that's it. Why waste money on other items that you like less? You don't start bare feet, pay a little gold for rags, then some more gold for normal clothing, and then a lot of gold for the cool shit, no. Its all the same level of expenses. And yes, you are able to unlock some vanities with missions but they ain't that much different/better than the already unlocked stuff. Nothing is out of the box, nothing is eye catching, nothing is super cute, edgy, or silly. Which is a shame, because the art style would totally work with over the top items! You have 20 jackets and they are all the same concept, it's a jacked. Why can't I chance my skin color to purple? Why can't i have ghost legs and float? Why can't I dress up as a fucking unicorn or a banana. Let me kill the kraken 10 times and give me fucking tentacles on my face/back. I want my boat to be glowy or painted like one of those hippy buses with flowers on it from the 80's. Don't hide the good shit behind a pay wall ether, because this is literally the only reason I play the game. If you make me pay for it, I wont play your game! Give us something special to grind for, because that's what this game is. Just grinding money with fetch quests.

That's my second problem with this game, how stale the actual game play has been so far. For a game which is marketed like an epic pirate adventure it feels more like an empty-daily reset bundle of fetch quests. Get a voyage, sail to an island, dig up treasure, smack some skeletons, sail back, sell loot, repeat. There are some big events and tales, but if you do not finish them in one go, you lose all your progress when you log out or get killed by some dude that had nothing to lose. So when you get killed, you feel like you lost a lot while in reality you lost nothing but time and that's what makes it feel empty. Why would I start all over again after getting spawn camped instead of just leaving the game to go play something else? Now don't get me wrong, we did have a lot of fun with random encounters! The moment a fucking meg came while we had JUST killed a kraken AND a volcano started erupting in the background? That shit was fun. It was, until other players came and shot our ship down to take all of our loot..


And that's my final problem with the game, the players. 

Combat doesn't feel fair. People with nothing to lose/no loot on them engage on people that just mind their own business or have just killed a big enemy, and grieve the shit out of you. There are guns that insta kill you, so forget about an epic 1 v 1 pirate battle like in the movies. So while you were digging up treasure or recovering from a big encounter, they both manage to set your boat on fire and also sink it. All your shit is already gone and yet they still wont leave you alone. You are stuck on The ferry of the damned for half a minute each time they insta kill you, fully taken out of the game. And the second you are back they are waiting for you again to insta kill you. Its just never fair. You cannot fight back with loot in your arms. You cannot fight back when they spawn kill you. And even if you win, you don't actually win, because they had nothing on them to begin with. And they knew that, that's why they went for you. Its not fun like a skeleton ship, because you will never gain something from it. There is no honor in this game, which makes it hard for players that want to earn their money fair without ruining other peoples game. 

Pretty lame to talk about 'fair earned money' in a pirate game, but we are not real pirates. We are players, and the loot has to come from somewhere. Do we just expect the passive players that just want to play with friends to always be fucked over? And I get it, not ever game is made for every type of player, but the moment you market it all around defeating flame heart and ghost ships, the order of souls and phantom mines, then I expect you to make a game where I can actually do those things without being grieved by other players. 
So you may say 'you are playing the wrong game' but then make it the right game. Because it got advertised as a pirate adventure for me and my friends. Not some type of pvp lobby fuck fest. 
And its all there! The content they advertised. I just can't fucking reach it because I don't want to keep fighting other players every 5 minutes I turn my back on my boat. Its all just hidden behind a wall of assholes and that ruins the game. I'm stuck doing boring ass fetch quests because if there is barely anything you gain from it, it's not that bad to lose everything when you get fucked over by someone else. Why not allow local servers, for only me and my friends? Or some kind of item/flag that disables both damage to us and our damage/interaction to other players? You have AI. You have enemy ships and land enemies and a story/quest line. The other players are not crucial for the game play.

So how do you improve this game? Go wild with vanity. If i have to grind 10 hours for a new set, it best be extra. 
And two: make private servers. No more shitty ass players that set your boat on fire when you are gone digging, spawn kill you 4 times, making you stuck on the ferry of the damned for 2 minutes, only to call you noob and not leave you alone even after they took your shit.
Is this game good? Hard to say. We did have a lot of fun with it! We also rage quit like 5 times. It looks amazing! Art style is fantastic, and the water is beyond gorgeous. Vanity is disappointing, especially if that's all you're working for. I love controlling the boat, i truly feel like a pirate. One to One combat with AI is fun! One to one combat with players is a lot less fun because they one shot you, and you are taken out of battle for a full 30 seconds only to get insta shot again. Fucking around with friends is great, I love the music and dancing we can do. I'd give it a 4/10 for now, and if they added private servers and more vanity, a 7/10.

This game is glorious! Honestly I've played a lot of games which didn't get my attention, but this, this game made me feel like gaming was worth it in the end.

If you have friends to play with on this game, then 100% play with them, it is so much more fun playing with friends.

Yes it can take a while to grind and to become a pirate legend (Pirate Legend is a Title that can be earned in Sea of Thieves) but that what makes it worth in the end, hours and hours of grinding feels so good, and do not expect the game to have many friendly pirates, you will at some point in the game get grieved and you will be left with a heartbroken mess if you had a lot of treasure waiting to be turned in.

Overall I recommend this game to players that are looking for some fun and a real adventure.

Had bought this game just two or three days ago. I dived right into the atmosphere of the game alongside a few of my pals. We headed straight on into the open-world, all four of us in a galleon without a clue on how the mechanics worked. Yet, we got moving, we saw a Brig up ahead and chased it, a sprawl of cannon balls showered the sky and the fight began. It was very enjoyable and a great experience just for only playing the game for about 2 hours.

Pro(s)

- Endless opportunities and voyages to be done
- Surprises at every corner, whether it be a ship, storm or AI.
- Customisation is vast, allowing you to edit your character, ships and weapons alongside tools such as; lanterns, musical instruments. 
- Making in-game money is fun and every voyage has different outcomes, some may be more dangerous and fierce whilst some may be digging up sand, regardless, it is a huge variety and all outcomes are fun to make gold.

Now, the cons, as for someone who has only played the game for fifteen hours, this may be more of a personal outlet. 

Con(s)

- Game is very much playable solo, however - you rarely encounter solos and you'll experience a lot of difficulty as a solo, especially if you are just starting out - however, some may enjoy playing solo and the thrill of it.
- Shooting aspect of the game feels too simple and tedious, guns are only loaded with 5 bullets and combat with AI feels like shooting plushies. When it comes to PvP, it is more of a 50/50 chance and how well someone elses' movement is. 
- Lack of enemy bosses / ships, you have a megladon, kraken and those ghostships with the regular AI.
- The price is terrible 

Overall however, if you don't mind the price, the game is worth it with friends as you can find yourself either laughing, scouring or worrying. The game provides different scenarios every minute with something new happening.

Wish steam had a "mixed" recommendation, because i do think this game can be fun, at times, and there are aspects about it that i truly think are very well done.
Sea of Thieves puts a lot of effort into the visuals and small things that breathes life into it's world. The visuals of this game are stunning, likely some of the best i have ever seen, and the ship and all it's aspects and little details you can tamper and interact with is a joy to experience. Coupled that with all the other things such as the effects, animations, soundtrack, level design and artstyle, but also the dedication and love you can see in being poured into the missions, lore and quirks of the game makes Sea of thieves very charming with visuals far ahead of many other games

However, Sea of theives suffers from an incredible dose of repetitiveness. 
Islands and biomes are most of the time samey, the enemy variety is very lacking, animals too, missions are repetitive and usualy burns down to simply just delivering items. This is more subjective but i personaly found the player encounters and interactions to be... not very engaging, infact i find it to be far more frustrating and tedious. Going off by my own experience, player encounters are either neutral or negative, and there are only two kinds of people in this game: The ones that want to be left alone, and the ones that want to kill you, it's a bit of a 50/50 situation, and the latter is always a frustration to deal with as the offensive ship will usualy always have the upper hand against the one they're targeting, it either ends quickly or drags out for an eternity. Generaly just extremely discouraging and disatisfying to play against. The combat is also slow and clunky, takes a million years to reload your gun, and swinging your sword is a slow process too.

However the worst aspect about the game is probably just the lack of progress. You'll level up and gain better missions, but all your rewards go towards cosmetics. This game has no other thing you can spend your money at, no upgrading system, no different items, ships, weapons, etc, and meanwhile i do appreciate the lack of an upgrade system as it puts everyone at equal measures, it still leaves me with no desire to keep playing once i had bought all the cosmetics i wanted.

TLDR: Charming, visualy stunning game, with a supreme dose of repetitiveness and an almost completel lack of noteworthy progress. An OK game, get it on sale.

Really good game to play with friends. The art style is nice, the music is awesome, and its fun to try to figure out where treasure is on each island. The ship combat is really fun and well made. It requires cooperation, communication and teamwork with your crew to take down other ships. It's a thrill.

However, the game isn't perfect. This game is NOT solo or small group friendly. At the bare minimum I would play with 2 other people. If you are playing by yourself or with 1 other person you are going to get obliterated by a Galleon with 4 people. Ground combat is a mess of buggy hitboxes and stunlocking, though you dont do ground combat terribly often so it's not a huge deal.

Overall, the pros vastly outweigh the cons. If you have a group of friends to play with, I absolutely recommend this game.

With 115 hours in this incredible game, a review is long overdue.

A quick summary for those who hate reading: 

Should you buy Sea of Thieves? Based off of what most gamers look for in video games then...
If you enjoy adventure, PvE and/ or PvP then YES. 
If you enjoy game lore then YES. 
If you like constant action then NO. 

It is worth full price.

Here is more detail:
Pros: 
[*] Beautiful graphics. The prettiest skies and the most amazing water details in any video game.
[*] Multiplayer is fun! This game is perfect for playing with your friends, you can all venture to find treasure, do PvE and/or PvP. Everyone on board has a role and can help manage the ship and fight together.
[*] Single player is fun! You don't need friends to have a great time. Playing solo allows you to be sneaky and sneak onto enemy ships, or get things done your own way.
[*] Satisfaction of progression. Almost every aspect of the game leads to progression of some sort. The achievements are fun, challenging and relevant.
[*] Lore/ Story line. Although not a huge fan of lore myself, this game packs so much detail into the reasoning behind why things in the Sea of Thieves actually happen. For those who love games with a story, this is one for you.
[*] Community. From my experience, the community is extremely friendly and helpful, and not all in-game encounters lead to PvP.
[*] Updates. The game is always receiving updates, and they are FREE. Enjoy free content.

Cons: 
[*] Slow progression. Some of the trading companies take a long time to level up and can become frustrating. In particular the merchant alliance was so boring for me, it is the most tedious company by a long shot.
[*] Solo PvE. This is doable don't get me wrong, but you'll have more fun fishing. PvE as a solo is far too time consuming and can become frustrating. (The skeletons are the most accurate shooter AI that I have ever seen)
[*] Minor bugs. At this stage in the game there are super annoying audio bugs, however they aren't game breaking, they are infrequent and they usually fix themselves eventually. Sometimes for myself, treasure maps have failed to work but this has only happened twice.

Go buy it!

I just completed about a 500 minute gaming session in this game. Yes absurd, but what better is there to do during quarantine? I found a couple of people that allowed me to join into their crew and let me play with them, pretty nice group of guys I would say, had a good laugh or too, but they new what they were doing, unlike myself, only at the time having about 8 hours in the game. We played did some PvP, and eventually ended up beating the skull in the sky thing with all the different colors and shit. Obviously i'm new so idfk what i'm talking about, all I know is you light your lantern and kill skeletons. In the end we ended up making 200k gold, but also at the end I realized that for the first time in a game I felt truly happy. It felt like the old Minecraft days where you would finish a build after hours, and feel so accomplished. And the music, the music just brought it off to the top, when that old sailor music started to play and it, I don't know how to explain it, it was just so beautiful, and amazing. That gaming session took me hours, and in the end I profited so much, and it made me just feel happy, like that sensation I got when completing a build in Minecraft, or just  being able to happily log off after a day of survival in Minecraft. This game overall brought me to believe that there is still hope and happiness to be found in games other than boring, repetitive non stop grinding, a stupid ass story, or solely competitive environments. I would recommend this game to anyone and everyone who is looking for a great game to play, and not having to pay that new game expense of $60. 10/10 good job devs.

PVE content is fun enough however game still feels under polished. All the quests amount to fetch quests with some light puzzles occasionally thrown in. PvE combat feels like a hack n slash with no depth other than run away from the exploding units due to them being a suicidal nuke. There is no progression system other than reputation grinding with factions that just allow more cosmetics and "harder" (longer) quest for do. It is nice that everyone has roughly the same baseline they work with but longer play just leads to collection of reasources that are lost on death and ultimately unneeded as you are basically supplied with what you need on each respawn anyway.

The online community is the worst I have ever been apart of. The new player experience is just avoiding every other player as no matter what you have or say they will attack and steal all of your booty. There are no safe zones, and there are often more of them than you can handle. The game is also extremely grindy with every quest boiling down to carry what's worth gold slowly back to your ship, race back to a port and pray you can unload it faster than any other players can you see you do it. Otherwise they will come gank you and steal all your gold turn in and set you back to where you started. 

PvP does not feel rewarding as anyone that you will be matched against will feel like a borderline hacker due to the immense skill gaps. The experience is not fun in the slightest, so good luck with playing enough to get good.

Huge improvements I feel could be made would be advanced and beginner servers/lobbies to help remove the frustration from being ganked constantly by players with a much greater mastery and understanding of the game. Or just a small implementation of not 100% safe zones, but guards that will help quell aggressors in more relatively "safe" zones. 

Game is worth it if you have a few friends to play with and can manage to avoid literally every other player, but as it stands other players ruin this game by being overly oppressive.

The game is an absolute banger at this point (53 hours in). 

Will be back when I reach 600 hours and then make an honest review.

A very fun game for those who want to sail the seas. There is no real storyline that is obvious but there are tid bits of a story here and there. The Microsoft version of Shift-Tab steam overlay, Windows_Key-G is utterly garbage and you find you need to use it more then you want to add people playing on xbox, or people playing through the Microsoft store. I would give this game 4/5 Stars and I do recommend playing it.

At the 100 hours mark i must look back and reflect on the time spent on this game. Although the vast majority has been thoroughly enjoyable, filled with trepidation and glory there must be a quiet moment spared for the sheer number of hours of other people's time - which in reality, pale my own in comparison - that i have utterly ruined with my own presence. 

Countless people murdered, loot taken and adventures destroyed for little purpose other than my own amusement. Many have fled, some have begged and a few have bargained, but all have regretted our passing.

To all of my victims i protest; Don't hate the player, hate the game.

Sea of Thieves is a stellar construction that culminates in a combination of playing as a pirate with fantasy-esque elements which makes the entire experience particularly enjoyable. While it lacks clear pointers of the game's goals, you'll be able to find your way on the seas in no time. Playing the game with two or more players (up to four total in party) is recommended. Not only for strategic purposes, but also for the enjoyment of controlling a ship and employing teamwork to brave the treacherous waters. Solo play is still very much possible, but it might be less inviting to boot up the game. Regardless, Sea of Thieves is a game that is worth a place in your library: big time, too.

Hard to recommend this. There's no character progression, no leveling system, you basically restart every time you log in. The only thing you get to keep are cosmetics, which is the only thing you can buy with the loot you get ingame. Combat is basic. The quests are cute, and I like the riddles and the fact you have to search islands sometimes to find clue, but overall the price is way too high for this imho. I'd recommend Rust over this for a survival PVP type game at this price.

A great game with great caveats. DO NOT PLAY IF YOU CAN'T STAND NON-CONSENSUAL PVP!

My play style typically emphasizes PvE which would lose almost all tension/suspense without the possible presence of PvPers wanting to ruin my day. Caution and vigilance go a long way to staying safe as a PvE player on the SoT.

There is a steep learning curve which requires seeking the help of other sailors/pirates or countless online videos. Do not trust that the Maiden Voyage has prepared you in anyway for what is to come.

The Sailing and wave modelling is pretty good, though there remains a maddening bug that encourages you to square your sails to the wind when heading directly into it. 

This is meant to be a social game and strongly suggest playing the game with a microphone and a crew. If you do not have friends who play, join open crews to slowly gather a set of like-minded friends, though expect to have highly variable experiences when open crewing.

This is a giant sandbox that repeatedly provides you with grist for your story-mill. To a certain extent, the game is what YOU (and often others) make of it. There is, thankfully, no one way to play. You can, "Be more pirate!" You can be a top-notch chicken merchant, You can engage is Goonies-esque multi-tiered quests. You can let your inner Sea Dog out by playing ship battles in the arena.

If you're still reading, please, join our community and help make the Sea of Thieves even better by your presence.

Loot islands and treasure for 2hrs. Have so many items I have run out of room on my ship. One last quest to finish. Boss wont spawn, so I attempt to move away from the island to try and reset it. Storm hits me immediately. A pirate ship of the damned (not ghost ship) rises from the water and begins chasing me. As I fight this ship in the torrential downpour, a meglodon appears as well. I battle the ship while ignoring the meglodon hoping that it will be gracious. For some reason, the meglo does indeed ignore me. After 30mins of struggling I finally emerge from the fight victorious. I then make the decision to loot the sunken ship. Two NORMAL sharks tag team bite me and kill me. When I respawn on my ship, the meglodon now decides I am a threat and destroys my ship. All my items are floating in the water.
I get my new ship and desperately race to where I think I was sank. Hopefully I can get my items and still make it out with a little bit of loot.
As I near the area to begin my search, the sky goes black and the sound of a mighty beast is heard. The krakken rises from the water, rips me from my cannon, and throws me across the water. I quickly make my way back to the boat and begin slashing at the monsters tentacles. I will not surrender my ship to this foul fiend.
It sinks my ship and smashes my face...the end. 10/10 will get face smashed again.

First day playing, I saw a boat on my map, sailed over to it alone in my little sloop. Big galleon parked next to an island. I had yet to engage in any pvp. Brought my sails to half mast, locked the wheel all the way to the left, and opened fire. As my boat lazily went in a circle off the shore, I was running back and forth between my cannons taking pot shots at the galleon. Since it was parked, it didn't take long for it to sink.  

I thought it was an npc boat or something because it had showed up on my map. But then I immediately saw tiny little people jumping up and down angrily on the shore. Proceeded to trade rifle shots, and killed all but one of them, who was stubbornly guarding a rowboat and kept trying to swim out and board me. Got fed up trying to snipe him, and just went back to cannons, which ended things quickly, as he disappeared in a satisfying plume of water, sand, and debris. 

Things were calm. I nervously scanned the horizon for any sign of incoming ships, and then swam over to the rowboat. It was stacked with more treasure than I have ever seen since then. At the time, I didn't realize I could attach the rowboat to my ship, so I would grab one treasure, swim over to my ship, drop it off and repeat. But I was also constantly on the lookout because I knew they would be coming back with a vengeance. 

And sure enough, after a few minutes, I could see their ominous silhouette on the horizon, coming straight at me. I dropped what I was doing and swam back to my ship. Even with a slight head start, they were gaining on me, because they had a larger ship and knew what they were doing when it came to sailing. Every time I looked back, they were closer and closer, until I could see each of them individually. I realized the only way I was going to make it out of this was if I tried to outmaneuver them, since I had the smaller vessel that was supposedly good for that. 

I tried weaving around rocks, changing directions on them, and at one point even got attacked by a megalodon, but they would not give up, chasing me what felt like across the whole map. On several occasions they got within firing range and put a bunch of holes in my ship. I had to hastily figure out to patch the holes and bail the water, while leaving the navigating unattended. 

Finally decided to try a handbrake turn, which I had seen in a video prior to playing so that I knew how to sail. I knew it would put me briefly in direct line of their cannons, but if I pulled it off, it would take too long for them to turn around, and I was hoping that distance would allow me to get clear of them. I swung the wheel all the way and dropped my anchor, turned sharply, nearly got blown off my ship by several cannonballs, but then managed to pull up the anchor in time and sailed clean past them. 

10/10 most exhilarating experience I've had in a game in a long time

Despite the best possible initial experience with the game, as a longtime gamer it still left me jaded about the state of Microsoft's first party $60 game.

Combat

Let's start with the PvE combat. In 8 hours we fought some skeletons. The same skeletons over and over, with the lone variation a "boss skeleton" that was identical, just with more HP. Let's just say that the PvE enemies and combat mechanics are utterly rudimentary, hardly befitting a first tier gaming experience.

Graphics/Environment

The game looks good, but mostly due to the well done lighting and water models. The stormclouds and rain were nice. The rest is average cell shaded "bleh" and at times shockingly subpar for a 2018 game developed by one of the richest companies in the world. The art style and environmental objects look almost identical to Torchlight, a 10 year old game that runs great on my 10 year old laptop. The islands are tiny and have minimal variation.

Gameplay Loop

It's a FedEx game, but not for better gear to kill bigger and badder enemies. You only get cosmetic upgrades and they are ridiculously expensive. A chicken fetch quest yields 500 gold. A decent hat costs tens of thousands of gold. I kept expecting a different mechanic to arise, new enemies, but sadly the only variation was "go kill this skeleton boss" or "go dig up a treasure chest which we have marked precisely on your map." Appalling.

The Sailing

Probably the best part of the game, as you can't open a map while sailing so a crewmate needs to guide you from belowdeck via voicechat. Some will find this infuriating, but making basic navigation a challenge keeps the sailing authentic. If you hit something, you have to bail water and patch holes but this gets boring pretty quickly, so you'll want to avoid crashes. You can change the angle of the sails for higher efficiency, and you need a good crew to sail properly. Many will find this utterly boring, but it is simply not a high paced game. It defines "chill game." Well done Rare, I say - at least they did one thing right.

Sandbox Play and PvP

I played for 8 hours with a couple longtime Xbox Live friends. We were ready for anything. We found nothing but barren seas - good thing we had grog. We love sandbox games, but there was so little in the sandbox our creativity was limited. We found an extra cage and kept a pet chicken named Eddy in it. The most exciting thing to happen in the first 5 hours was Eddy falling off the bow and me diving in after him. Finally, after 6-7 hours of super basic, simple fetch quests and exploring caves only to find nothing, we see another vessel. Immediately we decide to attack, if just to break the monotony. We hunt down the smaller caravan and begin firing, and a cat and mouse battle ensues which at times felt like a true historical naval battle, with the smaller ship outmanuevering us and the tension rising and falling with each volley of canonballs. This went on for over 30minutes, mostly due to inexperience and the difficulty of getting enough consecutive Canon strikes to sink the enemy before they could bail and patch the ship to full health. At one point, our ships touched, and I jumped down onto the decks of the smaller ship, only to be greeted by a cutlass and promptly killed. A cool moment, to be sure.

Amazing Moment / SPOILER ALERT

Finally, something actually amazing happened. During the height of this tense naval battle, off the starboard side I see a giant tentacle rise up. "IT'S THE KRAKEN!!!" Our ship was seized and while my crewmates fought valiantly, they were picked up and tossed into the sea like breadcrumbs. Our ship was pulled under, and we all died. The end.

CONCLUSION

Despite the epic final 45 minutes or so, I had a hard time believing that Microsoft could A) release the game with so little content and B) charge $60 for it. The game feels like it is still in beta. It feels like a tiny, inexperienced dev team made it and then added some high priced water and lighting models and a kraken. The world is small and repetitive, the quests are worse than even a budget MMO would offer, and the PvE combat is insultingly bad with only a single enemy type and extremely crude mechanics. After experiencing the very best moments the game has to offer on my first play session, I can't see any reason to go back. That's a BIG problem.

How can this be acceptable for a $60 game from a major publisher? Sadly, the answer is that people will buy it anyway, because it will be very well marketed. I expect the game to get bad reviews, but still sell very well, because that is the world we live in now. It is a sad state of affairs, and Microsoft should be ashamed to be taking part in such shenanigans. Bait & Switch is really scummy, but it is also really really profitable.

So I was a bit pissed that they didn't have regional pricing in my area and my friend talked me into getting the game.  I have to say it is worth it.  There are 2 modes, the pvp sort of battle royale style and the adventure mode.  So far the pvp arena has been a cluster fudge of a mess.  I haven't seen a full game of players and it just isn't that fun.  However, the adventure mode allows you to pvm while at the same time in a world of pvp anywhere.  If you don't like pvp I still wouldn't let that deter you because it is pretty easy to avoid conflict.  I would recommend having a friend cause playing solo can be difficult.

But the real reason I love it....  This takes me a little bit back to the days of Ultima Online.  Although the games are completely different and the consequences are greatly reduced in Sea of Thieves, there is a chance at any time to fight.  To me the fight is more valuable then the loot im carrying.  I don't even accept missions mostly, we just run out and look for people to loot...like real pirates.
