This game actively discourages solo play, and punishes anyone who has the gall for not have multiple hours free to be staring at their screen nonstop.
Otherwise if you can force some friends to tag along for those hours the mechanics are sound and there's enough to do I suppose.
If your connection is not the strongest, stay away from this game as well, you will rubber band everywhere including clipping straight through your ship. Doubly important as there are sections you'll want to have fairly good jump accuracy with, but instead of landing on the ledge, you'll end up at the bottom of the sea.

When, not if, you do get griefed by this toxic community, abandon your tall tale or sail away until the item despawns or something, when you restart it the checkpoint should return your item to your ship.

Also extremely buggy, especially the Steam version judging from other posts in the forums as well. Your character will glitch out, if not your ship, respawns will randomly throw you across the world so you have to swim out to a mermaid to get back to your not-sunken ship. You will pull out your musical instrument instead of your weapon when trying to fight, etc.

Все что сделано в игре - сделано качественно и со вкусом, но к несчастью сделанного ОЧЕНЬ мало. Это как попробовать крошки от очень вкусного торта и узнать что сам торт еще не испечен. Вроде как есть интересное управление кораблем, рассчитанное на кооператив, но и соло с ним справиться можно и тут же очень странная система морских боев, где из возможностей только абордаж и перестрелка пушечными ядрами, что как то совсем бедно. Вроде как обещали мир живущий по пиратскому кодексу, а на деле просто замес, где тебя на фортпосте убивает, а потом топит твой корабль только что зашедший игрок и при этом умерев он ничего не теряет. Из за скуки в этой игре самое ужасное комьюнити во всем интернете - скучающие нагибатели, которые готовы два часа тебя преследовать по морю, просто чтобы застрелить и взорвать твой пустой корабль. То есть портить игру другим это единственное развлечение. Ни торговли, ни банд, ни армейских судов... это не игра про пиратов, а игра про отморозков.

I cannot recommend in its current state. Perhaps this will change in future, but it doesn't seem too likely.

The mechanisms are overall pretty good. Manning the sails, exploration, navigation, ship maintenance, and the sort of mini-quests that spawn on your way to treasure make for a very appealing experience. Environments are beautifully designed and feel vibrant and alive. Combat is bland and overly simplistic, but they can't all be winners.

However, the entire gameplay experience comes apart at the seams when PvP gets involved. There are zero restrictions on PvP, meaning that an hour long journey of hunting treasures and fighting various NPC threats can be capped off by an onslaught of other players jumping down your throat to steal all your hard-earned loot. 

The way the game's PvP is designed basically means that if you're interested in doing something that isn't 'killing another player to take their stuff', you are the product being sold, not the customer it's being sold to.

For that reason, unless you're interested only in being a douche to other players, I cannot recommend this game at all.

I have put 100s of hours into this game on the Microsoft store. 

It is not a game for everybody at all. 

It does not have any actual progression (i.e. making your character more powerful, weapons better, ship better) which might turn some people off of playing this game. 

The game does have a solid goal of reaching level fifty in three factions to unlock a new faction to do quests for.  

It also does not have anything great in the way of story. Aside from the odd tall tale here and there. 

For those just seeking a very simple fantasy pirate simulator it will do that just fine. For those seeking to just hop in and not think about upgrading anything and just have fun, it'll do that just fine.

So overall, I would say pick it up after doing a fair bit of research and see if it's for you. Because again. It's not for everyone at all.

There I was, standing proud at the helm of my flagship. I had made it, my life had peaked. I was the Grand Admiral of the Zimbabwe navy, hunting my mentally impaired cousin. What could possibly go wrong? Things were going well, we were vibing to Mbaqanga and doing Meth. But then, something appeared over the horizon...
Pirates. Lots of them too. No doubt hired by my mentally impaired cousin. We outnumbered them 20 to 1, and had surperior tactical knowledge. We were going to win. We engaged them through ship to ship combat, some boarded us so we drew our willies and engaged in schlong duels. We were crushing them. What could my mentally impaired cousin be planning?
Then I saw it...
They had horse urine at their disposal. My one weakness, my cryptonite. How did I not see this coming?
We were being torn apart, and they took my meth. 
I was in a dark place, and thinking of ending it all. But then, like a holy beam of succulent testies Sea Of Thieves was released onto the steam store. It completely changed my life. In an instant, I was aware of ancient naval tactics used only by legendary shipmasters and Steve Irwin himself. We destroyed them, I got my meth back and personally executed their captain. These pirates had the location of my mentally impaired cousin's hideout. It was time to end this.
[i] The hunt is on. [/i]

I played this game while I was suffering from COVID-19. Had a hard time breathing, and honestly thought I was on the verge of death so I thought 'why don't I give this game a shot?'  I threw my 50 bucks in and realized I had a hard time focusing while playing the game. I felt like just sitting there, staring at the water.

Honestly, now that I'm feeling better, this was a great purchase. By default, PvP is on in the game and it's unclear if Rare wants to disable it. The game itself is simple but it's still a story generator. The game is pretty much 'bring x to y' or 'loot an island and bring it back here'. The entire game revolves around fetch quests. However, the game is designed in such a way that you will encounter random events that make the voyage interesting. 

I remember travelling the waters and being randomly attacked by a Kraken. While fighting the Kraken, we had a bunch of PvPers attack our ship. While they tried to stay away from the Kraken, it attacked them anyways. It was now two ships fighting each other while also fighting the Kraken. Not only did we drive them back; we sunk their ship, killed the Kraken, took their chests and killed every last one of them. It felt like we were in a Pirates of the Caribbean movie.

You will match with other players unless you set your ship to 'private' (although I HIGHLY recommend keeping the default 'open' setting). If you're a solo player and don't like interacting with random people in games, this game is not for you. You will have a hard time doing anything as you'll run into other players, random encounters and just bad luck in general. If you're a more sociable person, you can also invite your friends to your ship and head out into the big blue.

I'm a huge fan of Atlas and honestly enjoy that game a tremendous amount. However, I found that game to be time consuming to set up a proper voyage as it could take 5 hours of real life time to just load all the materials you need onto your ship. In this game, all the materials are already on your ship, you just raise anchor and set sail.

This game is suited for children and people with busy work schedules alike. It gets into the nitty-gritty without the horrors of pirate life that Atlas portrays (no, you can't own islands and hang people).

What's the point of the game, then? It's to build a reputation with the different companies in the game. What's the point of THAT? Beats me. There is no point. It's a bit of a grind and the joy of the game is not in the grind itself, but the journey to becoming a pirate legend. When the game first came out, there was nothing to do other than sail from island to island and find treasure chests. PvP encounters weren't really a thing as you couldn't really damage other players' ships. The lack of excitement is what killed the game for many fans until they came out with their more recent updates. The game is DEFINITELY worth getting now compared to how it was when it first released.

The game gets an 8/10 from me. It would get a 10/10 if there were more things to do (such as a proper storyline with cutscenes), had Windows 7 compatibility, and generally favoured solo players. The game does have a storyline, but it's more accompanied with procedurally generated quests that honestly feel a bit shallow. It's understandable though, given the massive size of the map.

Its an open world PVP pirating game that puts all players on an even playing field regardless of their playtime. Unlike other PVP games where hours of hard work are lost by getting ganked by other players or groups, fights in SoT come down to your skill, supplies and teamwork. Instead of being constantly on edge and anxious about meeting other players, SoT is actually super relaxing and fun to play solo or with mates. The art style and detail in the graphics (in all aspects) and world design is GORGEOUS on max settings! (Even just open water looks fu***ng amazing!) The ship physics and randomly sequenced quests are a massive highlight and the world is the absolute perfect size!

This is also what I imagine an open world RPG version of the Money Island series would feel like so thats just a massive bonus. 

Easily one of the best games I have bought in my time on Steam. $50 is well worth it! 

Don't wait any longer. Treat yourself....buy this game now!

I don't recommend Sea of Thieves. I tried playing it solo and alone, choosing my own adventures and following quests, played PvE and PvE. It's just not fun for me

+ it looks amazing, I love this sharp and vibrant style
+ music and sound design is great, enjoyed that part
+ some parts of (some) Tall Tales are quite fun and creative
+ interesting inventory design choice, you are a pirates after all, not a trading company

- it feels like there's no real character progression, only cosmetic changes [i](very average, basically recolors)[/i]
- you are as powerful and as effective during your first hour as you are during your 500th hours played
- there's nothing to unlock that actively changes the way you play the game, everything you see at the beginning is everything that there is in the game
- no abilities, no skills, no unique items or gadgets, only recolored cosmetics
- no way to change ship type mid-game, you have to leave the session
- awful combat system, with what appears to be only 3 different moves (light attacks, charged attack and block)
- PvP is kinda cool, and I like that it exists, but I never enjoyed it because of the respawn system
- if you leave the session, you have to log in again and watch (or skip) the cutscene, every single time
- minor stuff like connectivity issues with XBOX Live, bugged quests where the enemy spawns inside the wall or ground, etc

It just feels like a chore to play, knowing that everything you do amounts to sailing from one empty, samey looking island to another. To turn in a quest and see some numbers go up. Characters have no personality or flair, everyone looks the same but with different colors. The game just has this aura of meaningless monotony and sadness. Where all I can think about is "wow, I could be animating something in Blender right now". And dreaming about working during gaming is never a good sign

If you are looking to become an adventurer on the seas, this is the game for you. Absolutely awesome game full of trolls, mic-spammers, snakes, roleplayers and bananas. It basically has something for everyone.

The aesthetics of the game, the sea, the stars and the generally goofy look makes the game beautiful, mysterious and intriguing. I've spent most of my time within this game just in awe of how beautiful it actually is.

The gameplay aspects of the game include pvp, pve, pvm, puzzle solving, bossing, lenghty story quests etc. The pvp aspects of the game creates this dynamic of hunter/hunted where you always feel nervous of pvp encounters. Altough most people seem to be aggressive, the few that arent are super fun to come across. I've had some nice rp moments that I can look happily back at. Pve/pvm in this game is basically any random boss encounter (Kraken, Megalodon or Skeleton ships) and the voyages you take on. 

The game also has these lengthy story based quests/voyages that are called ''Tall tales'' and these will keep you occupied for hours and hours trying to solve the mysteries behind them and finding the treasures for that gold metal that is so shiny. For this you basically need a crew that you enjoy playing with, otherwise it's more of a hassle than a fun adventurous experience.

Performance wise, this game is so well optimized my old computer from 2012 handles it very well on medium quality. How they managed to creature such a lively sea is beyond my knowledge but it's one of the key features that had me hooked.


Looking forward to play more, sail the seas, explore and find hidden treasures. Btw, if you ever come across a well dressed man with golden locks and a snidy speach talking about the royal navy, then you know it's most likely me. Thanks for reading, have a great day!

This was a game that I pretty high hopes for when it was first announced at E3, and to me personally, I was let down at first. Not because the game was bad, I had no idea how the game was, but because I wasn't able to play it, nor want to, due to it being on the Microsoft Store.

Now that being said, it's now on Steam and I've owned it for about a month now and I gotta say.. it's everything I could have hoped for. For me I was itching a pirate game that both intense and lighthearted all at the same time, and this game checks those boxes for me perfectly. While for some the gameplay leaves more to be desired in I, I find myself great bliss in being immersed within the world and grand atmosphere it puts you in, and I never want to leave.

This game is wonderful and to me there's only one minor issue, the multiplayer factor. It is not because of the fact that it exists, that would be senile of me to even state, it's because of the fact that is still uses Microsoft's servers to run everything including the invitation system for lobbies prior to getting your ship. Now I don't mind having to deal with the extra step, that's not the worst thing I've had to deal with in order to get the job done. The thing that I hate is the fact that I deal with Xbox players. Now don't get it twisted, I have obviously found great people both knowledgeable and humble, even added a couple people because of it. The issue is the people who toxically will repeatedly spawn camp and sink your ship, taking your booty in the process.

While I have mentioned the main good and bad, one thing that I like about this game that likely has turned off quite a few people is likely the fact that absolutely everything you get in this game is sheerly cosmetic and does absolutely nothing functionally to make you stronger in the game. To some people this is the weakest point in the game, due to what can feel as a complete lack of progression. To me I believe that this is one of the games strongest, as it implies the player(s) get good(better) at the game in order to surmount their obstacles. This can be seen in every aspect of the game, and to me adds even more to the piracy-feel of it all, do you really expect a pirate to invest in anything significant like a new cutlass or gun anyway?

Overall, the game's atmosphere is extremely strong, and I love everything about it save for the fact that I'm huddled in with Xbox players and haven't seen a single PC, let alone Steam player, solid [9.5/10]

So the game itself is really neat, and has a relaxed feel. Sailing the realistic waters, with weather systems and winds is a blast with your friends. You can play sea shanties which sync up with others. It's a neat game.

There is not much progression beyond the cosmetics, which wears off pretty quick.

What really did it in for me, was locking what I think is the coolest cosmetic, pets, behind a premium currency paywall. This currency can be obtained in small amounts by finding a rare ancient skeleton that will bury itself after 10 seconds.

 For a game I paid money to get in the first place, I feel cheated. And for that, I do not recommend this game.
A fun and casual co-op game that everyone can enjoy. I implore you to get this game!

So, after i played it the first time when it released on Consoles at my Friends Place and now on Steam.. 
Yeah... no. If you played any PvP Survival Game, you played all of them and SoT is no difference, except that there is no Point in Playing this Game except for getting Gold to be able to buy Skins, thats it. No Survival, no Building, No Leveling, no Progression. While this is good for an PvP Game since everyone is granted the same chances SoT itself is just the wrong Game to implement such a Mechanic, as a Pirate i expect Progression and want to show it off to others.. but Skins arent very Satisfying.. no matter how long you Play, the Characters will always look like Hobos, and the Ships are all preset, except the Skins which all look.. meh.. 
95% of People i met so far are Hostile.
The Community is Toxic against new Ideas.
The Game offers not much Content. Its just drive from A to B, Grab some crates/find a Chest/Fight a Skeleton/kill a Player, get back to A, get Gold.. orr get fucked by other Players / Random annoying event like an Giant Seamonster which is just annoying to fight against. 

The Only good thing i can tell about this Game are the Graphics, the Game is gorgeous and has an very good Art style.
But Gameplaywise its just very shill, and the Price is WAAAAAAY too high for this Game. I had more Fun with Atlas, both in PvP and PvE.. and Atlas is a buggy mess. Oh.. right.. SoT offers no way to play only PvE, you are always forced to face random People that can and most likely will fuck you up.. so better get used to it.

I wish I knew how many hours I already spent in this game but thanks to the abomination that is the windows store and the Xbox companion app I can only estimate that I’m close to 1000 hours so I can share a bit of my experience.

Before you buy:
If you’re a solo warrior type of player you’re going to have a semi fun time getting started. I definitely recommend playing the game with friends or joining a discord community as co-op is one of the most crucial elements to success in the game. Playing open crew with random people is possible but not recommended as most are either half your age, afk farmers or utilize a potato as sound input option. Both PvE and PvP will be challenging without proper communication.

Quick Facts:
-The game is quite grind heavy so be prepared to sink some hours into it. 

-Amazing visuals and physics engine

-Frequent and free dlcs/updates

-Developers that actually listen to the community

-Microtransactions only for cosmetics

-A few bugs here and there but most will be hotfixed or addressed in subsequent patches

-Decent learning curve with many tips and tricks 

-Many helpful people but also quite a few toxic players that are twice as fun to clap up

-Open world sandbox with countless things to explore

-Tall tales with more deep lore than dark souls  

-Fishing Simulator 2020

And Sea of Thieves lacks any kind of block feature which is a pretty huge over sight.

I wish there was a neutral review for games because that is what I would rate this in its current state.  


***Pros***

Graphics:
The game is beautiful.  In fact, it is the best-looking water, sun and sky I have seen in a game.   The colors are vibrant and pleasing on the eye.   

Sailing:
Sailing is meditative for me.  It almost feels real and listening to the ocean is relaxing.

PvE Quest: 
They are enjoyable.  I really like finding a riddle in bottle and trying to solve it. Tall Tales are great (if you are able to complete them without people killing you).  Digging up treasure and finding other items is also really fun.


***Cons***

Forced PvP:
I understand what they were trying to go for, but humans suck and they go out of their way to ruin your gameplay.  They either need to add PvE servers, private servers or allow you to host a game and have your friends connect.  People say doing this will ruin the game, but they are wrong.  Ark and 7 days to die do it and those games are doing just fine.

Being killed in port:
There are pirate rules written on the wall when you first spawn in the pub that say all matters will be settled at sea.  Well guess what, people aren't following those rules.  If they don’t want to make PvE or private servers, then make ports and islands neutral where you can’t attack people or steal loot.  However, once you get out into open sea it can become far game then.  That would be a test of skill for all these die hard PvPers then.

Toxic community:
Being killed is one thing, but being harassed while it happens is another.  Kids and even one time a kid and his Dad were yelling and saying horrible things while killing my wife and I.  This is another reason for private servers, PvE servers or local host game play.  

Community in General:
I absolutely LOVE everything about this game except the community.  We can’t play without people attacking non-stop and then you lose an hour or two of work and gain nothing. You are always out numbered and no one, and I mean NO ONE will help you.  Everyone just shoots at first sight.  There is zero cooperation in this game.  PvP would be fine if it was a fair fight (1v1 or 2v2), but it never is.  You are ALWAYS outnumbered and those people think they are good at the game because four of them killed a solo sloop.

Needs more PvE:
Needs more enemy types and more variety of quest.  The ones they have now are fun, but they just need to add more to spice it up a bit.


My wife and I still want to play this game, but if we continue to be killed and harassed, we are just going to have to quit.  We just want to play a relaxing pirate game where we can hunt treasure and do quest.  I really hope they add PvE because you are isolating a HUGE demographic of people that would pay to play your game.  

Be smart Rare and add PvE servers.  You will make more money this way.   Other games do it and they are successful.  

This game would be a 10/10 in my opinion, but right now it’s a 4/10 with the forced PvP.  Way to stressful for people who just want to relax and treasure hunt after a long hard day of work.

_______________________________________________________

Update:
Screw this game, screw the toxic community and screw Rare.  Do NOT buy this game and support this type of behavior.  Wife and I are uninstalling.  

Rare goes and creates private servers, but no gold or rep farming?  Why?  It DOESN’T impact ANYONE by playing solo or PvE.  Everything is cosmetic so who cares!!!  I could spend hundreds of hours just sailing around and treasure hunting by myself.  That is fun to me despite people telling me it would be boring.  They don’t get to decide what I think is fun or not.  

This game definitely needs some PVE servers.  Rare if you implement this I will return and even pay money in your in-game shop because I do like some of the ship cosmetics.  But until then, screw you and your toxic game.   

You don’t understand people at all.  Give them PvP only and it will bring out the worst in people.  You don’t even listen to the LARGE community asking for PvE.  Terrible company.

Overall Score: 4/10 with the potential to be a 10/10 with PvE servers.

It's addictive, I'll give it that. The community, however, is as toxic as it gets. There's no friend-only lobbies. No way to change server-region manually. 

Players have a KOS mentality, whether your boat is fully loaded, or you've just spawned and have nothing but the starter boat. The trigger happy sailors will kill you, and sink your sloop simply because "It's the Sea of Thieves". 

Outpost camping and ambushing is real and there is no way to avoid it regardless of whether or not you've taken steps to ensure nobody is near before you dock. Until a form of safezones or private servers are implemented, this is not subject to change. 

It's a fun game, but after an hour or two grind each day just to have it all lost to a crew of 4 sailing by per chance, is immersion breaking and undoes everything you've done or tried to achieve in your session of playthrough. If they want to keep players on their game, they'd do something about this.

Steam and XBOX/Windows Store implementation is poor. You cannot invite or join friends through Steam, and instead are forced to deal with an iffy-at-best users experience of the Xbox Overlay to be able to play with your friends. They really could've done better with this...

I went to try out the game for myself after seeing the positive reviews on the game and in hopes of seeing improvements of what to do. so, i went out and joined the game with a couple of friends....

...and it was alright, until i hit a brick wall of reality that the core game play is essentially the same it has been since it's first launch. same doo doo different update. sure, new places to dig up a chest, but still that's it. you do a couple quests and then you are already burnt out by the third time you did it, so then you get drunk and then fire yourself or an animal aide out of a cannon. every once in a while, you have to fix the ship cause no matter how many times you try you can't get the ship properly on port, or one man on a mission walks up to your ship and asks" Are you friendly?" as he is firing his blunderbuss at you.

Here is the biggest complaint i have about the game.
it is too. bloody. dark.
I can barely see a single thing when im in my ship with 6 lanterns on all over the place.  it could be to reinforce the use of a lantern, whereas it would be just a useless trinket of piracy if this wasn't an issue, but my god is it so obnoxious that there is no option to raise the brightness. other games like GTFO have this same issue, but that game at least had it like that for a reason.  i went on local forums about the issue and it's a pretty mixed bag about any answers that should come up. most of the time, it's just some jolly joker who is like "Just use the lantern bro it's there for a reason". If i can't even be able to see in what appears to be a well-lit room in 1700 standards, there's an obvious issue going on. 

the next issue i have is the fact that you can't just invite friends over via steam, nonono, you have to go hit that win+G and then friend them on their microsoft account if not already then you are able to invite them. oh, and also let's just add another stupid overlay on top of your steam overlay and geforce overlay if you have that. 

the nail in the coffin for my interest for this game is the fact that if the game is stripped of tedious point a-b at 4 knots an hour across half the Atlantic game play, there is pretty much nothing going on for the game. sure you can fight other people, but that's not interesting. if you go against a smaller ship, it's like drop kicking a baby. if you are the smaller ship, enjoy losing everything even if you had nothing to begin with. "but wait, at level 50 there's more quests!" I will staple my balls together and have a smile on my face when offered the decision between that and get to that point of the game. why bother arguing that when for the previous 49 levels, it was rinse and repeat? i got an achievement for vomiting and that was the most exciting part of my venture through the sea. of thieves.

overall, a dissapointment even with positive reviews.

I originally bought the other open world pirate game that rhymes with matlas to get my fix of pirating. Since this game came on steam it's been my current game. Playing with friends and doing voyages and tall tales are really fun to do. My biggest issue is when you don't have friends available you either pray to god for competent randos or play solo and get dunked on by a 4 man galleon with the State of Decay collector's edition ship.

My impression after playing around 10 hours:

Negative side:
- confusing mechanic and lack of tutorial...
- Islands is very small, and consist only around 10% of full size map which majority is the water
- The ship is not upgradable. Can only be customizable with cosmetic.

Between positive and negative:
. Playing alone is quite overwhelming, but possible
. More fun if you play with a friends
. Limited crew in one ship (Sloop with max 2 crews, Brigantine with max 4 crews, Galleon with max 6 crews)
. Asia server quite calm. 
. frustrating puzzle

Positive side:
+ Huge map
+ Many islands
+ Story is very fun to play
+ The water effect and physic is very cool
+ Dynamic weather system
+ Official discord server is friendly toward people new to the game. There is even a section for a new player who want to sail together.
+ Even though the puzzle is frustrating, it's quite fun when you actually solve it...
+ This game based of skill, not gear, so everyone in the game has a same chance of winning.

I have played this game since the beta and have recently moved to the steam version. If anyone wants to do the same all of your progress will be transferred. Just sign in to your Microsoft account once and you're good to go. The story is decent but that's not what I play for. I play for the ship combat (which is great), player interactions, and of course the abundance of loot and progression. You might be disappointed that the only rewards are cosmetics but I think they do it in a way that makes you feel a sense of completion. If you just want to enjoy some ship combat and competition you can play the arena mode but I think that can get boring quick. Rare adds new content and patches pretty often if you ever want a reason to come back to the game.

Like: satisfying adventures with stakes, playing hurdy gurdy and enjoying the slosh of friggin' beautiful waves going past

Dislike: things can be frustrating and very samey--go to island, kill skeleton, dig up chest, sell it to guy, repeat repeat repeat repeatrepeatrepeat...and also sometimes someone or something will just come along and kill you and it's like 100,000 gold down the drain and a long long quest for nothing. 

It's very all-or-nothing. If you're unable to keep a multi-hour commitment to the game (like, say, if you're a parent, or just if your game crashes) then you may just end up having to take a big loss on a big investment of time and energy. 

All in all, however, it's a game with tension and laughs and style, and it can feel very satisfying to pull into port with a fortune or equip some unique item from a tall tale or a commendation. 

Don't expect endgame to be much different than the low-level stuff, however; it's just a bit harder and more involved, and higher-priced loot for more expensive stuff.

Probably the most balanced game in the history of video games since all the unlockables are simply cosmetics and titles that you can wear and use to show off your accomplishments. Personally for me this is the most chill game I have ever laid my hands upon. This game is all about creating your own adventures like solving riddles and navigating treasure maps to dig up treasures, killing skeleton captains for their skulls and bounties or just being a merchant sailor collecting and delivering cargo to different outposts. Then there is the skull fortresses that you can do, those are basically skeleton compounds that spawn waves of enemies to defeat until a boss will spawn,once defeated will drop a key to the stronghold that is full of treasures and valuables. Story missions? Got em too.
The details in this game are also beautiful! you can drink beer then vomit in a bucket and throw it on your friend. You can blow up a barrel near a chicken and it will spawn a charred piece of chicken. You can play music to a snake to tame it. You can get hit by lighting during a storm if you are wielding a sword. The water will start boil if volcano erupts.
The game world is just satisfying to look at from clear blue waters with big tropical islands, to deep black waters with volcano islands that may erupt. 
The game world itself is also riddled with dangers, from Megalodons and Krakens to Ghost Ship Fleets and other players. PVP aspect in this game is my favorite thing, it feels balanced and satisfying. The sound of you hitting a rival players ship and watching it go down, or jumping on board of their vessel and hacking them to death with a sword or shooting them is one of the most satisfying feelings I've ever felt in a video game. There is so many creative things you can use to your advantage when fighting other players from movement to explosive barrels and magical cannonballs. Strongly recommended, double the fun with friends but there is also a matchmaking system that will allow you to queu up with randoms.
If you like adventures, random hilariousness, epic fights and jaw dropping moments then this game is for you. If you ever dreamed of being a pirate then now is your chance.

amazing. just amazing.

Want to feel like a pirate? Love coop games? Then this is the game for you! From the resistance of the waves and wind against your ship, to the sounds of the creaking boards and cannons blasting into the beautiful horizon, Sea of Thieves keeps you immersed in it's world during your session. 

Mind you, it's not for the feint of heart. It's a straightforward game that's "easy to learn, hard to master". There are no upgrades or leveling up. What you see is what you get, three different sized ships meant for appropriately sized crews. You'll need good communication in order to maneuver properly in a galleon. That being said, soloing is not impossible, but can be incredibly difficult as you will be at a disadvantage. Sailing in a small sized sloop is you're only option when by yourself. No matter what your set up is, be prepared to sink. You will die in this game, but each time you'll be a little better, kind of like Dark Souls. It's expected.

I almost didn't get this game due to not having friends to play with, but watch some gameplay videos to get a feel for what it is and maybe you'll be convinced like I was. A good place to start is PhuzzyBond on YouTube. He has a great beginner's playlist that I highly recommend.

All in all, I'm having a blast!

honestly everything i'd want in a pirate game and then some, you can have the simplest fun just sailing the seas with a couple frens looting whatever you find or fighting off random encounters, without even initiating quests or intending to embark on some grand adventure. just get in, load up your ship with supplies, and you're off.

even the worst part of the game as critiqued in several other reviews -- the universal pvp -- feels organic enough that it can be overlooked or embraced depending on what kinda gamer you are. it's pirates, after all, why wouldn't they sink you for whatever you're hiding below deck? and there's enough utility via cursed cannonballs or clever navigating that you're not forced to engage if you're paying attention to your surroundings.

gorgeously stylized, accessible, exciting, devastating, but rarely boring. i'm thrilled sea of thieves came to steam so i could give it a proper chance to impress me, and it does. i'm amped for whatever the next monthly update brings.

Great game to play with friends in a crew, in the same way that you'd play Left 4 Dead with friends. Co-operation and teamwork, where everyone works together to achieve something. If that sounds like something you'd enjoy, in a pirate themes world, give this game a go!

+ No pay to win (from what I've seen so far). All gear upgrades are cosmetic. So you won't fall prey to someone who's paid for a special cannon.
+ Minimal information (can be a con if you want). The game doesn't explain much, but the solutions are logical, so you can figure it out. i.e. use a bucket to bail water from inside your boat and throw the water over the side. No minimap = Use the map and compass to navigate. Eating raw meat can make you sick = cook it!
+ Can pick up a quest whenever and do whatever.  
+ Fun little things you'll discover along the way. Just sail into a storm and fight the ghost ships! Find a note in a bottle, solve the riddles for a treasure chest!
+ Meeting other ships will be a lesson in first contact diplomacy. Playing musical instruments is a good way to show you're friendly.

- Much harder to play solo. Turn the ship wheel, raise the sails, lower the anchor- Oh, you've hit rocks, better patch up the hull and bail the water otherwise that small leak will sink you!
- Ambient voice chat will lead to abuse at times. Have to turn it off.
- Reputation grind. There are factions to gain reputation with. Best to play the game focused on quests and treasure, and have reputation gains as a bonus

I find Sea of Thieves can appeal to a lot of diverse types of gamers: 

  - The ship fighting in Adventure and Arena keeps the PVP (Player vs Player) crowd happy.  
  - The Tall Tales and hidden treasures keep the PVE (Player vs Environment) crowd happy.  
  
Me, I simply enjoy doing the trade routes for the merchant guild. You load up supplies, sail to another island and drop off supplies. Do I get attacked by sharks, skeleton ships, and other players sometimes...? yep. Do I mind, nope? The simple bliss of navigating the open (and mind-blowingly beautiful) seas is all I need. Most people hate chasing chickens.. but for me, looking for animals brings me the hours of mindless entertainment (except snakes... they suck).

It is better if you have a couple friends as random groups are bad (troll filled), but you can play on your own as well. There are plenty of Discord Groups to join welcoming inexperienced players. Me; however, the solo dolo merchant life is all I need.

This game is only fun if you have some friends to dick around with, but without friends it's just a slog through extremely long and boring fetch quests in order to sell a chest full of gold for a quarter of what its probably worth. I mean why would you sell cash? Even with friends its still a pretty slow and boring game as most of it is just traveling from one island to another trying to make dumb pirate jokes along the way (but those get boring fast) and desperately try to find any part of the small stories interesting. 

There is no sort of progression of any kind, there is no story to follow other than the small snippets of missions, and there are no upgrades for gear, ships, or equipment and it feels like there really should be as traveling is so slow and combat is dull. The only reward for missions is gold and levels with whichever clan you did the mission for which just earns you more gold in the next mission and some customizables. The only use of all this gold you earn is customizables (and to purchase other missions but they so cheap you can sell a barrel and get enough to buy them) and most of the customizables are either way to expensive for how lame they look, or just way too expensive. 

The only part of the game that I find fun is being able to cosplay as a pirate and listen to sea shanties with your friends while drinking grog until you vomit on each other.

This is a game about pirates. About sailing the high seas, encountering monsters of the deep, and finding treasure. Where you kill the skeletons that guard that treasure, and then keep said treasure out of the hands of other pirates who look to plunder it. Oh, make no mistake.. you'll be pirated. Your ship will be sunk, your treasure looted, and you sent to the Ferryman before coming back to the mortal realm. And it will be up to you to decide what to do next. 

But that's the fun of the game, to pirate and be pirated, where it comes down to the skill of you and your crew to best those that dare get within canon range. This game is one best played with friends, but do not expect to be able to play with more than 4 people on your ship.

I've played this game for 89 hours so far, and I have no regrets doing so. I love the game and highly recommend it to anyone that dreams of being a pirate themselves. See you on the High Seas, matey!

Do I recommend this game? Do I NOT recommend this game? That's a tricky question to answer. I LOVE this game. I love the experiences I've had with it. I love how much fun and how epic quests can be when you have other people to play with. I love that you can join with random people and dive headfirst into the game without knowing what to expect from your ventures.

I didn't initially like that this was an online game and that you would be sharing the seas with other REAL people (and namely how that's the ONLY mode of gameplay available), but I suppose I've gotten accustomed to it, and even started to appreciate it. The experiences you'll have can vary dramatically. On one server you might get attacked by a big ship while you, with your measly little sloop, are just going about your business trying to have a good time. On another you might get annihilated by the Kraken with at least 10k gold's worth of loot on board, only to lose every bit of it. Then there's a chance you'll run into a nice group of folks willing to ally with you and share their riches, OR you might get paired with someone who turns out to be a great and fun person. There's a lot of chance that goes into each session that you play, and depending on the outcome, you can either really enjoy yourself or find yourself rage quitting over something potentially minor. 

Now, with all of that said, here's what I DON'T love about the game, and strongly encourage the developers to consider changing. 

- There's absolutely no point to anything. Sure, that new sail might look pretty and all, or the capstan might look just darling with its cosmetic changes, but after a few dozen quests to make the gold required to purchase them, what does it REALLY offer you other than aesthetic appeal? And what about the swords, guns etc.? You can make them look awfully cool, but again, it offers you nothing except for AESTHETIC APPEAL. That's how all of the purchases go. You buy it because it looks nice, but then that's it, it does nothing else for you. It can seem worth it at first, but some of these quests are difficult, and you run the risk of getting sunk at any given time. The stress and struggle of each quest is fun, no doubt, but it does not equal the rewards you get out of it. 

- The online segment. Seriously, there are some real bone heads in this game who will sink you JUST because they can, even if you have no loot on board for them to steal. I was playing one time doing a map quest and I remember walking around the island wondering what the everlasting fuck had happened to my sloop. Then I saw the big big ship, the biggest one, where my boat was and they were hauling what little bit of loot I had back onto their ship. Sounds fine, right? Because that's how the game is supposed to go, right? Not when you've got bone heads like that screaming "F A G G O T S" into the mic because they're bigger and stronger than you and there's nothing you can do about it. This severely needs to change. On another occasion, a single sloop took down about three of my allies, including a big ship (can't remember the names of the ships) by silently hopping on board, setting everything on fire and repeatedly sword killing everyone on board. I SWEAR this guy was overpowered because all he had to do was hit me once with the sword and I was back on the ferry of the damned. Probably modded. Again, this SEVERELY needs to change. I suggest servers split into ship size. For example, if I decide to sail with the sloop, I want whatever server the game puts me in to be a SLOOP ONLY server. Same goes for the other two ships. At least in this case, players would have an equal chance to fight off enemies instead of, say, being a sloop and being attacked by a crew of FOUR people against only me, or only my friend and I. That simply isn't balanced gameplay. 

- I can only stack five wood at a time? Really? Not to mention, you can only stack five food items, ten cannonballs and five of the ones in the jars. It's a massive pain to go back and forth 20+ times to get enough wood to keep your ship from sinking should you be unlucky enough to go face to tentacle with the kraken. I would really like to be able to purchase upgrades. Maybe my gun holds more bullets before I need to refill? Maybe I can purchase an extra "slot" or set of slots in my inventory so I can carry more of something at one time. Say from 5 food, I can add one, make it six, or I can add another one, make it seven. I would like something to look forward to, a REASON to be going on these quests looking for treasure. 


Anyway, overall I love this game. I would recommend it for the upside but I encourage the devs to add a few changes to the game to make it better and more appealing for long-term play. Price is a tad greedy for its content in my opinion, but not much of a loss at full price. Give it a try, and don't stop playing if you have a streak of bad luck or if you get a few jackasses on your server in a row. The game offers plenty of wiggle room.

I do play this game with my friends. However when ships follow us and just shout 'die faggots' it kinda makes me not want to play it. It's got really cool PVE and the tall tales are amazing. 
I don't mind the PVP at all aside from the toxicity. I wish the video was more truthful. The PVP in the game isn't just in the area. Soloing is less likely possible because of bigger ships. The only thing that carries over are your gold and deblones. The tutorial isn't very useful at all really. 
The lore is amazing, the visuals are gorgeous. PVP can be fun. You know unless you have very toxic players but I mean having a good fight is amazingly fun. I don't mind the GG part and good sportsmanship. 
Steam did ruin this game a little with the amount of aggresive players. I want to fish. I don't have treasure on my ship. I've had players just take out my ship for no reason. At first I didn't mind and retaliated and got better at driving and menuvoring because of it, however as time went on it was almost every game to the point where it wasn't fun to solo at all. Having a second person made it easier yes. 
After a bit I realized it isn't about skill but numbers. Which isn't how I play at all. Doing tall tales is almost impossible as a solo mostly because of the travel time it takes to do them. Yes you make out with a bandit but the likely hood of someone just blowing you up are too high. 
Anyway, if you have friends you should be fine BUT if you solo be careful out there. With steam being in the xplay it brought a lot of people who verbally will abuse you. Just switch servers. I know you lose everything you had but don't give them the satisfactory of anything. Hope they don't kill this game. I've had 2 friends stop playing because they were insulted, and a streamer friend of mine worried about his twitch channel because of what was said.

Also the only thing you can spend your loot on is cosmetics. Whether its on your ship, character, weapons or pets its not that great. Of course its always about the journey not the destination. And the journey is great.

Edit: Right after I wrote this review my shipmate and I finally found our first player. They fired first which sent me out of my ship and into the water. I swam over to their ship and boarded it. I completely caught them by surprise and killed both of our soon to be booty snatchers with precision sword attacks. I ran downstairs where I found a treasure chest and then jumped back to my boat. By then both of them have responded. Then we preceded to be chased for 20 freaking minutes. We finally made it to a port and sold their booty. Since this encounter I have had a complete blast playing this game. However I do wish there was a character leveling or ranking system. There are factions you level up but you only unlock new cosmetics from them. The cosmetics are cool and all, but I wan't to work towards a new weapon not a different colored weapon. I also wish your ship and all your equipment didn't reset after you logoff. This means if you don't have 4 hrs to spend on this game in a single session, you're not going to progress that much. Sea of Thieves has a lot of potential and I hope they expand on some of the things they have going for them.

I sailed close to an island that had skeletons on it and they were shooting cannons at me. I was playing solo and was being overwhelmed and bombarded; i only had time to patch the holes in my ship and throw buckets of water out from below deck before another cannonball would hit and i had to repeat the process just to stay afloat. I couldn't get a single shot in, or else risk having my ship sink. It looked like I was done for.

Then, suddenly, another player was sailing by and offered to help! I was saved! Except once he took out all of the skeletons, he then set his sights on me and began to unload more cannonballs into the hull of my ship. I tried to outrun him but realized it would be impossible; I was out of wood and could no longer repair my ship, and i was rapidly taking on water. 

I jumped into the ocean, somehow unnoticed, and swam up to their rapidly approaching ship. I climbed up their ladder and realized I had the element of surprise so I quickly killed the captain, and then his only crewmate who was manning the cannons. 

I won. My ship would sink but I won. I then saw all the treasure they had stashed on their ship. It was an impressive haul that surely must've taken hours to collect. So I made their ship go as fast as it could and, before they could respawn, I systematically proceeded to throw all of their treasure directly into the fucking ocean.

I am enjoying this game. It's kind of hard to find a team initially and you might have to restart a few times since there's no actual way of browsing available teams. But when you find some randoms who actually want to play the game properly, it's a very fun experience. 

There are no stats or levelling or XP system to bog the gameplay down, there's only treasure which you use to buy cosmetics. When you complete a mission, you'll rank up in your reputation to whichever faction gave you the mission, allowing you to access harder and more lucrative contracts. 

It sounds very basic but to be honest a levelling RPG system would be unnecessary in a game like this. The PVP is a lot of fun and the ship battles are long and hard-fought, when you win you get to steal all the loot from the other guys' ship. 

 If you like sandbox survival games you'll probably like this one. It's less like ARK and more like Rust. The feeling of paranoia and the need to be vigilant and cautious is a huge source of fun. If you don't like games where you're under potential threat everywhere and there's no safe areas from PVP, you probably won't like this. It's surprisingly brutal and you can spend ages collecting treasure only to have it taken by a bigger group with a bigger boat. 

It makes me want to play it more, and I don't think I'll get bored of it any time soon, so that is a pretty solid recommendation from me.

In my opinion, this is the best pirate/sailing game out there, with the prettiest water graphics by a wide margin. It's also one of the best open-world, sandbox-y multiplayer games I've played: all the PvP, tension, and social interaction of survival games, but with none of the long-term commitment and risk that comes with base building.

There are three big disclaimers, which may either scare you away or draw you in:

1. No gear upgrades, no vertical progression: everything you unlock will be cosmetic. If you want to grind for functional loot, this isn't the game for you. If you want to personalize your outfit, gear, and ship, it's got you covered ten times over.

2. No offline mode, and going solo is pretty lonely. Playing alone puts you at a huge disadvantage, at least until you really know what you're doing... And even then, it's always more fun with a crew. If you don't have friends to play with and want to set sail with strangers, you should probably use the official Discord server instead of the in-game matchmaking.

3. Expect to spend a lot of time just sailing around. The trip will be gorgeous, and there's always stuff to do (trimming the sails, fishing, cooking, etc), but it will get boring fast unless you really enjoy the ambience of being on the water (or have friends to chat with).

If none of those three points sound unbearably awful, then you'll probably love this game.

I have 2 major problems I can't get over to give this game a good review. One is the complete lack of progression, which has been argued both ways, and the other is the community, which again has been argued several times over. I understand the reason for no progression, level even playing field and all of that. Does progression in this game really mean getting an advantage over the other in a major significant way? Why can't we get progression towards less sway of our sniper scopes, an upgrade to inventory space, even something as small as the speed you carry a chest. There's nothing that gives a player seeking purpose to play other than ruin other people's experiences. Open Crew is without a doubt the worst option to play this game. This community is the pinnacle of subhuman specimens. When I join open crew, I'm greeted by either 1, people who do not speak my language, in a server with 150 ping. 2, quiet griefers who throw fire/explosive bombs on deck and leave. 3, pre teens. 4, The people who actually know what theyre doing. This is a problem because when I've been a part of them, they sailed over to a sloop with 2 guys in starter gear begging to be left alone because they were trying to learn. I guarantee I watched and took part in helping 2 people no longer play this game again. So the PvP is forced, making people who don't want to take part in it the easy targets, and told to get over it because that's what the game is supposed to be about. The story in this game is probably one of the most dragged out, repetitive, and absolute boring story lines I've ever tried to do. Beating every tall tale in the game rewards only partial the rewards, because in order to fully complete the mission, it must be completed 5 or more times in order to be 100%. This idea was only created by the 1 man who actually thought this never ending fetch quest was decent, and that's because he made the thing. What's the reward for finally putting in all of that time and effort into beating the campaign? 10,000 gold. Bear in mind, a PvP infested area known as Fort of the Damned, has a reward that can net you well over 250,000. Another giant slap in the face to those who are trying to find the PvE, as if the lack of progression, lack of solid storyline, and lack of content in general wasn't enough. There's 4 factions. Get them to level 50 and huzzah you did it, go sink players until you're bored of it. Then we're told: we're actually lucky! We didn't see what this game was like 2 years ago, it was so much more shallow! If I played 2 years ago, I would've played well under half the time I played now, and I would've been led to the same conclusion. Who's really lucky then? That would be those who never play this "game" at all.

Welcome to the Sea of Thieves!

The sea where you decide whether you want to serve the order of souls and hunt skeleton captains, or perhaps you want to work for the Gold Hoarders company, and get a bit of extra coin for every item you sell! Or maybe... it just doesn't matter! You want to sail the darn seas, battling rivalries, diving into shipwrecks, or hunting the monsters of the sea.

A game with such solid design, and an artsy touch on the textures that it elevates the gameplay experience beyond your imagination.

Truly the best looking water you'll ever see in any game too!

- My experience for this game to date:

I've been playing with randoms and it of course has its ups and downs, from getting people with no mics or just plain people but the most important part, is that I haven't met anyone annoying or planned to grief his own crew and that's a plus. (In a 2 man crew, because if you're 3+ you can vote to put them in the brig)

The game itself is kinda simple and easy to learn, and gets super interesting when you want to learn proper naval combat.

Doing voyages is fun for the most part and very rewarding the more you do, they aren't hard at all and they don't take too much time either. As for tall tales they can get SUPER interesting and the puzzles become tough, like really tough, but its -as the name says- way of telling a quest like a tall (and it being tall lol) can keep you busy for a whole lot, and still reward you quite nicely.

- Bugs/Glitches/Issues:

Haven't noticed any lag or lag spikes or disconnects or crashes, very minor bugs that don't really affect anything.

* I was very flattered by the recent Haunted Shores update, it isn't the biggest update, but it is a foundation for the upcoming tales we are about to experience.

This could be my first truly flawless game, and I love it VERY much.

Thank you, Rare.

The game itselft is awesome, BUT it has no Steam support whatsoever apart from being sold on Steam. Why do we have to mess with a garbage platform like xbox live when we bought the game on Steam? A co-op game on Steam should use the Steam interface for match making instead of forcing you to create accounts on rubbish platforms that you would otherwise never use for anything. Xbox live is complete trash, their servers are constantly down, your account gets locked all the time for no reason, and they charge you 10$ for changing your profile name because apparently xbox developers cannot distinguish between an internal player ID and a public player name.

It's sad to see great games like this waste their potential on trashy platforms like xbox live. Thank god this game was released on Steam. Hopefully they will implement Steam support once they eventually realize that xbox cannot compete with Steam in any form, and that 90% of their player base will be on Steam. Get it right: Steam players do not care about playing with console players (who cannot compete anyways), we care about playing with our Steam friends.

If they add Steam support I'm changing this to a positive review. As for now though I cannot recommend a game that releases on Steam but forces me to use a dysfunctional and predatory service run by a company like microsoft.

DON'T BUY IT IF YOU'RE PLANNING ON PLAYING IT SOLO

 Now that I've addressed the obvious part out, I should say that I recommend this game fully (even tho I play solo too cause even the friends I have that bought the game won't even play it). The graphics aren't realistic per say but the cartoonish style combined with the spectacular sunsets and the general vibrance of the game makes it a good time on your eyes. If your pc is lagging for some reason then it might be because of either rendering distance or some particle effects options. Sound design (including the ambience and shanties) is on par with the graphics, in which they make me almost miss the AC: Black Flag times.
 There are some bugs here and there including the flying ships (which didn't happen to me luckily (yet)), and some sound bugs in which a certain sound gets stuck like underwater bass(?) but they easily go away once you do that sound specific action again.

 Now to speak of the community, I have stumbled upon a few people that avoided conflict and even one that I befriended for the remainder of a game session although don't expect this behavior from all you come across. A lot of the time people want to taste the freedom an open world PVP game gives them and attack you at no reason at hand, however that is the part of the game (hell, it is the game). Playing with your friends or a crew makes this PVP time a lot less frustrating cause you might come out victorious but as I said at the beginning, if you're playing solo, don't expect a good outcome. I have managed to get away from a few ships but that's the extent of good luck. Sinking your ship even though you just got into the game and haven't even got out of the port, backstabbing you after playing friendly, pursuing you to the ends of  the world just to get one chest from your ship (which is the most common thing you're gonna stumble upon), and finally the sloop's which are recommended for two players but a lot of the times only one player boards them and you trust this information so much that an actual two players come out from it to whoop your ass (happened to me right before writing this actually).

 Overall, a nice sailing/pirating game to, you know, being a pirate.

So I've known about this game forever and wanted to get it back when it launched but the Microsoft Store really is giant piece of bloatware so i stayed away. 

Anyhow i have a About 30 Hours into the game and I have to say it's a-lot of fun so far.    I've Mainly Just sailed around and searched for treasure on islands or did some of the in-game missions.     Some have you take supplies from one port to another.    Or Take Chickens to a vendor.     there's alot of different activities to do.   

I will say though this game is ALOT more fun with friends.    Not only to help you gather treasure and defeat enemies but this game has a pretty big open PvP scene and people WILL come by and sink you and take your stuff just because they can.     If you get easily upset i would steer clear.   

But i would also encourage to continue as losing some treasure really is not as bad as mostly the gold and doubloons in the game you get really is just there to help you buy cosmetic items.    Also Everyone has the same weapons so the playing field is all EVEN and no one has an advantage over another player.

All and All i give it a 8/10 and a 9/10 with friends.      It's a good time all around.

I was pretty confused at first when I started playing, so im going to sum up the key aspects of the game. You take quests from 3 different types of guilds, each which provide different styles of missions. Once completed, you get gold and improve your rank in that guild. Gold is just for aesthetics, and there is no weapon progression, the goal of the game is to get all 3 guild rankings to a certain level. If your ship sinks you get a new one for free but any treasure on board is lost, same thing if you log off. All in all, its a extremely fun and rewarding game that I spent 5 hours in my first session playing.

There is one reason why this game sucks and only one. One major flaw to rule them all and devs refuse to fix it even if the fix itself is actually VERY easy to implement.

Athena voyages (end game) take way too long. Especially if you are solloing on sloop. When you sign up for Athena, you better have anywhere from 3-5 hours of free time. And I mean free time. Because if you go afk for more than 10 minutes, you will get kicked and all your progress is lost. So better visit the WC before you start the session.

Take my current example. It took me 4 hours to get to the point where I was on my ship with the Legendary chest, burning one you can sell for over 8k gold and plent of reputation. At one point I was attacked by Kraken and pirate ship alongside an island that went boom (volcano), I survived all of that and more, only to get a server disconnection when I was nearing the port to sell the Legendary Chest. Meaning 4 hours of progress fully lost.

I have spoken about this one MAJOR flaw on forums more than once. The fix itself is easy. Just implement mini Athena voyages for half the reward that will take half the time. So instead of 3-5 hours marathons, you would have 1,5 - 2,5 hours. But no... Refunding again... I forgot how bad this issue was. Maybe one day they will fix it. Maybe one day they will actually listen to reason. Until then o7

As a (relatively) new player, who solo'd the first few hours of this (yes IT IS POSSIBLE) I can confirm that, whatever others may say, you can play this game solo, at least in the early game when you are taking on low profile adventures. However once you start picking up valuable items you are going to want a crew, for protection more than anything else.

Pro Tip: DO THE MAIDEN VOYAGE introduction level. Sea of Thieves doesn't hold your hand apart from this, so get everything out of the tutorial level you can. Mess around with your ship, anchor, sails, cannons, locate your inventory boxes and get used to steering and the map. No spoliers but I'd STRONGLY ADVISE fully exploring the island on the tutorial level, it can give you a big boost going into the main game. 

I recommend this game, however given it's price, I would ensure you are comfortable playing with others (either friends or strangers) because you are only likely to get 5-10 hours of single player enjoyment from this before needing others to help.

I played this game a ton using the Xbox Game Pass that came with my AMD CPU and fell in love with it. I got to Pirate Legend in those 3 months. It's a great game for people that love to grind out levels and earn cosmetic rewards.

It's not for people who love non-stop action and need other types of rewards, other than cosmetics.

I suggest signing up with a month of Xbox Game Pass to test it out before buying it, because this game isn't for everyone. I was planning on buying it from the start after getting that free 3 months of game pass. I waited until it was out on Steam though. I would personally put it in my top 10 favorite games of all time. It's a VERY unique and great game that still gets updated every month and there isn't really any pay to win DLC, since it's all cosmetics.

There are some bad things about this game though. The worst thing about this game are the servers and the method that Rare uses to find servers for players. I feel like the game doesn't place you on servers close to you, because i always have 60+ ping and going by the Azure latency test (They use Microsoft's Azure servers). That would mean the game keeps putting me on Central US servers, because the ping test shows 20-30ping on US East Azure Servers via the latency test tool for Azure. The game should be putting me on US East servers.

There are also server merges in the game when one server has a low population, so it merges the players from a dead server into a more populated server. The problem with this is if you aren't near all your loot when this happens. You lose it all. So if you dig up a ton of loot and hide it on an island, because you have to take a Mermaid back to your ship to help fight another player ship and then the server merges, that means all the loot that you left on the island will despawn. So you have to leave at least one player on an island at all times if you don't take all the loot. Shouldn't really be an issue for newer players, but this is a problem for more end game players.

There are also a bunch of bugs and exploits still many years later that haven't been fixed like sound bugs when coming out of the water etc and


The pros outweigh the cons though. This is an AMAZING game that is worth every penny. I will be playing it on and off for years to come.

This game has SOOOOOOOO much more to do now than when I last played which was not long after the game's launch in 2018. Back then all I really had to do was do Merchant, Order of Souls, or Gold lads voyages and fuck with other players. Today I spent the last maybe eight hours only picking up a single voyage like I used to and spending the rest of the time doing cool stuff I randomly picked up, fighting skeleton ships, RUNNING FROM A MEGALODON ON THREE DIFFERENT OCCASIONS (and screaming in terror when I get knocked off into the water with said megalodon), being terrified as a kraken stopped our ship from moving and killed us, and...well still being a total dickhead to other players and stealing their stuff because that's funny as hell all while working on a Tall Tale that sorta acts like a "main story quest" of sorts.

SoT has absolutely come NAUTICAL MILES from where it launched and is definitely worth getting now.

Also now that it's on Steam you no longer have to deal with the Win10 Store BS so that's another plus :^).

40 Hour Edit: The game kind of got boring at this point. Pve is limited, kill skeleton, kill boss, carry the loot to the ship, sell the loot at the next outpost. Still a good game but doesn't make me want to play it anymore. Another deal breaker for me was the lack of pvp in adventure mode in some of my sessions. While I would get to fight 4-5 different ships in a 3 hour gaming session, I would see no other players in my session the next day, which is kind of boring. If they increased the server capacity to 32-36 (right now is 24), I reckon it would be more of an enjoyable experience. It is kinda a lot of too repetitive- pveish at this point for my liking but recommended regardless, haven't had this much excitement in a game since a year or two.

Actual Review:

this is an amazing game, well worth its price.

-You will get to play as a pirate playing different instruments. there are 3-4 different instruments and the music syncs when all your crew play different ones! You will get to choose between 4 different weapons. Your sword (compulsory) or a pistol, shotgun or a sniper rifle. 
-You will discover new islands, new biomes. You will get killed by skeleton pirates (they have different variations and they could be quite harsh and spooky). You will have pleasant and horrible surprises through your journey between the islands, monsters and fineass loot per se. 
-You will have intense moments over loot, your heart will race through epic moments. You will learn how to fight.
-You will have sea sickness after you turn off the computer. 
-The splash sound as you jump into the water is extremely realistic, you will feel wet and see the bubbles like you jumped from a rock in real life.


-You will be insulted a lot as you could hear other crew's mic chats when you dont have much distance between you and them.

Some side notes:
-Graphics are fortnite-ish and cartoony. 
-Customisation of the characters is alright, you can have pets which are interactive and they will dance to the music you make! 
-You absolutely need a mic and this is not a casual game where you could enter and play for 30 minutes and disconnect (unless you are playing solo). Travelling between locations usually take around 10-15 minutes.
-Game is running solid 60 fps+ on i7- 4790k- gtx 1080 @1080p

Rare just announce a closed test for private servers, and these servers would not allow farming for gold and reputation.  

In my mind, Sea of Thieves is ranked lower than GTA V for encouraging toxic PvP gameplay and discouraging the PvE, puzzle, mission-type games.  In both games, you can't develop yourself (and in GTA your CEO organization/motorcycle club) without being in public and exposing yourself to players who exist just to grief.  But now Sea of Thieves wants you to pay for the ability to play privately while disabling your advancement?  No thanks.  If I have to pay for the private server in addition to the base experience, I expect to be able to complete voyages and reap full rewards.  I'm not paying to punish myself, thanks.  If they don't want me to use the private servers to farm rep in peace, then make the servers free.  You can't have your cake and eat it too.

Confusing, complicated, unrewarding and hostile to new players, this game is exactly the opposite of Deep Rock Galactic. 

"Why do I have 4 musical instruments? Why is navigation purposefully difficult? Why does everyone try to kill me for no reason? What's the deal with these mermaids? Why does the respawn mechanic suck?" These questions and more await you on the procedurally generated scenic vistas of Sea of Thieves. Once you get past the nice visuals and hip aesthetic you're left with a bewildering and unrewarding gameplay loop. Combat is a heady blend of boring, difficult and fatal and rewards get tedious and repetitive inside the first hour.

No PVE. The Adventure mode which has a max of 6 crews with 1-4 players each at once while not focused on PVP still has it and will still happen. If you want to try it anyway since it is a good game be aware that randomizing characters until you're happy with one can sometimes take over 2h (especially female characters) preventing you from refunding it if you don't like it.

In conclusion to do not go into this game expecting anything other than a PVP experience for now. They are planning to add private servers which would solve this issue but until then I'm keeping this review as negative.

Update: Private servers are getting added soon but you will get no rewards from anything you do on them. You can have a bigger crew than 4 on those but what's the point if there is no progression when you play on them?

- first, it asked to login into the Microsoft Live account, ok, we did, second - it asked to link steam, well, ok, not saying it does not do anything automatically and I was forced to login into my steam account via Xbox Game Bar overlay entering my credentials and 2 auth again (why would I need to Microsoft?! I am already on steam!)

- Ok, then the "Invite friend" on the lobby was disabled no matter what we do, it turned out that it does not work on PC at all and we need to use Xbox APP (what!). I had the app installed and was able see the overlay (though took me a while to figure out how to add my friend to the friends list), but my friend does not have the app installed, so he tried to install it from the xbox live site ( you know what? there is a beta available on the site, that's all, no stable or alternative version or whatever, only "download beta app") ok, he did download the app and tried to install it, but the installation failed silently (sick!)

- finally, despite my friend was unable to install the Xbox App and has no overlay, he managed to see me in in-game the invitation list when he created the lobby and invite me, and I did receive the invitation, but you know what?! you guess? when I click on accept icon - NOTHING HAPPENED, literally, nothing. nah, that's just EPIC!

In the first 4 hours I've played with friends, we've got a little too... immersed into the game, to the point we began singing some shanties and overall tried to talk like pirates. We sailed the high seas in search of precious booty, but ultimately found our demise when the scurvy of the seas caught up to us. Skellingtons came out of the waters, only to be followed by the Kraken itself! We fought to our last resources, we managed to hold it off for as long as we could, but as ye expect this tale to go, we were sent to the hereafter.... 

Game gets a ride of the valkyries/10

Bugs:

 There are still bugs reported over two years ago, while some of these bugs include audio issues which is mild annoyance there are things that break gameplay. As an example you cannot jump or move the mouse only vertically after you get off your ship. Solution for many of these seems to be dying and respawning to fix them, however in the middle of a sea battle this is something you cannot afford.

Players: 

 There are players who after joining your crew, start to firebomb your ship, throwing treasures you collected off board, dropping anchor, raising sails or diverting course by grabbing the wheel and not letting go. You can’t kick them or look for another group without sacrificing what you collected as supplies, treasure and emissary level. Only option is to send this person to the brig but if you and this person are the only ones in the group due there is no majority you can't vote for brig.

Voice Chat, Text Chat, Player Names:

 Racism and xenophobia seems to be everywhere.

 Ever forced to listen to a racist song because of your crew members character's skin color or their accent ? 
Solution: Mute the voice. 

 Tired of reading the same thing in text form ? 
Solution: Mute the text. 

 Oh player name is the same thing ?
Solution:  Hide player names. 

	 Somehow instead taking action you play three monkeys by seeing no evil, hearing no evil and speaking no evil. Inorder to report a player you have to jump through hoops, now that is the quality i would expect from small indie companies such as MICROSOFT and RARE, don’t believe me ? Have a look.  https://support.seaofthieves.com/hc/en-gb/articles/360000779227-How-to-report-a-player

Gameplay: 

	Sea Battles: As the name suggests thieves are in the sea rather than their ships. Sea battles are fought by dashing through the water either by climbing into a cannon and firing yourself or power attacking with your sword in order to climb the ladder of the opposing ship. These magical ladders are nor removable so they provide a constant weak point, if you are boarded you will be spawn camped and only option reminded while waiting for respawn is to sink your ship and restart in a new location.

	Cycle: You search for treasure, you sell the treasure and repeat 

Conclusion:

	I fell for the eidos or the essence of the concept. Reality sadly far from it. I would not recommend it.
