This is a game

Well, I was about to say that this game is totally undeserving the hype and is a bad game, but, it has these "burps of greatness" which changes everything. 

Let me explain, it is really atmospheric and open to imagination rather than grind. 

First night i was playing SoT, we were four friends and two were actual seamen. It was understandably epic to act like pirate crew while using all the lingo of actual sailors, trying to get into battle. However, it was the second night i played the game which actually hooked me.

Me and two others had this mid-tier ship and i decided that we should be pirate hunters instead of pirates. Since everybody is complaining about PVP in forums and wanting PVE, i thought "hey, i guess we can make friends" and it would be great to experience the other side for a change.

We've traveled around for a while with random quests and found this riddle message in a bottle, eventually leading to this avian themed island with bird like statues. It took us so long to get the riddle right, one of our crew members passed out from drinking in real life, so we put his character in brig (holding cell in our ship). After we solved the riddle as the remaining crew members, we've decided to get the goodies to an island with merchants and on our way we had an encounter which went friendly after announcing ourselves as such. We were now sure that we can sail friendly and only engage if necessary or to hunt more notorious pirates. After all, notorious ones are easier to identify, heavily modified ships are more likely to be owned by experienced players, which in turn more likely to be hostile on spot due to being more confident with the game.

Couple of minutes later we left the port again, we were chasing around another ship to ask whether they saw any pirates (hoping they would say; "Yes, us!" , so we could start a fight and end the night in high note with all the shenanigans) and found one lone ship anchored near a field of debris. Much to our disappointment, this group turned out to be friendly as well and pointed us further north for pirates. We, in disbelief and sure they were lying, sailed north anyways to maintain character but also keeping an eye out for this one ship on our back. Then suddenly, loud noise of cannonshots! Two ships, one manned by undead came out of nowhere and guns started blazing. The last thing i saw before leaving the ship with a keg of cannon-powder was Kraken's arms raising up. I lit the barrel, threw the keg at this huge tentacle and swam as fast as i can to get away, shouting "help" towards the crew we just had a chat. 

My ship went down, but,i survived the ordeal with heavy injuries, yet the undead ship followed me to battle with these guys as well. I immediately jumped to this unknown ship's guns, shouting "friendly! friendly!" and started bombarding while good captain tried to rout away from both ships and a storm. I must add at this point that we were not sharing a common language. Either i landed enough shots on the other ships or captain was good with his trim but we got away. Sound of sea and the wind went back to normal, checking the ship i saw only the captain was alive, the other crew member i don't know what happened. 

After a minute of silently emoting respect, I saw something shining on the sea, a bit behind us, closer to the battle zone. You see, i had to check it. Shouting one last farewell, I jumped off the ship, ofcourse i was trusting the friendly mermaids for a ride back home. Among some barrels floating, i found this peculiar blue stone, most likely from another ship sunk by the undead crew or the second ship which attacked us at the start of the fight. I wanted to take the stone back home with me but the damned mermaid refused to take me back with the stone in my hand. So, I decided to make my way to the nearest island, swimming angrily to the stupid mermaids. 

Everything was well until i saw a fin on the surface of the water, got attacked by the shark almost immediately after i saw it. Raising my pistol, i spent my last shot on the predator and immediately started slicing it with my new sabre. To my suprise, it didn't take too long for this shark to be mortally wounded and somehow i survived yet again. I made my way to this rock formation which i initially thought was an island and climbed a bit to use my spyglass, there were no sign of life for miles. The damned mermaid below me, i was checking for other ships to get a ride, hopefully not giving up on this blue stone (Sapphire of the Mermaid or something). It was one really long day for Papenbard the Privateer.

That is where i left off, an amazing adventure for me. What is even better, when i get in the game next time, it will start in a tavern with a mysterious stranger commenting something like "Aha, another new face. That was quite the celebration when you arrived... I am not surprised you don't remember it. "

It is atmospheric.

**Edited for typos & clarifications.

[h1] Fun, simple and engaging [/h1]

It's so refreshing to have a game where you can simply log in and start playing.
No leveling required, no daily quest, no grinding for 10 hours to unlock the meta item or whatever..

The game has different quest types. Most of them are, in a way, go pick up this and bring it back BUT the way you get that item is different for every quest type. Besides that, you have world events which you could call raids, and of course PvP is always around the palm tree.

[b]About the Game[/b]
[list]
[*]The GAMEPLAY is designed to be a cooperative experience. If you want to play alone you can and you will be able to get some things done, you might even sink some unaware ships, but you won't be able to get the full experience.

[*]The CORE of the GAME it's the open world sandbox element. It doesn't matter how many times you do the same quest, every time will be different because other players and the world itself will have different things to throw at you. Literally.

[*]The ENDEGAME: do pirating, get gold, get pimped.

[*]Explosive Kegs: They are a thing
[/list]

Sea of Thieves is a wonderful game to play solo or with friends.

There is a lot of content and monthly updates with great new additions to keep you going.

What I love most about this game is you come across such a variety of people while sailing the seas.. this can be from a typical pirate who wants to board your ship and steal your plunder.. or even down to a really friendly chap looking to create an alliance and work together.

The art style of the game is great, Rare have done an amazing job over the past years.

With every game there are always bugs that are introduced in updates.. but the developers seem to keep an eye on these and inform the community of the most important ones which are being tracked and worked on, with usually a fix put into place quickly depending on the severity or at a minimum within the next update.

Overall a great game, 10/10 and plenty of things to keep you going for hundreds of hours.
Love this game! Would recommend to those looking to tryhard and for those wanting a chilled time with mates.

My recommendation of the game comes with a caveat.

Yes, I recommend the game, but. It is clearly meant for teamplay and not solo play. 
The game proves it is very much PVP, which for a mostly casual gamer like myself is a bit off putting. Unless as mentioned earlier, you are part of a crew, in which case it feels amazing. Having friends man the cannons, trimming and adjusting the sails for optimal speeds, while another is at the helm. This is where the game shines.
Playing by myself I haven't found a single other player who doesn't feel the need to go out of their way to attack, harass or otherwise mess with me. Meanwhile, I am merely trying to do my own thing. Sail my sloop, collect some loot, grind some reputation. Which all too often made me frustrated enough to just opt out for the game for the rest of the night.
The game is gorgeous though. It being summer here now and hot....the water just makes me want to dive in and go for a swim, the amount of customisation for ones character and ship is a nice touch and really feels like you are your own (wo)man. 
Overall though, I do not regret having purchased the game. Have had an amazing multiplayer with friends experience, and a lesser solo experience.

I'd give this game 8/10 for what it is.

I'm a seafarer myself. It is just my passion to spend months at sea.
But because of the ongoing global pandemic, the job opportunities just doesn't come yet. Hence I really miss to be out there sailing away on the vast empty seas.

Thanks to the Sea of Thieves, I could finally relive the moments on the virtual world.
Of the sea breeze as I angled my sail away. Of the hard hitting waves from the rain pouring storms. The massive blue horizon as the eye could feast. The tankards we raised with friends as we dance to shanties.....

But now, I will miss this gem. As I would be sailing again for real this time, for how long I would never know. Thank you for this awesome and wonderful experience..
I will make sure to come back, to sail again on the Sea of Thieves.

Not a lot of hours yet, but so far really loving the game with my two other friends. Graphics are beautiful, sailing mechanics are perfect, customisation is brilliant and worth the grind, not to mention the funky instrumental music your crew can create. 

PVP is challenging as we aren't very good yet but hopefully we'll be the ones destroying galleons with ease eventually. Got frame drops on the shroudbreaker Tall Tale near the end, but my PC isn't that high-tier anyway. 

My only real complaint would be there's no sense of direction when starting out (except the very basic tutorial). Its kinda like the elite dangerous of the caribbean, make your own paths and stuff. Id recommend watching a few beginner guide videos and having the Sea Of Thieves Wiki on hand when you're not yet experienced in the game, it helps a lot.

TL;DR: Beautiful, satisfying, and very enjoyable with friends, but is hard to know where to go at the start.

This is a fantastic game with a large vast sea of content. The game is a mix of GTA 5 online, Rust and doing pirate stuff. It has satisfying both PVE and PVP gameplay.  Game can be played up to with 4 friends  (recommend), but this can be exceeded with alliances. The game is also popular according to steam charts but the player base is much bigger as steam does not include all the players on xbox and who bought the game through the microsoft store. Dont let the price tag scare you too much as u will get your moneys worth and u dont need to spend anymore afterwards as most cosmetics are purchasable through the currency you earn. Micro-transactions are for the little extra such as pets, emotes and certain skin bundles.

-loads of content and progression
-in game events which lead to fat loot and possible PVP fights
-very fun ship combat, and land combat against AI and especially players
-Ship AI arent complete bots and are rewarding to defeat. They can spawn when you have lots of treasure on your ship leading to some intense sea dog fights
-No pay to win
-large amounts of customisation through unlockable skins
-constant game support through updates
-large open map to sail the seas
-boss fights with monster creatures
-the game provides a large range of game play opportunities
-great water physics with a fun graphics style

Brilliant game. Everyone is on the same playing field whether you it's your first time setting sail or been there since launch. It comes down to skill and knowledge. Sure there will be times you log in and get all your hard earned loot taken, but next time you log in you'll know what you did wrong and make a different mistake instead, and have to learn from that one too. 

Once you get a handle on what you're doing, you'll be able to take this game exactly where you want, whether it be doing server raids, hunting other player ships, doing story adventures, or pure PVE taking on the skeletons and ghost fleets. Experience makes the difference and you gain it quick!


Sailing around and exploring the world is very rewarding. Sometimes just spending an hour sailing with no destination in mind is the exact kind of chill you need. 

I will say one thing, this game is 100% better with friends! Sailing solo is doable no problem at all, but taking a few friends and sailing a ship together will make for raucous fun, plenty of laughs, and a new story each time you log in.

Game's really good, even at a $40 price point. I've followed it since well before it launched and while I'm a bit miffed at Microsoft's vice grip over releasing this game on Steam and still requiring this to go through the XBL service, the game itself is solid and Rare outdid themselves and any other company as far as ocean and boating mechanics go. 

The gameplay feels fluid and has a decent skill ceiling for sure. Getting a really talented and aware crew of friends together is extremely rewarding, and allows you to tackle anything the game can throw at you, sometimes simultaneously. 

What might throw people off is the pace of the game, and the gameplay loop itself. You are spending a lot of time (some might say downtime) sailing between locations. The islands themselves don't generally offer too much for you to do on them unless there is a Tall Tale (quest) or event at them. For the most part, you're engaging in general piracy and a lot of the fun comes from what you want to get out of it. For the play style my friends and I have which is a hyper-aggressive band of pirates that want to maximize the money we make, it is extremely fun and the most fun we have is when met with a similar crew that challenges us. For the more casual or friendly players, though, I could see how this would detract from their fun but you have to consider that you are playing a PvPvE open-world game about pirates, so...

Anyway, I'd wholeheartedly recommend it. You can sample it on the Xbox Store with their game pass for $1 for a month if I'm not mistaken. Plenty of time to see if it's your thing. For me personally, who loves open-ended sea content and was depressingly disappointed with sea content from games like Black Desert and Atlas, this is the one that scratches that itch for me. 

Do I wish there was more to it? Sure. But Rare does a great job at adding new content and keeping things fresh. I have some faith it will get even better in time as it has been since the game launched, but it's already more than good enough for me.

Sea of Thieves is a very fun game. Forget everything you heard about it at launch, they have added so much content since then. Yes, it is yet another game that launched basically incomplete, but I'm glad they've have stuck with it and made all the content updates completely free. The price tag for this 2 year old game is quite high, especially when it didn't launch very great. But with all of the free content updates, it is worth the price.

If you're planning on playing this game solo, don't buy it. This game is amazing with friends, the fun you have is great, but alone you have to grind, and sometimes you'll get destroyed by a Galleon and all of your 3 hour grind is gone. 

There is quite a big gameplay loop. Go collect treasure, take it back to an outpost and sell it, repeat. But there are a lot of random events that make this loop not so boring. You'll have to fight off a Kraken from your loot, or blow up a Megalodon. Maybe you'll get jumped by a skeleton ship, or attacked by a group of players hungry for your loot. 

This brings me to the PvP in this game, it is simply amazing. It is by far my favourite part of the game. You can work out your own strategy for attacking player ships, and if you have a good group of friends to play with you, your ship should work like a well oiled machine. One man steering, 2 people to fix repairs and bail water while also manning the cannon, and one or 2 people to board the enemy ship and try to slow them down. The combat is completely skill based, as everyone has the same weapons. Only having a max of 5 bullets per gun is a great way to keep you on your feet in combat. 

Thank you for reading my essay for those who did. Overall this is a great game and I would recommend if you can get past the price and get a good group of friends to play.

I might not have committed hundreds of hours into this game yet, but I think 30 hours is enough for a review. Sea of Thieves is a gorgeous game with plenty of freedom; you can form a band with your friends all day long, sail the seas and hunt for treasures or monsters, do some story-based tall tales, invade a fort full of skeletons, or simply engage in PvP with other pirates. 

Sure, there may seem to be a lack of progression (since all the things you can buy are either quests for golds or cosmetics), but I think the game is not designed with a 'get-stronger-via-items' progression system in mind. It's a game meant to be played with friends or other people and have a fun couple of hours. The cosmetics are merely for a sense of achievement or connection with your character, but that's enough for me. 

With that system, people will not have to fear being owned by players who have better weapons or armor, and can instead focus on what matters: honing one's experience in sailing the seas and have fun.

I recommend you do a thorough amount of research on the game before making a purchase.  It is not ideal if you are a solo player / lone wolf.  It is designed for co-operative play, so if you don't have friends to play the game with or aren't interested in befriending randoms to join a crew, I would not suggest buying it.  The premise seems fun, but...  while there is a tutorial "maiden voyage" that teaches you the most basic of controls, you are pretty much thrown to the sharks beyond that.  The controls (mainly, the use of the radial to select different items/equipment) is a bit awkward and the graphics are so-so. From my experience, the SoT player community is not very welcoming to new players.  When you start a new adventure, you begin at a tavern on a random island within the game world.  Three times in a row, my ship was destroyed/sunk/under attack before I even got to it without even really knowing what was happening.  I got shouted and jeered at over the microphone by some kid yelling "GG!  GG!" before I was in the game for 3 minutes.  Maybe I just had bad luck and I'm soured at the experience, but as a mostly lone wolf player, my experience starting out in this game was disappointing.  Sadly, while I was tabbed trying to read up on some guides/tutorials to get a better handle of the game, I went over the 2 hour played mark and am unable to get a refund...  So, RIP to my $40 on a game I have zero intention of ever playing again.

On the seas it's either you or me. I've been playing this game pre-steam release with a thousand hours under my belt., and then some. Whether you're interesting in the peaceful and relaxing voyages and Tall Tales (story mode), or the hardened pvp and stealing loot all for yourself and your swashbuckling crew, which is what I participate in; there's bound to be something you'll enjoy in this game.

Ok I'm just going to blab some quick notes for you all.

If you can't handle the possibility of getting sunk and losing your treasure that you worked to get for an hour, this might not be the game for you. Because it does happen, and will happen to you at some point. But that's a part of the game and going in you should respect other players playing choices. Especially in game as malleable as Sea Of Thieves.

Getting sunk sucks but it's a part of the learning process and should help you understand what you did wrong, and what to do right the next time.

The devs are active and there are monthly updates, so you don't have to e-beg on the forums and discussion posts for updates :)

Despite what many Youtube reviews may say, this game is actually fun. It's quite literally an open world sandbox true and true. There is no progression system to make yourself better, no pay to win items, no lootboxes, no battle pass, nothing. Every player is on the on the same playing field. Obviously some players will be better than others because of skill, friends, or even their ship (the bigger the ship, the more players and coordination you'll need to effectively win battles. An experience sloop captain can easily take on a galleon if they're geared up enough and know what they're doing). The only way to make yourself better is to actually play the game and scavenge for cannon balls, wood to repair the ship, food to heal, and treasure to sell for gold (which can only be used to buy quests, flags, and customization). 

The tutorial alone was enough to make me smile like an idiot and keep saying "Oh that's so cool" because this is the pirate game I wish I had when I was a child but never existed. From shanties, to adjusting the sails length and angle, this is just such an amazing pirate game to pick up but can take a while to master. There is some bad with the game like low frame rate when a lot of ships are in close proximity to each other, the aspect of nothing to do once you get your pirate and ship looking the way you want, the often emptiness of the seas, and the quests are just so bad that the side quests in a Bethesda game are more varied than this. It usually involves killing skeletons, digging up treasures, sailing to one point of the map to give someone something then sailing to another; they're just so tedious and repetitive that it often kills the mood when there's nothing to fight. In terms of fighting stuff, not a whole lot of variation. There's skeletons, skeleton ships, sharks, mermaid statues, a megalodon and a kraken. 

Overall, it's a very very fun game in short bursts and if you can get friends to play it with you, all the better as good times are always to be had when you're playing with people you can crack jokes with or coordinate with. 7/10, fun game but again, only in short bursts. Playing for a long period of time will burn you out on the game quickly and you won't want to return to it again.

I played Sea of Thieves almost a year ago for about a month or so. It was a bit hard to get into but was very well made and fun, Harpoons were added during the time I played and felt like they were a tad too strong when other ships were used to bully me. I stopped playing when I got frustrated with the game balance.

I started playing again a few weeks prior to Steam's release and fully into the launch, it feels and runs better on Steam in my experience. It's not a massive leap, but a one worth investing. The gameplay is the same still but a lot has changed since I played, there's lots of content to earn and always something to do.

The game has a toxicity problem like most online games, but there's a lot more friendly people than you'd expect for an open world PvP game. The biggest problems I face are constant server merges which can be very frustrating and often very poorly timed, leaping on you without warning and potentially ruining whatever it is you are doing. They need to give an advance warning so this shit doesn't sneak up on people. There's time limited events a lot with a ton of cosmetics you'll never earn again too, the most of which you won't have if you didn't play prior to Steam anyways.

Great game.  Every adventure is different.

Note:  I've been playing this game for awhile prior to the Steam release.  

This is a PVP game through and through and that makes it difficult to review.  As a PVP game it's horrible.  In Adventure there is [b]no match making based on skill or team size[/b] and the match doesn't start at the same time for everyone so you'll be short on supplies while a crew that can be four man crew who've played this for years will decimate you before you can even leave the island you started at.  There is also a pure PVP mode called Arena but no PVE based modes.  

The PVE content itself is great.  There's Tall Tales (Story Missions), Skeleton Fleets, Treasure Hunts, Skeleton Forts, fighting giant sea creatures, merchant quests, Ghost Fleets, and more.  All of these can only be done on PVP Servers and very often PVPers will wait for you to do the content then kill you to take it.  They can server hop and teleport between islands to quickly locate anyone doing PVE content in addition to most being already marked by giant visual indicators in the sky.  It's a normal thing to have 4-man PVP crews individually server-hop looking for someone trying to accomplish PVE content and then gather once they find someone to ambush them afterwards.  The PVP is horrible.  There's no avoiding things like crews spawning new ships to teleport ships.  They simply can and will teleport to islands in front of you to cut you off if they can't catch up.  That's considered a good strategy in the game.  You will be spawn camped and you will be sunk for no reason.  I don't understand how they added a fishing faction to the game when it's all PVP.  If you fish you will be sunk.  They recently added checkpoints to the story missions every 10 minutes or so which makes them possible to complete as previously sinking at any point during them caused required items to be lost.  You will often hear of groups camping turn in locations and experienced it myself on the first story mission.  With the addition of checkpoints though you can finally change servers which makes them possible.  The fact progress needs to be saved every 10 minutes or that changing servers is sometimes required to complete the first story mission puts an emphasis on just how PVP oriented the game is with PVE content including the story missions being secondary.

Now when you get sunk in PVP you lose all progress made to leveling the factions in the game which is usually an hour or two plus any story related items you may have had like totems.  You also can lose your emissary progress which can be a few hours worth.  Sinking also means you lose all supplies gathered and resets you back to nothing.

Losing all progress will be infuriating for non-PVP focused players as new players only receive low level quests with small rewards.  It doesn't matter if you have no treasure or barely any, you will be sunk first and they'll see what floats to the top.  The only way to progress through the ranks and unlock any worthwhile voyages are by doing several of the lower level ones.  A lot of the content and cosmetics are locked behind your faction ranks like ghost fleets and a completely new faction with its own missions and rewards.

It just isn't a good gameplay feeling when you set sail with your friends and end up sinking and losing 1-2 hours worth of progress but that is what the game is designed for.  It favors PVP through and through.  This strongly pushes players to play in a full group of 4 on their larger more inconvenient vessels so you'll always need to play with 3 friends and the ship size can't adjust on the fly as people come or go so you'll have to restart if you want to keep a ship that's fully staffed for it's size.  Another agreed upon fact with the community is that the Open Crew (Group Finder) in game is the absolute worst.  You cannot kick and there are no bans for trolls joining to throw treasure overboard and AFKers in this game, they must remain in your crew until they choose to leave.  It is highly recommended by the community that you use discord groups to find a crew and those Discord groups widely will require you to have already become a pirate legend (Level 50 in three factions) to join most crews.  It's a completely backwards system that the community doesn't mind.  You can't level up solo due to PVP putting a one man crew against a four man crew, you can't use open crew because it's downright toxic with no penalty for trolling, and you can't use discords groups as 95% of the crews on there are only looking for people with years of experience.

Fortunately you can get a peek at what the PVE of the game would be like sometimes when you end up on a nearly empty server and can play without the PVP.  It's then a fantastic and beautiful game that I'd highly recommend.    If they ever add a PVE mode I'd highly recommend it all around.  For now I'd say avoid it unless you want to PVP against others who've been playing since 2016.  It's been out for several years but the game still needs major work.

Sea of Thieves is an absolutely amazing and to see the developers pick this game up from the empty void that it was first released as warms my heart so much. So much love has been put into this game and the tightly knit community shows just how attached they are to this game. If I was to add anything else to this game? More enemy types besides skeletons. If you are on edge about purchasing this game, find at least 1-2 friends to join you for the amazing memories that you will create while playing this game. On top of that, if you meet people in-game that you want to friend, the devs have even added a seamless, in-game feature that allows you to friend people in front of you.
If you are looking for something different to play and fun then this is it!

Sea of Thieves is a great game to play full of adventure. You start with the same stats and gear that you will have at the end of the game. There a few exceptions which can give you better rewards (look up emissary flags). In the game, you start by doing voyages for the three trading companies which each gives you different voyage types.

The Gold Hoarders give you treasure hunting voyages where you get a map or a riddle and you have to find the island, they give you a picture of it or the name. Then you sail there and follow the instructions to dig up some treasure.

The Order of Souls gives you bounty voyages were you go to a specific island where you will find an enemy. You kill them and collect their skull.

The Merchants Alliance which gives you delivery voyages. The first type of voyage is were you get cages to catch animals on the islands and then deliver them back yo the Merchants Alliance. The second type is where you get crates to deliver to one of the NPCs in the world.

Completing these voyages will earn you gold and reputation with that trading company when you bring what you found back to the trading companies. Every 5 levels of reputation you can pay gold to get a promotion. Get enough promotions and you can get better voyages from the trading companies. After your third promotion, you can get an emissary flag but it costs 20000 gold so don't go crazy with the clothes shopping early in the game.

I have only played 16 hours so there is content that I am not familiar with yet such as attacking forts, the story missions and fighting sea monsters. However, I am familiar with running from monsters. There is also likely content I do not know about as I have not been to the far right of the map and have only used the emissary flags for the trading companies and I know there are more.

Tips for New Players:

Play with Friends
While you can play this by yourself it is far more fun to play it with at least one other person.

Raise a Flag
Putting a flag up allows you to see which way the wind is blowing so you can angle your sail the right way to get more speed.

Turn Off the Lights
Turn off all your lights on top of the ship, if you don't you will be extremely easy to spot at night and might have some other player coming after you.

Play Music to Snakes
If you are trying to catch a snake play music to it so it will go into a trance and not spit poison at you, this does not last long.

Keep Your Eyes Out
There are more than just monsters and other players on the sea. There are also ship shipwrecks and floating treasure as well as NPC ships. All of which can have something worth taking.

Gems
There are statues of mermaids with gems in them if you find one break it and take the gem, but be careful they damage you if you stand next to them. These gems can also be found on the ground and can be the most valuable thing you will find at least in the early game.

Multiple Voyages
If you have just finished collecting all the stuff you need for a voyage you can start another one if you want. Just be careful because if another player sees you they may decide to sink you to get your hard-earned treasure.

I like the game a lot. When the games find you got stuck on a rock it sends you back to the ship. Don't need to restart or find a unstuck button or command. I like the constant danger of other other players chasing you down and stealing your stuff makes for some great interactions/stories. Fun to play  with friends.

There are a few complaints/ideas such as: 

Finding random sessions is kinda hard, you have trolls and toxic people. or people who leave mid session because we aren't doing the quest they want to do. I was fortunate enough to find a really fun crew on my first time playing match make.

I love the thought of making money. I hate that there really isn't anything useful in the game to spend the money on. Yep cosmetics are fun and everyone's favorite part of games but I wont improve with them. I would even be alright if somehow player bases/homes could be bought with the money.

Bounty system against players who sink and kill A LOT. emissary is cool n' all but what about the people don't have a emissary flag on? you got those players that sink just to sink not even to loot. Just a fun idea.

A safe zone actually sounds nice, there isn't one in the whole game and i think it would be nice to have one in the whole entire map where everyone on the server might be able to gather at.

If you're looking into this game, as I did before purchasing, you're going to see a lot about toxicity, griefing, spawn camping, etc. I don't have many friends that game, and none that play this game, so I was looking to see if it was possible to play solo. It took me thirty seconds to know that this was a PVP centered game built around teamwork, and that solo would be difficult. It's a PVP sandbox pirate game and people are going to pirate you. And yet, for some reason, there are thousands of people that bought the game and are upset that when they sail up and wave they get shot in the face and their loot gets pirated. It defies logic or reason to be upset about that.

As for the game itself, everyone is on equal ground whether you are a day one player or be playing for years. There is no character progression or special weapons or abilities. Everyone fights with the same gear and same abilities. The only difference is experience in game. Progression is in the form of cosmetics bought with gold you earn from loot you collect. The voyages (quests) are basic but enjoyable. The loot is mostly worth little gold, so losses to other players aren't game breaking. If you get sunk you spawn someplace else with a brand new ship, not much penalty at all. The game is beautiful and plays well. Sailing is engaging with many aspects of ship management.

If you want to sail around looking for buried treasure or killing pirate captain skeletons with a bounty on their head all while having the excitement of another player ship coming along and sinking you for your loot, buy the game. If only having the choice of running or fighting every time you see another player bothers you, or getting killed and having your loot stolen causes you to lose your mind and run to forums raging about how unjust the world is, you should probably save yourself the stress and move on to a PVE game. It's a PVP pirate game. Trust no one. No mercy.

Saw this forever ago in beta and I thought the PVP looked interesting but I was afraid it would be a lot of downtime and very little action.  Gameplay videos do *not* do this game justice.  Highlight reels seem unrealistic and straight up 'lets-plays' creates a sense of feast-or-famine of the fun of the game.  Only watching the gameplay does not provide the sense of  immersion and tension.  A 10 minute video isn't interesting, but neither is reading a book in 10 minutes.  This is for longer sessions and the allure of new opportunities can draw you in for longer and longer sessions, much like an epic Civilization campaign. Arena mode exists for shorter gameplay and helps scratch the PVP itch without any other distractions.

There is so much to do at any given point.  Derailing from your original objective is half the fun as random encounters, shipwrecked loot, and various opportunities arise.  Between a pvp-only arena and a free-roam adventure mode which contains guild quests, tall tale story quests, random encounters, and pvp opportunities, this is a game with enough variety to keep you busy for hours on end.  

The gameplay itself feels very rewarding.  Managing sail length, angle, choosing when to drop anchor or harpoon landmasses for quick turns, knowing when to show your broadside for cannon attacks, aiming your cannons to hit different targets, boarding enemy ships with a variety of goals (kill crew to prevent repairs, drop the enemy anchor to enable easier cannon shots from your crew, set it on fire to distract them and discourage usage of blazing cannons, or just steal their loot sneakily) you get a rewarding sense of variety in 'doing the same thing' but with small but important adjustments.  Storms with lightning, rain filling your ship, your wheel spinning wildly like a drunken sailor, sea monsters, and skeleton AI ships raise the steaks of even the most simple of tasks.

After a good long session of gameplay. typically you can walk away with an epic story of how you snuck aboard and sunk a PVP-guild ship only to have them sneak and set ablaze your own ship, regain control, chase a different smaller ship, escape a megladon during your chase, and have random AI skeleton ships sink the both of you as a third human ship also enters the fray and attempts to capitalize on the opportunity of your distractions.  Even defeating a kraken for the first time is a rewarding feeling worthy of sharing with your friends.  New content was published as recently as this week, adding a ghost ship fleet encounter to the game.  The micro-transactions are totally optional, and likely help fund the new content and encounters added.  Nearly everything you grind for is cosmetic, making near end-game content feel approachable, rather than gated behind the necessity for 'better guns'.  There is the need for ranking up to acquire certain missions, but there is enough in the game to keep you busy and happy as you learn the mechanics and glow wide-eyed and excited as you experience everything for the first time.  Rushing to the end would feel like a mistake and cheapen the experience of fearing of a simple shark in open waters as you desperately swim back to your ship.

The game released in 2016 and still has no proper Anti-cheat software.
Although the gameplay is kinda relaxing and fun with friends, when playing solo it becomes boring and repetitive.
Encountering cheaters in this game (which is not that often) is a huge turn-off
You see cheaters, try to find a report button, but there is none. You hope the anti-cheat to ban them, you go to google, try to find which Anti-cheat it uses and find NONE. there is no anti-cheat except windows 10 TruePlay feature(which as I assume is not yet implemented), All cheaters are searched almost manually by using logs, and most are banned for using speedhack or something as suspicious as that. So, If you are here for fun with friends, you're welcome, and it will be fun, until you encounter cheaters after 4 hours of straight grinding quests and they sink you and your loot almost immediatly.
The other issue is hitboxes, they are just squares equal for every character, even if it's bigger than the model.
Overall, Definetly NOT a refund and fun to play, but be ready for those issues

I had to come back and update my review after several tens of hours of playing the game. Unfortunately, I do not plan to play this game anymore and have completely uninstalled it.

This game can only be played with friends, there is no catering or extension for solo players. Like many others, I don't have a friend or a few friends to play this game with anytime I want, which means I roll solo quite often.

Whenever you play solo, the voyages you play spawn a skeleton crew that will destroy your ship, ruining any progress you made as well as resetting your emissary flag. The last four sessions that I tried to play solo, I got my emissary flag to Grade III (1.5x loot), and every single one of those four times, once I left the island, a skeleton crew spawned right next to me.

Unfortunately, skeleton crews are not limited like you and your crew. Though they spawn with an identical ship, they fire their cannons so fast you cannot bucket the water out and make repairs fast enough. This means that anytime you start to make progress, a skeleton crew spawns and sinks your ship.

I'm tired of wasting my time on this game, and it's ridiculous that you CANNOT play solo.

Would not recommend unless you have friends that will play with you every single time you want to get on.

The sea can be a cruel and terrible mistress. Would be pirates beware, this game has no easy mode; while you are learning the ropes your fate is in the hands of other pirates, and your burgeoning skillset. some are generous and others are... well they are pirates. You have cart blanche to play how you want, but fighting others for their loot or the safety of your own is inevitable and brutal. The learning curve is fair but the skill ceiling is high, and its a game that takes a lot of patience and dedication to get good at. At least all players are on equal footing equipment wise, never having an advantage from anything other than skill and nerve is excellent. not everyone will like this game, but those that do will probably play for a lot of time, with some really high highs and low lows in the meantime. Highly recommend for those that enjoy exploring, adventure, gold, glory, murder, and larceny.

I had heard of Sea of Thieves for a while now, but only now got it on Steam because a bunch of my friends had it and wanted to play it together. At first glance, it looked like Ship Sailing Simulator; grab a bunch of people, steer a boat from island to island, ???, profit. However, this was not the case. 

Sea of Thieves is, at its core, a PIRATE simulator. That means that whatever you do, it can and will likely be stolen from you by cackling players one ship over, potentially for no other reason besides they wanted something easy to hunt. 

This, of course, frustrated me immensely. How dare they steal my hard earned loot? How dare they just come over and ruin my day for no good reason? And I almost said I hated the game. I almost put it in the pile of "I guess I'll play this sometimes" games. But then I started to realize the most important thing, which I cannot emphasize enough:

This is PIRATE SIMULATOR. 

Once you wrap your head around that fact, the game becomes immediately ten times better. You stop fearing your loot will be stolen and instead prepare for it. You stop running from other crews, instead loading the cannons and preparing for combat if they dare fire first. You start to learn when to fire and when to hold, allowing the default sloop with a panicked captain sail by while sending the Reaper that chased you for five islands straight right to the bottom of the sea.  

If you're interested in this game, I suggest making sure you know how to lose with grace, as you will lose quite a bit. Remember, this is PvPvE, meaning that both the environment AND other players will be able to attack and kill you. If you're only here for the PvE, I still suggest brushing up on your PvP skills, since you can't turn that off. And remember. This is Pirate Simulator, not Ship Sailing Simulator. Plundering loot from others is a valid strategy, and naval combat is an essential part of the game. 

TL:DR, Good game for sailing with friends, just remember that other players exist and your loot would look good on their ship.

Very immersive pirate experience. A bit cartoon-like but not over the top. Seems like the only land enemies are skeletons but there are named boss NPC skeletons when you do the skull quests. Sea enemies are sharks, very large "fish" creatures ( as big as a small boat) and Krakens, Kraken, Kraki?... Gigantic ass monster. There are enemy skeleton ships that will surface from out of the water and start attacking you. Very "Pirates of the Caribbean" like.

So far it does not look like there are any RPG aspects like leveling up and skill points. Actually there aren't even weapon upgrades that I can tell. Only cosmetic weapon skins. This game is by no means boring but it would be much more fun with an RPG element or two. You can, however, level up the quests that you can purchase from quest vendors that reward much more loot as you progress.

The PvP has not been an issue. Most people I have met were very helpful although you come across the occasional KoS player(s). Even if players don't attack its exciting knowing there are no rules when you spot another ship.

The only down side so far has been having to use the Windows Xbox app to invite friends and such. There is no support for Steam friends anywhere I can see.

Sea of ​​Thieves is a unique game. Never before has cooperation in the world of shipping been so affordable, encouraging to play with other s and did not arouse such a feeling of traveling into the unknown. Adventures with a group of friends effectively obscure the only and also the key minus of the game: after A few hours we learn all the available content.

All gameplay elements assume team work. Any object held in your hand can serve both us and your companion - it is something beautiful. We can show the pocket compass to the person standing in front of us, just like the treasure map, and we can raise the olive lamp at any time to illuminate a larger area of ​​the cave explored with the group. These are just a handful of examples showing how in detail the use of various items has been developed - which, in total, are not too many.

During the game, various suggestions come to mind regularly. For example, we would like to collect decorations during island exploration and decorate the cabin with them. It would be nice if the mysterious paintings in the caves were associated with something, and during the fight we could use additional types of bullets - even karters and chains. Virtually every aspect of Sea of ​​Thieves is asking for expansion. Developing the potential of this game can result in something really wonderful.

Sea of ​​Thieves is a great and unique game for fans of collaboration. The content is currently not very diverse, so buying at the premiere price is difficult to recommend, but nevertheless it is worth using the Xbox Game Pass offer to test the title as part of the subscription.

First off, I am 50/50 when recommending this game. It's great fun when you play with others but I would not recommend getting this game if you plan on playing solo unless it is on sale. There is no difficulty scaling in the game so you can easily come across the random events where skeleton galleons can spawn right next to you at any time. Less than 25 hours in the game and I've had these events occur 4 times. 

Also quests rewards are random. I did a quest where I had to go to a small island and kill 4 skeletons who couldn't die at night, then 4 skeletons who were immune to melee, then a boss that couldnt die at night along with 4 skeletons who couldn't die at night. Annnnd then I had to do all that again but they couldn't die during the day. Annnndd then I only earned 900 coins and it took me 30 minutes to do. Bare in mind bosses usually drop a skull worth 1000 coins and a map to a chest.

I would enjoy this game more if there was actually something to do in it because all you do is collect coins to buy cosmetics and if you want do some raids or kill the kraken to get more cosmetics.

All in all, only get this game if you have friends to play with on it and if it's on sale.

I can thoroughly recommend Sea of Thieves, it's a unique and very beautiful game which allows you to enjoy the pirate life in so many different ways. Fancy a relaxing day's fishing, set off for some quiet backwater and fish to your heart's content. Want to rampage across the ocean looting and pillaging? Try Arena, or raise the Reaper's Mark. Enjoy questing and immersive storytelling? Set sail on the Tall Tales. Feel like something quirky? Spend a voyage completing commendations or the daily bounties. Grind to your heart's content with voyages from the different Trading Companies. The beauty of this game is that there is something for everyone and if you need to find a crew then set sail for the official discord, the forums or the affiliate fleets. Go out there and have fun with it!

If the time played carried over from my Microsoft account the same way achievements did, you'd see at least 500 more hours logged on this game than you do right now.  This game is an absolutely incredible experience: a story with a different retelling each time you play it.  A significant part of the reason I bought it on Steam is because I admire what Rare's created with this and want to continue supporting them from the platform I love.  It's followed a similar progression to No Man's Sky: a very rough start with very little content, with a dedicated, faithful development team that has tended to the title like a garden.  They spent the last 2+ years growing existing mechanics and regularly adding content.  It has since evolved into something almost unrecognizable from its original state, and I mean that as praise, wholeheartedly.

Whereas other FPS' maintain a consistent fast-paced environment, SoT's pacing shifts between slow and fast.  What starts out as a low-speed chase against the wind for a treasure-laden galleon can turn into a high-stakes hand-to-hand battle with swords, guns and cannonfire, all in a matter of seconds.  Tight, cohesive teamwork is a must, and playing solo is one of the hardest things to do.  That doesn't mean you're forced to eat-or-be-eaten in endless PVP; you can dig up some worms and go fishing, or embark on one of a handful of many different kinds of PVE quests.

Whereas other open world games are focused on constantly building up and fortifying in a persistent environment, SoT instead levels the proverbial playing field.  All ships are more or less the same, your only advantages against other crews are how many supplies you brought to that fight and how much skill you and your team have amongst you.  A skilled duo in a sloop can easily overpower a galleon crew twice their size.

On a less-important note: the water is rendered beautifully and marveling at it NEVER gets old.

ALL GUSHING ASIDE
- There is a STEEP learning curve, and as far as playerbase goes you will usually run into newbies or skilled players with not much in-between.
- You WILL run into dicks in this game.  It's called Sea of Thieves, after all.
- This game also has a habit of bringing out some of the more unpleasant parts of your own personality, for the same reason as above.

You will either LOVE or HATE this game, and you only need one session to decide which it'll be.  For best results, play it with friends and keep yourself... "open to opportunities".

I've really tried to give this game a fair go. It takes quite some time to figure out some of the mechanics, how -to sail your ship and so on- before you can really get your teeth into the content so I think probably the first 10 hours are simply finding your feet, but it's a good learning process which is simple to learn but hard to master, the Holy Grail.

Once you get the hang of things though, it could be magnificent game. There are messages in bottles, treasure maps, fights with Skeleton Pirate ships, clever merchant Cargo Runs with some really interesting mechanics to make sure you take care. Delivering silk that's been in the sea will reduce the reward for example. There's lots of random islands to simply stop at and rummage through. The sea looks magnificent and the physics of the ships and the changing weather is absolutely beautiful, crystal blue waters with brilliant sunlight gradually overcloud and transform into storm swept seas with huge rolling waves and darkling clouds. Very good stuff.

The crew mechanics are good, and it is definitely a multiplayer game, although you can sail the smallest ship solo and progress quite quickly.

So, considering this is all quite good - why the negative review?

the game in its current state is a Toxic Players Paradise. By making it PvEvP it sets up griefers perfectly to systematically demolish your session. Here's my experience of the PvPvE environment so far;

Complete a raid on a Skeleton Fortress Island, having spent 20 mins sailing there and 30 mins surviving the waves of enemies only for someone to rock up in their ship, sink your stationary ship for no reason, kill you with cannon fire while you're on the beach and then take all the loot you've earned. CHECK

Get followed by a ship while we fight a Skeleton Galleon, waiting for us to defeat it before killing us and taking the Galleon loot? CHECK

Get fire bombed in dock over and over and over again until we have to restart in another server? CHECK

People attempting to form an alliance only to blow the snot out of you for kicks? CHECK

So, the ONE thing that would make me give a glowing review to this game would be a PvE only server. I suspect it'd be full of players who want to cruise around, fighting skeleton ships, killing the Kraken, following clues to buried treasure, and simply cruising the high seas as they're rendered SO WELL. Sailing about really is a fantastic thing to do in this game and when no one comes and gives you a good fisting the game is great.

If you like having serious anger issues and blood pressure problems because the game is designed to reward the worst, most vile, toxic and nasty tactics and don't mind wasting time for someone else to get the reward, spend your money. I mean it, you'll be bloody livid when it happens to you - and it will. I have yet to experience in nearly 40 hours of gameplay a positive experience with another crew.

IF you prefer to have at least some restrictions on the people who get the reward from completing an event or raid (so you can at least be rewarded for you time if nothing else), keep your cash until PvE only servers come along  -or more importantly- go and spend it on something else.

The reviews on this game are pretty spot on. I bought this on a whim and a risk because... I love pirates. I wasn't at all sure if I'd like it or enjoy it, but honestly it's one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played, and one of the best MMo's I've played. Not to mention the game itself, from the graphics to the ambiance, is absolutely gorgeous.
You'll be signing into a world as a new pirate. But that doesn't set you apart from anyone else. The only difference between you and another is experience as a player and a variety of pirate-y cosmetics which aren't at all hard to get once you get started. There is a leveling system in the game, but that doesn't make you any more or less 'stronger' than another player. It's there to show your progress within the game.
While the main progression of the game is PVE based, PVP can and *WILL* happen. But if you don't like PVP,  I wouldn't worry much. It's simple to feel like the players in this game are just a part of the game itself, as PVE. Just smarter. Because you're playing as a pirate, it's only fitting there will be other pirates out there doing what you're doing. It does add a level of caution to your time in the game, but it's a natural danger that befits being a pirate, and it makes everything you achieve feel like a huge accomplishment which is absolutely satisfying. 
Sometimes people get upset and have mean things to say but it's possible to turn off your communication if you want to avoid toxic butthurt pirates shouting rude things your way. And sometimes you'll have pirates who want to form an alliance or help you out, or need help themselves. 
In the end, this game is a game about getting together with a few friends, working together, and coming out of it with a good story at the end of the day. It's a survival open world cooperative experience that will never leave you without anything to do. With your friends, you'll be talking about your adventures together, having a bunch of laughs, victories, and failures. You'll be solving riddles together, finding treasure, fighting pirates, skeletons, and sea monsters. You can play instruments to pass the time on long voyages, drink some grogg, or fish up a hearty meal for you and your best mates! 
Or if you'd like to sail solo, that's possible too. It just makes things a bit more dangerous but not at all impossible to handle. And if you like animals, they have pets in the game that can accompany you on your journey so you'll never be lonely! 
Sure I can think of a couple things that could be improved or added into the game, but all in all this game is a wonderful experience for anyone who likes pirates. You'll be getting what you signed up for.

Well, I would really like to love Sea of Thieves, the visuals are stunning and the pirate theme reminds me of Monkey Island. We have played 3 nightly sessions as a team of three pirates and we had some nice sailing and digging out treasure, but every play session ends with us being destroyed by another player's ship - players who have (it seems) much more time to practise and who do not react to any attemps of communication. It would have been such a great opportunity for roleplaying, getting captured by other pirates, sail with them for a while, etc.. but no. Our experience was that is it simply stupid PvP and you can not enjoy your time on the seas. This is tiresome, there should be some restriction to PvP, at least around the outposts to not have you ship bombarded and sunk while you are off on land selling a chest. Where is the equivalent to the british navy or at least some guards in town?

Furthermore, the only reason for collecting gold (beside having fun with freinds pretending that you are pirates) is that you can buy cosmetics - this is a flaw, there should not be some overpowered equipment but at least a little better sword, a little faster loading pistol or at least improvements to the ship itself. Some progression beside a new hat.
I know, it is a PvP online multiplayer game, but at first coop aspect did at least promise some adventure spirit and community, which, sadly, is not in the game.

Pros: 
- People who have been playing this for years wont have an advantage over new characters
- Microtransactions are purely cosmetic
- Graphic are wonderful
- Ship combat is intuitive

Cons: 
- Playing solo gives you a distinct disadvantage
- Loading screens are horribly long
- Sails block helms view heavily
- Brig

Sea of Thieves is an MMO you can play solo, but you shouldn't and you will be at a distinct disadvantage if you do. Best to play with a friend or to chose the random party option where the game fills up the crew for you. This obviously has some risks for the jerks out there who will abuse the weird brig function, but most players I’ve encountered are friendly and it seems like it has a good community.

There are not real character levels in the game, so a newbie has the same advantages as someone who has been playing since launch. Ships can go on quests for gold and standing in the game factions. Becoming higher in the faction opens up new quests and gear. All gear, whether with real money or the in game currency, is purely cosmetic. 

Ship combat is the meat of this game. The bigger the ship, the more cannons and speed you will have, but the harder it is to maneuver and the bigger target you are. There are two modes of games: Adventure and Arena. Arena pits a bunch of ships against each other in competition for who can earn the most points. Adventure is the standard quest voyage.

UPDATE: I just had the best gaming experience ever on this game. So myself and two of my friends are sailing the high seas collecting loot, fighting it out with other pirates, and just generally going through the normal routine. Nothing special. 

Then we get a ritual skull, and boy o boy does the story take some wild turns.

We proceed to do some research into what the ritual skull does, and this leads us on a wild chase to gather the items needed for the ritual (don't want to spoil the mystery for those of you who haven't done it). This even involves having to hunt down another player and ASK them to kill us for once.
They were sus, but like it worked out.

Finally we get to the place where you do the ritual, and waves upon waves of enemies spawn. Partway through the initial waves, I spy a brigantine on the horizon that I try to keep an eye on. I go back to fighting, and I then check on that brigantine like a minute later.

They are right on top of our boat.

I freak out and go running to our boat to try to defend it while my friends fight the waves of enemies, when lo and behold the brigantine starts yelling "Friendly!" at us! We quickly form an alliance and proceed to fight as a team of 6 for what felt like an eternity against this boss, and we eventually win. We decide to split the loot down the middle, and then we spied sloops on the horizon waiting to plunder our ships once we set sail with the goods. Thus starts another adventure of our two boats coordinating via shouting and light signals as we maneuver around other players and NPCs attempting to take us down on our way to an outpost. We manage to sail our happy little random alliance to an outpost and made off with 60k in loot. This whole encounter even spawned a discord server so we can invite those players to future outings! 

10/10 would pirate again


Original Review: For anyone who says that this is impossible to play solo... I beg to differ. Likewise, it might show only a few hours on Steam, but I have played this a lot more on the Microsoft store. While it is extremely fun to play with your friends as a group, soloing is it's own unique and fun experience. You can easily take on full groups of players in your sloop if you know what you are doing, and it's very easy to avoid players if you don't want to deal with PvP. I recommend looking up guides and watching streamers if you aren't getting the hang of it. Overall, this has been one of the most fun games that I have had the pleasure of playing! :)

When I finally got this game to work I was excited, thinking after the clips I saw of other people playing it that the game would be amazing, instead I found it to be incredibly boring and downright infuriating. The majority of the time I was 'playing' were spent sailing from nearly across the entire map trying to get back to where I died while doing the FIRST quest or having to rejoin a session after the game froze and disconnected with no reason repeatedly. The ai ships seems to only rarely miss even if your in the smallest ship while your shots will frequently miss. On top of that you have to juggle bailing water and patching up holes while trying to avoid being killed by not just the ai, but other players who will gladly screw with you and sink your boat even if you don't have any loot. If it was possible I would've gladly refunded this game, but the glitches that can end up happening when your trying to complete just the TUTORIAL can push you over the 2 hour mark. (It took me a whooping FIVE HOURS to get through the tutorial without the game timing or crashing.) Ultimately it feels like I blew 40 dollars on a rushed alpha instead of a finished project.

All of that said, heck is this an amazing game. 10/10 Sailing is rewarding and calming while punctuated with bouts of extreme violence and panic. It's great. The design of the game is amazing and solid, probably one of the best player focused games out there I've ever seen. There's no "progression" as in ranking up doesn't make you a god. Getting gud does. Learning, adapting, and understanding your enemies comes with growing in levels. Gold and loot aren't *really* important but there's something very satisfying about sinking some bastard because he's trying to steal your loot, or chasing down a loot ridden boat because you saw they're on a gilded athena. It's fantastic!

Sea of Thieves is a one-of-a-kind game that has given me unique experiences like no other. Sea of Thieves is different from other games in the terms that there is no upgrade-based progression, only cosmetic. All equipment is given to you at the start of the game, and it is up to you to master the mechanics of everything.

While on the surface it may seem like there is a lack of direction, there are actually many different activities and story content to experience and master with monthly updates adding small bursts of new content.

Overall a very fun game that can be played with 1-4 players across three different ship types.

INTRODUCTION

The idea behind Sea of Thieves is simple. Get a ship, sail the seas, collect treasures along the way, sell them to make money, rinse, repeat. On paper, it sounds a bit too simple to be of any meaningful fun for the veteran gamer. Do not be fooled by this façade though. What makes the game so special though is that the player has complete agency over how to accomplish their goals. Will you be honorable and find treasures through exploration and teamwork with your crew and others? Or will you sit back and let other crews do the work for you before relieving them of their hard-fought booty through brute force?

GAMEPLAY BASICS

In Sea of Thieves you take command of one of three ship types. The Sloop, Brigantine, or Galleon. Each ship is designed for a certain number of crew members (2,3, and 4 respectively) and each have their own specific strengths and weaknesses to consider. For example, while the Galleon has by far the superior firepower of the three ship types, it suffers from reduced maneuverability, significantly reduced speed against the wind, and requires a hefty crew to properly operate. Whereas the Sloop requires half the crew and can turn on a dime (comparatively) while easily outrunning the other two ships against the wind. It will however lose in a standard broadside battle against the larger ships. The brigantine sits somewhere in the middle of the other two.
Using one of these vessels you and your crew (or you alone) will set sail on the high seas as you follow maps that lead to buried treasure, kill the undead skeletons of crews long forgotten for their valuable skulls, sink ships (both player and NPC) for the treasure store on board, along with a whole slew of other things that I will not spoil here.


CREW NUMBERS

If you payed attention to the crew numbers mentioned for each ship in the above section, you may notice that never did I mention a ship requiring a single crewmember. That is because, as you may have surmised at this point, the game is not explicitly designed to be played alone. Before continuing, allow me to quell any fears and say that the game is most certainly playable solo; however, the experience when doing so is far from ideal. If you decide to purchase Sea of Thieves, you should ask yourself whether you have at least one other person who will want to play regularly with you. If not, do not fret! There are many things you can accomplish on your own. Just keep in mind that some tasks will be a much tougher challenge. I should also mention the game has a community wonderfully welcoming of newcomers and, being as such, you should head over to the official Discord server and ask to join other people’s crews. 
With that out of the way, let us suppose you DO have a friend who will play regularly with you but you are worried you’ll be missing out by not getting to sail on one of the larger ships. Once again, do not worry. You do not need to sail on a brigantine or a galleon to have a great experience. Some of the best, most memorable experiences I personally have had in this game were with only one other friend on a sloop.


PROGRESSION

Probably the biggest thing that sets Sea of Thieves apart from most games is that the game utilizes a “horizontal” progression system. This means that you end up as strong as you start off. As in, you will never grow “stronger”. There is no traditional leveling system. There are no weapon upgrades.  Your ship never increases in defensive or offensive capability. The only “upgrades” you get are purely cosmetic in nature and only serve to distinguish yourself among other players.
To be perfectly honest, I was incredibly skeptical before purchasing the game because of this. I pondered, “How can a game hold my attention if there isn’t any way to track progress or improve? What am I accomplishing?”; however, I took the dive and what I found was a much more interesting and complex model of a progression system hidden within. Due to the lack of the conventional systems of leveling or gear upgrades, player progression takes place entirely organically. This means that while your character may not improve in any way, what does improve are your personal skills and game knowledge. For example, when you start the game there is an exceedingly good chance you will get slaughtered in your first few ship-to-ship PVP/PVE encounters. You can expect to miss almost every (if not every) cannonball you fire that is not at point-blank range. However, as time goes on and you practice, you will become much more accomplished in your abilities. So much so that before long you will have few qualms about that fully manned, decked out galleon approaching your two-man sloop rapidly from behind.


PVP & PLAYER INTERACTION

PVP and player interaction is, without a doubt, where the game shines most luminously. Every experience with another player-controlled vessel is different but intense. Perhaps you are minding your own business collecting treasure when another ship comes a little to close for comfort leading to a standoff or prolonged altercation. Perhaps, you know another ship is laden with treasure that is just ripe for the taking if you can manage to sink them. Or maybe combat is not your cup of tea at all and you would rather just sneak aboard a moored enemy vessel and load up a rowboat full of treasure before skulking away, leaving the enemy crew completely dumbfounded when they return to their vessel to find all of their trophies missing.
Some experiences are friendly, some hostile. Some are epic, some are mundane. This uncertainty is something that most other games never have you experience as in most multiplayer games the only options are that the other player in front of you is either a friend or foe rather than both at the same time.


CONCLUSION

Sea of Thieves is a wonderful game and I wholeheartedly recommend it to those who like adventure, the sea, and interacting with others. The gameplay loop is unconventional in many ways; yet, this does not make it uninteresting. It keeps you guessing and before long you will have a book of epic seafaring tales to tell others. 
Before purchasing though, I recommend trying to convince at least one other friend to take the dive with you or at the very least you should join the SOT Discord community. Playing with even one other person makes the experience go from good to excellent.

This game is a few of the best co-op first-person game that I’ve played. Don’t take my words though because I’m the kind of people that thinks Anthem is not completely trash. Anyways, the lack of progression in this game is somewhat of its downfall but it’s also one of the reason I love it so much. You are urged on to improve your own skills rather then relying on your equipment meaning that if you have good planning and a fast mind you can get out of bad situations relatively quickly. It also means that you will not be destroyed by the pro players when you first enter the game. It is still very playable without friends if you are lonely like me. Most people are pretty friendly but i suggest you settling down with a few  crew mates rather then jumping around from crew to crew since that will be exhausting to comprehend each play style. Solo play style it’s not really recommended in my opinion but you just seem that much more skillful if you are successful with your solo play session. Do I recommend this game if you have a basic social skill? Yes, it will be 9/10 for you, but if you are introverted you can still play this game but without much communication it might creat miss-information. Also if you can’t find someone to play with your there is always discord servers and also ME.

Game is pretty good. 
Definitely a Sand Box experience that can feel a little bit empty at times. 
I would still rate this game in an overall positive manner.
A major pro is that it's easy to just kind of fire up and see where the wind (literally) takes you.
What you have at the beginning is what you'll have at the end as far as mechanics go.
There are literally 4 weapons in the game, 5 if you count cannons.
All upgrades that you can ever purchase are strictly aesthetic.
Lots of fun random things to do.

A major con I have is that there is quite a lot focus on the real money shop
You cant earn the pets, which are pretty neat, unless you have ancient coins (Which are more or less only available through real money unless you manage to kill some ancient skeletons.)
I'd be more accepting of the real money shop if the game's price point was a bit lower than 40 bucks.
I find the real money shop to be easier to accept than other games because Rare does seem to do updates on a monthly basis and the game seems to be a consistent work in progress. 

OVERALL: I would recommend this game, it is a lot of fun and looks quite nice!

PS - Be sure to bring a friend along for your adventure, this game is not very enjoyable as a solo experience.

Holy shiiiiiiiiieeeettt this game is nice.

I was skeptical at first.

I bought the game.

I joined, did the tutorial, found all the secrets from tutorial (there are plenty!!!).

First outpost I spawn, I take quests, search for loot, my boat gets raided, even if its empty.

I stay at the outpost for 30-40 minutes, My boat gets raided 3-4 times in the process.

After 40 minutes, I go to the boat, and inside, there are chests, treasures, and some random dude talking.

Apparently somebody saw I was getting owned and decided to "protect" me for my first gameplay. They gave me treasures, helped me do quests and all for the price of an Uber (get them to a location). They were AWESOME, FUNNY and HELPFUL as hell. Best pirate experience with them.

After I dropped them off there, I did several quests, I ran from other players as they were chasing me, I managed to DEFEAT another ship in a 1v2 situation, stole their loot, ran away, sold it, it was epic.

All this in 4 freaking hours!

Even if the quests are some kind of repetitive, the PvP element is awesome!.

I don't regret any money spent on it, too bad I don't have any friends playing this masterpiece.

Positive review, as I haven't had bugs or unpleasant gameplay. 


PS: Great optimization also, 2080S + 4790K, 1440p, Mythical graphics (max), 100 fps. Amazing!


Part 2 (10 hr gameplay): 

So I played again, 2nd gameplay, I finished first 3 Tales and it was a "good" gameplay.

This time I haven't seen a single friendly person. I've been attacked and raided about 6-7 times, sometimes by solo, sometimes by gang of 3-4. But I adapted quickly.

At first I went to cash in my voyages and treasures ( i had 3 chests with 9 skulls, 3 chests with 9 gold items, a crying chest and 2 regular treasure chests, all from farming/voyage). I went to an outpost, I did a 360 to make sure there's nobody there, then docked the sloop. When I went with the first chest of 3 skulls, there was a dude hiding in a bush next to the Bones tent, he jumped out, gave me a heart attack, then took a shot at me. He missed the shot, I dropped the chest and I went full ape on him, killing him. Then I ran to drop all my treasures, cause since he didn't have a boat, meant his team mates are circling around. On that run I felt like mom's spaghetti, palms were much sweatyyy... 

Amazingly, I managed to cash in ALL my treasures, and THEN, the bad guys were aready at my ship. I saw them trying to ram it in the rocks. I throw 2-3 blast bombs and they drop in water, then I shoot them down with the pistol. Managed to get back in my ship, repair it , and went full speed into their big ship, while they were respawning. I didn't stay to repair mine, I just shot their ship down, then ran away.

Then I got killed and ship sank about 4 times, twice from crew of 4 , once from a duo on a sloop, they put a barrel on my ship and sank it down, while I was doing a quest ... and once from the freaking kraken, right AFTER I FINISHED A TALE...  Lost a lot of treasures including the Tale treasure, but....

While trying not to ragequit, I saw a crew of 4 again, probably same guys, they were fighting a skeleton ship. I got close and managed to spot 2 of the 4 guys, confirming it was the crew that gangbanged me (i think ^_^ ) . I went to them, flanked them and placed them between me and the skull ship. Shot them 3-4 times, then with a singing/dancing cannonball and a fire cannonball, and their ship started to sink and burn. I saw them jumping in the water. I went there to see if they "need" help and just finished the job, shooting them in the water. Then I took ALL their treasures, which compensated a lot over my loss, and went to a safe outpost.

That feeling was the best. Yes, I lost some battles, but also won a few. First gameplay, 4 hours, 2nd gameplay, 10 hours straight. The PVP element is priceless in this game, otherwise it would've become boring. 

And I just found out about sunken ships, mermaids skeleton lords and kraken :)) 

New challenges ahead !!!

Edit 3: 18-June-2020

This game has improved so much since it's original launch. I have played somewhere around 2000-2500 hours previous to the steam launch, and for the most part I have enjoyed every hour.  Its by far the best co-op PVE and PVP game I have ever played. (And I have played a ton of games). The artwork is unique and fun, the "story" (Tall Tales) are exiting, and its overall an extremely fun game to play with friends. I really like how every time you encounter another pirate on the sea nobody is at a disadvantage, because everyone has the same level of health, ammo, etc. Very good mechanic in my opinion. The game is routinely being updated every month bringing fresh new content into the game. Trust me when I say this is game that you can play forever. Thanks RARE.
