Great game. The adventures are so in depth and the graphics are beautiful. I got it the day it came out on steam and I had so much fun with it. Personally, I love the game, but beware, this game is not a primary story mode game.  If you are used to games with a guided story mode as the main objective, this game might not be for you. While there is a story mode and other missions, it is not the main goal of the game. The games real purpose is to have fun exploring the map and go on adventures to increase your reputation with different factions. The story mode adventures, or Tall Tales, can be found across the map and are voted on by crew members to start. the main mission, Shores of Gold, is very fun. While I am only on chapter two of it, it is exciting and hard to stop playing. The reason I say that the Tall Tales are not the main part of the game is because in my opinion, I enjoy exploring and trading and the Tall Tales seem to be only a small fraction of what there is to the game. Like I said, this is my opinion, and someone else might disagree which is fine, as there is so much to do in the game. Additionally, instead of exploring the sea of thieves, you may also play arena, in which five teams fight it out over 15 minutes to collect treasure and silver by defeating other pirates. Arena is a great mode for players who love to be in the action and fight it out against real players. I have only one other complaint which is so minor that some players might even enjoy the realism of it. The game is online, and the max crew size is 4, so you can be able to play in groups larger than 4 by hoping to get in the same game and making an alliance. When allied, you can communicate with the other crew that you are partnered with, but only at close range. If you get to far away or face the other direction of the other crew mate speaking, they become quiet and at certain ranges, you can't hear them and they can't hear you. (The communication takes place through in-game chat). If this is the case and you do need two different crews, the easiest fix would just to settle with Facetime of a group call. All in all, the game is fantastic and I would recommend it to anybody that is considering to get it. Easy five stars.

SEA OF THIEVES

Don't let my hours fool you, I have atleast 40+ more before I bought this on steam. Sea of Thieves started out a pretty barebones game. Bounties were all you did to grind to level 50 in each faction, and it was and still is a pretty boring grind. Athena's Bounties ended up being the same thing, and while the cosmetics were good looking, the grind felt unrewarding and tedious. Eventually, story missions were added in the form of tall tales. This brought the game back to life essentially, and told a compelling story while sailing through the amazing looking world. They've also added in things they promised from the beginning of the game, like fishing and pets. More tall tales are promised for the future, and my friends and I will await them patiently.

11/10 Best game ever made

Pros: 
Decent optimization, game looks great even on the lowest settings
Skill curve to sailing, very involved process rather than just "steer"
Nice art style and lore
Megalodons/Krakens are scaled in difficult to your crew and ship

Cons:
Poor tutorial that only shows the absolute basics
Solo play is extremely taxing
No option to not get involved in PvP
Zero difficulty scaling vs Skeleton ships, easy to get destroyed by a single ship
Inconsistent combat. Its hard to know how much damage weapons do without reading the wiki, or how consistent they are
Very grindy gameplay with no real objective outside of buying cosmetics and mini-quests

Sea of Thieves has good bones, but with so little concessions for solo players and no option for people who only want to engage in the PvE/Trading aspects of the game, which are very fun, I can't recommend it for solo players

It's fantastic, I strongly recommend it.

The vast majority of people I have played with (largely randoms through open crew but also the SoT discord) are extremely friendly and fun to play with. I've had so many great and memorable adventures with total strangers that I'm honestly in awe.

The gameplay is great! I've seen some reviews complain about the lack of content however I would disagree; the mechanisms in the game facilitate many opportunities for complex personal journeys which span beyond simply finding treasure and selling it. The best part of the game is in fact the journey you go on and the hurdles you face to meet your goal.

It's these "hurdles" that you face on your journey which provide such memorable experiences. They come in the form of environmental hazards and other players, and both forms are fantastic. The PvP in particular has an extremely high skill ceiling and provides the core experience of the game. Yes, it can be extremely annoying to lose hours of work to more experienced pirates, and I've been there. But as you grow experienced you learn to defend yourself and win flights, and being on the winning side reaping the rewards of a hard fought battle feels so rewarding because you have the conscience of what is like being in the losing side, of knowing that you may have just stolen loot that took hours for the enemy to gather. That may be the best part of the game.


tl;dr: its good, don't listen to the sore losers :)
If you like hard, adventure and online co-op this game is for you!

What can I say other than that this game blew my expectations out of the water. Get it? Good. Sea of Thieves is by FAR the most fun I've had playing a video game since my early days of Halo 3, World of Warcraft, COD4 and other classics. This game takes multiplayer to another level by seamlessly combining both story and procedurally based quests with high intensity, high stakes PvE and PvP battles, often both happening at once. Many other multiplayer games try to make online play feel like it's a living breathing world inhabited by the players, but no other games in my opinion even comes close to the feeling that you get in SoT. Combat in all areas feels great, with a high skill cap and relatively straightforward mechanics, players are highly incentivized to get good. Every single time I've died, had my ship sank, or lost all my loot has been my fault, the other player was better, no questions asked. You can pull off some sick shit in this game if you're a skilled player, and the game encourages you to do it. With completely overpowered gunpowder barrels and even stronger stronghold gunpowder barrels, a single player acting alone can take down an entire galleon of 4 other players on it if they're experienced enough. With a deep understanding of the mechanics, a well thought through plan, and bit of pirate luck any player can become a terror of the seas.

Let's talk bugs. There aren't many! It seems that the development team is actively looking to stomp anything that would cause immersion break and they're damn good at it. There are the occasional issues that slip through the beta tests and into the live server. In the most recent patch there seems to have been an issue introduced that when a ship collides with a landmass, and then gets pushed off of the landmass, the ship still things it's in contact with something. This causes the ship to moan and creak like it's rubbing up against rocks and sounds quite horrible but causes no damage to the ship. I also think it slows you down until the effect wears off but that is not confirmed. However even this issue is not that big of a deal, it was surprising the first couple times and then I got used to it and learned to stop running into things...unless I'm trying to run into something in which case it's a tactical pirate maneuver.

The artistic direction in this game is phenomenal, hands down. I cannot even begin to describe how absolutely stunning some of the views in Sea of Thieves are. Sailing across a pristine ocean that glows with the most beautiful blue while the sun sets and the sky is and explosion of orange surrounded by a transition to a perfect blue sky and fluffy white clouds is just another day in SoT. The atmosphere of this game is a magnificent combination of hyper stylized graphics and incredible sound design which makes for an almost unbelievable at times gaming experience you won't soon forget. I'm so in love with the art in this game I've spent almost $50 on aesthetics alone, and I've only been playing it for 28 hours.

But that brings me on to my last point, the price point. If you saw $50 and felt the trauma of old ArcheAge coming to haunt you, fear not, this game only has cosmetic options for sale on the cash shop. Not only that, most items will cost you around $5. The more high end items will set you back about $40 but that is money well spent in my opinion. As a general rule of thumb, I do not spend more money on games than the price of the game itself. I am not someone who buys cosmetics or toys because it is just not worth it to me. This game is completely different and you better believe I bought an entire ship overhaul with the collectors edition items, and I did it happily. These developers have 100% earned my money and I will gladly continue to support this game financially as long as I'm enjoying it.

Sea of Thieves is a 10/10 for me and I highly recommend you try it.

Sea of Thieves at first sight u would think its a beautiful game amazing graphics and a open massive world to explore. I am a sea of thieves Veteran player I joined since cursed sails ( The second content update to the game ) I met a lot of people from around the world and discovered the "PvP Community" and with that I noticed that the game I thought is a perfect pirate game is false. One of the most known issues in the game is the hit registration ( you hit an enemy with a ranged weapon and he doesn't get damage) and then the back track issue ( you miss someone but it will deal damage ). Now Sea of thieves is about the freedom every play style is welcome at least that's what the developers wanted however it is the opposite the hit reg issue is an issue since the game was released and was never fixed. The Developers tried to fix it however failed multiple times and just ignored the problem since the amount of people who do the pvp in the game is small and for the xbox players there was no problem. Now there is a sort of hidden fight against the play style called double gunning ( players equip 2 guns instead of sword ) and the casual part of the game that tries to avoid pvp and do their pve wants it removed because they think its too op and don't take the time to get better. Problem is that the developers are listening to them and ignoring the players who like the double gun play style so they nerf it and buff the sword to force players use the sword. With developers like this that don't listen to their good players but instead to the players who don't even try to get better and even promoting a server alliance that is an exploit of the server system the game goes to a bad state. I love the game however the changes that developers add to the game that are completely unnecessary ruin the experience of the game. The developer team is super unprofessional since they release a hot fix with a 7 GB update. Think twice before you buy the game with reading this review.

Although not without problems, I love this game. So the problems, lets get them out of the way first:

[list]
[*] The game is tied to xbox live/microsoft live/bullshit garbage game service of microsoft that doesn't work right.
[*] The most serious issue about the above, is that to join a friends on-going session; or invite a friend to an on-going session, rather than starting your adventure over to invite them, you and your friend need to do a little song and dance of installing some xbox game service app which can only be found on the microsoft store (good luck if you're not on windows 10!) just to be able to invite each other to an ongoing adventure. There's no support for steam invites outside of the main game lobby before you start playing.
[*] Everytime you start a new adventure, no items from your last one will be carried over, this means that if you spent a lot of time collecting cannonballs, food and wood to stock up, and didn't end up using all of it, then when you start your next adventure despite having had spares the last time, you will now have to gather all that again (this is by far my biggest issue with the game, because you start with extremely low resources, and if you want to fix that you can expect to spend at least a good hour of your time looting barrels on various islands to stock up on mundane items that are necessary for basic gameplay)
[*] The only real advancement in the game is unlocking cosmetics; Sure there are faction levels and ways to increase your income and whatnot but where all that income will ultimately go is cosmetics (because that is the absolute only place you can use any in-game cash at all, what I wouldn't give to be able to spend a few gold to buy a proper stock of cannonballs at the start of the game, geez, but no, there is absolutely no way to spend your money on anything practical).
[*] This is at minimum a 2 player game, don't buy this game unless you have at least one friend who will be willing to actively play it with you!
[*] The server join/change message, and the way it locks your controls, is cancer. Especially when you're trying to steer your ship away from a cliff.
[/list]

As for the good...
[list]
[*] Whether you like strategy, tactics, gunfights, swordfights, cannonfights, the game has it all!
[*] This is a game made to be enjoyed, it's a multiplayer sandbox, where any other player may or may not try to rob and kill you. The gameplay itself outside of pvp, for the most part is grindy (but you get to choose between a lot of options of what to grind, so ultimately it doesn't have to be grindy; after all, one of those options is grinding other players! :D ) ultimately the point of the experience here, is quite clearly to find your own fun in the life of a pirate, grinding gold and unlocking cosmetics is just a little extra to keep your hands from being idle.
[*] The developers have paid a lot of attention to detail, they've added various seemingly pointless but actually enjoyable functions, such as:  Shanties playable by 4 different instruments which do sync into a band when players play at the same time, Cooking, Fishing, Complex (yet not the most realistic) aiming mechanics, Wind direction + need to angle your sails, different ship classes, for different size crews, endless stream of dynamic quests (game always hands you out quests in a consistent stream so you never run out of stuff to do), you can shoot yourself from a cannon, get drunk, and there are also special rare cannonballs that can do weird things like make the entire enemy crew drunk, or lower their anchor.
[*] The combat is awesome, although the swordfighting leaves a lot to be desired and gunfighting suffers from extremely slow reload speeds, ship combat is amazing! Besides all the factors that need to be taken into account when maneuvering a ship which is quite tough on it's own, shooting the cannons is no walk in the park either, boarding is a constant threat/temptation, and while all that stuff is going on you still have to remember to plug the holes in your ship so you don't end up being the one that sinks! That while also shoveling out the water that flooded in through said holes... As you can imagine, there's A LOT of stuff going on in combat even if you're just on a small 2 man sloop, as such, every victory is just that much sweeter, since you truly had to work for it. Teamwork is mandatory, you can't shoot cannons, steer, adjust sails and repair your ship all at the same time as one person.
[*] Everybody starts off the same, with the same scarce resources, the same choice of weapons, the same choice of ships, you will rarely be in a position where you are outmatched by another player unless you allowed it to happen, for example by not stocking up on enough resources for a prolonged battle, failing to be mentally prepared for the fact that other players can always try to kill you, forgetting to look around for other ships regularly, lack of skill in ship maneuvering and ship combat, underestimating the firepower of a galleon, etc. On the flip side however, this also means that when you encounter other players, if they made these kinds of mistakes, you can turn it into your advantage and raid them if that's your thing.
[/list]

If you're on the fence about whether you should buy this game or not I suggest you watch some gameplay videos or guides on youtube; but to summarize.

This is a multiplayer game best played with friends, ship combat rocks, any player can attack any other player outside their own crew; there is no safe zone concept in this game, it's a sandbox with lots of grinding, don't get too hooked on the grinding because the main fun of the game lies elsewhere (you literally go on adventures with your friends, what's not to like? If you focus on grinding, you're gonna get robbed and then you're gonna ragequit!), customize your character, don't worry about microtransactions (they're there but honestly I don't see the point, I rarely see a player who uses them, they're purely cosmetic too like everything else of course), Microsoft sucks.

Look, I love this game. It's good. It's frustrating. It can even be boring at times. You'll hate pretty much every random you meet now that the game has resurged in popularity. But, if you can find a good group to play with, the game is great; you'll relish calm moments when you set your wheel straight and just party until you hit your destination, and it'll feel great when you finally start winning at least half the ship battles you get in because you guys all figured out your teamwork and how to run your ship efficiently. In my experience, the game is best played on a brigantine with 2 friends, as IMO the galleon is WAY too slow and is a pain in the ass to maneuver without dropping anchor to drift, and the sloop just isn't as fun as you have 1 less friend. HOWEVER, solo slooping in my experience is also pretty damn fun, as long as it's not ALL you do. 

But what if you don't have anyone to play with? Well, then you can either look at the discord LFG or add the first friendly person you meet. Both have worked out good for me when my friends aren't around to play. The game WILL run out of its allure for me for sure, I know that already, but I also know I'll put in at least 200 hours before I get there. And since the game is updated semi-regularly, there'll be plenty more new things to do.

Capn Warlock here of the SS Dinglehopper. I’m not normally a fan of pirate themed things, I hate pirates in fact, but something about the colorful graphics and decent reviews and the intriguing sound of an open guilt free PVP experience made me decide to give it a shot. 

My very first long session of game play was worth the price of admission. 

I did a few missions and got a good feel for the game and actually had a good time solo despite some people saying solo was kind of too hard and that it was easy to die solo. Still, there was something immersive and fun about setting sail and dealing with the rigging and stuff. The constant watching over my shoulder for scallywags on the horizon added just the right touch of tension to make the otherwise simplistic PVE content more exciting. 

I was dropping off a cargo load at this tiny little trading station when I spotted a sail and some lights in the distance. AHA! PLAYERS will they be friendly? Or villainous? I know, I will be villainous first!

So I turned in my mission and got my gold, Nothing left to lose now but my pride!

So I unfurled the Black flag and my sails, and hoisted my anchor and set me sails to catch the wind. I loaded some regular cannon balls into my pitiful pair of cannons, wishing I had 2 more and a partner to operate them. 

I sailed straight at them angling for a close pass, as a solo player I couldn’t steer and shoot so I let the ships wheel give me a slight turn to make me less easy to predict. Hoping I would get a nice broadside pass and catch them off guard then sail on by them to get a bearing for a second shot. 
To my horror, as I missed my first shot due to being a newb, the player ship took an aggressive approach and came right out me. 
I quickly reloaded my cannon and fired point blank right into the prow of the ship as it crashed into my starboard side. 
My ship made horrible crunching and gurgling sounds as it began taking on water. I reloaded and fired again, but then saw my HP go down, I was boarded, and someone was slicing me up! 
I turned around and lowered my pistol at them, but they already had a blunderbuss out. 
Somehow, they must have just grazed me because I was kicked off the ship with a mighty bang and had but a sliver of life left. I watched in desperation as my ship and their ship were locked in a death grip and my ship was riding low in the water with fire all over and players ransacking my meager supplies. 

I found a merman and was taken back to my ship, I managed to gut one of the cads before the other killed me in one hit. 

By the time I respawned, my ship was sunk and I lost utterly. 

But I didn’t feel bad at all, it was 2 versus one, and I never fired on anyone in anger in this game and I did ok. I’m sure their ship was in need of real repairs, and one of their crew would remember the sting of my sword on their back. 

I decided to go back to the PVE content to get more practice, and about 20 minutes later came across the same ship docked in a nearby harbor with the same flag. 

I sailed in when they must have been dropping off loot, so this wouldn’t be a robbery it would just be revenge. 

I fire 3 shots, and saw their ship took all three at or below the waterline. But then heard a crash and crunch sound followed by the familiar bubbling sound. I Struck a rock and my ship took a hole!

I ran below and plugged the hole and bailed out a few scoops and returned to the deck to see if I could fire again. 

But now I saw one of the ruffians in the water heading my way!

They activated their push to talk and shouted in a funny accent “Death to American dogs!” and I hit my own push to talk and shouted “Tally ho you scallywag!” and gave him a proper welcome with my blunderbuss, killing him in one shot. I turned my attention to their ship; it was going down!  And no sign of their partner!

I fired a final parting shot with and watched as their ship listed over and sank to the bottom. I got my revenge! 

The next few hours were more or less just as exhilarating, with undead pirate ship battles where I actually sunk one solo, a kraken encounter that killed me in an amusing way, and a fun encounter with a megaladon shark where I harpooned it and rode around with it for a while till it swam off with 4 cannon balls in its belly. And several intense and fun PVP exchanges where I even sunk another player fair and square… that battle was epic, lasting easily 10 minutes as we broke off and reengaged several times and even had a thunderstorm land on top of us making us lose sight of one another for a while. The final shot that sent him down and left him stranded in the water made me smile a wicked smile. 

And tonight, I found a 3 man ship and decided to harass them with hit and run attacks and make their night more interesting. I ended up accidentally losing my ship when it got stuck on the docks near the seadogs. Thinking I lost the 3 man ship forever I scuttled and was about to jump into a mermaids arms to respawn, and that was when my enemies in a 3 man ship rolled up to collect loot probably thinking I died or had sailed away. I snuck around to the top of the base and used a sniper rifle to kill 2 of the crew and blow up a gunpowder keg they left on the very front of the ship for some reason. 

They tucked their tail and ran leaving some of the loot they were picking up behind, I guess they didn’t know I was just a single player with a sniper and no real way to harass them if they just stayed on their ship and scooped up the loot, even if it meant I picked them off one by one they would have gotten away. 

Or they may have hunted me down and finished me off. I heard them sailing away laughing and shouting about not knowing where it was coming from and to “hurry hurry hurry and put the fire out” followed by “but how? How do you put out fires” then “I uh. I dunno actually!” was the last thing I heard as they sailed off, with the fire burning far into the distance, finally being put out after quite a while. I had no ship and this island didn’t have a way to turn in my loot, so I dove into the water and found a mermaid and lost my ill gotten booty… But it was worth it hahaha. 

I know, I have been acting like a jerk to people just trying to play the game, but honestly, it’s harmless and expected, I fully expect my turn to come around when some jerk in a Sloop swoops in a takes my loot. 

Bottom line, if this game is this much fun playing solo without a real purpose, if I can ever get a crew to join me, I can see many hours being “sunk” into this game. 

True it lacks almost any real sense of meaningful progression and is based on just cosmetic upgrades. But I haven’t even tried the story missions yet, and so far, I love everything about this game. And I hear the story missions are actually fairly good content and totally repeatable. So, I can’t wait to try them. 

Till next time, beware the Dread Pirate Warlock aboard the SS Dinglehopper!  I am coming to grief and harass you and take your stuff!  Come and get me if you can!

This is a very entertaining game. it keeps you busy, and it isn't a grind. there are several different flavors of quests and the PvP fighting is great! They keep the PvP fair by limiting the number of "crews" on each server, and by making everyone's abilities the same. There is no pay to win, or skill upgrades. Only materials you find laying around the islands. The restrictions on crew numbers is one of the bad parts of this game. It's a necessity to limit the size of crews to prevent griefing. This makes it hard to play with more than 3 friends at a time though. Also the crew inviting is clunky, and needs to be worked on. It is hard to find friends on XboX when playing on PC, and vice versa. Overall a very enjoyable game though.

The fishing is good. Which is what I enjoy in games. World is pretty, fun things to do for completionists and a good amount of customization options for ships and characters. There are monthly events to earn some premium things from what i've seen. That said there are some hefty drawbacks.
-The game is made for groups. Playing solo is suffering or 'hard mode'.
-Get used to having things stolen from you. It's called sea of thieves for a reason.
-Buggy at times.
-Microtransactions in a full priced game.(Character animations, costumes, ship customizations, ALL pets.) Mostly cosmetic, but the advantage of some emotes that allow you to hide in plain sight can't be ignored. 'Tucking' is what it's called. And while possible with a free emote, a premium emote does it better, allowing you to hide in a box on the floor.
-Motion sickness warning. There is alot of bobbing on the seas. Those with sensitivity to motion sickness might have a problem with sailing. Which takes up the majority of your game.

In the end the voice acting is fantastic and what the game offers is fine for my tastes. If you're a fan of 'make your own fun' kind of games with some missions mixed in, thanks to the tall-tales, I would recommended this game. If the above bothers you, I would wait for a free weekend or sale. If you're weak to motion sickness, avoid this one.

To be short - f**ing grinding and absolutely disbalanced process, when if you are a new to the game all you will do is runing around the deck and dying again, again and again, basically just bacuase there is always a bunch of other players with experience much higher than yours on the server.

Hour of preparations, running around islands and collecting cannon balls, wood planks (which you only allowed to carry 5 and you need them like at least 100 to get into fight, but you must find them first), food and all of this to f**ing die in first 15 minutes to the first little boat that decided to fight you. And I've tried to play solo, in pair, in squad of three and four people. Absolutelly unusable Galeon. You can be easely sinked having crew of 4 and big Galeon with 8 cannons by the little boat when there is only 2 enemies on other side. Because they have over 600 hours of experience. Great match making there!

It's like playing R6 Siege, but you're level 5 and everyone else is ~200. Not even a bit close to an interesting time spending. I've newer thought that I will say that, but this game is even more pain to start playing, than Siege. Bravo. That's a success.

And WHY there is no harpoons on the back of the ship??? Why I always forced to drop an ancor, remove sails, turn the ship and only after that I'll be able to harpoon something. It's so annoying!

After first week of suffering, you finds yourself in a place where just noting much to do, but seek for chests, all of which costs litterally nothing, hunt for sceletons and... dying. Because in any other activite you will be killed in first 15 minutes. You're dying all the time and losing all your progress. And forced to collect cannon balls, planks and foor again and again and again.

I robbed a fort couple of times, I've tried to fight aginst sceleton fleet, I've delivered a bunch of ripers chests. That's it. All activities marked, now I can delete this game, because everything else is nothing but suffer.

Plus sound bugs, when I have my headphones connected, but I hear other players from loudspeakers on my PC AND my monitor. Don't even able to imagine how it is possible.

In the end, I simply don't have 3-4 hours a day to grind and I would love to get back in time and never buy this.

Sea of Thieves is one of the most polished games I have experienced in recent memory. Its environment, immersive sailing and beautiful graphics made this game a pure joy to play, explore and experience. The campaign stories (called "Tall Tales") are intriguing, inventive and curious to play-through.

When it comes to combat regarding the melee strikes with the sword or guns, it feels a bit lackluster and basic. Battling enemies head-on lacks challenge and is relatively simple. That said, the boat battles against Skeleton Ships, Ghost Ships, Kraken, Megalodon or other players is very satisfying and unique. The amount of ways to mess around with your opponent, blow their ship while also repairing and steering your own creates a frantic scene of cooperation among you and your crewmates each and every time. Moments where you T-Bone an enemy ship, grapple their hull and then proceed to invade their deck to release the anchor to prevent them from moving as your allies rain down a variety of cannonballs that inflict different effects and damage is exciting that I have yet to see matched in other games. To add, depending on the size of your crew from 2 players to 4, you will be provided larger ships from a single-said Sloop to a massive Galleon, all with their own benefits and short-comings, making battles incredibly challenging.

Another key part of the game is the progression in the game. For some players, the lack of progression detracts motivation to continue playing. However, if you are someone who enjoys the experience of games more so than rewards, this may be the game for you. In Sea of Thieves, what you start with is what everyone else has and there is no additional unlocks, access to better weaponry/ships or other in the game. The quests, currencies and rewards are all related to cosmetics to improve the look and feel of yourself and your ship.

To end, if GTA is the open-world grindfest to unlocking cooler cars, upgrades and real estate then Sea of Thieves is its counterpart where everything is already unlocked and you simply sail for the great times and moments with your shipmates.

So.. time for a new review..

As of the time of writing this review, i have player 30 hours of sea of thieves. Since it's release i've wanted to buy it, but for some reason i held off. Maybe because i didn't have any friends who wanted to pay that much money for a video game, back when everyone was just playing PUBG and CSGO. One of my friends told me that we should get the game and try it out. Just our luck - the game was about to be released the next day on steam. I should also mention that another thing that held me off was the "lack of progression". I liked the fact that it was all skill, but i didn't like the fact that there wasn't anything to put that skill into. After launching the game and playing through the maiden voyage, i was hooked, but still a bit concerned. "Surely they just put all the best things in the tutorial..." 

Boy was i wrong, after playing with my friend, i realized, that every voyage with your friends is a new adventure full of laughter, jokes and even a few hardships when we lost our loot to other pirates... but that is the reason this game is fun - the teamwork you put in while sailing your ship, digging up loot and solving riddles, fighting skeletons, bosses and other players is where the fun lies.

But it doesn't end there! Remember when i said that i was afraid of the "no progression" feature? NO PROGRESSION MY A**! Each emissary has it's own levels and little rewards that you get and they get progressively more difficult, there are also secret emissaries and Tell Tales which are story line quests. 

The customization options are limited for characters, but it's not difficult to make your character look like a pirate legend no matter how ugly it is, thanks to the massive array of clothes, hooks, peg legs, haircuts, beards and even cute pets!

Now i also have to give a big thanks to RARE for fallowing the footsteps of Hello Games, the makers of NO MAN'S SKY. They manage to make this game amazing with constant free updates that come out monthly and let me tell you - they are not lacking whatsoever. Heck, even the in-game shop that uses micro-transaction currency... wait... THE CURRENCY ISN'T EVEN A MICRO-TRANSACTION, YOU CAN GET THE CURRENCY JUST BY PLAYING THE GAME! "Oh but it has to be like 10 ancient coins per ancient skeleton and everything in the shop costs about 3000 ancient coins... right" Nope, the drops range from 150-200 to 500-800 coins. The main features of the in game store are pets and they cost about 450 ancient coins (350 if they are on sale) I felt BAD when i killed an ancient skeleton, because RARE seriously deserve the money. 

Welp... i usually never write reviews, nor do i make them this long. The reason why i'm doing this, is for the people to see that there is a game which might be more fun for you than CSGO or PUBG or RUST... it's right here... and it's worth every single penny. I want this game to have an Overwhelmingly positive rating, which is also why I'm writing this review. 
 
Take care everyone! See you on the Sea Of Thieves!

This game is fun solo or with friends, though each experience differs. Only real problem are the negative players, though you get that with any open online community. You can get gud or learn to avoid them, but even if one ruins your haul, you pretty much only lose what you didn't take time to cash in.

Other than that I find the gameplay an absolute blast. The characters look wonderful and interact with the world realistically, if a bit comically. There's no leveling up, the pirate who's been on a hundred voyages will have the same weapons and tools as one just starting out after their maiden voyage, and losing one's ship simply means they will respawn with a new one. Instead, one collects gold and standing with the several NPC factions to unlock cosmetics for one's toon, equipment and ship. Only thing that costs only real money are pets, monkeys, parrots and cats, but they are strictly for show, as are the other cosmetics.

I'd recommend this game to anyone who likes FPS and can handle a griefer every once in a while.
gd

Pros: playing the game with random people one meets while playing the game is great. Having the choice to be friendly or not is great. Coordination with crew mates is something one needs to find in crew mates. Proximity voice chat is great, although direction of the player speaking is usually wrong. The mechanics in this game for doing whatever you want is great. The game is freely updated every month with new content and bug fixes. These updates aren't small, either. The bugs found and worked on are actually fixed, and the new content is really good on every update.

Cons: Xbox's player reporting system is broken. It is commonly abused by players, mostly by kids who seem to not be able to succeed in achieving their bullying quota on the seas for the day. I suggest not communicating at all with any player who isn't an adult in the game, or one might be subject to such a consumer controlled ban system. I also suggest purchasing/playing the Steam version of the game, since it has less connection to Microsoft/Xbox for such a reason, however it can still affect a player. The other con to this game is the hit registration for each of the four weapons that one can use, the worst of which seems to be the flintlock/pistol. Rare/The Sea of Thieves team indicate that such an issue is being fixed, which is always good, but the issue is consistent, although less of a problem every other monthly update, approximately. This game can be really frustrating. When (not if) another crew approaches a player and decides to attack/steal that player, only the skill of that player will determine whether the attacking crew will succeed. The hit boxes for the player's pirate avatar are the same as every other player in the server. The weapons, jump height, running speed, everything is exactly the same as every other player. The only difference is the cosmetics per pirate avatar and the skill of the player. This also means that there will be times that a new player will be overwhelmed by a more experienced player. I include this in the cons simply because there isn't any clear way to understand which players are day one players or have played the game for one day. This is also a pro, since anonymity can be beneficial in the relatively infinite number of scenarios that can arise in the game.

This is my review. I definitely recommend this game. It's one of my favorite, and I only play two of my three favorite games nowadays. I don't play any others. I consider that a strong compliment. It's really enjoyable for anyone.

Awesome, beautiful game (the water graphics and different day/night/weather cycles are worth it alone), repetitive in a few senses but it's mostly about cosmetics and providing a fair challenge.

Only real con is that it's microsoft - haven't figured out a way to add friends (at all) besides hooking up on discord. It is crossplay so there's a good sized community. As I'm writting this review, this game makes me feel plenty of different emotions. This game makes me angry, stressed, anxious, but also satisfied, excited and happy. I'm also really happy that this game launched on steam, more developpers should do the same thing.

It's definitly a game to play with friends, but you can still play by yourself. Hear me out, this game is repetitive, but it doesn't feel like it (yet), because it's a game where you make your own adventures. Every session is unique. Unique encounters with other players, some are wholesome, other goes terrible. I'm currently 46 hours in, I haven't done everything yet, and not a single session felt just like the other ones.

Sea of thieves is also quite different from any other games. There aren't really a progression system in this game, someone with 500 hours more than you will only have more cosmetics and more experience as a pirate. You can level up the different guilds, but it doesn't change the gameplay much (slightly different quests). This isn't the type of game that I would recommend to someone not ready to have long sessions. Everytime I play, it's for at least a good 2 hours.

Even though every sessions don't always end well, I highly recommend you to give it a try.

After the tutorial shows off some features that are promising the game is a massive let down.  you get to an empty open world with nothing to do, no one to fight no one but merchants to talk to and you have to pay to accept missions but are too broke to do it.  Im sure there is somthing you are supposed to do, but the game wont tell you and exploring just shows you empty islands with some cool empty forts, with nothing to do.

So i joined an arena game thinking: "okay maybe some PVP so i can do somthing."  I select a team match that involves what were supposed to be teams of 5 because i didnt want to slow down a 2 man team.    Low and behold, i get shoved into a two man team.  The other guy is not on voice coms, and doesnt help getting the ship moving.  After raising the anchor on a galleon all by myself, and setting the sales by myself, and getting to the wheel all by myself we get raped by 2 other galleons with full crews sinking us to the bottom of the sea.  the game has a bug that prevents you from swimming when on deck, even if the deck is under water so i had to run to the edge of my ship on the bottom of the ocean and jump off of it, before the game would let me swim to the surface and find an NPC to let me respawn the boat.  Boat respawned and... i was 100% alone on it.

Look, i like some games that are pure multiplayer pvp, and i like some games that are single player, i even like games that have a mix of both.

BUT

If a game has zero single player, and zero multiplayer... its not a game.  Its a waste of $30.
cool game

-Insert amazing story with plot twists, near heartbreak, and triumph-

8.5/10

-The water itself makes this game bare minimum a 5/10
-Traversing long distances CAN turn into a chore, but if you sit back and admire the water graphics, physics, keeping an eye out for other pirates, etc. it makes it interesting
-Quests aren't too bad on your first 10-20 hours, after that, it CAN get repetitive (unless random events kick in and make a simple trip into a 3 hour fight for your life)

-Customization is great (although more flair would be amazing)
-Primary enemy types (Skeletons) get boring. New enemy types per biome please?
-Sword gameplay is dumb. 'Nuff said.

-Ship mechanics are stellar (paired with waves crashing into the ship making it rock during intense fights is mind blowing)
-Arena mode is okay

Now everything mentioned above is already pretty darn good for a $40 game that'll eat up hours upon HOURS of your life (85% of it being in a good way)

but you definitely multiply all the POSITIVES by 4x when you get great ship-mates along the way to share the journey with.

This is the best game I've ever played in long, long time. Sea of Thieves is the only pirate game on Steam that's worth the time and money to sink in. Amazing game that I cannot get enough of.  Owned it on the Microsoft store and decided to make the hop to steam when it was released.  I've been playing for two years and still find myself excited every time my friends and I hop on for a night on the seas.  This game is worth the money hands down.

For new players:  Please do not let yourself get frustrated if you find yourself sunk and your loot stolen.  This is the nature of the game.  You learn and get better and soon you're the one stealing loot or knowing better how to defend yourself and your ship.  It wont take long to get there but if you rage out the first time you lose your loot you're going to have a bad time.

Yes, you can form an alliance with other crews but I have not seen that happen a lot.
We got lucky once in that our Sloop was being chased by a Galleon, we sailed towards an other Sloop and with both Sloops we managed to sink the Galleon.

Your loot is for anyone to take until you hand it in at the merchants for coin.

Don't feel bad when your ship sinks it's part of the game.

The Installation period of this game has been horrible.  Clearly there are still some kinks to work out between linking steam and microsoft accounts, as I am unable to play the game.  Once I had installed the game, I launched it and "linked" my steam and microsoft account easily.  when I continued on to try and PLAY the actual game, I was greeted with an error, stating "Sorry, you are not allowed to join any sessions.  Check your account settings and try again. (avacadobeard)"  What settings?  What account?  I swear these error messages are worse than Windows 10.  After some research I found that this message appears for people on XBOX who haven't paid for Xbox Live Gold.  This is odd, considering I'm on steam and a PC, not on Xbox.  I got in touch with Xbox support, who basically shotgunned possible reasons for this issue and standard fixes, none of which worked for me.  These "fixes" included restarting my pc, reinstalling the game, launching from steam instead of desktop, launching from the Xbox app, (which uses the steam directory so how that is any way different I'm not sure).  Half the time the support team wouldn't read the initial complaint and imediately assuem I was using an Xbox, simply saying I needed a Gold Membership (Wrong, Microsoft explicitly stated Sea of Thieves would NOT require any paid memberships aside from an Xbox account, which I have.)  I have linked my steam and microsoft accounts, which did not work.  As of yet, I am considering getting a refund.  the process I have had to go through to play this game has been terrible and I have been offered no actual help by Microsoft's helpers.

[h1] First Impression Review [/h1]

Firstly, I feel that the 40$ price tag is fair. There's a lot to do in this game, it gets major event updates every month. I would recommend you buy it on sale or game pass to try it out. It's definitely worth trying in my opinion. The developer cares about the game and provides regular free updates. If you can play with friends, it's even better. I have been playing solo and I'm having blast. It takes an hour or two to get used to micromanaging as a solo player. It's absolutely playable as a solo player, I've had no problems playing on my own.

Rare honestly deserves the love they've gotten for this game. While it had a rocky start and it took them a while to bring all their vision to light, they promised continued support and development. They've been honest with us on every issue, not tried to sweep things that were genuinely game-breaking under the rug, and ran a few decisions past the players too.

In Conclusion, the game is excellent. Definitely worth buying if you have some money to spare. If you're on the fence about buying it, sign up for the Xbox Game Pass. This lets you get access to the entire library for a monthly fee, and has a two-week free trial. You can hop on board, cancel the subscription, get your two weeks in and make your decision then.

This was a game I wanted to get when I first heard about it. Unfortunately, I didn't buy Sea of Thieves since the game did not release on Steam Initially but I am happy it's finally here now.

This game should serve as a reference of why publishers/devs should strongly consider releasing their games across all platforms (especially at launch) since there is clearly a plethora of gamers who enjoy great games here on Steam. Failing to do so clearly prevents a company from receiving the numerous benefits of having their game on Steam such as more sales and significant exposure due to its high player count.

One reason why I didn't get the game when it came out was because I want my games on Steam. I have a profile that is unique to me and is something I can call my own. Not every platform has that and on some you're just a username and a number. It's fun to show off your in-game accomplishments with friends through screenshots posted to your profile or discussing your favorite game with other steam users in the community hub. So, I hope the overwhelming success of Sea of Thieves on Steam shows we're a platform that shouldn't be counted out.

Pirates and adventures upon the open sea have long been things of interest to me, and so when I first learned about Sea of Thieves I was excited and eager to play it. Unfortunately for me the game was an X-Box exclusive, and I had long been a PlayStation gamer. Though it pained me to admit it, I thought I might never get a chance to try out that awesome sounding pirate MMO.

When I discovered that Sea of Thieves was also becoming available on Steam, I was overjoyed and purchased it immediately upon release - and I am immensely happy that I did. The game has proven thus far to be immensely satisfying, adopting an open world styling that truly allows you to be the kind of pirate you wish to be. Want to explore every island you come across? Do it. Want to take on quests and earn gold? You can. Want to hunt for buried treasure? There's plenty to find!

Of course, this freedom does result in players being able to raid and combat one another on the open sea, sinking their ships and stealing their plunder. This is less frustrating than I thought it would be, and fights between ships and players can be truly entertaining - though if you are not sailing with a crew, the battles will rarely swing in your favour. That said, luck and cunning can allow even an outnumbered pirate to overcome their foes.

If I had to gripe, I'd choose the following two things to complain about: firstly, as nifty as the Infinite Pirate Generator is, I do wish that players could simply design their own pirate to play rather than having to cycle through randomised options; secondly, and as an addendum to the previous paragraph, it can get frustrating when brand new players are hunted and killed the moment they beat the tutorial, scarcely having a moment to find their feet. I understand this is not always the case and is entirely player-dependent, but it was something that made my own introduction to the Game far longer than it needed to be.

Visually, the game is beautiful, and possesses it's own style that makes it instantly recognisable and appealing. Some might not like it, but I enjoyed it immensely. It certainly meshed well with the humour and music - the latter of which is also fantastic. I've become a big fan of this game's soundtrack since picking it up; it enhances the game very well!

If you like pirates, give this a go; if you don't, I'd still recommend it, though admittedly it probably won't appeal to you anywhere near as much.

[h1] IT'S NOT ABOUT THE GOLD... [/h1]


Sea of Thieves it`s an amazing game, you can have hours and hours of fun with a friend and you'll never realize how much time have you spent in the game. I've been playing Sea of Thieves for over a year now, first in the Microsoft store and now, here on Steam [spoiler](Finally!)[/spoiler] 

It took me a while to understand the game, or at least to see from a perspective that didn`t make me quit haha  You know, in the beginning, Sea of Thieves was really hard to enjoy, because it`s super repetitive and a year ago it didn`t have a lot of content, so it was really hard to spend time sailing the seas since you only had a couple of things to do. Now... there is a lot of content, that you can spend a lot of time on, or if you want to rush things, you can finish all the content in two or three weeks, but don`t do that! [spoiler](or go for it, idc)[/spoiler]

But to me, what makes me understand the game was when I finished all the Tall Tales. [spoiler](Tall Tales are basically the "Main Story" of the game)[/spoiler] When you finish you get to watch a cutscene which a very important person in the game is talking and he'll say something that got stuck with me for a long time, "It`s not about the gold, It's about the Glory!". And that's the most beautiful way to describe the game. Yeah, you`re in the PVP world, where everybody can [spoiler](and will)[/spoiler] kill each other (most of the time for no reason) but Sea of Thieves it's not about grinding gold or getting rich.

In the Game you have a system of commendations, there are basically achievements that you can complete and by completing them you may unlock titles or cosmetics in the game and for me, that's the main objective of the game, collecting commendations, titles, and very exclusive stuff that really shows that you spend way to much time in this game, for example, I just spent two weeks fishing so I can have a fishing rod that glows in the dark... did I spend waaay to much time just for that? Hell yeah, I did. Was it worth it? Yes. (maybe not, I've mixed feelings about it).

But in the end, you might have a completely different vision of the game, maybe for you, this is all bullshit and meaningless and I might understand why, but If you don't have the game yet, please considered buying it, because it's really worth it, and I'm sure you and your friends will have great moments playing it :) And don't worry about the content because the game gets updated every month just keep an eye on their social media,mostly Youtube)

[url=https://www.seaofthieves.com/] Sea of Thieves Main Website [/url]
[url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCtt2JqBTG-KoBae4F0Ay2tg/videos] Youtube Channel [/url]

I almost forgot, with you don`t have friends to play, I recommend you to find a Discord server, like this one, [url=https://discord.com/invite/SeaOfThieves] Official Discord Server [/url] or any discord server that suits you, you can find a list of Discord servers from your region here: [url=https://www.seaofthieves.com/affiliate-alliance] List of Discord Servers around the World! [/url] 

[b]and remember...[/b]

Pretty fun and good game. Unfortunately, my laptop was a bit underpowered and lags quite a bit, but I still got enjoyment out of it! I definitely would say that if you want to play this game, go for the recommended specs because otherwise it's pretty hard to play. Great game, though!

I wish there was an option for "inbetween" because it really depends on what you're looking for in Sea of Thieves. If you have friends who also play it, you are pretty much set since it is all the game has to offer in the sense of multiplayer. Otherwise it is a tiresome grind of going back and forth in open crews to find the right crew to play with. Not to mention it takes a little while to join a game. 

If you're looking to solo the game, I wish you the best of luck (because luck is apparently everything when you solo). Wanna do a tall tale (the closest thing to a campaign?) better hope no other players come along to ruin 3 to 4 hours of progress (I wish I was exaggerating it). Some tall tales take even longer to complete. It took me alone roughly 2 days to finish the first chapter since I either ran into strong NPCs or players who were just out to ruin the fun. 

If you're looking for content, there is some out there, just not a whole lot. There is no sort of progression in the game (level up, going up in rank etc.) except for flashy cosmetics. 

As for the quests, it is the same repetitive "go from point A to point B" type of quests with different factions so it "feels" different.

I really really want to love this game. It is beautiful, sailing feels very nice and there is a world to explore. I just wished there was more than just basic bare bone quests, flashy cosmetics and "having fun with friends" as an incentive to reel you back in for more. 
As soon as your friends are busy or can't play when you want, it can become quite boring real fast.

My final verdict, wait until it goes on sale because it is definitely not worth 40 euros. Maybe 20 at max.

I love this game overall. The positives outweigh the negatives by a lot for me. This game is better in a group but can be played solo but you must be vigilant. 

Positives:
I love the graphics and the water is probably the best ever put in a video game. The combat isn't fantastic PVM or PVP but it is fun and engaging. I love the sailing mechanic in this game. It feels so immersive and just hits the sweet spot. I like the quests and riddles which are fun to figure out without a guide. I like the PVE a lot as well. Doing fort raids, Kraken, Megalodons and ship battles are so much fun to me and rewarding. Even the main story is fun and engaging, making me want to learn more about the lore. I love trying to level up the factions as well.

Negatives:
You shooting other ships doesn't really matter, unfortunately. People will just repair their ships constantly and try to shoot themselves at your ship to take you out, which is fine. However, the main PVP strat is to sneak on the ship with TNT and blow it up, which will kill the whole crew and put many holes in the ship. This always feels dirty and like you've been cheated. It sucks this is the main strat in the game. A lot of the people you run into are toxic as well but not all. Most will just avoid you though.
There are some bugs here and there. Getting stuck in geometry or dying for no known reason. Some of the Skeleton captains have gotten stuck underground, forcing us to abandon the quest or raid.

Sea of Thieves has a nice concept of a MMO pirate game.
However there are a lot of cons, which make this game boring, repetitive and unsatisfying to play.
First of all the bugs, there are a few of them, that i've encountered in my playthroughs and already reported all of them for the Sea of Thieves Support.
Like Megaladoon was never attacking my ship, when i played online with a friend.
It always appeared, did nothing, but swimming around the ship for a couple of minutes and moving away from it.
Sometimes a ship's compass stopped working for my friend, forcing him to use a pocket one to navigate.
One time the game crashed and before i closed it i saw an outpost not loading at all.
No buildings, no npcs, just some bad looking textures, of not loaded buldings etc.
Aside from bugs, game doesn't have any real goal to play and farm gold for.
You can only buy cosmetics to look cool or make your ship to look cool, that's it.
Once you've got your fav outfit and a ship's look you're done with a game.
It would be better to have some goal, like raids, buying islands to build farms, storagerooms etc.
To produce resources, storage loot etc.
PvP should be optional imo.
Like everyone will have a special flag to set in order to go into pvp mode.
And to prevent ppl from abusing raising and lowering a flag add a cooldown after you raised a flag, that in the next 5 minutes you're not allowed to lower it.
And everyone else, who doesn't have that flag raised will not be affected by pvp players shots etc.
And a final thing is to add iron sights or a crosshair for firearms and making a swordfight more faster and satisfying, instead of slowly swinging a cutglass.
Game's concept is fine and i want it to become better, with more stuff for players to do and farm the gold for.
However in it's current state, i'd rather wait for more updates and improvements before buying it or coming back into it.
There are many other games in 2020 to play meanwhile you're waiting for more updates for this game.

TL:DR
no content, fortnite on prozac.
Long Read:
We bought this together with my Wife as a nice chill after work co-op.
First look -
the best looking waves, weather, sky i seen in long time.
co-op mechanics is quite fun and keeps you interested (for first 3 hours) .

After first two hours:
-there is no real tutorial, you spend ages alt+tab to search for information on the most basics of the game.
-there is no progression, there is nothing to grind for,  only thing that you can keep between session are cosmetics.
-due to fact that there only 3 types of quest (fetch,kill, complicated  fetch) other adult players get bored straight away.
-because there is no progression, and nothing to do, people are creating their own entertainment: hunt other players.
  but because combat mechanic is super simplistic it usually ends up using tricks (hide somewhere on the ship,glitching through wall) or simple 4 against one.
Let me give you an example: You sail together with your friend, you are enjoying the views and the suddenly BAM your dead , second later your friend. Both shoot in the back by bored player who hid in your ship and sneak on you while you were busy tending to ship.
Well you could say: But this is PvP game get used to it , get gut. 
Mate I was wall bouncing with saw-off shotgun in first Gears, together with my Wife we got through original gears trilogy on "insane" difficulty level.
No... There is no skill in using graphic glitch to make yourself almost invisible to moment later "one shot" player from the back.
Even more frustrating is fact, that they gain nothing out of it, no exp ,no K/D ratio nothing.
Game is a waste of time, it has a potential to be a "chilled hangout place" for work tired adults, pop the beer , get few mates together, do something that does not require to much front lobe activity and reflexes of redbull infused teenager.
But there is nothing there, seriously nothing. 
 
We both tried to refund but sadly it was pass 2h limit.
I'm having a good time with my friends :D.

I like the graphics, aesthetics and atmosphere, and there are some fun ship and team based mechanics, but ultimately there seems to be a very limited appeal. Waiting in a lobby for a match takes way too much time and sadly like many other games with potential, the experience is often ruined by the community. In my few arena experiences, 2 out of 3 were negative experiences due to the needless toxicity of other players. also 2 out of 3 games results in people quitting at the start or one team taking over other teams ships and spawn camping.

And despite the amount of quality that is in the game, truly immersive moments, there is just not enough depth to it to feel like 40$ is worth it. I would only buy this game if its on sale and you have friends to fill your crew. Otherwise you're going to have a mediocre or bad time. now and then you may actually have a fun match, but those seem too few and far between. 

I might play the game a bit more just to give the community another chance, but judging by how they are reacting to my review? point and case. don't waste your time, this game is full of gen-z clowns.

+graphics / atmosphere / art style
+music
+ship / team mechanics

-overly basic weapons and movement. sniper can be fired under water, swords take too many hits to kill, there is noblock or nuance to melee. the charged leap attack feels more risky than it is worth
-price is high considering how hungry they are for you to spend extra money on their shoppe
-takes up a lot of HD space
-takes a long time to get into and play a simple match, chances are low that its truly fun
-people are often toxic
-only lasting appeal outside of frequently playing with friends is earning cosmetics. so if you don't care for "dressing up your dolly" like me, there is nothing to gain from sinking many hours into this game

I've played probably about 80-100 hrs of the Windows Store version, and I can tell you this is easily one of the best multiplayer games I've played. There is a huge variety of activities to do, both PvE and PvP. And since there's no sort of gear progression or power levels, you can participate in (almost) all the game has to offer right from the start (unlike most MMO's where you have to grind through to the end-game in order to get the the good stuff). In addition, since there's no gear or levels, everyone is on an equal playing field when it comes to PvP, regardless of whether you're brand new or if you've sunk 3000 hours into the game. Speaking of PvP, you earn treasure from completing activities, but you don't earn any gold until you sell the treasure at a port. This means if a player comes along and steals your treasure, they can turn it in and you get nothing. This WILL happen... A LOT, and it can make for some really salty moments, but it's honestly just part of the fun. There's no bigger rush than when you get attacked by another crew when you're close to port and have a huge haul waiting to be turned in. Can't recommend this game enough. Get a few friends together and have the time of your life (just don't use Open Crew... unless you like crews full of angry, screaming 12 yr olds)

If you like a mix of PvP and PvE, then this game is for you. While I can say that there are times where I wanted to pull my hair out, I then remember that I am not very good at PvP (somewhat due to the fact that I am playing on a 2016 intel I7 core hp notebook laptop AKA potato computer), there are plenty of times where I succeed at what I am trying to accomplish. This is the best pirate game that I've played, and so far I am enjoying my experience.

KEEP IN MIND, most players have played for a long amount of time, and they probably will be hostile, so just a fair warning, don't attack unless you have friends that know what they're doing. Also, only hoard loot if you are mentally prepared to lose roughly 6-8 hours worth of work in less than 30 min.

TLDR, Sea of Thieves, while it had a tough launch, is now better than what it was in 2018, much better. I recommend this game for anyone looking for a game that can run on lowend pcs like mine and still look somewhat pleasant, all the while you plunder chests, kill bounties, and explore. I don't recommend this game to people with low tempers, as they might end up destroying there set-ups in milliseconds.

This game has a narrow sensitivity range that hurts some who used to play in very low or high sensitivity...For example, I have 4.68 x 800 dpi in ow. If I want to ensure my hip fire is similar to other games, the zoom sensitivity is out of range(way higher than 10). Vice versa, to ensure my zoom aim is the same, I have to use a very high sensitivity on hip fire - probably 2 times or even 3 times.

I still stand by this game being hard to deal with. 
The PVP is frustrating, unbalanced, and nearly impossible to avoid. 
However there is so much i love about this game. 
I am constantly torn, there SHOULD be a way to avoid it, whether it be a private server or PVE only server, but the game still is good. PVP ship battles out in open sea are a lot of fun and tactical but the actual face to face combat is pretty much garbage, you get 1shot by the Blunderbuss and then they can sit on your ship They can 1 shot you again and you don't even have time to equip a weapon. Honestly just talking about it is annoying because i was just trying to do the story quests, they are well written and i wanted to enjoy them but i got attacked (i had no treasure) 3 times, left server tried again was attacked again (still no treasure) and they just knew where the story quest was so they hung around there attacking me so i couldn't do the quest. 
Basically the story doesn't matter if you cant actually enjoy it, and the devs seem to have no interest in catering to a more casual fan basis, when i first started playing this i actually got TWELVE of my friends to get it, we grouped up played and there were a lot of good times but they ALL rage quit because they wanted to have fun and just got harassed constantly. 

That being said, i have actually made a few friends in server, when you get the chance to get revenge on jerks who were just bullying you it is fantastic. The style is beautiful, and what lore you can actually get to (ALMOST NONE OF IT) seems to be thematic and fun. I would buy the game all over again if it meant i could have a private server to enjoy the game with friends and enjoy the well designed social aspects of this game. It has potential to be much more inclusive but as it stands should basically be called Sea of dickheads.

Pros:
- Tons of fun with friends with a heavy focus on cooperation
- Unique art style
- Tons of character & ship customization
- Very few bugs
- Fantastic sailing mechanics

Cons:
- Very repetitive
- No character progression (other than visual)
- Solo play can feel daunting and not worth it
- PVP and PVE (Mainly non-ship combat) feels boring and slow because of locked/slow animations and lack of weapon diversity (stats wise). Nor is hit multipliers a thing, so headshots etc, don't do extra damage, not even in PVE.

Content suggestions:
- Customizable player owned islands (With production features for food and special cannon balls)
- A perk system or special weapon variations (To make PVP/PVE less mundane/repetitive)
- Larger town settlements/islands (A central place where players can meet and socialize)

Overall SoT is a great game, but can't personally recommend it because of the cons listed above.

[Played SoT since it's release on the Microsoft Store, my Steam hours doesn't represent my experience with this game.]

Our three-man brigantine crew fought a four-man galleon for over half an hour. We fully expected it to be a suicide run. Our battle took us halfway across the map in pursuit of each other. We boarded them, they boarded us. Firebombs were slung, as were insults and taunts and musket shot, from both sides. And when the smoke cleared... The merchant brigantine SS (sinking ship) Chunderbird floated alone on the waves, splintered, charred, beaten, battered, still a little bit on fire and filled knee-deep with seawater, but victorious nonetheless.

10/10, screamed my throat raw hurling pirate-themed insults and had the greatest multiplayer adventure of my entire gaming career. Would absolutely recommend.

The community is garbage, but this game is called Sea of Thieves. Not Sea of Friends, not Sea of Merchants, Sea of Thieves. And looking past the fact that you have to watch your back 90% of the time, you've got a truly good game. Most of the combat is skill based (cept the Blunderbuss but A. It's a shotgun and B. It's more of a melee weapon than a ranged weapon) and the learning curve is not that bad. Not only that, but this game is full of those moments where you would be on a solo sloop or something like that, and you see a galleon bearing down on you, and rather than getting blasted into oblivion they'll set an alliance flag and send you a pre-generated "Ahoy!" It's a really good game.

The game you never knew needed. All my life I fumbled under the misunderstanding that I was a normal person and not a pirate. Then I played this game and now all I want is a galleon and a crew with which to take on the high seas! Some people say bring back the 70's or the Roaring 20's. I say, bring back the Golden Age of Piracy!

I'll start this by saying I know this isn't a game for everyone. 
Tall tales serve as a narrative you can follow, and you have Voyages that will give you objectives and treasures to hunt, but outside of that it's open ocean. Gorgeous, expansive, constantly active open ocean. 

the PvE content is really fun, even if the on foot combat is a little simple. Fighting skeletons can get to be tiresome on occasion, but the appeal and fun of exploring, searching islands and caves, digging up treasure, and palling around with other pirates honestly never gets old!

and that last statement is kind of the crux, here. "other pirates." You could very well play solo, and it is fun and relaxing to just sail on your own, fishing and exploring, "vibing" as the kids say, but the majority of the fun you'll have in SoT surrounds your crew. A full 4 isn't always a requirement, you'll get on fine with 3 and a Brig. I'd honestly suggest that 9 times out of 10, just because a Galleon is really a lot to juggle, and it's easier to convince two of your buds to buy this game as opposed to three.

the biggest downsides to the game as of right now are two things: the player base, and its occasional bugs.  

the player base - Immediately hostile. All the time. Get ready to get into ship battles, gun fights, and brawls every time you encounter another group of players. You can plea, and bargain, and explain you have nothing of value on your ship because you just left spawn, it doesn't matter. Other players will kill you on sight, every time, all the time, no matter what. So, just keep your cannons loaded, and be prepared to shoot down anyone and everyone. 

bugs - my mic does not work in game, at all. I can't seem to find a solution to this anywhere, and I've altered a thousand settings both in windows, through the Xbox Game App, in game, etc - still doesn't work. No idea how to fix it, but thankfully text chat can be seen by all players, which makes desperately asking people to stop shooting at me a little easier. The more detrimental bug is the fact that the compass next to the ships wheel just stops working occasionally. It'll get stuck on north and never move, which requires you to use your pocket compass, taking your hands off the wheel every  couple of seconds just to make sure you're going on the right course. A minor thing that I hope they patch out soon.



my closing thoughts is this, though - It's a fun open world game where you get to be a pirate, wear basically nothing, and get into drunken swordfights while hunting for treasure! It's a wonderful time, I loved it in the Technical Alpha, I loved it in the Closed Beta, and I love it here, on Steam! 

(sidenote - fully cross play with xbox one and windows store players! which is kinda sweet tbh)

I played this game way back in beta when it was only on the Microsoft store but never actually purchased or played the full game. I purchased this version on steam and i'm so glad that I did. It is so much fun !

PROS :
+ tons of quests to do including tall tales quests.
+ Different factions you can level up by doing their quests.
+ No player has an advantage over the other because every item you can earn in the game is cosmetic. The only advantage to be gained is your own skill with the game and learning its systems.
+ Skull forts are really fun and have lots of loot
+ Game is Fun with PVP  as well . There are only 6 other ships per server so you can avoid other players most of the time if you want to.
+ Game can be played solo but playing with randoms has been really fun in my experience. 
+ I've made alot of new friends playing this game who are a blast to play this game with. 
+Devs really care about their game and are constantly adding new things.

Cons :
- Ships compass has a glitch where it always points north which is really irratating .
- Sometimes it can be very time consuming but its overall a great experience. Not a game you can just play for a few minutes because you have to do your quest and then cash it in.
- Sometimes you get people that just like to ruin your fun on your crew but it hasn't happened very often.


Overall the game is a very amazing experience and if you like Pirates , and sailing the high seas , and taking treasure from others ( aka the name sea of thieves ) then this game is for you !

I haven't played for very long, but I've been having a decent time.

Pros:
- The game does a great job of fulfilling many of the fantasies of being a pirate, including digging for treasure, drinking grog, dancing to music, fighting other pirates and looting their remains, being attacked by the Kraken, following maps, and many other creative and clever design decisions.
- The game overall is gorgeous. The pirates are rather ugly, but mostly in a quirky, piratey way.

Cons:
- Microsoft forces you to create an XBOX account, and your playing with friends forces you to interact with them using that, rather than inviting friends via Steam. Linking the accounts together didn't allow my existing friends to be discovered, and we had to manually add each other on the XBOX accounts instead. It was a poor player experience.

- The camera FoV is capped out at 90 (and is set to 75 or so by default). If you're like my girlfriend and me and you're more sensitive to motion sickness, this might be unplayable when combined with the bobbing of ships and disorientation swimming around shipwrecks. Apparently to preserve "fairness" between console and PC users, this setting is unlikely to be fixed officially ever, which is a big shame.

- The game uses your microphone by default, broadcasting whatever you say to other players in your vicinity. It never warns you of this, which feels kind of privacy-invading.

- Not exactly a con, but something you just need to acknowledge, but the game is solidly PvP. From what I've seen, there are no safe areas, no "protection". You can get murdered or robbed at any time. It's not very punishing (you don't lose much upon death, and stealing your stuff back is possible when you re-spawn), but if this gives you anxiety, then the game's probably not for you.

- The microtransactions feel a bit like the game's double-dipping, but it's just for cosmetics, and I guess players are used to companies doing this nowadays, even if it leaves a bit of a bad taste.

As you can see, all of my gripes are more to do with meta-decisions, and many people would disagree with me over whether those are problems. The developers who did the game's design and visuals did a really great job. If the cons don't turn you off, I think you'll have a great time.

The game looks good if you're into that kind of visuals, and many game mechanics work pretty well, but I cannot recommend this game because it's too frustrating.

The game basics are poorly explained through a tiny tutorial, then the player is thrown into a world without any indication of what to do next.
Quests give poor information about what's expected, but it always boils down to sailing for hours between islands to find some poultry or treasure and bringing it back to another island.

Meeting other players in-game always concludes with the rookie being killed and his treasure taken away, completely losing the latest 2 to 4 invested hours.

There are weird disappearing items bugs, really annoying when you get back with your ship with every treasure chest you found, only to realize there are no more chests on your ship.
There was also a time when the ship started flying away, so steep that my character slid to the water with every chest on board. The mermeaid got the character back to the ship, which was back on the water, but the treasure chests were once more gone.

Refund requested.
