Holy ****, where do i begin. This game is truly fantastic and beautiful, I have played the game for hundreds of hours and I still play it a lot! I must admit this game is for certain players, this game is much about grinding for reputation and commendations, but of course you can also just troll around on a ship with your friends and terrorize everyone. 


What can you do in the game?
There is so much content in this game, you can do everything from doing a relaxing tale tall to hunt the freaking kraken. You can do skeleton forts, skeleton fleets, kill megalodon or die to a megalodon if thats what you like. You can go hunting other people, or just simply relax to this beautiful game, and there is much more! There is 2 kinds of gamemodes in the game. Adventure where you can do everything you want, and then there is Arena. Arena is also a fantastic gamemode, much less relaxing, because you might need to tryhard fo the win! Simply just ships against eachother and 1 chest on the map, you go for! Personally I would say the forts, fleets and Arena is my favorite. Tall Tales is also a huge part of the game, there also takes many hours to complete, I have not played it so much, since the other things have interested me more.

Is the map big, how about the graphics? 
This game is unbelievable beautiful, when you sail around the ocean just a watch on the beautiful waves will make you buy this game, and you will not regret it. The game is huge, like really huge. There is many small and big islands and of course a huge ocean. There is forts, outpost, islands made for tall tales, islands made for stuff and so on. 

Ships:
In Sea of Thieves there is 3 different ships, the Sloop, Brigantine and the huge Galleon. The sloop is made for 1-2 people, a really nice boat, its the smallest, quickest to turn and pretty fast. The Brigantine is made for 3 people, its a bit bigger, a bit faster and slower to turn. The Galleon is made for 4 people, its the biggest, fastest and hardest to turn of course. 

Weapons:
There is 4 different weapons in Sea of Thieves, 3 of them is guns: flintlock pistol (50% damage per shot), eye of reach sniper (70% damage per shot) and the blunderbuss shotgun (10% per pellet), and then there is the effective cutlass who is good to basically everything.  (20% damage per slashing, 60% per lunge)

Are you able to improve your ship and weapons?
Nope, which was one of the reasons why I didnt buy this game earlier, I have always liked the idea of being able to improve your stuff. My friends advised me to buy the game, they also played the game much at the time, and i really dont regret buying it. Instead of improving you are able to cosmetic your stuff, which is a fantastic feature I think. You can cosmetic your own cloth, weapons, ship parts and even get titles by doing stuff in the game as commendations or just simply buying skins.

Reputation & Commendations:
The reputation and commendations are a huge part of the game, this is the part there makes you grind the game a lot! When doing reputation and commendations you can earn titles, clothing and weapon skins.

 Thanks for reading my review, and sorry for the grammar errors! :)

Okay so this is a pure love-hate game. I'm playing it but it's hitting me so damn hard. Let's start with positive things:

1) The sea is beautiful. Nuff said.
2) Really nice pirate setting - envoronments, skins, music.
3) A lot of space for customization.

Negative things:

1) Very unforgiving to new players, the tutorial covers things that are easy and says nothing about really important ascpects of the game.
2) You can't save even if you are playing solo. If you are disconnected or need to close and return in a bit you lose everything - loot, quests, uncompleted stuff.
3) Very time consuming. Everything is manual - even handling chests takes a lot of time. And you are able to  lose everything even in the "village". So kinda often it's difficult even to have bio-afk, not to mention larger breaks.
4) This is NOT a game for a single player. You are gonna be easy prey for larger ships and more experienced players. There are no mechanics to balance that. I've warned you.
5) A lot of in-game mechanics don't spare you. For example, you get an Ashen chest. But you can't handle it to anyone, can't store it, and you need Ashen key. Not an easy thing for a new player. NPC skeleton ship sinks you? Bye bye everything.
6) No in-game encyclopedia. Kinda difficult to joggle controlling ship, watching map and doing everything else at the same time. Some may say it's great but for a new player it's just tough. 
7) It's impossible to play it in a casual way.
8) This is even worse that I thought. I was trying to kill a pirate captain for an hour. I don't know how much HP those stupid developes put into those NPC but still. After an hour of shooting him and mob waves with sniper rifle he finally died. You know what happened next? 2 more captains spawned with more adds. And by this time some sloop with 2 players arrived. No loot, no fun. The game is broken. 

This is really the most terrible and unbalanced bs I've played in years.

3 things to say about this game:

Sea of Thieves is an amazing online pirate game. You don't exactly need friends to play. If you want to have a crew with more than one person, you can choose an open crew where you are put in a crew with random people. The open crew feature can put you in crews with toxic people and other stupid sailors, but you can go to the Sea of Thieves discord server and multiple other official SoT chat groups and ask people to join your crew. Or, of course, you can invite your friends if they have the game.

You can do lots of things in this game. Go on voyages for trading companies, do story quests, just explore and grab whatever booty that you find, look for other sailors and take their loot, and many other things. Most of the other players you meet will be toxic kids (or just sad adults with brain damage) who will attack you on sight even when you don't have any loot at all. As you play, you'll get better, though. Arena is a good way to practice combat.

In Sea of Thieves, you don't buy better weapons or armor or anything like that. Right at the start of the game, you get all the weapons. Instead, you can buy (a bit overpriced) skins and outfits with in-game money. Some are overpriced because, well, a dirty, plain jacket costs thousands of gold coins and it costs around half of 100,000 coins to have someone PAINT your SHIP, but you'll earn the money eventually.

Like a lot of other games, Sea of Thieves is a great game with a horrible community.

This game, though it does have it's flaws. is an incredibly fun PVP and PVE experience. with free content drops coming every month, and tons of free cosmetics done by completing ever changing challenges there are always things to do in this game. I recently purchased the game a second time on Steam for a better launching and social experience, which did not dissapoint, but I have been playing it for well over a year and am looking to play it even more as they continue to add and improve features and content within the game!

The game is a lot of fun, HOWEVER i want to point out some issues that you may find REALLY annoying. First off the BIGGEST PROBLEM is if you're playing with friends you wont be able to join/invite your friends through Steam instead you'll need to use your Microsoft account which by the way, you have to have in order the play the game and for whatever reason at least from my observation i cant add friends within the game you need to use the Xbox companion application or Windows game bar to add your friends, only then you can invite people, also as a side note joining/inviting friends with-in a server is also tedious for whatever reason sometimes it works sometimes it doesn't but that might just be me. To me this seem's to be a HUGE missed opportunity to implement steams easy to use join/invite system.

( EDIT, As of very recently ive suddenly been getting 70 ping it seems more servers have been opened for the SEA region! Hurah!) Secondly, if you are playing in regions other than the US, EU and i think Australia you will have high ping i personally live in Asia and i've gotten between 150-200 ping, HOWEVER i have not felt this impact my experience of the game as shots seem to land and hits seem to register and overall seems fine, however i can see this being an issue for people fighting others with high ping. So keep this in mind when purchasing! hopefully we will see servers in other regions in the future but i highly doubt it.

So if you can look past these issues i would recommend this game only for people who want to play with a group of up to 4 friends including themselves, though you can play solo i can see it getting boring quick, the charm of the game is looking for treasures and doing story quests/puzzles together. Many will say "Whats the point? everything you can buy with gold in the game is only cosmetic there's no progression". I personally dont see why all games need to have some sort of progression if the game is fun and enjoyable to play with friends surely that's enough, there is lots of content to do within the game and hours of laughter.
Finally in steam... I've played it for a week and it's great!!!

It's fun.
Its immersive and atmopsheric.
You may have heard there's no progression in the game, that is correct, as in new mechanics don't unlock as you play, but rather, are available from the start,
however, there is progress via "reputation", allowing you to take harder, longer and more fun quests as you play.
There are also skins, which you can buy with the in-game currency you acquire, making your character, ship, even tankards to drink grog with
Buy it. A lot of fun.

After having devoted over 50 hours to it on the Xbox app I couldn't NOT buy it here.

The coop experience to this game is unique and something that I haven't seen in any other place. This is a game that has to be played with friends, as it enhances every bit of it. 

Graphically and artistically, I love it. Unless you're into fully realistic graphics, I'd say you won't have any complaints. Performance wise, too, this is great. Game runs fine and it has a plethora of options to tune.

In terms of gameplay, as I said, it is unique. Be aware, though, that the loop is somewhat grindy so make sure you'll enjoy the limited amount of activities you can do before you buy. In my case, for instance, I don't mind repeating the same things over and over because the great variety of locations makes it worth the hassle. 

Now, the bad in my opinion boils down to the rewards. I don't think there's much incentive to get rich because all the rewards are cosmetic. A good decision from the devs not to include any level-dependent advantage that would hinder the newer players experience BUT a bit boring nonetheless. This is why I say that this is meant to be played with friends to have a good time and not that much about the rewards.

Overall, a great game. Just watch a couple of gameplays and hype your buddies before you get it.

my opinion of this game has varied in the past few days and i think ive finally come to a solid conclusion

the game is great. but id does need a lot of work, as well as a few additions i think would be pretty neat.

work wise:

-i feel like the character creation or rather lack there of should be implemented. theres a reason people joke about hitting random on character creators. in this case its 999.99 times outta 1000 you're gonna get a pirate that looks like they have a crippling case of down syndrome/elephantiasis. it kinda sucks having to spend hours re rolling again and again just to find someone that looks half decent. theres plenty of arguments of "oh jack sparrow or people will wanna look like their favorite streamers" okay who cares? thats what they wanna do so let em do it. if people wanna make their characters look goofy or elderly cool. give them that option. but have people who wanna make pirates that look like them or just look good in general have the option to do so as well instead of having them re roll for hours only to finally get in game only to realize they look horrid because they missed a small detail or two and need to spend more money to buy another re roll potion.

-next i feel the PVPVE system could use a lot of work itself. theres a reason why people never do Fort of the Damned and why people want pve servers so bad. because the way this game works is like a food chain, PVE players do all the work where PVP players go out and sink them to gain all the reward for little risk or work involved. most argument is that pve players wouldnt have much risk on pve servers however thats really not true. if anything they have the most risk of all with the time they put in going to waste, the effort into solving the riddles, the rewards on their ship being lost if they screw up once, the land based AI, and the sea based AI with players to worry about topped up all on top of it. I would go into further detail about it but i already did in a post I made here: https://steamcommunity.com/app/1172620/discussions/0/2448217258988085793/ regarding it. long story short, i feel the game should stay pvpve but they need to add more features that make it so its not so much of a pvp players constantly preying on pve players. they need to balance the scales a bit which would keep both parties happy if they are never going to add pve servers.

thats really all the complaints i have about this game. now just additional features id like to see

-legendary AI ship battles.
have there be legendary skull ships out there that are extremely powerful but are also extremely reward heavy. like a raid boss but on the open seas.

-add dog pets
we got cats, parrots, and monkeys. now all we need is our pet pup pirates to have the true salty dog experience

-let us name our ships
they got name plaques on the gallion already. they seem kinda weird when they're just left empty. let us name our ships to truely make them our own. (another thing with the character customization argument. let us make them our own)

-add ship interior cosmetics to buy
once more, let us make our ships our own. we got a lot of exterior cosmetic options. now all we need is interior. let us buy big fancy beds or luxurious rugs to really give our ships that personal touch.

thats pretty much it. I love the game. i truly do. theres so much to like about it. the exploring, the puzzle solving, the atmosphere, the feeling of adventure while sailing this grand ship you call yours. its not perfect. but theres still plenty to love about it. even if a good amount of people (including me) arent that big on the pvp aspect, we can still appreciate everything else. though like i said, the game does need work. hopefully rare can start on that said work as soon as this whole real life pandemic clears up.

This game is incredible. My first moments in the game were spent just looking around at everything. The water is stunning, but you can tell that there is extreme attention to detail in everything. The islands, the outposts, the player models, clothing, ship designs. Fabulous.

This game can be challenging to play alone, but with others, it's not only smoother sailing... but it can be comedy gold. There is nothing funnier than a friend accidentally falling off the boat, or harpooning in a crew mate by surprise. 

But really, what sucks me in is that there is ALWAYS something to do. Whether you just want to sail around with no base objective, if you want to work on emissary voyages, or fort challenges... I have spent time simply going from shipwreck to shipwreck, swimming in the water around islands only to find chests and other interesting finds. It never gets old. And lemme just tell you, 20+ chests and you'll be SWEATING tryna get to the nearest outpost. It's a good kind of thrill.

My only couple gripes generally revolve around connectivity. Sometimes the game won't let me connect smoothly with people playing on console. It will allow you to add them as a friend, but when you go to invite them to your crew, the option remains grayed out. This problem seems to come and go and doesn't ever last for very long thankfully. 

Also, fishing. Seriously, why the fuck is it this hard to catch a tiny fish? And god forbid a rock is nearby and the fish swims towards it. Say goodbye to your line and watch it snap no matter how close you are to catching it. I struggle more with fishing than managing my own ship, which says a lot. 

Solid 9.5/10. Fix the fishing.

Could just be a bad day, but it seems like this game is a horrible experience for anyone trying to play it solo.

Honestly the game is fun with friends, solo it can be one of the worst and most toxic experiences you can have in a game. Let me explain what I mean.

Picture this scenario, you're solo in a swoop, minding your own business, grinding on the Crescent Isle when you see a Brigantine roll up with 3 people. This is followed by a few simple steps: Get killed 3v1 because there is no chance you win that, wait for a respawn, spawn camped 3 v 1 and die almost instantly, wait for another respawn, and appear on a different island with an hour or two's worth of work down the drain because you didn't stop to turn in your loot after every drop. What's even worse is getting killed again by the same people immediately afterwards, spawn camped, ship sunk a second time, knowing full well you had little to no time to acquaint anything of value, is about the worst experience I have had in a PvP game. In a moment of frustration in a sinking ship I pulled out my cone and asked over voice chat "Why did you kill me, you know I have nothing". Followed by the voice of one of the three, "Because it's Sea Of Thieves..."

This game is so close to being great, its a shame they let toxic people ruin the experience for me, among other solo players. I have had too many times where I thought to myself, "wow I wish I didn't have to run from this Galleon/Brigantine right now". Especially with doing story missions like tall tales. In my eyes tall tales are supposed to take this epic open world and actually craft this amazing story to follow of it's past, present, and future. In some aspects they actually do that and it's amazing to see some of the work done, especially with the Ashen Lord. But for a solo player it ends up being 'thank god there is a checkpoint system or i'd refund this game'. I say that because your at the will of the players around you if you actually get to do any of the quest. To give an example I had started a tall tale and as I was returning to my ship a Brigantine comes by and shoots a crew member onto my ship and tries to take some loot I had on board. I win the 1v1 but then I think to myself "crap well now I got to leave so I don't get clapped by this bigger crew with a bigger boat." so I leave where I have to be for the quest, while doing so seeing that they are an emissary on the map. I wait out of sight behind a nearby island and hope they leave me alone so I can do the tale. One hour later, then they finally leave and I can continue playing the game.

I love the atmosphere, The tall tales are fantastic, and playing with friends is something to behold. But I can firmly say without a shadow of a doubt playing this game solo is not worth your time. Maybe if they add more content, maybe if they add a mode where solo players can choose to have PvP off and they have a specific flag up so other players know not to waste their time. I think it would be amazing to roleplay as a trading pirate, chests for skulls, skulls for chests. But you can't do that unless you have a random person willing to not just destroy everything on sight as if its there duty to ruin all fun you could have. 

To wrap this review up, yes, I do realize you could read this and say 'get good' or whatever and if you feel that way so be it. I'm writing this to all the people who want to play this game majority solo so they fully understand what they are getting into. If a solo mega chad reads this and says 'get good', kudos, I bet you will enjoy the game and the challenges of being outnumber and outgunned 99% of all PvP interactions. However, to all my fun loving gamers who are in it for exploring a vast open world filled with loot and skeletons galore. Heed my warning, no matter how many Megalodons bite your ship, or Krakens wrap your ship up tight. Undead Pirate ships filling your swoop with more holes then thought possible. The thing that will cause you the most pain and ruin your experience will be another pirate who is just in it to ruin your day.

Engaging open world game that's easy to jump into. I was able to figure out to play just by joining open multiplayer games and in a few shorts hours I had a good grasp of what to do. If you want a game that you can easily put down and then jump right into later on, this is a good one. I suggest building a network of friends because PUGs as in any game can be sketchy. However, you do get lucky from time to time.

It's not for everyone ... like any game. You've got to remember that Rare gave us collect-a-thons like Banjo Kazooie. This is in the same spirit. You just sail around with your friends and encounter various islands with buried treasures, and skeleton crews along with online players, and krakens, and megalodons -- I mean, this game is so much fun ... but you have to know what you're getting into. There is no skill progression system. It's all just cosmetic stuff for fun. The heart of the game is the adventures you have with your friends. If that ain't your bag then don't play. It also has the best sailing mechanics I've ever played in a game. So that's pretty cool.

One of the most underrated games of the last few years. There's a phenomenal amount of content. Every session offers something new and engaging. I find it enjoyable both solo and with full crews. Just remember, it's not called Sea of Friends. You will die. You will have loot stolen. There is a mildly punishing learning curve but the end reward is worth it.

Overall while many aspects of the game are enjoyable, you will need a party of at least 3-4 people in order to survive, the game is also online only meaning you will always have to deal with a multitude of people who enjoy the game in the other way it is meant to be played, through pvp and ship warfare. Their are no places that are safe from other people, some will wait by merchants simply to kill you and sell your loot.

I really wanted to play this game, and even bought it for a friend so we could play together.
Unfortunately I can't. 
I spent the entirety of my play time +a couple hours outside of the game just trying to get the game to stay connected to a server for more than 5 minutes, but never could. 2-5 minutes after connecting to a server I would get booted back to the menu with an error message. This happened every. single. time. Once or twice is a fluke, be I tried at least 10 times and got the same result every single time no matter what fixes I tried to do on my end.
Error message claims there was an interruption in my internet connection every single time, but I was in a discord call with the same friend I bought it for the whole time and we had no issues on that end.
After attempting and failing multiple times to resolve this issue I took to the discussions and looked online to ways to fix this only to find a very handy list of the game's error codes that doesn't list ways to fix them copy pasted to several sites.
So I reached out to Rare's tech support...
I never heard back.
Like I said, I wanted to play this game, but the game won't let me and support hasn't helped at all, so I'm forced to refund it so as to not have wasted my money on something I can't even play.
Cannot recommend this game knowing other people might have this same bad experience I had.
That said, my friend had 0 issues outside of a single crash, so maybe it'll work fine for you.

This game is perfect for an exciting and relaxing adventure on the seas. The game's continuity is a bit different but makes for a great challenge in shorter than average continuous playing times. I've already recommended to friends so we can build a crew!

I started this game thinking I was going to be exploring with friends with the occasional ship battles with other players. Edit: this is what the game sells itself as in the store page.

What I got: same loot over and over, there are like 20 items total, so it's never a surprise. The quests can be interesting, but all of it gets ruined by the main issue I've encountered - there is absolutely no reason to do anything. Nothing to aim for. There is no end game, no weapon upgrades, no armor upgrades, no ship upgrades, nothing. You can work towards having a cooler outfit or ship, but that's just not enough for me.

Edit: I understand there is other loot later on, but who wants to get that far while getting the same 20 items over and over for days?

Also if you play with one or two friends, expect to get harassed over and over by 4 people crews. This game could use a PvE option or a crew max limit for new players so that battles are always fair for those that are not familiar with how to take advantage of their type of ship yet (and this is where an MMR system would come in handy, but there isn't one).

The arena can be decent, but that's not what I bought this game for.

The game is a gorgeous and innovative take on pirate games, and could have been a great deal of fun if not for a few key problems that completely ruin the entire game. Those problems are listed below, in no particular order:

- NO viable solo-player content. There are so many things to do around the ship at all times, each demanding their own separate "interact" mode, which together makes even steering your ship to an island something of a challenge. Actual naval combat is outright impossible alone, as you must simultaniously steer the ship and constantly adjust your heading, reload and man your own cannons, and repair holes being blown in your ship because you actually can't keep up with either of the other two. Unless you have a crew of 2-3 other people to play with, you can barely play the game at all and are functionally a sitting duck when you do. And those have to be people you personally know, as there is no matchmaking with randoms in the game that I've discovered.

-Toxic and inescapable PvP. The entire world is a PvP battleground with no safe havens whatsoever. Which can be fine, since it's a pirate game and some amount of fighting other crews for their loot is to be expected, but in this case only enables toxic spawn-campers and griefers to go out of their way murdering anyone and everyone they come across for the laughs. The community openly bullies you at every opportunity, which is every encounter, and there's no way to actually improve your skills at doing anything because of it.

- Server migration. Servers open and close constantly as players log on and off, and whenever the population of a given server drops below some hidden threshold it gets merged with a more populated server. In-game, this locks your controls and prevents you from moving or interacting with any part of your ship. Which in turn means it's incredibly easy to run yourself aground and lose your ship and the majority of loot you may have gotten. That's even if you don't get amazingly unlucky and spawn inside someone else, which simply deletes one of the overlapped ships and everything on them.

If none of the above bother you, somehow, then it's a great game that I highly recommend. If any one of those is a turn-off for you, hit that ignore button and never look at it again, because from what I've followed up on there's little chance of anything substantial changing for this game, ever.

I am enjoying my time with Sea of Thieves and am glad it finally came to Steam.

It really is an open-world pirate adventure, laden with quests, treasure maps, evil treasure guardians and a lengthy super quest (the Tall Tale) which gives a great experience too.

I read a lot of reviews of people complaining about being grieved. I had my fair share, but most sessions you really don't see anyone else. Although players amount is 50k on most times, the servers I play on are very scarely populated and you can play for hours and see no sails on the horizon (excepty for Skeleton Ships). 

Just earlier today some grievers thought it was fun to destroy my docked ship at an outpost while I was on land. When returning, my ship was burning and they made short work of me. So when you die you go to a ghost ship until you respawn with a new ship, usually several islands away. While I had unfinished business with a quest giver on that island, I set sail and sailed back to it. When approaching, I saw my grievers just loading their ship with gunpowder. Yep, one cannon shot on their ship and the whole ship exploded with a giant kaboom! They were unfortunate enough to be still on the ship and perished. The ship sank, I got their loot (9k worth) and revenge was sweet. This is just one experience you get when you play this game. 

Another time my ship was sunk by a galleon. I managed to respawn on my burning ship as it hadn't sunk yet. A quick jump in the water and I swam to the grieving ship. I tagged along for a while on the ladder, and made my move on deck. I was able to take two with me before I was killed by the 2 others, but this was also a great experience. Especially seeing them on the ghost ship with me. 

These sort of things really feel epic!

There are also friendly players ofcourse, but in my 4 encounters only one was a friendly one. Still, this doesn't mean that much as   I explained earlier, you can have sessions where you don't meet any other human players for hours.

There are a lot of quests to get, from a few different factions and completing them will net you reputation and allows you to get more advanced quests. But loot which you find (or steal) without quests active can be handed in by the specific faction trader for reputation and gold. 

There are some NPC enemies on the map too. Skeleton Ships, The Kraken and the Megalodon, not to mention fortresses which can shoot their cannons towards you too.  Furthermore, sailing in a storm is risky but can be a good way to lose any enemy ships.

With the curerncy you can buy new cosmetics for your character, ship and equipment. As ingame money is only used for cosmetics, this game is not pay to win or anything. You can spend real money too, but again, only for cosmetics.

A big mention must go to the graphics. The sea is out-of-this-world-beautiful. Really a joy to look at. Furthermore the weather effects, like storms, sunsets and sundowns are awesome too. The character and settlement aesthetic are Lucasarts-esque, a bit like Monkey Island 3, which will not suit everyone, but again, when you are at sea, there is so much awesomeness critics of the cartoony character models will forget all about it.

I recommend this game tremendously. PVP must be your thing, but with the amount of encounters I had in my 19ish hours of play, this really feels more like and PVE game, with sporadic PVP thrown into it. So it caters for both types of players.

There is a certain tension when you load loot on your boat, and really have to look out to the horizon for enemy sails. When you spot some, and your boat is loaded, more tension is gained as you race towards the closest outpost to sell your loot, especially if it is a bigger ship than yours. This tension is way less with no PVP so I think it is a great addition to the game as it really isn't overpowering like those famous shooters.

A friend, or more will help with surviving though, as a loner to stay on course, adjusting your sails, fix hull damage and shoot cannons can get frantic at times. Still when you manage to survive, the feeling is awesomesauce!

Edit: The game is plain broken. After a few hours of hauling treasures with my friends it appears that there is some bug that prevents two of us(out of a party of 4) from using our hard earned gold to purchase items. After googling a bit it seems that this bug or glitch or whatever you want to call it has been in the game since 2018. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

The only point of getting money in the game is to buy more skins for your existing gear. There are no upgrades, nothing to unlock, no new features, no better ships or better weapons. Once you finish the tutorial you have every gear you'll get in the whole game.

The m/kb controls are bad. It's the typical early 2000s half-assed PC port type of game.

In game audio is terrible. Zero filter for noise and the audio quality itself is early 90s tier.

PVP is laughably bad. One single death animation. Players respawn(back in to the fight unless you totally sink their ship) after 10 seconds or so after death.

The only redeeming thing is that this game is fun when you have 3 other fun friends to play with. For a time. It gets boring fast as you discover the shallow mechanics behind the game.

This might be a worthwhile game if you're a parent and you want to play some video game with your 8 year olds and 9 year olds. Yeah, I can imagine that specific scenario would make this game fun.

I wish it included the few hundred hours I've sank in on Windows store.

A bit barren of a start has been bolstered by content update after content update to make it a game worth playing. I started on launch day then got bored quickly, then came back for the Forsaken Shores update. Have been playing on and off fairly regularly since.

First off, obviously, the game looks and sounds beautiful, they mastered exactly the feel they were going for.
And they gameplay loop itself, while won't be everyone's cup of tea I find super enjoyable. Every time you boot up you're faced with a choice, "What flavor of yarr do I desire today?"
Digging up chests, smashing some skulls, dueling in pvp, fishing for loot, story quests, or even just going out solely for the purpose of ruining someone else's day. All are valid on the Sea of Thieves.
A full crew off friends, getting up to as much or as little trouble as you'd like, all making new stories to share with your other buddies, thanks to the truly unpredictable nature of the game is where it really shines.

But something I myself like to do? Is load into a solo sloop, put the wind at my back and see where I go. What I'll find, what i'll do. It could be anything.

Sea of Thieves offers from calm to calamity and everything in between, and I'm excited to see where they continue to go.

Holy shit.

Okay, so I wasn't entirely sure whether or not my friends and I would have fun with this game, but we all had the money for it, and a friend who gave it a positive outlook, and had experience. We bought the game, started playing and learning the ropes, and set goals for ourselves on what we need to do.

We took out many a ship over the time. Blew holes into ships. Plundered loot from monsters and players. Dug up mountains of treasures from islands across the sea of thieves. These events and quests we go on (for the sake of fortune, fashion, and glory) are fun escapades with a good feeling of satisfaction after we were done with them.

Today, we went on a voyage like we normally would, deciding to fly a flag that would multiply our rewards from fighting a fort of skeletons. Along the way, we saw a sloop, the smallest of the three ships. We knew that would be easy pickings if they contested us, so we loaded our galleons's cannons, the largest ship of the bunch, and just as we were about to fire we were told to parlay. The two people flew an alliance flag, and offered to help with our journey. 

We all fought together for ages, eventually beating the fort, and fending off a pesky crew of two that attempted to take us down. We fended them off, and escaped with our rewards. As alliances should, we split the rewards and headed back. We truly felt like we were pirates allying to take out a bigger, skeletal threat.

Afterwards, we were chased by the same ship that planned on taking us out. Bit of karma hit them, they got targeted by a Kraken the moment they went to chase us. We also sent a crew member to blow up their ship with a black powder keg. Revenge was sweet.

This experience left us all very happy, and feeling a sense of pride. Eventually we did need to depart from our allies, in which we did so after playing a shanty, all six of us.

This game is truly great in the state it is in now. I'm not sure if its too viable for solo players, but if you8 can get a small group together, and learn the game, I'm certain you'll have a blast. Hopefully not on your ship though. Explosions on the ship aren't good, trust me, I know from experience.

Disclaimer for a Great Game: The single biggest problem with Sea of Thieves is the cost of skins on their premium market, the price of a set of skins for your ship cost around 75% of the price of the game at full retail value, (aprox 30 quid for a full set of cosmetics for your ship) Its ridiculous. That's not to say there are free skins in game you can work towards getting, there are, however for a premium priced game there is ZERO justification for it. Having said that...

Sea of Thieves game play loop is super casual, its immensely satisfying. Just sailing around doing nothing and when you are searching for treasure the balance or threat and puzzles really works great to keep your interest. The interesting part is the PvP, its threatening but avoidable. A ships heading your way, fine, you can see it for miles off. You can bug out try to sail to the nearest port and sell your loot and no loss. Stay and fight, maybe steal their loot. Lure them to an island sneak aboard and maybe steal their loot. sneak on their ship in an ocean battle and chuck their loot overboard. Its great. 

The best part is losing your current loot has little consequence as anything you're handed in at an outpost is safely banked so if you die, fair play, hunt down your killer and make them regret it the next time they try. 

There's new story missions, lost of cosmetics, the game is beautiful. Totally worth the price.

P.S. RARE!!!! LOWER THE PRICE OF PREMIUM SKINS! YOU'LL GET MORE SAILS (HEH)!

This game is great and I definitely recommend it, but I'm going to use this opportunity to gripe about the parts that I don't like in the hopes that they get changed.

There are only a few that I can think of but the worst is winning a fight with a ship/group only to have them chase you across the whole map over and over again because they're salty about being smashed the first time. Your supplies will run low over the course of being harassed while they get a fresh new ship with a bunch of cannonballs etc. Eventually you're going to sink unless they give up.

The only PvE enemy type on land is skeletons which is somewhat boring. I'd like to fight skellies on horses or bears or something, just more than the 4 flavours we have now.

During skelly brawls, keg skellies will pop out the ground right under your feet as you're swinging your sword and they'll nuke you without giving you the chance to react. Most of the time it's just disappointing, but when you're pressed for time because you're grinding forts it's a joke.

Sometimes there will be situations where you're fighting another ship and both ships run out of supplies, so both crews are venting water and no one can end the fight because there are no cannonballs left yet crew will carry on spawning with full HP to fight. In this scenario neither crew can break free from the stalemate and win the fight. Something needs to change because it's stupid.

We have different types of cannonballs including chainshot but I want a shotgun ball to crush skellies and players, like the cannister tank rounds in battlefield 3.

Everyone who gives this game a negative review probably sucks at PvP and gets rolled because they're trash. My group is pretty decent so we have tons of fun pulling up on people and splitting them in half. Git gud or go home.

Something that isn't too annoying but annoying enough is the way you still have to have an xbox live account to play on steam. I hate having to screw around with multiple launchers and the like. Admittedly this game is more or less fine once you link you accounts but it doesn't let you join a game in progress through the steam friends system - someone has to invite you, which makes no sense to me. 

One last thing - the nightshine parrot ship set is awesome, but my group hate the wheel due to  the fact that the centre spoke is too similar to the others. You can't tell where the centre of the wheel is as easily as you can on the others, especially at night. Please make it more obvious.

I've had two main different experiences in this game:

[b]• First, [/b]adventuring by myself. Piloting the sloop is actually pretty simple, so you can do everything you need to take on the PvE quests. Plus, it's surprisingly calming. It's just you, the crashing of the waves, the cries of the seagulls, and the clink of coins. I get lost in the game for hours.

[b]• Second,[/b] adventuring with a crew of my friends. The galleon certainly requires a full crew of four, but it's still manageable. With the four of us, we're more confident engaging in fights, taking longer quests, and generally dicking around. The game isn't any less fun, but it trades serenity for chaos.

My only main complaint is that the maximum crew size is currently four, which is frustrating when I have five friends with the game. There's a system where you can team up with other ships, but that's mainly for finding randoms. There's no way to reliably get two crews of your friends into the same server, which sucks. They need to either make a bigger boat, or add support for fleets.

So, it's fun by yourself, and fun with friends, but don't try and play with more than three other people.

I genuinely wanted to like this game and maybe in time this review will be irrelevant because of changes they make but in it's current state I can't say I do. To be frank I think the design of this game is really bad. A lot of people have mentioned the lack of progression and other factors wrong with this title but rather than that I would like to talk about what happens in sea of thieves if you make the mistake of playing without at least 4 competent players. 

Sea of Thieves rather then be what maybe a lot of people hoped this game would be which is a pirate game where you raid AI ships and compete for loot with other ships like some games have done in the past. You are likely the person getting raided unless you have a crew of 4 which all have a really strong skills towards the game. What baffles me more about all this is that the developers seem to be completely unsure of what to do with this dynamic. 


Getting all resources that you can sell in this game fall into one gameplay loop. First set sail for an island. Then do something on said island that nets you treasure. After that's done return to the port for your reward and repeat. That is the main gameplay loop in it's entirety with one factor omitted. At any point in these steps you can be raided or raid others for loot until the exact moment when the loot is sold to someone. The problem with this is that there is so much risk and time involved in getting these materials that it makes dying in sea of thieves and getting raided a real point of contention if not handled well in the design and this is where I think the game really falls apart. This game relies on player generated raiding and ship to ship fighting to be fun. That means yes big ships that are traveling the islands but also small ships that don't have the firepower and less people that will likely be more trading focused. However what the game does is down right malicious in it's design here. Light ships are actually slower than bigger ships in every case except when facing the wind. Take that in for a moment. That means that small radius of maybe 30 degrees is where your one gun on each side sloop has an advantage and the rest of that 330 degrees is all gravy for the much larger 3 gun on each side galleon stocked with 4 people chasing you. Oh and if you like that sailing against the wind means you have no control over your direction long term for your ship. So if you happen to run into some AI enemies randomly then your just f***ed. This could all be remedied by one simple change. Make the sloop faster, but the devs have had two years to work on this and never considered "hey maybe the smaller ship with less people and less fire power shouldn't be at a disadvantage on the open sea?". This one example kind of defines the entire experience of sea of thieves, it's a 4 player game with an option to play with less people at a penalty. 

If you are alright with that and you have four players to play with who are pretty good at games then ya go for it but if you have one or two friends and just want a fun chill experience riding the waves then play something else. Sea of thieves has a unbalanced hard mode and you just need to reduce your crew to play it.

At time of writing this - I'm 16.2 hours into the game. It's late, I should have gone to sleep hours ago and I played the last five hours straight. I am doing this early because I am so sure that by the time you read this - my gameplay hours will be much much more. This game has me absolutely hooked!

I see a lot of comments and concerns on whether you can play this game solo and fears it may be too hard or not competitive without a crew of online friends. This was a concern of mine coming in which was making me toss up whether to purchase or not. Stoked I made the right choice because every minute I've played so far has been Solo and I'm loving it. I'm able to go at my own pace and do what I want, when I want. I'm not worried about doing quests/voyages for my teammates and staying on longer so they can finish whatever. The people I have interacted with so far have been mostly very friendly so I'm sure I would have no problem finding a party online to team up but at the moment I'm happy! You do NOT need a crew to enjoy and do well in this game!

I think the coolest thing about this game is that each time you start the game. Whether you've put in 1 hour or 10,000 hours - you are starting over with the same kit as everyone else. The only difference is the custom skins to show off but they are purely cosmetic. It's crazy to me that when I log in now, even though I am still very new, that I am in the same position I was, same gear, same boat, same everything but now that I have that experience and have learnt the ropes, it's a whole new game.
When you log on for the first time, the stuff you start with is the same stuff the guy with 20,000 hours starts with. It is about your skill and experience but more than anything, how YOU want to play the game.

The game doesn't hold your hand and tell you that you have to go here or you MUST do X quest. You are completely free to explore and do whatever you want, so much more than the standard Open World games. It can be a bit daunting at first but you come to appreciate it so much. 

This game is a MASTERPIECE.
Visuals are fantastic and unique, the soundtrack is wonderful and fun. The story and pacing are unlike anything I've played.
10/10

Having played this games for a few hours now, I can only say: "Hands off, maybe buy it if it´s on a 75% sale!" Whereas the graphics and overall Atmosphere in the game are gorgeous to look at, controlling the ships feels quite immersive, the game loop itself is absolutely barebones, exploration is absolutely unrewarding since there are only about 20 different items to find, there are no levels, ugrades for gear, ships or whatsoever. All you can achieve in this game is gold (mostly through finding one of the..maybe 10 treasure items) which you can invest in cosmetics, that´s it. Yes, all you can play this game for is  cosmetics. 


Then there is PVP. In case you dont have a premade crew of 4-5 people so you can take advantage of sailing with the biggest ship, I would`nt even try engaging in any ship battle. With a small crew and ship, you will get sunk within a few seconds in naval battles, infiltrated by teleporting hackers (randomly appearing on your ship out of nowhere, not taking any damage) or pounded in land battles. So if you´re masochistic and simply love, getting teabagged by filthy PvP enthusiasts in big premade groups, this is totally for you nontheless. The community as far as i could experience it in adventure mode and arena is absolutely toxic, blasting loud music over the ingame voicechat or spouting insults, showered with racial slur.

It´s really sad to find out that this game, albeit having an intriguing premise, is a huge letdown and a waste of time.

Bought this game almost 2 years ago, this game is a limitless playground for you and your crew to play around. Tons of treasures to find without even doing quests, a lot of PvP and fights against enemy NPC across the whole sea of thieves map. This game will take you away for couple of hours when you play it, because it has so much that you can do while having fun at the same time. Over the years they changed the game a lot and the amount the content that has been added is really amazing.
Even if you are new to the game or not a fan of PvP you can team up with the enemy pirates and make an alliance so everyone gets gold together. The journey to becoming a Pirate Legend is going to be filled with new challenges and lots of fun finding treasures and interacting with everyone in the seas. This is one of the greatest games that i have ever played so i definitely recommend everyone to try it out, you wont regret it :).

This game is so much fun! 5 stars! The water mechanics are the best i've ever seen in a game. Sailing the seas is so realistic. It's flawless and a blast. Matchmaking with others works great. I've met people from all over the world and every adventure has been a unique experience and adventure. I just wish more people played with a microphone as this makes the adventure so much better. 

The variation of quests and things you can do in this game is perfect. I love finding rare items and chests on an island, like a message in a bottle that leads to a quest, etc. The sense of exploration is perfectly executed. I love trying to track down the treasure with maps, and the riddle quests are equally fun to try to figure out. Of course, the sense of danger is always there as there are always going to be some toxic idiots in games like this, but from my 30 hours experience it's rare. I've met more helpful and friendly people than those trying to pawn you. AND if someone were to attack and sink your ship. all you loose is the treasure you haven't turned in yet. So it's not the end of the world! It honestly wouldn't be fun if there were no sense of danger in this game. It really makes this game awesome! So you can't loose your ship or anything you have unlocked. The islands are also all so unique and after 30 hours i still haven't gotten the "I've been here before feeling" or i've done that exact quest before. It has not felt grindy in other words. They have thought this out very well. 

This is a MUST buy game if you like open world, especially survival games, adventures, pirate games, exploration or just want to try something completely unique and original.

Sea of Thieves is a breath of fresh air.... ummm i mean sea air... OH and be warned.. you might get a little sea sick at first, especially if you are sailing through a storm. The game can be that realistic!  Oh did i mention the ship battles are epic and SO much fun! 

Now off to my next epic adventure!

P.S. CAN YOU PLAY SOLO?? Yes you can play this game solo, and sometimes I like to just grab a Slooth (the smallest ship) and just cruise around and see what I can do by myself. But there are definitely HUGE pluses to join with others. You can earn money faster this way, as you all share the loot 100%. And of course there is safety in numbers. It's also ALOT of fun to work together sailing a ship, you get one guy on the helm, another on the sails, and another watching the horizon for any loot or threats. If you don't have any friends that play like me don't worry.. There is a MATCHMAKING system in place so you can easily join up with others and have a crew. Okay now i'm official off to adventure!
7.8/10 - Too Much Water

Sea of Thieves is a fantastic sailing, treasure-hunting, cannon-blasting, chanty-singing simulator. You do occasionally get picked on by jerks doing PVP or get the misfortune of having a shark, kraken and ghost pirates attacking you all at the same time, but most of the time this game is quite fun. I recommend watching a stream of it first to see if it is for you, but I think it is one of the best co-op games I've played. I would not really recommend playing solo, as a lot of the fun comes from the mistakes you and your friends will make.

I know the review time seems very small, but I have been playing this game for two years, since beta, and I've had over 1000 hours in the game. This is a masterpiece of a game, the graphics are amazing especially the water. The music is severely underrated. The combat system is fun, but some people have issues with it. More changes are on the way to it however. People complain about it seeming too grindy. That's a stupid mindset, if you just focus on getting to Pirate Legend, you'll never have any fun. As I've already said, I've had 1000+ hours in the game, and I'm not Pirate Legend. I'm serious. I've just been having fun, not caring about the loot. There is also a deep and exteremly interesting lore, but most people don't even notice it. There's tall tales, there's multiple kinda of battles with more on the way, and it's just plain out worth it to buy. I would recommend finding a crew on discord, using open crew, or watching videos and streams on the game. It will help a lot and SoT is better with friends and other players.

I want to give a positive review, but I can’t. The graphics are great, the gameplay is fun, and the atmosphere is excellent, but the matchmaking is terrible and the people who play are generally repugnant.  The other main problem is that there is no progression or customization of your character whatsoever (except for clothing).  A lot of these issues could be easily fixed, but it’s clear the developer just doesn’t want to.  Ultimately, Sea of Thieves is a wasted opportunity to make a truly great game.

Oh wow, do I have a review for you.

I've been waiting for this game to come out on steam ever since I first saw it. Since I'm exclusively a PC gamer, I couldn't play it before hand, but I was still really excited for the first really good looking nautical game I've seen in a long while. Boy oh boy was I in for the hoax of the year.

First warning sign I had was that my headphones wouldn't work with the game. I have a pair of pretty nice, bluetooth headphones, because who likes getting all tangled up in cables when you're gaming, right? Well, the game took one look at those and said, "Nah, let's just give you no noise at all." I had to switch over to some old plug in earbuds to hear anything. So, strike one.

And then there's the game itself. I'm playing solo, which I know probably makes it even more difficult, but there's no tutorial. There's not even a hint of a tutorial. Hell, I couldn't figure out how to get out of a dialogue loop with one character, where I kept desperately keyboard smashing to try to get out of it. So, I fumbled my way through a few shops, because I had no idea what else I was supposed to do, then got to my ship, and proceeded to spend the next fifteen minutes trying to steer and lower and raise the sails only to realize that there was an anchor I didn't know about because, oh yeah, the game never told me it even existed. I finally made my way to an island, crashed, got stuck, couldn't turn around or back up, and gave up with this disaster of a game. 

I'm going to be looking into getting a refund, just for how much of an utter scam this is. I don't know if it's the PC version that's a load of garbage, or if that's just the game itself, but it's a waste of time. If a game isn't immediately obvious how to play, developers should always include an optional tutorial.

Anyways. Please, please don't make the same mistake I did by buying this terrible game. I know it looks pretty, but the actual quality of the experience of playing it is one of the worst I've ever experienced.

I have well over 150 hours total played and I love this game. It's definitely more fun with friends. There are a couple bugs within the game;

1. The Steam version locks the compass on the ship to North. It doesn't move.
2. If you have an RTX GPU, you'll occasionally see the grid lines from the map on the water itself. Rare is aware.

Overall, this game is amazing. It's a sandbox game with friends where you make the adventure. Want to just sail around and fish? Go ahead. Do you want to seek treasure for 10 hours? Go ahead. You want to hunt down other ships and steal all their chest and valuables? Go ahead.

Rare continues to unload free updates every couple months and is very good about feedback from players. 

During PvP, most people that I have encountered are all friendly and we all have a good laugh.

It is worth the money and I bought it twice. 

BUT, if you buy it from the Microsoft Store right now it's only $20.

Played this game solo for 8 hours now and having a blast so far! The sailing and sea mechanics are an absolute joy - it's easy to learn, but difficult to master. Love the treasure seeking, shipwreck diving, fighting, etc. Ran into other players a couple of times. Once someone sailed my ship away from the harbor where I was docked, but as I had no treasure onboard, no big deal. I just respawned somewhere else. Most of my treasure hunting I have been left alone. Or at least by other players, as there are skeleton ships and huge sharks for example. 

I am sure some of the late content is going to be difficult solo, but so far, so good. Immensely enjoyable and extremely polished. And there is no character progression, just vanity items you can buy with the gold you can find by selling treasure. This is awesome!

Edit 10-6-2020:
Example of some the great emergent gameplay and Pirates of the Carribean like scenes:

- Being a cowardly pirate, the first encounter I won against another player, was when I picked on a ship anchored in front of an island.
- I peppered the ship with my cannons and fire bombs. It's owner came running from the beach, cursing. But alas, his ship had already sunk.
- As I was sailing away I saw chests and riches glistening in the water. The former captain desperately gathering his treasures from the wreckage into a rowing boat.
- I turn my ship around and I start firing on the rowing boat. I get a hit in and the enemy gets knocked into the water. I quickly anchor my ship and see him swimming towards me. He boards my ship, we exchange a few shots and he gets knocked into the water again. I jump in after him and kill him with my saber.
- Now, taking a look at his rowing boat, I see it's filled with plunder. This is when I get really excited. Greedy and also afraid other pirates will show up, I start a mad dash to bring all the chests on my ship. There is just too much plunder, so halfway there I decide to dock the rowing boat to my ship. I set sail to the nearest harbor, to sell my newly acquired riches.
- Halfway towards the relative safety of the harbor, the sea below me darkens and a Kraken appears. Starting to panic, as this is my first encounter with the beast, I quickly lower my rowboat and jump aboard. Just in time to see my ship being torn apart, sinking and taking a good part of my new found stash into the waves. Had I not taken the rowboat with me, my life would have ended right there.
- The rowboat still has at least half the loot, so I start to frantically row away. However, one of the tenctacles of the Kraken grabs me and somehow I grab one of the treasure chests as I get lifed from the boat. I can't slash at the tentacle with the chest in my hands, so I have to drop a chest full of treasures into the sea. A real noteworthy moment, as I didn't want to let go of my precious gold, but my life was more dear to me in the end.
- I get the tentacle to drop me, I quickly swim to my rowboat, glistening treasures floating around me everywhere. Ignoring the chests, I jump in my boat and I manage to row away. 
- Once in the harbor it takes me a couple of minutes to unload all the chests and sell the contents, many gems, goblets and other trinkets, so great was this stash. Once finished the beach near the boat is littered with open, discarded chests. 
- Amazing gameplay for me, though the captain I robbed will likely think differently...

I can already tell this is a game I will spend too many hours on I think it's a great purchase but you have to have friends or other people to play with if you want to experience the game as intended. I've had a blast playing it so far but despite the large amount of content already in the game I feel its lacking somewhat in areas. I know the game is constantly being developed and having new expansions but these are my thoughts on what I think would be great to see as additions, like;

A gambling system like poker, blackjack, or a pirates of the caribbean classic liars dice

A event or "boss" that would force players to have to work together to fulfill it not like the fort of the damned but another ship based boss featuring a Man o War or something of the like that is incredibly difficult

More customization of the ship, I love that you have premade models the sloop, brig, and galleon. but I feel like they should be more customizable so each ship is unique and gives more of a personal feel to them this would be incorporated by simply making the captains cabin or other aspects of the ship open for customization such as barrel, lantern, chests and other items that can be kept.

I also love the attention to detail this game has but another addition that would definitely be difficult to do but I think everyone would love to have is an ocean expansion that similar to sunken ships is available with scuba diving gear or something of the like which would unlock the exploration of the ocean floor.

Also as I have written previously I like the three ship system but I feel like in order to counter certain aspects of ships as well as more versatility we should keep the system but add a subsystem that give three different variants of each ship, one for offense, one for defense, and one for speed and storage capacity. Of course the details would have to be tested and tried but I feel like it would change the game for the better. 

These are just a few ideas for the development of the game I think its great so far and I am really looking forward to playing it more.

Nice seafaring experience, with tide, wave and storm. Might be much better if you can actually create your character instead of randomizing them(you need to keep randomize until you got what you want), and lack of sea creatures variant(as of now I only saw shark, which is few and far between).

There's a choice of 2 weapons to fit your playstyle including a blunderbuss, sniper rifle, flintlock, and of course a cutlass. Very interesting game so far and I can't wait to see what the rest of the game has to offer.

This is a great game, I was very excited when it came out for Steam because I didn't want to deal with Xbox's shitty Microsoft app. That being said, I've noticed there have been some bugs in the Steam version that I didn't experience in the xbox app but it also literally just came to Steam 6 days ago so I imagine some of the bugs will be worked out.  

Bug 1
The issue I'm specifically experiencing is that the ship compass is stuck to North.  Regular compass in my inventory still works so it's more of a mild frustration than a colossal deal breaker. This reddit post seems to indicate that this is primarily an issue for AMD processors, as Intel processors don't seem to experience this issue (I of course have AMD)

https://www.reddit.com/r/Seaofthieves/comments/gwj9ih/searching_the_seas_compass_stuck_on_north/

Bug 2
This was an issue that also existed in the xbox app, sometimes the game won't send invitations, or let me invite people. In the xbox app I could join a session in progress, but I don't seem to have that option in Steam. (For the record, I'm aware you can join games in steam, I'm able to join games for any other game on steam except for SoT).  

That being said, I would say I've had a lot more fun in this game than not. I've just started playing recently, but a lot of my friends confirm that there have been a lot of great changes since the game first came out. 

Really my biggest issue with this game is that I find myself in situations where either all of my friends want to play with me (i.e. two crews of 3 looking for a 4th) or no one wants to, or is able to play (really wouldn't recommend playing solo in this game).  I haven't checked out the Sea of Thieves discord server myself, but I hear it's pretty popping, and a reliable way to find more people to play with than the game's matchmaking system. 

Game would be a lot cooler if you could load two ships in, or if they just increased the player cap to 5 or 6 on Galleon (largest ship).   Anyway, I like this game, but it might not be for everyone.

This is easily one of the most immersive, satisfying and terrifying games I have ever played, and I have loved every single moment of it.

Sea of Thieves is a always online PVP Pirate Simulator, and is brutal for new players because of this, seriously this game only tells you the bare bone basics, as for the rest, you need to figure out yourself, and since it's online, running into hostile players is common.

[b] Pros [/b]

The game looks amazing, I love the water and lighting.

It runs on older PCs quite well, while I'm not sure how good mine specs is, it doesn't run most modern games well like Doom without cutting into the graphics big time, however I've had very few performance issues with this game and when I did, just turning the graphics down slightly fixed it.

The physics of the ship bouncing in the water adds some awesome challenge when it comes to sailing and ship combat.

The sound effects for the weapons and enemies are amazing.

Everything you do is satisfying, from shooting, digging up treasure, sailing, setting up the mast, lowering/raising the anchor, everything I do brings a big smile to my face.

Has Rare's classic sense of humour, including their writing for characters, and stuff you can do, like launching yourself out of cannons.

Also has multiple references to Rare's classic games (please add them to steam, I love Rare so much)

Indepth customisation, from your pirate, to your ship, equipment and pet, seriously there's a lot of stuff to make your pirate the way you want!

You can play music, and when other players join, the instruments sync up to make some Sea Shanty Fun for everyone!

[b] Neutral [/b]

Since it's always online, regardless of who you are, you're gonna run into other players, they will either ignore you, maybe try to be friends, or worse attack you, it's hard to tell what's going on since the best way is via a flag which is ontop of the crow's nest, but even then it might be a trap.
Single players are gonna be hit hard the most with this, since having an actual crew gives you a huge advantage in fights.

The game tells you next to nothing about the game, I like it since it encourages experimentation to see what works in this game, but at the same time, I couldn't do quests for my first 3 hours, as I had 0 clue on how to activate them (but the way you do it is kinda cool, go to the Captain's Quarters, and you can start a vote on what quest to do.)

It has crossplay, meaning you'll run into Xbox and Microsoft Store players who have had a lot more playtime then you, I've seen them help other players like myself, raid other players like myself, and having their mic always on with every single thing in the background going on while talking to you... which happened to me... seriously Xbox players stop it, I don't want to ask you to say what you said over and over again, just because you have a hoover and washing machine turned on next to you.

When you die in single player, or when your ship sinks with your crew, or if you disconnect, you lose all items not tied to your account (Account stuff being Cosmetics, currency, pets etc, while the stuff you lose is like Wood, Treasure, Cannonballs, Food etc, so you'll start fresh everytime you login, I like this, but at the sametime I do wish you can store more cannonballs and food so you can go do a mission straight away, but I can imagine people hoarding them and unleashing hell on other players can be a major issue.

[b] Cons [/b]

While the game does say it needs Windows 10 to be played, many games have this too, and can be played by older OS, but this game NEEDS Windows 10, I had to upgrade from 8.1 to 10 to play this game (Worth it imo) but it needs to be more clear since Steam has many types of OS's running it.

I've seen some bugs relating to ships, I had one where mine got dragged underwater for no reason and it respawned at the outpost I was at not too long before, I've also seen others bounce away from docks too, but these are rare.

I had a few crashes relating to my video driver, I lowered the graphics a bit, still crashed, finally manged to update them, and so far no crashes and I hope it stays like that, losing all your items because of 1 crash is very unfair.

The game doesn't have traditional progression, the tools you start of with, are the same ones you keep till the end game, the only real progression are cosmetics you buy via gold, but there's enough items to keep you happy for a very long time.

[b] Overall [/b]

A very fun and challenging game, while I suck at this game, I've been loving every moment of it.

Definitely the best pirate game out there. This game is super fun and satisfying to play. Just sailing the sea feels incredible. There are plenty of voyages to complete and islands to explore. Also, multiple people sail in the same sea, so you will run into other player ships, and you'll have to decide to attack, make peace, or flee.  There are also fortresses to attack for major rewards. Though, there is a huge high risk high reward factor for this game. Even if you just got a major score, don't get comfy until you've sold all of it. While sailing you can get attacked by sea monsters or other players, or someone might loot your ship while you're selling everything. This is what makes the game so thrilling. My only big problem with the game is that I can't recommend it to people who have no people to play with. You can sail with randos, but it's rare to get a solid crew. If you got at least 2 people to play with, I think it's worth the $40. If no, I'd hold off for a sale. The game is still fun on your own or with just one other person, but it is just not nearly as fun as having a 3 or 4 man crew.

So, I’ve wanted another good pirate game since Sid Miers pirates back in the early 2000s. This game is definitly what I have been waiting for. It’s fun. I actually feel like a real pirate. The ships handle like I imagine a real ship would. You have to manipulate the sails, rigging, anchor, guns, wheel, crows nest, etc. It really feels like I’m on a ship.  I recommend this game obvisouly, but there are a few disclaimers and suggestions I’d like to mention to potential readers and hopefully the developers.

Disclaimers: There isn’t much actual progression. Aside from earning domestics. You’re still EXACTLY the same on hour 1000 as you are on hour 1. Literally. No exaggeration.
Also playing solo is much more limited in enjoyment. Having a crew of 3+ is where the game gets god teir.

Suggestions to developers: 
1) Add more ships one I could think of would be an up to 6 person ship called “Ship of the line” (I’m shameless taking ideas from Sid miers pirates here. But the other ships you have are in that game as well)
2) Add more permanace to the ships. What I mean by this is loot should be able to be carried between sessions at least. I know that this would raise the possible abuse of players logging out when they are gona lose a ship battle. Easy fix. The players have to have the ship anchored at port and not in combat to be able to log out safely,  This would make it feel like I’m at least working towards something instead of my ship resetting every time i log off. Also I saw someone raise the valid concern on whose ship out of the crew would get the loot? Again easy. Make a new type of que as captain so that you can associate all the loot with them. Players could still have the option to join ships in open parties or captain them in open parties. But I see this benefit primarily to me and other closed party players.
3) More guns and maybe fun upgrades. Again it kinda sucks that I haven’t gained anything with my playtime. I’m still the same aside from a cooler sail and flag. Maybe add different types of cannons and guns that can be upgraded to. For example on cannons we could have 8 pounders base, but maybe were allowed to upgrade to 16, 32 pounders or a howitzer mortar. 
4) The world feels a bit empty. Perhaps have some more AI pirates around, or better yet. Have AI merchant ships you can  engage with to board or sink to take some loot.
5) The grappling hook sucks. It doesn’t make it easier to dock and it sure doesn’t make it easy to board. Make the grappling hook stuck on the object it hits until the crew reals it back in or it is wackes off with a sword. Idk many be 5-10 hits or something. I’d like to have boarding fights too. Also make it actually reel yourself closer to what you’ve hooked. Enemy or dock,
6) Were getting into smaller suggestions now, but maybe have like paintings and loot that can be hung on walls (or sold) if you make customization of inside ships more doable. Also maybe make the barrels and tables and stuff inside the ship moveable. I know some things are where they are for balance, but some free range on my ships would make it feel more mine.

Thanks for your time and thanks for a great game.

Edit 2 (12 hours in):

TL/DR: Stay FAR AWAY if LeEtmINMaxpLAYErkILLeR style is not for you!

Unfortunately this game still lacks the most basic explanations, tutorial, quality of live functions and multiplayer balancing.
Game: "Get sunk too frequently? You can wobble yer snoffle!" Me: "Yes, I am! How?" Game: NIL
Want to learn at least the basic functions by yerself? Haha, nope! Everyone and everything kills you (PvP and PvE) if yer alone. There is no ship that's good to handle alone.
Once you reached the first few levels with a faction the tasks clearly and only are optimized for multi player with no option to get back and do some more carebear ones.
Hell and bad weather, I got constantly sunk by environment and NPCs trying to deliver some of the most basic cooked fish to the hunters call!
See something shiny blinking on the shore of a smol beach on a very smol island? Do never ever go there! Chances are there's a skellie captain ganking you and one time I reached the shiny, it blinked red and the world detonated! Explanation what that was? Zilch.
Get ready to Alt-Tab to your browser constantly to look up the most basic mechanics of this game. And even without that it takes a looong time to get to even the slightest sliver of progress with a 90% chance that you get killed or your ship sunk before you can turn it in.
Ah yis, and of course noone wants to play with beginners anymore :D if your lucky ppl are letting you follow and help a bit but be ready to never be able to experience the game as an enjoyable progression.
Did I mention that the devs didn't get around to character growth of any kind? No chance to better your char by grinding and taking on the hard missions after you outgrew the non existent multiplayer balancing.
Seems like the devs ran out of cash and just decided "Heck this, we're declaring it 'pure multiplayer' and see what happens." Newsflash, the casual and relaxed player demographic is far bigger and has far more disposable income!
Remember kids: If you don't have a good foundation it doesn't help to build more and more on top. Who'da've guessed!

I am just a few hours into this game, but I've already gotten my money's worth. I had a high seas adventure with a friend that involved: an act of destructive piracy, exploring a sunken ship, retrieving a hoard of loot with a cursed chest, getting randomly attacked by a sea monster which we narrowly escaped, weathering a severe storm while another group of pirates pursued us (but we played the wind better). Upon turning in our loot my compatriot was struck by lightning but lived to tell the tale, we proceeded to find a safer harbor where we could get ripping drunk on fine ale. 

Here's the thing, none of that was scripted. It all just happened organically. The devs here have created a game that is just plain fun and have given players a lot of options for how to find their own flavor of fun. Even just sailing a ship around is enjoyable because you have to mess with the sail, pay attention to the wind, navigate, and steer the ship. One person can handle a small ship, but two makes it an absolute treat. 

Oh, we played music while we sailed into battle, I was on the bow with a banjo. It's just a great game.
