Refill your tankard of grog and have a seat by the hearth.  Me hearties, do I have a story for you.

I found myself crewing a galleon with some friends of dubious skill.  We were bumbling our way around the islands, digging up long-lost treasure chests.  Having sold our booty for a tidy sum, we spotted a player brigantine in the distance.  Deciding to raise the Jolly Roger, we set a course to catch them.

Suddenly, on the port side, a skeletal ship rose from Davey Jones' locker and began to attack us.  Our prey had meanwhile fallen victim to the kraken!  We fought valiantly, and one of us boarded our skeletal foes, but I was blown clear off the deck by a rogue cannonball.  By the time I was able to swim back, our ship had succumbed to her wounds and sank.  With me and two of my shipmates in the rowboat, we did all we could do; we rowed into the kraken attack!

Between the tentacles we sailed and climbed aboard that brigantine.  We manned their cannons and patched their hull, one by one of us being picked off.  We sliced a tentacle that had wrapped itself around the ship clean off, and when the dust settled and the kraken slain, only I stood of my original group, along with the new crew. 

Taking a short rest, we were beset upon by more skeletal ships!  Running low on ammunition, a brave soul boarded the enemy vessel with a barrel of gunpowder.  Determined to find some firebombs to set their ship alight, I jumped between our ships and was blown clear of the melee, out to sea.  I was never going to catch either vessel, so I floated alone and contemplated my fate until I was rescued by a fair mermaid.

Having finished up some more treasure hunting, we decided to call it a night.  One of us left the ship early, leaving three of us to crew the galleon.  We made our way to the nearest outpost, and managed to skillfully sink some NPCs along the way.  While cleaning up the last bit of loot, I hear a voice in the water... "I don't think they see me yet."  "Is this a good idea?  You saw what they did to that other ship."

Our first uninvited guest was greeted with my blunderbuss to his face.  His friend in their tiny sloop pushed off from the outpost and headed our way.  What followed was a 90 minute knife fight.  Outmaneuvered and outgunned because we were low on cannonballs, I rammed the galleon into the outpost and dropped anchor.

Screaming for my crewmates to grab out loot and sell it, my wife and I held our attackers at bay and took turns boarding each other's ships.  We were all killed many times.  Finally, all the loot secured, the raging fires were too much and our galleon sunk to the bottom.  From the water, I pulled out my bullhorn and shouted "joke's on you, we already sold all the loot!"

What I heard back was "that's ok, we were bored anyway" in 12 year old squeaker.  All I wanted to do was sell my loot and go to bed, dammit, and now it's after midnight.

I have played this game A LOT on the Microsoft store version.

This has to be quite possibly one of the most underrated games out there. It never got the love it deserved on release and I feel like if it would have come to steam on release it would be so much more popular than it is. A lot of the negativity aimed at this game boils down to two things:

1) No real progression
People often complain about how there is no true progression. The progression in this game is purely cosmetic and for the sense of accomplishment for the things you achieve like attaining "Pirate Legend" status. I feel like the game is fun enough to look past the fact you can't upgrade your ship or weapons; farming for a really cool skin for  your boat or weapon and putting it on is the way I see the "upgrade" side of things.

2) PvP
People claim the Arena game-mode is trash to which I have to agree; the mode basically pits numerous ships in a closed off area of the map to fight it out for 15 minutes and whoever has the most score at the end wins. It sounds fun but in the majority of the games there are AFK ships and leavers which means it's only a couple of ships actually playing the game which is not what was intended. The PvP in Adventure mode (which is the games main mode) can suck [at times] for both PvP & PvE players. There are a few reasons for this; one of them is that the map is so big and the server has limited ship slots that sometimes the PvP players have a really hard time finding anybody and when they do, they usually flee forever until the PvP'er eventually gives up. PvE players complain about playing in a sloop (1-2 player ship) on their own and getting ganked and sunk by a team of 4 in a galleon (1-4 player ship). People seem to forget that this is a PIRATE game and pirates STOLE from other ships. I see noobs crying for there to be PvE only servers but this defeats the entire purpose; PvP players need PvE players to exist so they have people to rob from and get their enjoyment out of the game. The game would absolutely stink if you didn't have to worry about a gang of pirates rocking up and stealing your hard earned loot.

Graphics are a bit arcade/cartoony but still incredible. The graphics of the water stuns everybody who looks at them and I would argue they are the best in any game I've played.

Before we get on with the review and my thoughts on this game, I should inform the reader (you) that there are some things that you need to know before setting sail for your pirate adventure on the Sea of Thieves;

First and foremost, I've owned the Microsoft Store version of this game for about a year or so with a frustrating curse, in which I could not actually play the game on my computer due to the Microsoft Store parameters being so fidgety (go figure), but I have logged some hours on the Xbox and only a couple when miraculously it would run for an hour or two on my computer... only like 2 times. I've had previous experience with this game and it's quirks, and now that it's on Steam all seems to be well and enjoyable at last.

Second, both Adventure & Arena game modes are open PVP only, meaning you can chose to engage other player crews if you want to, but that being said you will DEFINITELY encounter griefers who are out for more than just gold and doubloons... their after your utmost sour of salt.

Third and lastly, You can take treasure from other players with the repercussions of them defending their haul, however there are lots of treasure chests and other booty to be found lying around on islands or floating wreckage out at sea... be careful who you chose to attack.

Now, onto the review portion.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

When Rare announced Sea of Thieves back in 2015-2016 (can't exactly remember when) I had a VERY high hype vs. standard margin, So many Pirate oriented games have been attempted with varying amounts of success and notoriety; everything from Assassin's Creed 4: Black Flag to Blackwake have seen some success and have made good on the promise of a pirating experience, so I had my hopes up in this being the next big Pirate video game since even the days of The Secret of Monkey Island... it didn't disappoint. Sea Of Thieves is a wonderfully crafted and stylized open-world pirating adventure experience that puts you in the sea water drenched boots of your very own pirate character, with no backstory or big arcing plot, to freely sail the seas and search for treasure on your own, or with a crew of up to 4 people! (officially, you can still get with more players and form even bigger raiding parties with party chat on Discord or whatever)

The setting and backdrop for this adventure is set in a hand made ocean called, you guessed it, The Sea of thieves. All the islands you come across are handcrafted and unique from one another, no two islands will ever be the same in the map layout. But beware on your journeys, for there be sea monsters lying in wait for a ship to sail past for a nice snack; The Kraken & Megalodon make appearances from time to time and can deal a might blow to even the most best laid plans of any pirate captain. You can take control of one of three unique ships; The Sloop, The Brig, and the Galleon, depending on your multiplayer preferences and the size of your crew.

The aesthetic and Graphic presentation of this game are B-E-A-Utiful, The most eye catching aspect is the water effects and how surreal-yet-realistic they made the water with those shaders. The semi-cartoon look and feel of the game give it a unique character all of it's own, with gorgeous shades of color from the greens of the palm leaves to the tans and browns of the sands to the deep blues of the sky & sea. All aesthetic parts of this game bring together a mosaic of eye candy and glorious immersion into a hand-crafted world. Dynamic weather also plays a role in the aesthetic and sailing mechanics of Sea Of Thieves, with ravenous thunderstorms swallowing up your ship and flooding below deck as well as sending you off course and disabling your ship's compass. And let's not forget Franklin's worst enemy besides tyranny... LIGHTNING, hitting the main mast will set the ship a blaze!

Combat is a pretty standard thing when it comes to the game's player conflict, a sword and a small assortment of firearms are available to use but only so satisfying every once in a while. Swordplay is a simple 3 swing n' slash combo that can be blocked up until the final blow that breaks the block of the defending party, holding down the attack button (the left mouse button) will charge an attack for about 2.5 seconds and lunge forwards towards wherever the player is aiming, this can come in handy for dashing into water and escaping a losing fight or braking someone's defense in a sword fight. Guns, such as the Flintlock pistol, come with a woeful 5 shot capacity that must be refilled via the ammo box located on your ship or scattered on  islands, make every shot count! the other firearms are the Blunderbuss, a pirates favorite scattergun, and the Eye Of Reach, a pirate crafted musket rifle with a cracked scope for farther targets. All of these weapons have their disadvantages and unique perks that allow them to be used in certain situations, the pistol is probably the best to keep on hand when exploring alone or while scouting ahead of your crew.

The ship controls are designed to be as realistic as possible, while still allowing an arcade-like ease of use to better the sailing experience. To start off, lower the main sail, turn the helm (the steering wheel on a ship) to the direction you want to head in, and finally weigh the anchor (pull it up). Once you've started off, head back to your wheel and get to open waters. Now once your clear of hitting anything and feel the coast is clear of other pirates, head below deck and read over the map to see where you are and what you want to do. The game uses with basics of learning realistic skills, such as map reading, compass orientation, sail adjustment for maximum efficiency and predictive maneuvering and steering.

When it comes to the gameplay between players, that's where things can really heat up. Most players in Sea of Thieves tend to stick to themselves and avoid unwanted attention... there are, however, those that wish to plunder the hard working privateers that seek treasure solely from maps and riddles (it is a pirating game, after all). You can chose however you like to engage or flee fro other players, be social or be destructive... there's no limitations to how you handle the interactions. As for a more competitive gameplay atmosphere, the Arena is where you should look; A frenzied dash to gather treasure from different locations before the other teams/crews can amass a fortune greater than yours.

Of all the features mentioned so far, there is one feature that I, as well as many others, are really happy to see missing in this particular experience... No Pay-2-Win micro-transactions to be found! The only micro-transactions that are available are strictly cosmetics for your pirate, your equipment and your ship, that's it. everyone starts off with the same equipment and with a ship without any difference in level, experience, weapon variation or difference in damage tables. 

Perfectly balanced, as all things should be.

there are some small nit-picks I would like to add just for the sake of a fair review and not a gushing piece about how much I think this game is awesome;

-The servers on steam are brand new and slightly laggy (though it might also be my internet being faulty for the past week or so).

-The respawn system for the entire game takes about 2 seconds too long.

-The Blunderbuss (mentioned earlier) has woeful range and doesn't do as much damage as you would expect unless you've softened your target first.

-Swordplay is too simplified and gets boring or even frustrating if you are not looking DIRECTLY at the target.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Above all, I would recommend this game a thousand times over just for the world and open-ended experience Rare have crafted for players.

Fisherman/Fisherpirate? Awesome!
Lazy SoB that eats all the bananas? Check!

Get the game, it's horribly cheap for what you actually get!

It all started with the error code lavenderbeard i curse the day i set eyes on him, he was the worst person i ever met. he killed me and my friend at a dock while yelling "I'm gonna clap those cheeks". And clap our cheeks he did, well mine anyway. You see he stole my .pak file, the man corrupted and gave it back to me. I knew something was up the moment he showed his ugly mug. Alas i called upon the proper authorities, IT people they call themselves. But it was all for nought, they gave me a riddle about port forwarding and UpNps and Nat types. i was able to deduce what the meaning was however i was unable to fix this issue. My .pak file has been fixed however as i have tossed it overboard as the junk it was and happened upon a new one. Alas the dreaded Lavenderbeard still plagues me to this day. I hope neither i nor you run into him or his galleon ever again. 

My tale continues: Lavenderbeard has been struck down, i had disguised myself as one of his crew members and hit him over the head with a soggy fish. I can finally sail upon the Sea of Thieves and claim my treasures.

Thank you for listening to this old fools tale of woe. For i am nought to sale the Sea of Thieves again until this Lavenderbeard is gone.

*If you get the Lavenderbeard issue try logging off and logging back in on the main menu*

Sea Of Thieves is a ton of fun when you first start out, it looks amazing, sailing the ship and getting into sea fights is great, and the quests are a lot of fun taking you from island to island seeing all the different island designs. But it gets super stale super fast. There's no depth whatsoever, what you see within the first 4 or 5 hours is what you get. It feels like its a refined beta version of a game. There's no character customization apart from cosmetic clothes that are all recolors of already existing sets. The ship designs are all super bland recolors. This game is definitely amazing for what it is and is a bunch of fun to play with friends or other people but every game is so it staying alive based off that alone doesn't give it much to stand on. Servers are very limited with numbers of ship so pvp is pretty rare and you often end up fighting the same ship over and over. Bounties (quests) start to feel like more of a chore than a fun experience and the rate at which you earn gold verse how much the in game cosmetics cost is super unbalanced. The story is fun for the first quest and then every quest after is a rinse and repeat. There's a lot of potential in this game and it's a beautiful concept I wish there were more like it. But the ocean is shallow and the adventure is short. 2.5-3 out of 5. Don't really recommend it.
Def a fun game to play even if you are solo but would recommend bringing a few friends..

The game is incredibly basic. I wanted to like this game but there is really nothing interesting to do. There is absolutely no progression. You have 4 weapons to choose from and the only thing you can do to them is reskin them. The biggest ship in the game is pretty small and once you get to it there's not much reason to use any other ship. The AI enemies alternate between being absolute jokes due to their inability to run you down, or god tier snipers who will kill you from a mile away and theres nothing you can do about it. But dont worry. The cosmetic store lets you purchase with real money and its totally up and running. Maybe it will be worth buying with a discount after several updates but right now, its a free to play game that costs 40 bucks. Do not buy it.

it's a 45Gigabytes game which i think 30Gigabytes of it is dedicated solely for making the Sea. You will understand what i mean after you play it. The gameplay is easy yet hard to master and it's a PvPvE game so the "hard to master" part is heavily on the PvP side. But, watch several youtube video for tips and tricks, and you are good to go.

3. Kraken, Megalodon, Ghost Ship
4. All purchasables are cosmetics only.
5. There's No Grindhell (No leveling, no skill point, no upgrading equipment, no classification).

CONS :

This game is really fun but it has its pros and cons.

This game offers a lot so here are some pros, the game is really fun to play if you have a couple of friends and offers vast customization for your ship and character as well. It's very addicting and fun to venture around to different islands fighting skeletons, Kraken, sharks, and of course other players (Other than that those are the only enemy). This game is the exact opposite of pay-to-win every is equal no matter how much time you have spent in the game. There are amazing views and adventures to go on as well.

However, The game is not to fun solo you get bored pretty often doing the same quests over and over again. Although they prevent a pay-to-win it also doesn't allow for anything to look up towards, you could grind all you want but there are no upgrades, no weapon boost, nothing to even buy expect for skins for weapons and your ship. So you're doing all of this work just to customize your character and ship, which doesn't give me anything to look forward to. 

I would recommend this game if you do not mind the lack of upgrades and have friends to play with.

Not sure where to start with this, I'm not all for PvP and haven't been since the Dark Souls and Battlefield 3 days. But to me this game isn't PvP. 
It's peacefully sailing around enjoying beautiful sea and sky, waves crashing noisily and storms throwing you head for tails as you grip the wheel tight. Fishing on an island for a bit, tracking animals for merchant reasons, or sniffing up your next chest. General rat and loot goblin behaviors. 

Once you get a little used to your ship and the concept of questing in game, the tall tales are sometimes a whole different level. Not buch elaboration here for the sake of spoiling cool concepts; But I thought I was slick until my maps turned into sky charts and riddles.

As for the PvP? Honestly kinda thrilling, but to me it adds to the immersion, they're only out there trying to make a name for themselves too. Plus there's nothing like seeing a crew and the night and day difference between the downtime of playing music and admiring interests through your spyglasses to the roaring cannons and frantic repairs/navigation happening. 
Once you get down to it, there are some downright hilarious and dirty things you can pull off. Like sharing a powder keg amongst "friends." Afterall, you are a pirate.

Pretty cool experience for a solo player, but this game SHINES with a few buddies. Just to clear up, there is no PvE or Singleplayer gamemode. There's always the risk of your ship being raided, but that is the risk&rewards that keeps you going (kinda like Tarkov).
Besides, if you keep crying about being raided and there being no PvE mode, your gained currency can literally only be spent on cosmetics, so you're not even losing that much when you get raided.
Yes it's frustrating, but that's why you get some buddies and learn to defend yourself or scare others away.

One thing I'd complain about is some of the community being toxic though. I don't mean people coming back to attack your ship after you sunk them, I mean people who will spit out bullshit and slurs after killing you once, even if you sank their ship and killed them several times. The Ocean is salty enough, you don't need to be even more salty..

I recommend this game but there are a few things to note.

First to note is the gameplay loop. It seems weird to say that this game has a Dark Souls mechanic as the main loop but hear me out. You set out for treasure or bounties and the like, once you've the treasure or killed the bounty you have to make your way to an outpost to cash them in. You do not get anything if you don't make it back and cash them in. So if your ship sinks, all the treasure and bounty skulls are left there where it sank. Now to be fair, the gold you get is only for cosmetics to your outift and ship and since there is no way to get more powerful via XP (or any means really so everyone is on an even playing field), the only other thing you don't get is Reputation with faction you were going to sell to. Rep basically just gives you better paying jobs to do. So all in all, losing a haul can be sad or frustrating, especially when taken by another player, it's nothing that can't be gotten back pretty easily.

Second of all is Seasickness. I don't mean in the game either. Every time I play I get a headache so I can only play for a few hours at a time. i attribute this to two things, the first being the FOV. The max FOV is 90 while I normally play First Person games around 100-110 so 90 is a big step back. i've looking for a way to increase it but to no luck since it being an online game you dont want to mess around in the files. The second reason I think would be the up and down movement of the ship. In most games you mainly move horizontally and while vertical movement is there, it is normally under your control. You might think that maybe this is caused by me being new to games or something but I can say that's not the case, one look at my profile should how much I put into games that such a thing isn't the case. 

Other reviews have done a good job of covering issues and positives but i didnt see anything about these two. If this gameplay loop seems interesting I would totallly give it a try. With constant updates and plenty to do, this is a very fine game. 

I hope to see you on the Seas, matey.

This is completely and ridiculously unacceptable support from both Steam and Microsoft. [h1]Boring Nerd Stats[/h1][list]
    [*]Performance: GPU eats max setting @ 4k like its nothing. Simplistic design but beautiful
    [*]Gameplay style: Immersive time-sink with unique blend of simulation and part arcade. 
    [*]Lonewolf: Very much doable. Be weary of others or outright kill at first sight
    [*]Stability: Stable. May regularly transfer you to another server in non-intrusive manner
    [*]Average Session: Good hour or 2. No last minute gaming here. Grab a cup of coffee.
    [*]General playerbase: Like Elite Dangerous but in boats. Kill them before they get close.
[/list]

[h1]Simple but Pleasing[/h1]
Not enough game developers get that making a game does not have to centralize around extreme realism. A game does not need to be physically demanding to look nice. SOT is a prime example and not enough developers get that these days. It's all about blowing people's gpu up these days or forcing people to buy a 1-thousand dollar gpu (Red Dead 2 anyone?).

[h1]Striking Resemblance[/h1]
The first game that popped into my mind was [b]Elite Dangerous[/b], concerning Sea of Thieves. The two games are on a tangent of sorts. Elite is a space simulation game with more 'hardcore' mechanics. Everything takes an extended amount of time, the map is gargantuan (which is not necessarily a good thing), and options for full flight control, which can become difficult to manage without a hotas.

Elite is a simulation game. It has a lot of space. Too much space at times, but space nonetheless in a very raw form. You have your ship, you're in the 'main server' with everyone else, and  you're free to do whatever. Pirate, combat, mine, explore, hostile pvp'ing (ganking, griefing, etc. done beyond reason), or whatever else you may want to do. Free universe and players are free to do as they please in a very unrestricted format.

[h1]Simulation Differences[/h1]
If you are familiar with [b]Elite Dangerous[/b], it is very much not ideal to get 'blown up' by other players. Other factors such as upgrades (engineering as its called) that can offset encounters very much so; however, due to the map size, it is trivial, at best, to avoid people. Learn the hotspots, avoid them, or prepare for it.

Sea of Thieves takes a more friendly approach. They know what they're getting into. A PvPvE with almost 0 restrictions. How to make this fun despite that? Strangely, quite simple:

[list]
    [*]Everything is unlocked for everyone
    [*]No 'upgrades'
    [*]Virtually 0 penalty for dying, losing ship, etc.
    [*]Fresh, equal start whenever logging in
[/list]
This enables players to quickly get in the game and mitigate the encounters with overly hostile players.

[h1]Simulation Variety[/h1]
[b]Sea of Thieves[/b], on its foundation, is not an outright simulation game, but due to its own nature, it turned out to be one for specific areas. It primarily simulates the art of sailing and use of individual tasks. This, in turn, compliments a player's immersion as if they're the lone pirate, sailing their own ship by themselves. Its calm, liberating, and quite fun. 

As with [b]Elite[/b], vocations have a striking resemblance. Pirating, npc combat, exploring, cargo runs, looting. 

Keep in mind, as per simulation, these things will take time, especially the sailing and navigating. Setting aside 1-2 hours may be necessary.

[h1]Pleasant Surprise[/h1]
I did not go into [b]Sea of Thieves[/b] expecting it to be an unintentional simulation game. Certainly, there are quite a few 'arcade mechanics', if you will, attached to it. Solo, despite being a game encouraging coop, is remarkably fun, and if encumbrance sails your way, the game makes it more than easy to get away from it with a fresh spawn. 

[b]Who knew Sea of Thieves was a part Simulation game. That aspect is certainly not advertised well enough as it makes for an incredibly immersive experience.[/b]

This Pirate Simulator has it all! I have over 200 hours on the Sea of Thieves at the time of writing this review. This game was fantastic to me a year ago when the biggest PvE things to do were: (1) Clear Forts and (2) Clear Forts. One year later, there are now multiple Tall Tales (story quests), Fort of the Damned (endgame Fort), Emissary Faction Point/Reward System, Expanded Base Faction Reputation Gains and a PvP faction within Adventure Mode - The Reaper's Bones! I still have yet to try Arena Mode because Adventure Mode is a blast. Oh, and you can just sit around on the dock and fish if you want. Whatever floats your boat! YAR!

There's an unbearable audio and lag issue when fighting one of the main story bosses, won't spoil which, but it's prevented me from continuing the story, Other than that, the gameplay is smooth and the combat is simple. There's always something to do when sailing between islands, which is half of the game, so you're never bored.

Sea of Boredom

+ graphics are nice
+ controls system is working
- story quests are awful and boring: some puzzles are well done, others are a pain in the a**, what you do is that you sail over half of the map which takes you 15-30 minutes, then you solve a riddle or dig out a chest or kill skeletons only to sail again to the other end of the map
- the sailing itself is extremely boring, there is just nothing to do. you occasionally get attacked by sharks or ghost pirate boats, but they dont pose any threat, you shoot the share 2-3 times when it gets close than it disappears, you fire 10 rounds at the ghost ship which stays aligned to your side, so you can just constantly fire and it sinks. there is also a kraken which isn't strong either.
-you will fight a lot of skeletons which is also very boring as you basically have 2 attacks with your cutglass and you spam them.
-there is no customization or unlocks or progression regarding for your weapons/ship regarding playstile. you only choose one boat (small medium large) and 2 out of 4 weapons. no different boats as more flexible boats or stronger boats or cannons placed differently, bigger and smaller sails, nothing you can customize
-the goal of the game is to grind fetch-quests (depending on the faction: deliver goods from this to another island, kill skelettons, find treasure) which is very repetitive and boring.
-only thing you can buy is cosmetics (some of the best you can buy for EUR 25), some are very overpriced. some ship cosmetics and black market cosmetics are extremely expensive, e.g. hull color for 220k, if one simple loot you and in is from 200-3500. but who wants cosmetics to look good in a game that is so boring that you don't really want to play?
- only thing that is kind of fun is the pvp, but it also lacks of motivation as the combat system is very simple, respawn times are so low and you cant do things like steal ships or something like that

all in all its just a huge repetitive and boring grind for cosmetics

I love this game and it makes me a little upset to see some people complaining about the PvP system.
Here is my take on it after around 350 hours of gametime.

Read the title of this game carefully before you buy it.
It is called "Sea of Thieves".
It is NOT called "Sea of Friends".
Nor is it called "Sea of Privacy".
[b]Thieves.[/b]

It is a game where PvP is always enabled with no way of turning it off or playing on a private server.

Have I been killed by other players? Yes, many times.
Has loot been stolen from me after I spent hours collecting it? Yes.
Have people tricked me into going into an alliance with them and then backstabbing me later? Yes.
Are some people super aggressive and will attack anyone they see on sight? Absolutely.
Have I met awesome people who has given me memorable experiences? Many.
Would the game die if there were PvE servers? Without a doubt.


The game needs a balance of PvE and PvP players, or else it would not work.
The PvE players need to have a threat out there on the waters that keeps them alert and makes them do more than swing their swords at skeletons all day.

And the PvP players need PvE players because there is no point in fighting a ship and sinking them if there is no loot reward at the end.

There are many things you can do to avoid PvP.
If you are on the smallest boat and the enemy is in one of the larger boats, sail against the wind with your sails facing forward, that way it is impossible for them to catch up. It's called "Dummy sails" and it's very useful to know about.
Always keep an eye out for boats that could be coming your way.
Never park with your anchor down. That way you can just drop sails and leave as soon as you see trouble coming.
Park smart. You can use a lot of islands as cover if you park correctly.
Just to name a few.

If you don't give up after defeat, but keep on trying, eventually you will be able to outmaneuver and fight off the attackers. Maybe at that point you even get a taste of the forbidden fruit and decide to go attack some ships yourself?

If you are absolutely hellbent on only doing PvE content and do not want to engage in any kind of PvP, then the sea of [b]thieves[/b] is not the place for you.

EDIT: Someone commented on my profile that I have 0,2 hours in the game and not 350.
The game has been out for years on the microsoft store which is where I have played it. Ignore my steam playtime, and look at my achievements if you doubt me.

The game is sooo fun and wonderful and it has a lot going for it. that said. its only sooo fun and wonderful if youre a sweaty tryhard or have at least 4 people on your crew cause you cant go 15 minutes without a bigger ship with a larger crew boarding you and spam killing you without taking your one chest then sinking your boat. the community is toxic and all the big names advocate for PvP only play even though the game has a lot of PvE content that is IMHO way more fun that the PvP aspects, and according to a lot of the internet a lot of others feel the same. i was gonna put another $40 into the game just to get premium stuff when i was having fun, but rare lost essentially another full purchase of the game from me because they refuse to fix one of the baseline issues that a lot of players have with the game. have fun sweaty PvP babies, but im only gonna play when i have at least another player online, that being probably a couple times a week now at most.

Edit: I have no idea why people say PvE servers will kill the game... like, if so many people are going to go to PvE servers to grind, then clearly people like the PvE aspect more. If Rare then decides to update the PvE as opposed to the PvP to sate the PvE audience, then clearly the PvE audience is making more money. PvE servers can only help to grow the game, especially since people like me would come flocking back to the game quickly. I would love to love this game, but I decided long ago that I don't have the time or will to get good at video games when there are so many other things that are more worthwhile to get good at in life. I put over 1000 hours in Minecraft almost 7 years ago, id be willing to put in more than that if I just got the opportunity to have fun on the high seas without worrying about griefers. Plus, the game is only loosely based off of pirates. Pirates didn't even loot other pirates as they had a strict code, so anyone who defends the "Thieves" part of the game by talking about pirates, that's not a valid point. There's even a "pirate code" listed in the game that almost every PvP player straight up ignores. This game is not worth the $40 you have to pay for it if you are buying it to sail and have fun. Either you run around looking to sink others, or you wait for someone to find you to fend them off. There is no other way to play the game and that is disappointing.

This game is great. Honestly. It's one of those games with quite peaceful moments and fast paced, risky moments. Even when you are sailing long distances with little action, it still somehow isnt boring. This game is for both casual and hardcore players. You could sit on the crows nest spotting incoming ships and rocks, or you could stay on deck jamming out with your friends in a band. Also, the combat is actually amazing. You can do stealthy combat or loud combat, both being really fun. One event I remember is when my friends and I found a crew on a small, isolated island. Two of us distracted them and talked to them while the other one snuck around to their ship and bombed it with a gunpowder barrel, sinking it instantly. Just get this game. I promise.

This game has come a long way. I was really tempted to get it when it first came out, but wasn't quite convinced.
Now that it's released on Steam there's been tons of updates and additions and it's a really fun game. The sailing is interactive and the open sea is deceptively dense in terms of things to see and do.
The water looks amazing and the graphics in general are great, the gameplay is varied enough to not feel like a chore even after many hours, and while hand-to-hand combat can feel a little clunky at times the player interaction in general feels good.

Really happy with Sea of Thieves and I'm sure I'll be playing more than enough to get my money's worth.

This is a game to be enjoyed for what it is and not what it isn't IMO.   The one thing that really seems to be missing is any sort of progression.  

You never level up, increase stats, get better gear or anything traditionally associated with making progress in a game. At the same time, on Day 1 you will be just as powerful as any player who has hundreds of hours invested in the game.  In-game currency is earned to buy items which modify appearance but not performance.  

It is essentially open-world pvp/coop.  In my first gaming session I was educated by other players to put up an alliance flag to group up.  Joined them on their galleon ship for some questing action, engaged a skeleton ship and when  it was over got knifed several times in the back.  It's a pirates life...  I've been ganked a time or two since but you know what?  Who cares?  I gain experience and lose nothing of value.  

Graphics are a little cartoony but doesn't detract from the game.  The ocean looks great and you really get a sense of the ship riding the waves.  Weather is not something to be ignore either, I guarantee you will be paying attention to moving storm clouds on the horizon after you've been battered by a storm.  

10/10 - Would get struck by lightning and eaten by the kraken again anyday

Sea of Thieves is at it's core, a fantastic game. Going out and sailing the seas, finding treasure, killing skeletons, Solving puzzles and getting rich! there is no greater feeling than after a few hours of grinding, getting that massive turn in. But this game is not about the turn in, you will lose treasure, you will get killed by other players, over, and over. But one day, you'll sink that ship chasing you. and wipe out their crew, that will feel amazing! You'll get caught by a bunch of different, and amazing battles, and you'll lose at first, but with time, you'll stop losing and start winning. This game is about the journey. The adventure. The story you make along the way.

You will grind your way to pirate legend, and it'll be fun. But it wont be without heart ache. I still remember the first time I lost my 4 hour loot haul to another ship, I wanted to uninstall. But I didn't. And I'm glad I didnt, because honestly, I've never had more fun in a game before than in this. 

Doing a skelly fort with friends, only to be ganked by another ship, fend them off, and then watch them get caught by the Kraken coming back after us, amazing! I wouldn't have cared if we lost the loot, it was just a fun time! After a while, the gold becomes meaningless and it's just about what craziness you can get up to while sailing. 

TL;DR - This game is amazing, the start is hard, you will die and lose everything a lot. But stick it out, get better. And remember, it's about the journey, not the destination with this game. Every time you sail, create your own Pirate tall tale!
Very Very fun, addicting, graphically beautiful. I've played this on Xbox and now Steam. The PC port runs very well and i'm getting over 180fps on max settings. I highly recommend!

This game is PvE...vP
if you bought it for an incredible story, lore, immersive world, you will not be disappointed. If you expect players to leave you alone when you have high value loot you're insane. That being said 50% of the people you see will give you a hard time, the rest will let you do your story quests without interruption and there's a checkpoint system that makes the PvP moments not able to ruin your experience with the story. All of the PvP elements the only thing you can lose is treasure, big deal, money means nothing in this game beyond cosmetics. It sucks when someone makes a smart play on you but it's also funny when your ship explodes because someone snuck a mega-keg on. 
They've balanced it so it turns into a lot of fun when someone attacks you. All the people complaining about these elements should actually play the game, it's not all stream moments where someone is sneaking on. i did 6 strongholds on the uniquely titled fort night without interruption and didn't get into PvP until we realized the event was over and went to raid a group doing the fort of the damned. PvP is a choice, don't let fake reviews convince you otherwise. 
The game alone is amazing, the players make it unique.

Best Pirate Game Ever ;)

First off this game is called "Sea of Thieves" not "Sea of Friends" or even "Sea of Half-Decent People." This is full on Mad-Max, everyman-for-himself piracy. There is no such thing as a friendly face here, everyone you meet will either try to kill you or be nice and try to rob you. I'm beginning to take on a policy of shoot first, ask questions later. Seeing another ship's sails in the port you're sailing your hard earned loot to means a full on dash to the map room to route around and away from any other player I meet. I snuff the ship lights at night and sweep my cargo hold for hop-ons (A real thing that happens is that an another will hide in your cargo hold, wait til you dock at an outpost, then kill you and cash in your treasure while you sit on the Ferry waiting to respawn on what usually is the burning remains of your ship at dock.) This game has made me full on paranoid of other people. Basically expect the basic human decency you'd see at a Walmart parking lot in Florida. This all sounds bad, sure. That someone can just come along and fuck up the good time you're having can feel shitty. Been there. But there is some sort of weird magic in this game, watching the sunlight filter through a wave giving it a greenish glisten is just incredible. Watching the sunrise over a white sand beach, it's like a beautiful day in paradise. And for the most part, you can avoid most other people and focus on exploring and hunting bounty skulls or buried treasure. I'm told that this game is better with people but I've always held the belief that nothing is better with more people, so  if Rare ever had an offline mode I'd be pleased but oddly enough one of the fun things about the human factor is actually getting to outclever someone else. Keeping an explosive barrel in your hold to scuttle your ship and intruders and make sure if you can't get your treasure no one will? Been there, done that. Using the anchor to drift your ship into a perfect spot at dock? Got the T-shirt. Snuffing your ship lights and picking out other players ships from miles away at night by identifying their ship lights? Oh yeah baby. Blinding another player by hucking a bucket of your vomit at them? Got the liver damage. One nice thing that makes the forced PVP tolerable is that treasure can only acquire you cosmetic items. A day 1 player with the default gear is just as effective as a well-seasoned Pirate Legend. So if you lose your treasure, it's no huge loss, and if you play solo you shouldn't be stockpiling loot anyway. A few hours work can net you some pirate gear that will make you look much more respectable / piraty. I'm recommending this game because Rare made effort later on to catering to weirdos like me who prefer to play alone. And if you do choose to play, you can ahoy me all day and I'll greet you with a blunderbuss. Remember; never trust a pirate. Except one who is recommending this game, then absolutely trust that pirate.

My mom said I could be anything, so I became a pirate
GET IT! BE A PIRATE OR MISS OUT! YOUR LOSS..

-Losing is fun-

Try not to let negative reviews talking about forced PvP sway you away from this near-masterpiece, while the PvP can be frustrating, it is some of the most dynamic and exciting PvP I've come across in a long time. Blow them to bits with cannons, repel boarders, shoot yourself out of a cannon and board them, drop their anchor, steal their rowboat full of loot and slink away into the night.

Yes, the PvP is unavoidable at times, but if you're paying attention to the horizon and keep situational awareness, you can certainly diminish your player interactions or avoid it completely. Yes, large crews prey on solo players, yes, you WILL lose your loot after gathering it, yes, you will have a total blast if you learn from the times you lost and turn that into victories.

I spent around 10 hours on a solo ship and the rest with friends/public crews. Here's how it boils down -
Solo - Incredibly atmospheric, high tension and excitement.
Public - Mixed bag, generally pretty good but can be awful as well.
Friends - Where this game shines, sailing a galleon efficiently is a nightmare, with 3 friends it's a breeze.

All in all, it's utterly beautiful, dynamic and fun. PVP ISN'T GOING ANYWHERE, embrace it, you will certainly lose, but it gives you the best stories, and really, isn't writing your own sea shanty what this is all about?

I've been playing this game ever since it released on March 20th 2018, I've taken part in every major(and minor!) update from Hungering Deep to Ships of Fortune and have been loving it all the way. I probably have well over a thousand hours at this point but the Xbox companion app unfortunately doesn't show that. That's one of the reasons I bought it a second time here on Steam, along with having it next to my other games. Now, let's get to some pros and cons of the game.

[u]Pros[/u][list]

[*]A large and colorful world with incredibly beautiful and stylized graphics.

[*]Due to one of the big focuses of the game being player interaction you will always leave a playsession with a new story to tell. This is one of my favorite aspects as it makes sure there's always replayabiliy, even though you've done every possible task in the game.

[*]There's a large amount of different activities to do. Be it a voyage to find some long forgotten treasure or a battle aginst a fleet of half-rotten ships manned by skeletons there's always something to do.

[*]Emergent gameplay. This goes hand-in-hand with the point about player interaction. Even though most activities in the game are repetetive they blend together so well to make sure the game never feels stale. You might find yourself in a situation where you just completed a Skeleton Fort but see a enemy ship on the horizon. Better get that loot onboard quickly and then prepare for a fight!

[*]For you who likes following a story the game has that too! Sea of Thieves' story-centered missions are called Tall Tales and sets you out on quests where you'll have to solve puzzles and follow clues to progress. If you really want to delve into the lore there's the books "Athena's Fortune" and "Tales from the Sea of Thieves" to explain the backstory of a few of the characters and locations. I really recommend buying them if you're into that kind of stuff!

[*]There's also factions which you can build a reputation with by delivering different types of loot, unlocking cosmetics and also higher value voyages as you go up the ranks. In my own opinion you should never focus on this completely. It serves as a reason to sail to different islands and as a cause for conflict or friendship between different crews. To quote the great Pirate Lord, "It's not about the gold... It's about the glory!"
[/list]

As with any game, there will always be a few aspects that are not as good

[u]Cons[/u][list]

[*]Let's start with the most obvious one, the community. There's a substantial amount of players that you will run into that are very toxic. With toxicity I mean pirates who throw mean-spirited insults at you that may in some cases even be racist/homophobic/you name it. Then there's also players who join your crew for the sole purpose to troll. The best way to handle situations like these is to mute the abusive players(there's an option under "Other Crews") or to just avoid playing in open crews. I'd also recommend joining a community to find good players to sail with([url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/fleetofthievesgrizzly]shameless plug[/url]).

[*]Combat. While PvP and PvE is for the most part very solid there is some issues. A very well known one is the game's hit registration, which can sometimes very noticably make your shots not count. For some the weapon system might also not be deep enough, but for me it's good and pretty enjoyable. I enjoy PvP most of the time.

[*]The game requires a certain mindset to really enjoy. You might've noticed how I didn't put much of my focus on the game's progression system, and there's a very good reason for that. Many people buy this game with an intention that in most cases doesn't fit. I'm talking about players who are just in it for ranking up, making more gold and not really like engaging in PvP, fearing they might lose all that progress that lies in their hull.  [u][b]If you are this kind of person I don't think I can recommend this game to you in good conscience.[/b][/u] This has lead to much discussion and arguments which you can easily see after taking a quick look at the discussions page. The PvP aspect isn't the only thing that will get in your way. Grinding this game with no focus on anything else strips away all the parts that make it so unique and fun, leaving only a repetetive and mindless loop of gathering treasure and selling treasure for gold that you'll use on some cosmetic you think look cool or funny before going out to gather more treasure.[/list]

Thank you for reading my review of this wonderful game! If Sea of Thieves seems like something you'll enjoy I hope to meet you one day on the seas.

This game is a broken heart waiting to happen.

Microsoft services/xbox services are built into this game even though you are playing the steam version. This causes minor issues and annoyances.

The game has zero progression, what you start with is what you have the whole game.

There's no customization of the ship layout whats so ever. I played with the Sloop supposedly the fastest ship. The reason this is important is LETS SAY. You are chasing another sloop... the fastest ship in the game. Oh ok Looks like we are gaining on em! (30minutes go by you have gone from one end of the map to the other) The sloop doesn't have a forward cannon, and since i can't customize the loadout or angle of fire on cannons or upgrade any of my cannons/harpoons to account for this. Combat goes from this pretty exciting moment to the enemy running and you chasing for 30mins, till either you make a mistake and they get away or they make a mistake and you gain on them, this sucks because the combat last 5mins or less.

Problem is this will never get fixed or added into the game because after reading the forums the devs have made it clear they have no intention to giving other players advantages, which is stupid. Which is also a pitfall for developers, as what creates really exciting moments is kicking someones butt or outsmarting someone that has better stuff than you and taking their stuff. And gives players a feel that their ship is unique. Basically adds more depth and strategy. as currently there's little to none.

The games controls suck on keyboard and mouse (No idea for controller) needs work, which will never happen since the games been out for 2 year and everything thats been added in the last 2 years was stuff you would expect in release. The game is secretly an early access game with slow development.

And this sucks because the game is beautiful has a lot of roleplay/immersion = fun moments which is missing in a lot of games today. Just the core gameplay loop is trash. I don't want to spend 20 hours farming random stuff with lackluster game controls and riddles/puzzles on islands to earn 40k gold just to buy a gold ship piece with no gameplay dynamic to it.

The game should be 10$ so you can actually convince a full party of friends to purchase it and have a full crew, as this game should not be played with less than 4 people. You can get some fun out of it, but no where near the amount you can with 4 people.

I've been following Sea of Thieves since before it was released two years ago.  I'm not sure how many hours on the microsoft store I've put into the game, but it must be over 300. From that time to the present, Rare has been extremely open and honest about the development of the game over time.

While when the game first released there was some poor feedback about lack of content, the developers have really added a lot of content over the least two years with the anticipation of more. All updates to Sea of Thieves are free and the only microtransactions are purely cosmetic.


As far as gameplay goes the game can be enjoyed solo on a ship but is best played with two or more friends. There is a lot to do between the story-rich tall tales, the skull forts, leveling with the trading companies, bilge rat adventures, and good old fashioned pvp with players. 

It's the kind of game where you remember the stories and adventures because no two encounters are the same.

Half of this game is spent roaming the most beautiful ocean scenes ive ever seen in a game, with excellent ship controls, open combat, and a true sense of exploration in what is definitely the best pirate-like game ive ever played. The other half is spent coping with the incredible amount of bugs. I can tolerate the very poor loot system, you lose literally everything you have found that you dont sell on death or LOGGING OUT. As frustrating and annoying as this system is, i can deal with it and still enjoy the game. The bugs on the other hand. I cannot count the amount of times ive been rocketed off of surfaces hundreds of feet from my ship, ive had megladons and krackens spawn no loot, ive had invisible holes in my ship, lost items from inventory without logging out or dying, sometimes it can take up to 20 minutes just to log into the game because of the server finder "Searching the seas." The  developers have created something amazing and if they don't stop trying to dump more content into the game before fixing what we already have the game will die. As it is right now, the game is very fun, i recommend buying it, i recommend playing it and exploring and plundering and fighting but, be absolutely prepared for the shitstorm of bugs that are in this game.

Bought this game from Day 1 of release and have I would guess over 1,000 hours of total play time, mostly on Xbox. I recently got back into PC gaming and back into this game from a hiatus and had to get it on PC. Very happy I did and glad to see this game come to Steam to further expand the player base. 

When the game first released, I won't lie, it was fun but far from the finished product it should have been. Very little to do besides an extremely mindless grind of the exact same voyages over and over and over again. My friend and I made it to Pirate Legends only to find an even larger grind ahead of us and that is when we both quit playing.

About a year an a half later I decided to try the game out again after some big streamers I follow had got back into it due to an update, and I am really glad I did. The game in its current state is great and what I think the game SHOULD have been like at release. IMO the game was released too early with little to no content. Addition of the Reapers Bones, Tall Tales, additional Athena loot types and runs, throwables, the Emissary system, new food types including cooked foods that give over healing, tiered leaks in your hull, etc etc etc are all amazing additions to the game and had they been there on launch, I believe this game would have been even bigger than it already is today(10 million unique players to date).

Long and short of it, $40 for this game is a steal. 1,000 hours for $40 is a hell of a deal in my mind. And if you can catch this on sale its even better. Is this game for everyone? Hell no. Especially if you aren't the type of person who enjoys PvP. This isn't a strictly PvP based game, but you can rest assured that if you don't keep a keen eye on the horizon, another crew will gladly attempt to rob you of your hard earned treasure to claim as their own. This is a pirate game after all, and you must understand that and go into it knowing the environment you are going to be playing in. And, that this is also a game better suited for group play with 1 or more people, so grab a friend and hit the seas!

Here's an example of my previous play session:
>Crew of 4 people
>One is a veteran since launch and others, including myself whom are relatively new
>We decided to take up the Reaper faction and do reaper chest hunting and skull forts to cash in for fat money stacks
>Things going well, bested tons of skelly ships one after the other
>We all progressed through the reaper faction enough and got the costumes so we ended looking like a band of cultists...
>It was getting late, like 3am late
>Saw a skull fort pop up and we collectively agreed to make it our last run before hitting the hay
>Skull fort was going well and we completed it with no issues
>Take some pictures of ourselves and our crew with the loot.
>Plunder a bunch of really good loot along with some gunpowder kegs that fetch a modest price with the reapers vendor
>Placed all of our loot on the rowboat including the powder kegs and sailed to the ship
>Upon the rowboat docking with our ship we had just started to transfer the cargo to the captains quarters
>Suddenly a load explosion and the next second all of us on the ship died and the ship immediately sunk
>One crew member left on the island who witnessed our loot and riches going down with the ship to eventually resurface on to the water
>After questioning what happened there was one crew member who was silent during the whole thing
>He very quietly said the word "miss clicked" in a very ashamed tone
>We all plummeted into despair pretty quickly
>We decided to do what we could and once respawned we attempted to race back to the island to grab the loot that the crew member who was left behind was keeping safe for us.
>Crew member left on the island advised a player ship was heading towards the island
>fuck.jpg
>We raced the ship as fast as we could but their ship had already plundered all the loot and sailed off. 
>Gave chase after the ship which turned out to be a sloop with 2 people which was a lot smaller than galleon of 4 members
>We was confident we could sink them and take back the loot
>The sloop of 2 turned out to be very skillfull players who sneaked on to our ship to lower our anchor to slow us down
>The 2 pirates had consistently shot us dead each time we revived.
>Two members of our group, namely the one who was left on the island and the one who caused the mess in the first place had both rage quit at this point.
>Me and the veteran in our crew left who felt we could still salvage what we could out of the situation.
>Decided to parlay with the enemy crew who turned out to actually be rather friendly
>Advised them of what happened to us originally
>Veteran crewmember asked if we could alliance with their crew (they would still get 100% reward while we would get a cut of 50%)
>Enemy crew accepted on one condition
>We both had to sing them a song
>Me and the vet decided to sing "Let It Go" to the best of our ability at 4:00am
>Enemy crew loved our act and decided to allow a truce and alliance
>Me and the vet boarded their ship and sailed to the reaper island and we got a 50% cut of all the loot profits instead of 0% if we had given up earlier.
>Had a good chuckle and laugh with the other crew and we all logged off to sleep.

10/10 would stay up at 4am to sing frozen to a bunch of strangers for loot again

This game is very enjoyable.

Though, for those that are solo players: be prepared for frustration and anger.
As a new player I've had nothing but bad experiences meeting other players. Though they're far and few in between, I'm constantly being shot to pieces.

The dynamic events will jump on you at the worst possible times. Surviving a Kraken straight out of a respawn is not possible.

I don't have IRL friends to play with; and I think that's 90% of the experience in this game. I don't know how I feel about playing with strangers - but we'll see. I might try signing up for a crew soon enough - don't know yet.

I've been shot in outposts/safezones, had my boat sat on fire and you name it - it's not a solo friendly game. Know that when you buy it. If you HATE PvP... well, take a guess.

I've only played 28hrs as of this review and it's been solo.
I hope you get to enjoy the game if you buy it!


Edit on 07/06/2020
To clarify on Whiterabbit's comment:
- I'm not saying people shouldn't shoot each other, but that I used the first hours of me playing this game *trying* to learn the mechanics and it was overwhelming. I've been attacked straight after spawning in on new ship, while docking for my first voyage, while in town. The pirate code is just that: A CODE! not a rule. And I think PvE minded players need to be aware of that. There's no safe place; you can be shot, killed, and sunk anywhere at any time - even as a new player who just opened the game. I've also tried turning my back on my ship to turn in my treasure for like 20seconds, I came back and a Galleon had docked and sat my sloop on fire; they apologized and repaired my sloop and when I was out on voyage again, I noticed they had ripped my sloop for every possible resources. 

As an anchored sloop trying to do a voyage, meeting a PvP ready Galleon was by no means fun and they shot me only for the sake of shooting me. This type of encounters can be grueling and very demoralizing. New players need to be aware of this because it makes or breaks the game for some of them.

Not everyone is okay playing with other people due to anxieties and playing solo is their only option - this game will not be for them. I'm simply trying to make a certain group of gamers aware that there's no Single Player version of this game and you won't be left alone out there on the seas.

Solo and Single-Player is two very different things.

If I'm going to play with other people, I'll play with someone I know in real life.
The game does encourage team-work and I love that - even the alliance system is cool.

And I know I'm making it sound like the game is such a bad thing, but I just have to highlight certain events that'll make some people really bumped out about having spent 40EUR.

Personally I love the game to bits. There's things and details that annoy the living out of me, but I understand why it's done as it is. The treasure system is fantastic, I LOVE the riddles and bounties, I love the different factions and that some items can be turned in to any of them for extra experience. The Sailing mechanics are very enjoyable once you get it down - and sailing a sloop alone is almost therapeutic.

While the game is very linear and grindy, it's a joy.

This is a game best played with friends.

The mechanics are very simple, which makes it well balanced. The only factor is individual player skill in so far as clicking at the right time is a skill.

Ship mechanics take a bit of getting use to, lowering your sails, angling them correctly and then steering which reacts pretty much how I guess a ship would steer (slow like a walrus).
There's riddles if you're into that, and every treasure you chase has a map that points you to an island that takes a few minutes to find on the world map ( which is only available in your hull/captain's cabin on the ship).

Is there a point to it? Not really.
Is it fun if there's no point? Yes if you're playing with friends and yes if you enjoy a very repetitive grind.
Downsides? Griefers/trolls/general asshole players who have nothing better to do than just ruining other people's fun, but this is the internet so expect a lot of that.

Sidenote: Steam or the game bugged, so when I quit, Steam thought the game was still running and now I have 13 hours played on my game when its more like 4 - 5 hours

I originally bought this game on the Microsoft store back in 2018 and have played it a lot more than my Steam playtime says. I'll be honest and say I suck at writing reviews, but I definitely recommend trying this game. Absolutely brilliant

This game puts everyone on a level playing field by not incorporating any stat/equipment progression. Everything you can buy with the in-game currencies is purely aesthetic. That said, there is a surprising amount of content. The fun of this game is in taking risks by amassing more and more loot on your ship before turning it in for a currency reward, all while avoiding getting your ship destroyed or looted by other players or the environment. I have only been playing solo and that adds an additional layer of challenge because it requires me to singlehandedly run all aspects of my ship and makes getting taken out by larger groups of pirates that much more likely. I don't often write reviews, so this review is a bit unorganized, but overall if you like games based on your own skill rather than in-game-progression based skills, and you like pirate games at all, this is worth the price. Solid 9/10.

I realise I have only played 11 hours, but for me this game is thoroughly enjoyable. I know a lot of new players had gripes about having to deal with powerful, experienced ships that were just out to rob gold, but the hint is in the name. If you're going to play Sea of Thieves you have to expect that there is a chance a bigger, more powerful ship is going to come along and rob you blind.

I actually find this to be a really excellent element of the game because you have to think like a lowly solo pirate. Even in my short time playing I have managed to rack up thousands of gold with a minimum amount going to human pirates who have attacked me. I personally find it quite satisfying when I am attacked and beaten, knowing that they wasted their time because I have no loot on board. And the few times when you do lose loot you don't lose a whole lot.

It's such a beautifully immersive game, and I have already had a great time playing with total strangers from across the world when I fancy mucking in and helping out others. A cracking game for all I reckon, but you definitely need to overcome the initial obstacle of not taking it too serious, not being offended if you are sunk and just know you can always get back to a new ship and continue on. Just enjoy the experience. It's not all about winning

This game is for anyone who loves to play as a pirate. The game lets you experience the pirate life to a great detail which is unique and amazing. There is absolutely no pay to win elements and the microtransactions are only for visual enhancements. This game is like minecraft but on a ship with other players. The water texture is breathtaking but the remaining is tf2 style but not bad. The tutorial is short and doesnt help you understand the game fully. There are two modes in this game- adventure and arena. arena is where you duel against other pirate crew. arena games are quite short and thrilling. Adventure is where you and your crew set sails to explore the large map, find loots and kill things. Adventure mode can get quite boring at times as it is almost never ending. The game dev need to improve the games UI as it looks like as its made in the 90s. They also need to work on making a penalty system for those who leave games suddenly. The game should introduce a one man boat exploring mode because sometimes your teammates will suddenly leave and it puts you in a disadvantage especially in adventure mode. This experienced players in this game are quite welcoming to new players to this game as they help you learn and make mistakes instead of flaming and raging which is nice like most multiplayer games today. I was lost when i played adventure mode for the first time as i had no idea what are skulls for, how to get quests, how to use a gun, how to use a sword effectively in taking down a skeleton and how to shoot a canon. The tutorial only gives you a small glimpse of all those things and does not give you the time to take down a ship, try killing a kraken or how to kill a Walking skeleton!
Overall a great game if you are bored and want to play a pirate game. Small flaw fixes could really boost the potential of this game.
Very easy game to learn and get into though with a lot more layers and nuance than meets the eye. Even the more mundane becomes an adventure with friends. Great to pass the time with friends.

The game is great. The players are sad man-children with inferiority complexes they try to assuage by making life miserable for others. You think defeat is you getting killed, your ship sunk, and your loot stolen? Nah, that'd actually be fun. PvP here is a bunch of heavy breathing guys camping your respawn for an hour because they apparently have nothing better to do. And then there's the voice chat they will liberally make use of to verify that they are as useless in real life as they are in the game.

Despite all this I still recommend it. But you have to be keenly aware of what you're getting yourself into. Turn off all voice coms, and treat everyone that you do not personally know as if they were NPCs designed and programmed with the sole purpose of ruining your experience. The game then becomes a quite interesting effort of learning and exploring, while killing, dodging, and subverting the drooling morons that inhabit the world.

If you expect emergent gameplay and tense meetings on the high seas, you will be disappointed. That is not what this game is, despite what it is marketed as. Everyone you meet will attack you on sight no matter the situation. If you're on your ship they will sit around without sinking it and kill you every time you try to respawn. If you're in an outpost they will camp you until you log out. If there is anything, anything at all, they can do to make your time in game unpleasant, they *will* do it. And they will keep doing it. 

Is that a good situation, that creates a healthy long term playerbase? Nah. But it is what it is, so get used to it and play accordingly. Or don't buy the game. Which is a very good choice as well. But if you attempt anything in between those two extremes you will have a bad time.

I have to agree, with some of the negative comments so far. 

The game is visually appealing, the game mechanics are fairly easy to grasp, it fits. Sailing is the fun part of this game. The PvE content is enjoyable but that's where it ends for me. The new player experience only lasts for the time you start the game and enter the PvP world. 

The enforced PvP is after minutes of exiting the intro is a kick in the X. As a new solo player, once you've completed the intro, you're left to your own devices and at the mercy of others as you figure out what to do and where to go. In both times I started the game, I was pretty much ganged up on by other players as soon as I left port. You fight back and then it becomes a cycle of harassment until you scuttle your ship and start anew somewhere to reorient and  continue with whatever you were doing, which could place you randomly somewhere else far away from where you initially started. First time impression, the enforced PvP sucks. There is no lead up, no time to prepare; I can understand if you have a boat full of loot, pirates be pirates, that I can get behind, and that can be the thrilling part as you race back to sell your loot. But if the other players are complete trolls picking on new players as they start to play the game, then they'll simply ruin the experience. Game needs PvE only servers or a time-limited "protection" indicator for new players to get a handle on the game, other games similar to this do it with success, not sure why it has to be PvP all the time. People will just take the fun out of it if you're solo playing and trying to enjoy the story aspects like Tall Tales or simply looking for the buried treasure, it's definitely a game where numbers are required, solo players be damned.

Even if you play with others, it's not a fun experience unless you know them. I started an Adventure with a small sloop with one other random crew, who simply did not communicate. It was only when I decided to take the ship after 15 minutes of silence from the other player and sail away did they finally started talking by swearing at me for leaving them behind. At this point, is this game worth paying full price for if the effort to reach the fun part is going through hours of bad experiences. I assume if you've already done the intro then the adventure aspect should be to just start playing. The other player simply ignored me by without saying a word in text chat or voice. What's the point of the Adventure with random players if they go about their game as if you didn't exist. Yes, I imagine this could be a fun game if you have friends to play with that are on the same page, so far, not a fun solo or multiplayer random experience.

The other thing that kind of surprised me is that fact that once you leave the game, you don't start back at the same point you left. I had quit the game to come back 10 mins later to find all the progress and loot I collected on the ship is gone. Which is disappointing because the game forces you to stay online to keep progressing. If you don't have time to sell your loot, you leave, it's all gone when you come back. At least that what it looks like to me, not sure if that's by design. If it is, that sucks.

Overall, if you want a solo pirate game, this isn't for you. If you want to simply spend a few hours playing with random people, maybe if they're communicative to make it enjoyable. The best way that I can see to really enjoy this game, is play it with friends you know and then sail the seas with people watching your back. It's better than seeing the ferryman over and over and over again.

EDIT: I'll admit that I may not have given this game enough of a chance, especially since I was able to get a refund after 3 hours of playing it. It's not a quick-play type of game, it requires time that I wasn't willing to invest in and quite frankly the first impressions of being repeatedly dying after just starting didn't help. Other comments stated you will be frustrated and angry if you're playing this game solo. That's no lie.

After reading the official forums and seeing the same experiences by others is kind of disheartening. I really wanted to like this game, although, I'll admit that I did not jump on Discord, Reddit, etc to try and find other like-minded people to play with. But that is also a problem, I shouldn't have to find like-minded people to play with "outside" the game.

It's such a great idea with pretty lackluster execution. Plays like Destiny but with mindnumbingly poor combat, and even less clear tutorials that are simultaneously obtrusive AND entirely uninformative. 

Worth mentioning, the community is pretty much entirely 10 year olds, and if you can find any who are the slightest bit communicative, you'll wish they weren't. Solo play is doable but obviously not how it was intended to be done, but playing with silent hyperactive kids that make completely senseless decisions is even less conducive to fun.

Definitely not worth $40.

Sea of Thieves is vastly underrated. Since the addition of the Emissaries Update, this game has finally taken full form. SoT is essentially a PvPvE title, meaning it's an always online Pvp game with sprinkles of PvE elements in order to give PvP'ers things to steal. From the Tall Tales story missions to grinding to become Pirate Legend to dying in certain ways in order to get different colored flames from the Ferry or the Damned in order to start the Fort of the Damned to even using the hide emote on an enemy ship in order to steal their newly obtained Chest of Legends chest, this game definitely has something for everyone, and it shouldn't be overlooked. Rare grinds out free updates each month, adding new features to the already content-filled seas.

From day one, I've pondered glimmers of what this game could be, hoping that one day my dreams would finally come to fruition. Well, now it has. Now is the perfect time to dive into the Sea of Thieves, finally on Steam. You won't be disappointed.

A great example of modern sandbox games, where devs give you a bucket, a scoop and suggest to entertain yourself. You put a bucket on your head, while keep poking your friends with a scoop, all of you start eating sand and dig all the dog sh.it out.
But after 5 hours of fooling around you realize: there completely is nothing else to do. By 10h gameplay mark your scoops are broken, whole desert is eaten and all the buckets are full of dog poops.
And you also have to divide this gametime by 2 or even 3 times if you are alone, there literally is nothing for you to achieve except purchasing sh.itty pirate and ship cosmetics.
No leveling system, no weapons or armor sets, no upgrades for your ship, nothing. You just swim from point A to point B, dig some sh.it out of sand, or sometimes beat it out of some mobs and other players and bring it back to outpost to get some useless coins.
The difference is only between selling different type of trash to a different faction's merchant, which raises the level of your reputation in this faction, which gives you... Nothing. Access to more useless cosmetics, less trash quests with just slightly more rewarding trash piles.
I think, there are literally 5 types of AI enemies in this game, which are Kraken, Megalodon, normal sharks, skellies and cobras. That's it, that's all there is. First 2 are completely random sea encounters(I mean, go towards stormy clouds and you're fine) and are complete pain in the ass if you have less than 3 members of your crew, other 3 types are island enemies and skellies have some varieties, some bosses among them, but they all feel the same and are completely boring and have same shape. 
Oh, and there is some sh.it in-between them, which is mermaid statues, they are even more boring than everything else mentioned before.
The Islands you encounter are beautiful, empty and useless. Any decent enemy encounter never spawns untill you find yourself a quest somewhere. Like, completely never. You can run into some pathetically looking skelly-ghosty-themed fort and expect to have some good fight and loot? Nope, go fu.сk yourself, it's empty as your wallet during the lockdown, and nothing is going to happen untill you complete a sequence of boring trash quests and looting. There simply is no life in this game, it looks like an alpha to me. After all this time passed since it had been released at MS store, it looks like nobody but a couple of surface designers were working on it.

PS. Oh and I forgot to say that I've wasted at least 2 hours of this playtime on trying to add my friends in fu.cking xbox account and connect to servers which were dead. Have fun.

TL;DR
Do not buy it, if you have less than 3 more friends to constantly play with you, but if you do, buy something else nonetheless, because there are tons of games which are much more funny to play in a party of 4+ people.
This one is empty and boring, with no goals and no progression.

I didn't find a great guide to what the heck you do in this game. 

Basically in the beginning in PVE, you:
-Grab a quest from one of the factions ( find treasure, capture/trade animals, fight skeletons)
-Sail to the island identified in the quest.
-Get/capture/kill the chest/animals
-Return and get gold and reputation with the faction for cosmetics and grind.

There's more depth/emergent stuff as you progress, but that's the jist. Oh, and other players are able to wreck/steal your ship while you're doing this. Or you can wreck people on quests.

So, good times overall.
