There is no steam friends list support whatsoever. You are forced to use the xbox app friends system. If this issue doesn't bother you, then I'd recommend this as a game because it is really great for what it is today, aside from the rampant racist competitive salty adults running around shouting the N word at every opportunity they get.

When you launch the game, it allows you to connect your Xbox app account to your Steam account. However, it does not in any way link your friends lists together. You can only form groups for playing the game with your xbox friends list.

What this means is, not only do you have to connect your accounts, but you also have to either pull up the windows gamebar overlay (I disabled mine a long time ago), or launch the xbox app from the windows 10 store, find out your username, and add each other through that app. Then and only then will you be able to invite your friends.

This has zero Steam implementation outside of being sold on the Steam store. You can't invite steam friends, you can't join on steam friends, they can't join you, and there is no in-game functionality that is even aware of what your steam friends list is or who is on it. It doesn't matter if everyone playing bought the game through Steam. That's what is absurd to me.

Sea of Thieves is only aware of your xbox friends list.

If they ever change or patch this to include the most primitive and basic of Steam support, being able to play with your Steam friends in a multiplayer game that everyone purchased through Steam, then I'll change this to a positive.

Having tons of fun sailing a sloop with one other friend. 
Many people on the forums complain about griefing. I guess we are lucky as we've only had one run in with players that spawn camped us, which is easily solved by either idling in the respawn realm, or just scuttling the ship. Overall it's a pvp game first so we weren't bothered by it at all. 

The quests can get repetitive, but there are enough for you to change things up if you're tired of doing one thing. 
We typically would do one of each, turn in, rinse and repeat.

There are also random events that can spice things up, such as fighting the Kraken or a shark, as well as skeleton ships, shipwrecks, messages in a bottle which lead to valuable quests. 

The only thing to purchase with the in game currency are cosmetics, there is no way to improve your gear or storage space. Seems this was a deal breaker for many. To me this is perfect as starting late in the game we are on the same playing field as everyone else. 

Overall worth the money and a great pick up and put down game to play casually. 
Be aware the game will only run on Windows 10.

I have played this game since it was first released on the Microsoft store and am so glad it had made it to the steam client. I have spent hours in this game doing things simply fishing to playing a Tomb Raider/Indiana Jones adventure. But I am gonna go into a few things about why this game is worth your buy:

Pros:
- This game has hours and hours of content. From playing the story driven "Tall Tales" that have you discover some of the lore of the game to hunting the commendations that unlock special cosmetics, there is never nothing to do.
- This is a sandbox adventure game. I think it has been rare that I log in with friends and don't have a great story to tell from us playing. So many crazy stories happen that range from cartoon comical to absolutely epic.
- Ship combat feels really good. When you learn how to properly aim the cannons, use the special cannon balls, and more, the ship to ship battle are incredibly fun. And as you master the sailing aspect with the combat you truly feel like epic pirates.
- The Tall Tales are a lot of fun and have very successfully captured the essence of a "high seas adventure"
- The in game events have been a blast each and every time the have expanded the content of the game.
- You are always on a level playing field. There is no progression in the game that puts you at an advantage over other players. All rewards are cosmetic so just starting off you have access to all the same things as someone like me with hundreds of hours in the game (other than experience of course).

Cons: Unfortunately, no gaming experience is perfect, and you will want to be aware of a few things that may or may not make you leave this game alone.

- As mentioned before, all rewards are cosmetic. This has led some people to be dissatisfied as their aren't many "progress" levels to achieve. You have reputation levels and reaching "Pirate Legend", but this doesn't provide you with anything other than more cosmetics. Those who crave better loot for their effort might find this a tad disappointing. 
- As a sandbox, there is not a lot of direction. While it's true you get to adventure in whatever way you want, their is no really good way to know what to do in the game without some kind of help. You wouldn't understand how the companies worked or that Tall Tales are even a thing without stumbling on them accidentally. The "tutorial" tall tale is fantastic, but doesn't show these aspects of the game off.
- Ship combat has a learning curve. You will have to learn how each ammo type behaves and master sailing your ship AND fighting at the same time. Fighting against experienced players can be frustrating as they know a few tricks that a new player can't really deal with until they either learn the hard way or get some help.
- Leveling is a grind, although this pain has been greatly relieved with all the ways to get reputation levels now. "BACK IN MY DAY!!!..." is a real thing for some of old players as we had to truly grind some frustrating fetch quests to reach the high levels. Now it can still be annoying, but its more varied. This grind can still put some people off so be aware of it. Best to just enjoy the process and have adventures!

This game is by far my favorite in a long while and I will continue to enjoy it. I recommend looking up the content creators on YouTube as they have tone of guides, tips, trick, and other stuff that will help you get into the game! I hope to see you out on the Sea of Thieves!

A very enjoyable pirate game, solo or with friends. Beautiful landscapes, effects, music and the W A T E R, oh mah gawd. Combat is fluid and and fun, pulling off the easy to learn and hard to master mechanics just feels very rewarding to the player. Same goes for the sailing, extremely fluid and rewarding once you get the hang of it and a skilled player can easily solo a sloop.  The price alone is worth it, perfect for a mp only game with little to no story, but endless hours of enjoyable game-play and quests. Oh and the quests can get pretty damn good, especially the Tall Tales which is where you will find the "story" aspect of the game.

 Most of the negative reviews are from the same type of people that get upset that they died by a player in any other survival game. Spamming refunds the second they die and demanding pve servers. There are plenty of things you can do to avoid players and its as simple as talking to another ship and allying up if you need a hand, plenty of people in game will help you out. From my experience this is one of the most forgiving player bases in a "survival" type of game that ive played. Countless times ive had players come to my aid in combat just because we wave the same flag. But of course with any pvp game you do occasionally get those "toxic" players but that just comes with the nature of these kinds of game, just makes it feel even better when you outplay their ass ;)

 If you do buy this game and you should at least give it a shot with a friend or two, just give it time. There are plenty of new players just like you trying to learn the game, you will die..a lot but you will get better and make friends along the way while you try. Your experience with SoT changes every time you play, this is why there should never be a split between player bases with pve and pvpve servers. You will get a casual and relaxing play-through surrounded by traders some days and others you will experience the true nature of the game..pirates. 

 Try the game out and if its not for you then its just not for you. Personally I think everyone who gives it a chance with friends will enjoy their time with SoT. Hell I even bought it twice, once when it came out on the ms store and here on steam. There is also cross-play so if you have some friends on Xbox, have them hop on too. By chance if you dont have a friend to play with you can look for other crews that have an empty spot on their ship in the main menu when you go to join a game. With the easy to use friend request system of just using an emote and the various forms of non verbal communication in SoT its very flexible with people who might not have a microphone to communicate with ease.  And dont forget to use that tutorial in the main menu, its on the bottom right of your screen when you start the game up :)

The combat is simple and to the point. It makes it pretty easy for anyone to snag a kill, but the learning curve gives those who know what their doing an edge. Same goes for ship combat as well.
The only downside for me is that it has to be connected to an Xbox Live account. While I get it, it doesn't make it less annoying. You're unable to join through Steam and you cannot invite your friends without added them on your Xbox friend list.
Otherwise, this is a great game and worth the $40 USD spent on it.

Ok here is my schpeel, this game is great, it looks great, it feels great, it sounds great. I truly do like this game. BUT, some things need to be fixed. First and foremost, loading times. Loading into an actual server has taken me 5+ min each time, which you know, whatever, but that's not the end. It is truly infuriating when I am in a solo sloop and I get two goons in another sloop that jump me while I am anchored at an island. They miss 3 shots by the time I finally get to my boat, they don't have a mast any more there are 17 holes in their ship, its on fire blah blah. I finally die to one of the nerds that respawned. and then I am met with a 2 min loading screen, a 2 min (or so it felt like) respawn time, another 2 min loading screen. Which gave them oodles of time to sink my ship. Keep in mind my ship had not been hit prior to me dying. Since I spawned in my ship as it was sinking I am hit with once again a 1 min loading screen and then I die to a shark. Poggers. Next problem, frame drops and optimization issues. This might be my pc it might not, idk, I have a pretty good pc, definitely good enough to run this game. Last issue, some times hit registering is spotty with cannons, the before mentioned goons had been challenged by me once I got my ship back again. I lay into their stern side of the ship and hit both of them head on with a cannon ball. They don't die, they then didn't have their ship sink and turned around popped one shot that hit my mast and I instantly die, cool. I respawn, run back on deck and I get thrown into the atmosphere with a shot that hit the side of my ship. At that point I gave up and let them have their way with me. I have seen all of these problems I mentioned before this specific moment, but, it just all collected itself into one instance.

Some positives now that I am less salty, you really FEEL like a pirate, almost all encounters you get are surprising and you get a genuine rush out of it. Landscapes, water, sky, colors, everything graphically about this game is fucking gorgeous. The amount of little things in this game that makes it worth playing with friends is beautiful. Would highly recommend getting some friends to play with. The mechanics to sail your ship is JUST chaotic enough that it keeps you on your toes and keeps gameplay fresh, I always find myself messing something up just once and getting a good laugh out of it when we tokyo drift onto an island shore. Combat and gunplay are all satisfying. And oh yeah, the sounds for everything in this game are top notch, especially all of the instruments.

TLDR: This game is fantastic, I love it so far and I plan to play it for many more hours. All of the good things about the game are really good and keep the game alive. Glaring issues that stick out to me: Long loading times, optimization issues (might be me might not), cannon hit reg issues. They don't happen a whole lot but when they do it really makes the game frustrating to play. Thank you for reading my rant/review have a wonderful day.

I've never played a game more beautiful and potentially fun.  It's surprisingly similar to Rust, in the sense that it's solely a numbers game.  4 dudes playing optimally on a sloop will always outperform 1 dude playing optimally on a sloop.  Play it with friends or don't play it at all, unless you're keen on being chased for hours just trying to turn in the most basic of chests and trade goods.  That being said, it's fantastic fun when tensions are lower and you can play a nice tune across that gorgeous water.

Personally one of my favorite games to play on Steam. You hook up your game to a Microsoft/Xbox account, allowing you to play with everyone who owns the game regardless of the platform. When it comes to playing the game, you get to enjoy sailing the huge seas, exploring new islands, encountering players with the plan of battle or the signs of peace, and each quest and loot that comes along the way can only benefit you... or bring you disappointment in case you meet the wrong players. The most intense moments are when you hear the music change to something more intense, when you hear and see a disruption and the water, and you get to experience a battle to remember. It could be a pirate ship full of skeletons, each and every single one having the intentions of bring you down. It could be a Megalodon with it showing hunger in its eyes, circling you along the way. Or it could be the Kraken trapping you where you once sailed, forcing you fight it by destroying every last tentacle none are left standing. In my opinion, this game will keep thing interesting and give you things to do until the end of time...

I fumbled my way through the first 4 hours of the game (which the game does a terrible job explaining what you actually need to do...) and found a few magic skulls and finally started getting the hang out of finding treasure.  Found my first chest and so I had my two skulls and my chest in my ship.  Was trying to find another chest when I see some player making off with one of my skulls. Great solo experience, even greater with friends (what multiplayer game isn't?).  I must have over 1000 hours of playtime on the Win 10 version,  600 of those hours may have been spent playing solo.  This game has it all.  It's relaxing at times, just sailing around the gorgeous ocean and checking out the lush tropical islands, enjoying a grog and catching some fish.  Intense at times, while running from pirates so you can cash in your loot, or battling a kraken who has paid you a very surprising visit.  The Tall Tales are told wonderfully and deliver a movie-like experience, the story is very deep and engaging.  The game is also HILARIOUS at times, especially when played with some good buddies.  As I said, I have about 1000 hours in this game, and it has it all;  relaxation, excitement, humor, everything.  Just like in real life, you may meet some nice people, you may meet some not-so-nice people.  It's the name of the game.  I personally love this aspect.  It makes it more exciting and real.  I have been gaming for over 30 years and can honestly say I have never enjoyed or played a game as much as I have/do this one.  The constant stream of updates and DLC will keep me coming back for a very, very long time.  Well done, Rare.  And thanks for this.

Very fun game with near infinite replayability. Even though it's a grindy game, if you have a group of friends it'll be a very enjoyable experience. If you don't have any friends to play with like me lol I would suggest hopping on the SoT discord server. There are very few veteran players who wont be willing to help you out. You can also find people to learn the game with. 10/10 would sink to a kraken with 10 year olds again.

I've been playing this game prior to Steam launch for about a year. If you're looking for a fun PvP experience, this game is not what you're looking for. This game used to have great swordplay, but the developers decided, for some reason, to remove all the skill gap from the sword to cater to a more casual player base. Sword play now consists of spamming left click, and sometimes blocking. Oh yeah, blocking doesn't work half the time anyway. On top of the poor sword game play, hit registration is worse on this game than any shooter on the market that I can think of. It seems like 1/3 of my shots don't register on enemies, even though the game gives me a hitmarker, telling me my shot connected. Not to mention there are plenty of times where I'll shoot an enemy and not get a hitmarker, but still kill them. Lastly, this game is loaded with bugs that the developers go months without patching, if they even decide to patch them at all. If all you enjoy is killing skeletons and digging chests (which is really boring in my opinion), then sure, this game might be for you. But if you want any sort of fun PvP experience, I would NOT recommend this game.

I want to love this game ... but the first "human contact" kind of set me of to a rough start ... a full galleon (fully customized, cannons hull color etc., not me) decides to attack a fresh, no customization at all, galleon (me, no loot on board, nobody on board for that matter, just wanted to make clear we only started playing) while we were frolicking around on the adjacent island... so much for the pirates code ... when i heard that people who were already playing the game wanted more players/more alive servers i was eager to get into the game. now having had the first "encounter" (backstabbing) i have to say if i wouldve had any loot on that galleon i probably would have refunded the game on the spot ... (pointless) pvp really screws with the pve part and i feel like pvp should be in some way or another optional to give pve players who just want to get some treasure a little more room or there should at least be matchmaking based on playtime or syndicate ranks so that newer players have a chance to get into the game without instantly being shit on by people with more experience ... other than that the game seems really great(havent seen to much of the tall tale content so far) apart from the pvp seemingly making pve almost unplayable with other players around on another hand i feel like having  a coop game where you cant have a fleet join a server (multiple crews on one server) seems kinda meh especially when you are a bigger circle of people say 5-8 people and only being able to play as a party of 4 really really sucks

overall a hard 2,5/10 for the game with pvp being forced a good 8,5 for the game without the forced pvp

First real people I met sank my empty, docked ship while I was scavenging an island. Kind of expected this given the nature of gaming online but the second people I met cheered me on as I reeled in a big ol' fish. While the servers may be a bit off sometimes and there's a good chance you'll be called a slur by raiding pirates, the sea faring, treasure hunting, skeleton slaughtering life is an enjoyable one.

Steam version has a ton of issues on launch. Makes game literally unplayable and support articles for the steam version are at the moment, non-existent. I'm sure Rare is working to resolve the issues but since the game currently will not launch at all for me and I have no recourse to fix the issue after hours of troubleshooting, I can not suggest buying this game yet.

Story of what went down:

I bought the game and installed it. Steam did it's usual "first time install" song and dance when I launched it, only the Microsoft Visual C++ install failed, it couldn't find the old version of Visual C++. I closed out the error window and then the game launched anyways. I played the tutorial and called it a a day. The second day I tried to launch it and same thing Visual C++ wouldn't install. Spent an hour troubleshooting that and resolved that issue, I no longer get a C++ install error when I try to launch. Instead it just doesn't launch at all. No "it launches for a second, I see the title screen and it crashes" type deal, just a click play, steam says I'm playing, 5 seconds later it says I'm not. No processes being run, nothing. I spent HOURS researching and troubleshooting, I verified files, I reinstalled everything including Cisual C++, all the articles from Sea of Thieves and Rare are written about the windows version, the ONE article I found that acknowledges steam version not launching says that anti-virus software sometimes flags it as bad. So I add an exception to my anti-virus (Avast). Still nothing. I entirely disable anti-virus and my firewall, still nothing. Rare seems to be at the very least aware of the issue, but after hours of troubleshooting and I still can't play, I just want my $40 back.

This game is complete, and utter bullshit. The fact that you can be attacked ANYWHERE, by ANYONE, at ANYTIME for ANY REASON is this games downfall. 

Bought the game, played 2 hours by myself, did the tutorial and then was thrown into the world. In that time, I was exploring the starting area, running around getting my bearings. The graphics are a beaut that's for sure. Started to get really, really excited about everything and what I was going to potentially uncover, and explore in this game. As im exploring different parts of this island, I noticed another ship, with a real life person coming into dock as well. I thought, "Very cool."

Little did I know, that would be the reason im leaving this negative and hopefully informing review. 

Suddenly, my starter ship comes under cannon fire, by the same ship that I saw moments ago coming into port. (Mind you, I LEGIT just learned how to man the sails, man the cannons, fix the ship, sail the damn ship, etc.) He yells out some sort of command to let me know, "Take all of there loot" or whatever it said, and then proceeds to run down the dock as I fire my dainty little Flintlock thinking this will do him justice. Little did I know, this dude looks like the Devil himself. He had a hook, and peg leg with a demon hat and eye patch. Proceed onward to the shit PVP battle, he pulls out his overly large upgraded Blunderbuss, and hits me 1 time to take away 75% of my health, and then hits me again with the last and final shot that sends my ass to Davey Jones Locker.

At that moment I realized that I just wasted 2 fucking hours of my life I'll never get back, and proceeded to rage quit just to end up here. Telling my sad, little tale for all of those who would like a good chuckle. Har Har, this game is complete garbage and will continue to do so, until the PVP shit is dealt with and balanced properly, or just implement PVE fucking servers for those of us who like to play games, without complete Douche bags ruining all the fun. 

With that being said, if you enjoy rage quitting, cursing like a Pirate, having all your shit plundered after hours of hard work and dedication in a moments notice, then please by all means BUY THIS GAME. If you enjoy an open world, free roam, single or co op experience with friends who detest PVP as much and my friends and I do, DO NOT FUCKING WASTE YOUR GOD DAMN TIME ON THIS ONE. If they decide to make this a private game where 4 friends can play together at the same time, PVE style sailing and fighting NPCS of all shapes and sizes, plundering islands fresh with booty, and gold da bloons to boot, then yeah, I'll give this one another go. If not, then let this title sink to the bottom of the ocean, and carry on you wayward soul.

Starting off with the positives, a lot of fun and great game play (with a catch). The game is an adventure game which consists of a vast world with lots of things to do and explore, its probably one of a kind and it's only rival would be Atlas. 
There's PVP and PVE elements, however as new players we mostly came across the PVE elements which were both fun and terrifying. "If you see the kraken you will die" will happen a lot. 

These are the stuff that has currently happened to us as of 8 hours - Sea sailing adventures, looking out for enemies, 'Why do I hear boss music?', kraken arrives, PANIC, killed by the kraken, set sail again, 'WHY DO I HEAR BOSS MUSIC PART 2', ghost ship spawns on us, PANIC, killed by the ghost ship, set sail again, searching for islands on the map, digging up treasure chests, underwater diving, solving puzzles (lack of common sense was visible in us a lot), playing songs with your band, cooking food in the ship, forgetting to take it out, cause mass fire, PANIC. 10/10 will do again.

Now then, the weirdest thing about this game would be the horizontal progression system. There's literally no progression it feels like the server has been wiped every time you log on. Now is this bad or good? 
I will take it as neutral as I enjoy the 0 risk of losing my hard work and grinded stuff for hours (which happens a lot in Atlas) and also I'm sometimes disapointed that it's the same thing over and over again and my ship and character never gets better. The game saves only your micro transactions which are purely cosmetic and never affect gameplay in anyway.
You will pick a new ship as you start the game and depending on the amount of friends you have, you can handle a bigger ship. Ship handling is also a great aspect of this game loved the part where one controls the sails, and one handles the anchor and wheel makes you feel like an actual pirate! There's sea monsters and other ships to battle as the PVE elements and random events happening throughout the world at certain times.

As for the mini progression you have some factions where you do different quests for them like find a treasure, kill a skeleton etc. Overall repetitive but fun with friends. You gain reputation with these factions
and unlock different items. (Again 100% cosmetic)

Graphics - The graphics are purely cartoony, and the art style is lush and beautifully detailed. Small forests are full of colours and very dense, water physics are amazing and realistic, getting shallow at wave peaks and 
the sea will roughen or soften based on weather and other conditions. The day night cycle is greatly detailed as well at night times you see aurora's and sunsets cause beautiful shadows across the sea. Animations are quite well done too with emotes and all of this just adds to the games great graphics. The game's opening scene and tutorial will awe you for sure!

Combat - One thing I didn't like much was the melee combat, (yet to experience ship combat) it was just simple sword fight with skeletons and gets repetitive. Guns work in the same basic way too and due to no progression, damage is the same there are some varieties of guns but nothing major.

Story - I'm guessing one of the main reasons for all the backlash was the lack of a proper story in the game at launch. Now the developers have added 'Tall Tales' 9 chapters of what seems to be like a great story.
We just finished the 1st chapter and it took us around 3 hours. This was probably the peak of the game finding clues in underwater wrecks, reading notes to solve puzzles and finding artifacts. Hope the rest
of the chapters are as long and filling. One more thing about the story is they are adding an entirely new arc which will contain another set of tales and currently 2 chapters have been dropped in.
I remember the game having a lot of backlash at launch, however the developers have shown quite a commitment. By just having a look at the patch notes I can see that every month since launch
new content has been dropped in and there's 5 major expansions as well. All for free of course. 

Sound - The music aspect in game is generally good, a great sea side sound track and eerie music at times when you find secret items and explore caves. You can also make you own music along with your crew as you have free music instruments. Never thought it would be so much fun!

Optimization - The game is extremely well optimized. One of the reasons I stopped playing Atlas was the server issues and frame rate disasters. This on the other hand I've never seen a server, never seen packet loss it feels as if I'm playing a offline game with friends! Frame rates are very high hitting 120-144 on my i5 9600k and RTX 2070.

Now for the catch - Loads of fun is in this game is possible only if you have at least one friend to play with. It might get quite boring if played alone and too difficult too. I wouldn't recommend if I had to solo this game. 
Is this worth it for the asking $40? Sure! I would recommend if you have at least one friend to play with. Maybe you can force a friend to play by gifting them a copy if the game is at a region price  :D

I’ve played this game quite a bunch before it came to Steam. When it first released, it was pretty notorious for being lackluster (similar to No Man’s Sky), but the devs have been super consistent about great monthly updates to the game that keep it feeling very fresh, and today the features it boasts are definitely worth the pricetag.

The way the game makes other players feel more terrifying than any monster or enemy you encounter is unlike anything I’ve played. I know some people get turned off by how demoralizing it can feel after a long quest to get raided by pirates and lose everything, but I feel like that honestly adds so much to what makes this game unique. It’s such a wild intensity that makes the game really stand out.

They just added a new feature this last patch which allows saving checkpoints on Tall Tales (the “story mode” quests), which is a wonderful quality of life change that’ll help people feel less worried or bogged down with long quests. So much of the tedium and repetition that used to be in the game has been reduced greatly with so much more variety in quests & events. The fighting and movement in the game feels so great, with the swordplay rock-paper-scissors of blocking, swiping, and lunging being really compelling in the heat of the moment. Learning to master the angles on cannon shots, fireball throws, mastering movement techniques, and learning ship control leads to a very gratifying feeling of growth as you switch from being intimidated by foes to being the intimidator.

Even though there are several little bugs that pop up every now and then, they usually don't hamper the experience, but even so the devs are very quick to respond. This game is wonderful and I’m so glad it’s finally come to steam.

If this was early 2017 and you asked me if I would recommend SoT I would immediately say no. Why? Because it wasn't a complete game. You barely had anything to do. The merchants voyages were stale and could easily be a huge waste of time. PVP was basically a waste of time if you found another ship w/o any treasure. And when you did find a ship with treaure because it took so long to get, almost every time you would end up in a stale mate or trying some unintuitive sneaking around to sell your few treasure pieces. Then 'end game' was none existent. You just got another faction to farm. Don't get me started on the in game items and how you spend your gold/dablooms....

Now, today. If you asked me the same thing? I would answer definitely yes. Now the game feels complete. There are several exciting world PVE events, 1 or two not so exciting, tons of treasure to find. Money is not such a grind anymore with the amount of stuff you can do. Tons of cosmetics for all currencies. Emotes, pets, and so forth. Just today I spent almost 12 hours doing voyages to PVP'ing to world events and everything felt exciting. There were really good moments to pick from, some clipped, and lots of stories to tell. Now it feels like a pirate game. Now it feels like worth while to spend idling and sailing because now there is a worth while reward.

The 1 major downside is the servers during off hours. If you tend to play when there is very few people in the server, voyages will feel easy with very little risk. If you want a good mix of everything you're best bet is to play during peak hours when there are more people populating servers. Again, during the 12 ish hours, we server merged 3 or 4 times because finding people, sinking them, and taking their treasure made all of them quit the server.


TL;DR : Buy the game. Play during peak hours. Sink some ships. Bask in the glory. Set sails so I can take your treasure!

Sea of Thieves is an absolute masterpiece in my eyes. It was the first open world exploration game i had ever played, and i couldn't put my controller down when i got it. I've met really nice people along the way, and a few toxic people too, but there's a few in every game you can find. The developers also pay attention to the community, and i love watching their streams. And sure, there are a few bugs here and there following updates, but with such a massive community, someone is always quick to spot it. Lots of people don't recommend it if you don't have any friends to play with, but solo slooping gives you a challenge and a feel of independence, and when you find the treasure it's honestly such a great feeling because you probably weren't just sitting on the ship while you had someone else go dig it up. The enemies in the game lack a little variety, sure, but people haven't stopped to consider how Rare would explain that 'oh now those cursed objects also turn people into zombies or something' and it would be a little hard to tie into the pre-existing lore. a great game overall, i definitely recommend it!

Game is great overall, there are a couple issues that I have with it, but for the most part, it's a good game.

Pros:
-Sailing is super chill, one of the most relaxing activities I've done in a game.
-Nothing is P2W, everyone has the same equipment.
-Variety of activities to do, if you get bored with one, you can switch to another.

Cons:
-PvP feels too focused on who can jump on the other person's ship faster and drop the other's anchor. I wish PvP was more based on Ship vs Ship.
-You really can't have a short session on this game. You have to usually invest at least an hour in order to complete even a simple task. 

I highly suggest trying the game out first on game pass, as there is a small learning curve to get full enjoyment out of the game.

[b]I played the Beta version of this game 2-3 years ago and I instantly liked it. I was planning on buying it via Windows Store but the lack of content it had in that time and also the price was very high in that time, so I decided not to buy it and wait for sale. There's been many rumors that this game (Also many first-party Xbox Studio Games) would come to Steam so I waited for the Steam release and bought the game as soon as it was on Steam[/b]


[u][h1][b]About This Game:[/b][/h1][/u]
[b]In this first-person style game, you play as a pirate who accepts and completes voyages on a vast open-world map mostly on the Sea and few numbers of small to medium islands. Player takes voyages from different Trading Companies in-game and earn Reputation, XP and rewards along the way[/b]


[u][h1][b]About The Story:[/b][/h1][/u]
Unlike other games, this game tells stories via Quests which is called Tall Tales. Tale Books are given to player by various NPC's who direct players to different adventures through out the world of Sea of Thieves which uncovers various secrets or stories in the game.


[u][h1][b]About Multiplayer:[/b][/h1][/u]
Though you can play the game Solo but this game is all about multiplayer. When you start the game you get a ship the size of your choice and put on a server where many players like you are in your server as well. Players can be hostiles (And yeah there's grieving involved) to you or they can help you if they want but everyone is pirate so don't expect friendship in the Sea of Thieves.

This game is best played Co-Op which supports up to 4 players and it's very difficult to play Solo as you'll need to constantly control your ship in a various way possible and of-course among other things.

Been following SoT for a lot of time, but never made my mind about it. Took advantage of the steam release to give it a try. I like it, a lot.
I used to be skeptic about a lot of stuff, mainly gameplay mechanics and PvP elements,  but not anymore.

Let's just say Sea of Thieves includes all the good old pirate clichés we learned to know and love when we were kids. Pegs, hooks, parrots, eye patches and such, it's all there. The overall scenario is a grotesque and cartoonized world where pirates can live free. Jump on your boat/ship, set sail alone or with your crew, complete missions and legendary quests to earn gold and buy cosmetics to show your wealth to others.

The good thing is that every player, from the bilge rat to the legendary thief is equal: no progression system at all, just cosmetics and gold. This is a very good thing. Every time you log in, you get a brand new ship that you can choose in three different sizes: sloop, brig, galleon. Each ship has a minimum of players to be used with, otherwise it might become ungovernable. To be more clear, a player can run a Sloop solo, but not a Galleon. The overall goal of the title is to create camaraderie among players, encouraging teamwork to operate a galleon or a brig in the proper way. 
Nothing will beat sailing to a destination and singing merry tunes all together or playing instruments while checking for the horizon for opportunities, monsters and even other ships.

The water physics are among the best I have ever seen. Beware the rough seas, don't sail upwind, check your bilge for eventual damage, leaks and floodings.
The Legends of the sea are present as well, a very good element to appreciate the pirate world as well.

I did not want to buy this game on the Microsoft store, and I did not want to use an Xbox Live Account, but you still force this upon us on Steam. 

Your gamer-tag system regarding the Xbox live accounts and the methods of changing gamer-tags are anti-consumer and underdeveloped.

Sadly, Sea of Thieves still uses the old unique gamer-tag system. I was not givin the option to alter how the unique version of my gamer-tag would appear on my 1 free change. But instead you only offer the ability to change your unique tag on the change that costs $10 bucks after the first free one. And yet, the system is flawed because I have to buy 2 separate changes to get the unique name I wanted, because I have to change my non-unique tag to something else and then back to the original for it to work due the system not allowing you to alter your existing unique tag unless you also change your non-unique tag to something else. 

It's such a messy system, even an Xbox Live Support Agent told me that I would have to buy 2 separate username changes just to get the name I want under my circumstance and that there is no other option.

I don't want to use a crappy console based account system on Steam.

If there is one thing Microsoft loves to do to its consumer base, it is to force things into their products nobody wants to push some mass Xbox based agenda.

Im sorry, but not having the username I should have had on my free change and then telling me I have to pay $20 bucks on 2 name changes after to fix the issue caused by your crappy system is insulting,

While fun to play, the experience is ultimately shallow because there is no progression. There is no experience bar, skill trees, or levels. There are no weapons, armors, or upgrades. Your ship never improves. You have one pirate and only one pirate and he will be the same day 1 as he/she is on day 1000. Every time you log in, you are reset to full health, no quests, and at a random outpost with a ship stocked with the same set of basic items. You only earn two things for your efforts in the game: gold and reputation. Gold gets you quests and cosmetic items. Reputation unlocks cosmetics and different quests.

If you are specifically looking for a solo or singleplayer experience, this game is not for you. While you can experience much of the game as a solo player, it is an effort in frustration. Quests take longer, not because they are harder as a solo player but because they are more tedious. You don't find treasure in this game, you find errands. Everything you find, from gems to crates to treasure chests, must be taken back to an outpost to be sold. Only then do you get your gold. If you get kicked from the game, either from a disconnect or from needing to step away from the computer for 10 minutes, your quests, ship, and any treasure you haven't turned in are all gone.
The game is really really fun.... until.... PVP. There should be an option to opt out of PVP.

Sea of Thieves is a game with a long history of ups and downs,
that have shaped what has now become one of my favorite games of all time.

It's hard to pinpoint what exactly went wrong during the 4 years before the closed beta started,
but to say that, what would eventually be released to the public at a full price, 
would shape the reputation of the game for years to come is an understatement.

Despite all efforts, Rare has been continually fighting the sour preconceived notion
from consumers that have grown cynical from years of being burned by corporate business 
not unlike the initial release of SoT. I'd say that mindset is more than justified.

I believe this game is a massive outlier when it comes to genuine ethical backtracking 
in terms of ongoing work retroactively fixing the game.

Over the past 2 years SoT has recieved close to the most free updates and hard labor of love 
I've ever seen put into a game that never needed it to bring the money in.
Many would say that sort of description already fits games like No Man's Sky, 
but its approach to it and the design decisions are what makes Sea of Thieves stand out.

Unlike NMS, progression in SoT isn't vertical, but horizontal. 
Meaning all of its mechanics can be experienced in the first hour of play 
and will not differ from someone like me, who has played it for over 1000 hours 
on the M$ Store version. 

While this means overall incentive is that not unlike your high score in an arcade game,
if you actually view the game as what is essentially an open world, 
per session arcade experience, the genius behind this design starts making sense.

Every single update the game has received doesn't suffer from the growing pains of any service game that relies on conventional progression systems.
If Rare decides to add a literal grappling hook mechanic to the game 
that lets you hook onto rocks and pull off drift maneuvers, 
you will get to experience that mechanic the moment you log in. 

This is where that approach really shines.

New mechanics aren't just one and done features, every single one of these now gets to be designed to enrich the gameplay loop itself, meaning the developers have full freedom to find all kinds of secondary and primary uses for just a single mechanic.

For example: 

The rowboat was advertised alongside the volcano region in the game, 
but it's not just a tool to savely park your ship away from erupting volcanos.

- Rowboats can be used as a stealth item that lets you hide your ship 
and silently sneak up to another crew to steal all their belongings. 

- If an island holds many treasures, a rowboat is usually the fastest way to gather it all up and bring it back to your ship if you're in a hurry, which you WILL be.

- If your ship sinks, your rowboat remains and you get a second chance to secure your efforts.

- Rowboats also include their own storage space and as of recently are a very reliable source of supplies if you find them on islands. Effectively cutting supply gathering time in half.

This doesn't even touch on how new features retroactively add to previous mechanics as well.
For example, the aforementioned harpoon can be found on certain rowboats as well which, 
if you have it docked on your ship, allows for an entirely new grappling angle.

So yes, Sea of Thieves is a service game. 
As such it has benefited from new content stacked on top of the already existing structure.
Thankfully that structure is incredibly flat and wide, meaning climbing that structure 
to reach said features is non-existent.

This unfortunately means what was already there could hardly be fixed without entirely redesigning the whole structure which has NOT happened. It's still the same game but with most of its holes and gaps being closed up by genuinely great mechanics and content.

Yes, if you played Sea of Thieves on release 
and disliked the "go from point A to point B, back to A then repeat" experience,
that has largely been unchanged and the occasional dead air, while now being shorter than ever, will probably still bore you as much as before. 

However when that dead air is gone, you will experience many many more interesting and fun
scenarios with an incredible amount of tools and ways in how you deal with those situations.

The point of this review isn't to just list all the positives and negatives, 
after all you will find plenty of those already, but to explain why people who have stuck with the game all this time consider the new additions it has received to be much more valuable than they might look to someone who's never played it.

Sea of Thieves has proven to not only be one of the most unique 
and fun coop experiences I've ever played, it reminds me of a time 
when Rare took a formula, injected as much of their own personality and charm as they could
and also manage to introduce an incredibly polished and innovative title 
that stands on its own merit... It just took as long as a Steam release to make that happen.

Hi everyone! I've played this game for thousands of hours! I just bought it on steam because I wanted to do away with the Microsoft store. There's a huge HUGE learning curve, and so I'm 100% going to list the pro's and con's as some one who has IDK how many thousands of hours on the game. Any controversial topics I will explain down below.

Pros
- Hundreds of commendations to unlock and achievements. Your effort and time put into the game style your ship and your character.
- Tall Tales are extremely fun to play through. The main story of the game is fun and a whole adventure
- Skull forts, Skull fleets, Fotd, and reaper chests are fun PVE, PVP environments that appear on the map to bring pirates together.
- Absolutely no P2W mechanics.
- Everyone has a fair start
- Many different treasures, emissaries, and ways to earn gold. By far a fun grind for me.
- A huge learning curve that's extremely rewarding after you figure out the ropes and get good.
- Easy to play with friends or connect with randoms.
- A wonderfully helpful community, that understand at the end of the day it's just a GG!

Now, a lot of people don't like the grind, and I understand that. Though back in my Halo 3 days, you earned armor from achievements, and it feels the same playing this game. You got cosmetics you can purchase, and cosmetics you earn.

Cons
- In game currency called ancient coins. Pay real  money to get content I feel should be earned instead. The game is already 40 dollars! The ancient coins are too expensive for a game at this price imo. 
- Getting sunk means losing hours of progress. This can be disheartening to a lot of the playerbase, even though it's a part of the game
- It takes too long to sail from island to island and to get to specific locations. So many hours just sailing.
- Too little amount of ships in adventure. Reapers emissary is boring half the time!
- Fishing makes no sense, and I feel is a very unrewarding aspect of the game. No one is gonna fish for 450 gold when one FOTD gives 140k gold.
- Arena is very unrewarding. Matches don't last that long, and I feel should have a different rhythm. Half the players you get on open play are mindless twats! You have to do LFC in the discord to even have a chance.

Now, a lot of people have controversy around the reapers bones emissary. I get it, it sucks when you get sunk. Though, PVP has always been an aspect in a game where you're meant to steal from other players and islands. If you get sunk, get better, get stronger, learn new strategies and fight back. This isn't solely a PVE game so people need to stop complaining. Yes, a reapers V emissary can see all emissaries on the map. So, form an alliance and take them down. If you decide to play solo and a galleon is after you, go against the wind. Look up tips online. 

All in all, I love PVP, and I love how reapers adds much more action in the adventure setting. It's fun to be chased, fight, and sink them. 

So, in conclusion. The game has a unique PVP experience that I love! The game's arena is mediocre without a fun crew, but can be rewarding with a decent crew. The ship and player aesthetics are absolutely rewarding as you earn them. The adventure mode has about 5k hours worth of your time if you enjoy the game, and I think that alone says enough. 

I'll see y'all on the seas. I also teach new players, so feel free to add me if you want a trainer.

If you are the type of person who can make your own fun in a sandbox where you are given virtually no direction, then you will enjoy this game.  Just don't go in expecting a grand narrative adventure from the start.  And expect to get jacked by other players.  Great game.

I've not played the game for that long, but starting off picking my pirate alone was a fun task, especially given that I was on discord with a few friends doing the same. Getting into the actual game, even just the tutorial was exciting. This game gives you that sense of "adventure". Most poor reviews I've seen have to do with a lack of friends, I agree to some extent. Initially I was playing with a random for just a few minutes as I waited for my buddy to finish the tutorial. The guy that joined my crew immediately tried killing me using fire bombs. Another guy joined us later and he tried blowing up our ship (he actually did). So, yes, there are a lot of trolls and random crews can be complete toxic. I can say this, even with just two people, we had a blast. Some of the downsides was we couldn't figure out a way to add friends unless going through the Xbox live friendlist (not a big deal, but annoying at the very least). You're limited to 4 person crews and we dont see a way to join on friends, at least not an obvious way. So for now, we just join the lobby at the same time and go in together hoping no one crashes. Despite some of these being major concerns, we've enjoyed it thus far!

The game is great to play with friends.

It's a good game, but there are a couple of issues.

1. No decent voice chat in game. Sure, the game tells you there is, but for many (myself included) it simply doesn't work. No matter what solutions one tires, and I've tried them all, it simply does not work. This is disappointing. Apparently, it has something to do with how Rare implemented things and many players who use a USB headset or microphone just can't use voice comms in game. This is a black mark against the game, but it isn't game breaking, as most players just type in chat anyway.

2. Adding friends or joining friends to play with together is an absolute ball ache. There is no way in game to add a friend. Doing so through Steam appears to be pointless also, as your friends list does not appear in game. Apparently, this is done via the X Box App. This is another black mark against the game for the Steam release, as these features should be integrated for use through Steam if it's going to be released on Steam.

Overall, the game itself is great, it's lots of fun. But is is hampered by these 2 issues which makes it fall just short of truly excellent. I wouldn't worry about lack of content either, as it appears that plenty of stuff has been added recently to keep people engaged, so I'm sure there will be more in future.

Playing solo and grouping with randoms has, so far, been a good experience. I have only been met with one bad group, and have found nice people to play with 90% of the time. I would say the community is generally positive and welcoming.

Another thing I would complain about is the need to pay money for pets. This is greedy for an already extremely rich company, and an already expensive enough game. Boo Microsoft, Boo!

Still, I would recommend this game and give it a thumbs up if you are into a bit of pirate shenanigans.

I left the Microsoft Store version at about level 47 in Gold Hoarders, Merchant Alliance, and Order of Souls which translates to around ~400 hours (if not more) or so unlogged on that client. The gameplay in "Sea of Thieves" (2018) is fundamentally basic however the feints, mind games, and digital hooliganism creates a full range of emergent scenarios in how you go about being a pirate. There is a quest item you can abuse for example to make others think you're trashing your loot into the abyss to spite them when in fact you are losing nothing.

Real skulduggery. The aesthetics and visuals of the sea as it transitions from different biomes and weather are unparalleled and sometimes produce nostalgia of older Rare titles for me. Sound design also deserves a mention.

In sum, the Steam client appears to run a bit better than the Windows Store client and as more people convert I will not have to navigate the Xbox Companion App which hangs and misbehaves. 40 USD was worth the hours I placed into this title just to avoid the headaches of that program. Time to become a Pirate Legend on Steam!

I have spent hundreds of hours on the Xbox App version of the game before the steam and this is one of my favorite games. There is tons of replayability and many different ways to play whether you want to focus on pvp or pve. 100% of the progression in the game is cosmetic so you start out with the only disadvantage against veterans being knowledge of the game. Its a game that is easy to learn but hard to master(particularly in the pvp area of the game). If this game looks at all interesting to you, I would highly recommend trying it. You can also play a trial of sorts with a month sub to xbox game pass on pc. You do unfortunately need to use an xbox account to play but you never need to use the xbox app again after making your account and adding players who play on xbox app/console. Cross play is done very well so its easy to play with people even if they arent on steam. The LFG community is also very large so even if you dont have any friends with the game, its easy to find people to play with. If you cared enough to read all the way through this, youll most likely enjoy the game so just get it.

A pirate walks into bar and sits down. The bartender notices that he has a peg leg, a hook for a hand, and a patch over one eye. The pirate orders a beer, and while he's pouring it the bartender asks "So what's the story with the leg?"

"Well it were many a year ago," says the pirate. "I were walkin on the deck a me ship and a rogue wave swept me overboard, and a shark swum up and bit me leg clean off! I swum ashore and were fitted fer a peg leg that very night."

"That's terrible," says the bartender. "What about the hand?"

"Well it were the very next day," says the pirate. "I were walkin on the deck a me ship and a rogue wave swept me overboard again, and a whale came up and bit me hand clean off! I swum ashore and were fitted fer a hook that very night."

"Wow," says the bartender. "So what about the eye?"

"Well it were the very next day," says the pirate. "I were walkin on the deck a me ship, and I were lookin out fer rogue waves, and a seagull flew over and sh!t right in me eye!"

"Oh man," says the bartender. "And that blinded you?"

"Well no," says the pirate. "But it were me first day with the hook."

Short Review: The game itself is unique. The story is short, but it's not meant to be played for the story then uninstalled. It's an online Co-op/PvP with a story. You customize your character, hop on an introductory quest to teach you the basics, then you go on your journey. It can be played with or without friends, although better with friends as most games are. But for the solo gamers with no friends, which i take are the majority of us, the game is still absolute fun. Give it a go, nothing is like it on the market as of now.
Dont get. Poopoo game

Just to be clear i am writing this review as someone who has played this game since launch through the Windows Store and not just for a few hours on Steam.

This game is amazing, easily the most fun and rewarding game i have ever played, yes it is very difficult to play Solo i will say that now and you probably won't be able to play solo consistently until you become experienced at the game mechanics but remembering a few simple basics like keeping an eye on the horizon as much as possible will go a very long way to helping you play solo.

There is a plethora of content to this game in terms of both PvE and PvP that will keep you entertained for hours on end, you can grind, you can play chill and you can fuck around. Story mode in the open world, awesome events like the Skeleton Forts and Fleets, you name it, the game has it all and has regular 4 weekly content updates keeping everything fresh aswell!

I have no problem admitting there are also flaws to this game, i don't want to sound biased because i love the game so much, yes there are problems with some bugs and the fact they update the game every 4 weeks means new problems present themselves alot aswell, but lets be honest, no game is perfect and to the Developers credit, along with the 4 weekly updates bringing quality of life fixes with the new content, they do also release hotfix patches on a regular basis to try and fix any bad bugs.

I will also add that you would need to have at least 2 hours playtime in any given session to make some progress in the game, any quest or fight in Adventure mode could take you over an hour depending on the circumstances so its not really a game you can hop on and play for an hour unless you were to do the PvP Arena mode in which matches are only 15 minutes long.

Sea of Thieves is an amazing exploration game where you can do many things. These things range from fighting the Kraken while having a leisurely sail along the ocean, doing voyages for the 3 main trading companies to earn money and rep and eventually building up to being a Pirate Legend, engage in intense PvP and even engage in the Sea of Thieves story and lore with Tall Tales.

The map is perfectly sized with 4 main regions (The Shores of Plenty, The Devil's Roar, The Wilds and The Ancient Isles) to explore to your heart of fire's content. This game is, in my opinion, absolutely worth the price and the graphics are a masterpiece. All round, this game is absolutely worth atleast a try.

As somebody that's been playing since the technical alpha, I therefore have at least an hour in this game. It has some of the best (and fair) PVP mechanics in any game I've played, as well as a pretty good microtransaction strategy which involves cosmetics, and nothing else. Zero pay to win mechanics to speak of. 

At its core, the combat is simplistic, yet so very deep. You only get three weapons in total, each with various skins that you can earn through in-game missions and in-game gold. You can also (sometimes) buy time-limited stuff, but it's all purely cosmetic, so if you're the type of gamer that plays with your parents credit card, you can buy a bunch of parrots or eye of reach skins, but you can't buy skill. Sorry, bummer. Guess you gotta get good manually through trial and error. 

And there will be a lot of trial and error,  especially in regards to how you operate your ship. There's a natural learning curve, and you *will* find yourself being absolutely destroyed by the more veteran players, at least for a while. You might even end up losing to a couple of Xbox players that just so happen to know how to operate their ship better than you. PC gamers do not have any kind of discernible advantage when it comes to ship combat. Sure, you can aim your cannons a *little bit* more accurately, but in the end, it doesn't really matter all too much. A cannon ball hitting a ship in one spot will do just as much damage as a cannon ball hitting a ship a tiny bit to the right of where you were trying to aim. Plus, couple that all with the waves and weather system, and the fact that physics exist, you'll find that your cannons don't always go where you want them to anyway, at least at first. You will eventually learn the patterns, and how to properly adjust your aim for the various conditions Sea of Thieves can throw at you. Point is, there's no advantage as a PC player when it comes to core ship vs ship combat. And no, that's not a negative by any stretch. 

All in all, Sea of Thieves is absolutely, stunningly, beautiful, with the absolute best water effects in any game, ever. Couple the water and weather system with the gorgeous lighting system, and you've got yourself eye candy for days. Seriously, you can take a picture of practically any island at any time of the day, and it'll always somehow manage to be impressive. So, great graphics, great gameplay (with weekly updates and events), fantastic naval combat, a freaking arena mode (don't do this, please), and the best player vs player combat I've ever witnessed in any game. Sea of Thieves is something truly unique, and is the absolute best pirate game you can buy. I'd even go so far as to say it's one of the best online games of all time, and I have over 5,000 hours in Team Fortress 2, so that's saying something. 

In short, buy this game. You will not regret it. Just remember, if you're a friendly pirate, you will be taken advantage of. Eventually. Just don't be salty, okay? There's enough salt in the sea already, don't need you adding to it. 


Oh, and beginners tip: if you're brand new to the game and want to test it out as a solo player, be sure to pick the Sloop, and create a Closed Crew. The Sloop is a small ship, and is great for solo players. Though, Sea of Thieves is definitely intended to be played with friends on one of the larger ships. A full 4-man Galleon with a proper crew of talented pirates will be darn near unstoppable on the seas, assuming there's enough teamwork to keep everything running smoothly. 

So yeah. Buy this game. I can't wait to destroy your ship and steal all of your loot... cause that's what pirates do! Arrrrggg!


ps. if you're coming from the Microsoft Store version, yes; all of your progress will be transferred over if you buy the game again on Steam. This includes your achievements, and everything else you've earned over the years. This includes the Xbox version, too. Everything is handled through Xbox Live, so all progress is tracked on their end, for a true cross-platform experience.

So, for the longest time, the gaming community has been lacking in the terms of high quality pirate games. Sure there are some here and there, but none of this quality. This game has very good graphics, and the cartoon-ish feel makes it more enjoyable than having super realistic graphics. It is also a semi-solo friendly game, but having a couple crewmates is the best part of this game. Its quite simple to understand, and mechanics are good.

-The fishing mechanic is intuitive and is quite fun, yet a bit annoying.
-Ship control mechanics are a masterpiece, due to so many factors on the ship making maintenence and such quite annoying, but is one of the charms of this game.
-Custimization is one of the most solid part of this game. Its fun grinding money for a while, then FINALLY being able to buy the outfit you've been wanting for a while. This makes it much more satisfying to grind, because the payoff is so good.
-Now that the game is on Steam, its much more accesible to many many players, and that makes filling up arena lobbies much easier.. It will also make finding opponents randomly when exploring much more common, which then helps if you're itching for a fight.

All in all, this game is shockingly beautiful and mechanics are great. As far as I've seen, I can't see amy game breaking bugs as of my small 6 hours of playing. This is also a game you always learn new things. With 153 achievments, its also quite fun to hunt and achieve 100% on this game. Highly recomended to anyone thinking of buying it.

Most fun pirate game since Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag
*I've played a good bit on Microsoft Store before I picked it up here, ignore my hours

Pros
++Cartoon-ish art style
++God-tier physics for the ocean water that is just gorgeous
++The world is fun with stuff like skeleton-manned ships and forts, megalodons, krakens, etc.
++Cosmetics-only progression; you have EVERYTHING when you start, you just work on your reputation in the factions to get cooler looking stuff (sword, pistol, compass, ship sails and cannons, a whole bunch of stuff)
++Something for the casual players as well as for the grind-heavy players

Cons
--None, really; you might not care for the open-world PvP aspect, but that's preference. This game does a lot right.

Sea of Thieves is the most amazing pirate game. Please don't listen to the first time new player reviews of this game. This game has a tutorial called the Maiden Voyage. This does explain fairly well the game and shows you it's mechanics. Be happy this is there. When it first came out, this game had no instruction. It was essentially DayZ you spawn and GL. But now the maiden voyage shows you every aspect of the game and gives you a little bit of free starting money if you find the key. This game is a PVP pirate game with PVE aspects to get loot. Players will compete in the world to sell your own loot and try and get others loot. All things bought in this game with currency is purely cosmetic. I have many hours on the MS Store and am Pirate Legend. So at least 300 hours. The game has bugs. Every game does. That's an aspect we will have to come to grasp as games get larger and more ambitious. But game breaking bugs need to be gone and rare tends to patch game breaking things fairly quickly. My only real complaint about this game is Skeleton ships are way too op rn on the sea. There have been at least 2 or 3 times I have recorded where they shoot 3 consecutive cursed cannonballs. Which is way too many. And the last thing is hit reg overall. Hit reg is pretty terrible but has been vastly improved from this last update a day or so ago. They improved player hit reg. Ship hit reg needs some work as well as hole placement logic. This game makes you always stay on guard to protect yourself, your ship, and your loot. This game has lots of fun things to do in servers from skull forts, fleets, voyages, tall tales, and mythical creatures of the deep. Be weary of the Kraken always...

If you are weary on getting the game still, don't get it on steam first.... Go to the MS store and try the game on xbox game pass where the first month is a dollar then you can decide if you like the game or not. Then fully purchase if you want to play it past the month.

I absolutely adore this game. It can be both relaxing and one of the biggest adrenaline rushes you'll experience in online PVP play.

Sail the seas in a personal adventure reminiscent of the 90's movie, "The Goonies". With cartoonish, yet strangely beautiful graphics.

The game's PVP is very balanced, absolutely nothing you do progression wise will make you "better" via PVP mechanics than someone just starting the game. Some will complain about this, I will not, I love it.

It should also be noted that you can NEVER opt out of PVP in this game, some just cant handle it.

But if you can... play with friends and experience a PVE (with PVP) storyline that takes you around the Sea of Thieves, or just attack other ships and pillage, fight PVE forts and fleets that give loot you must defend on your way to turn in.... or just chill and go fishing, there are many different things to do in this beautifully cartoony world.

The community itself is a complete wildcard, you'll find children, old men, teenagers, all with varying degrees of classic online toxicity. To some this is not a selling point, and to those with thin skin, it probably isnt. But for me, this is the perfect place to set out helping some n00bs with their loot haul.

Highly suggested if you've ever dreamed of being a pirate as a kid. And as a gamer from the 90's this is one of the only games that has ever rivaled "Pirates! Gold!" or "Sid Myers Pirates".

Buyer beware!  Misleading reviews and shallow gameplay ahead!

By this point most people like me have forgotten about Sea Of Thieves - wide as an ocean deep as a puddle.  
I figured that it would be worth a go and made the mistake of buying it at full price(thank god for steam refunds).

I get in and play the initial tutorial mission which takes close to an hour(this is a scam on the dev's part designed to string it out so that you don't experience the real game and get stuck with it and not able to refund).  From there I get to the initial beginner island.  I'm trying to figure out what to do next when I die suddenly.  Some griefing idiot came up behind me and stabbed me to death.  I spot their galleon pretty quickly and swim over and kill both of them without even getting killed myself.  So the take away there is that we have spawn camping griefers and the griefers that aren't even competent players.  After I call them out in chat for griefing they say 'it's a pirate game'.  What they should have said is - it's a toxic community.  I actually really appreciate the fact that they were there and gave me a wakeup call before it was too late to refund.  

After that experience the game's been refunded as I realised that it's not my cup of tea.  Objectively speaking the design is stupid in that you can have griefers hanging out to kill the new players right out of the gate.  
People who don't like being ganked or ganking others should stay away from this.  Also you need a group of friends to enjoy this with.  To anyone who says that it's fun with a group of friends - playing rock paper scissors, getting drunk and driving off a cliff are also fun activities with friends.  Almost anything is fun with friends which isn't saying much about the game.

In terms of the more technical aspects; the graphics look okay but are nothing to write home about, the music is about what you'd expect, and there's very little voice acting.  I didn't really play much of the actual game content but you can tell pretty quickly that it's a thin game without much point to it.  

If you're considering buying read the discussion boards first and watch some youtube vids/twitch streams to make sure it's a good fit for you.

Most importantly - what's up with the astro-turf reviews that have saturated this product?  This is a thin slice of mediocre PVP.  There's no way it should be getting a very positive review.  I suspect that either the dev or the gankers are out in force trying to pad the reviews with misleading reviews.

I have played this game since release on the Xbox game store, and to sum things up in one sentence: This game is incredible work by Rare, and is one of my favorite games of the last 5 years.

More detailed review to follow:

Graphics: The game looks stellar. Water and seascapes are rendered in incredibly pretty detail, even on lower graphic settings. The environments are varied and exciting to explore, and the ships and liveries for them are simply beautiful. The overall style of the game is more stylistic than realistic, but it accomplishes its visual look exceedingly well.

Sound: Take my advice -- turn on Windows Sonic for your best pair of headphones for this game. The game sounds incredible and is built to work around Windows Sonic. Gunshots, swords clanging off each other, footsteps on the beach, creaking boards on your ship... everything sounds just as you'd expect it too, and adds to the experience. The music is also very well done, without being overdone. Robin Beanland (composer for some other rare titles such as Donkey Kong Country and Killer Instinct) did the music work for this game, and I can't recommend it enough.

Gameplay: This is where it all shines, but also where the game may not be for everyone. First of all, this is a PvPvE game. PvP is an integral component to the game, and it is not possible to play alone on servers with no other players, as the entire game is designed around players encountering each other on the seas, and the best moments come from those interactions (whether they be cooperative or competitive).

I know some people will never enjoy games that have the element of PVP where risk is involved. If you are one of these people, this game is not for you most likely. However, I would recommend to keep reading, because this isn't yet another Ark, or Rust, or even a PUBG or similar. This is something entirely different.

The PVP aspect of this game revolves around the fact that you and your crew, can meet up on the seas with other players and their crews, and can choose what to do in those situations with no restrictions. Do you want to try to sink the other boat for sport, and take whatever salvage you can? You can do that. Do you want to try to avoid the encounter entirely and try to sneak around other players and avoid being seen/engaged? You can do that. Do you want to form alliances and cooperate with other players to take down the more challenging pve encounters, or simply pool your resources? You can do that. Do you want to pretend to be allies... only to eventually backstab them and take everything for yourself rather than share the load? You can do that too.

If it wasn't obvious, the point is that everything with other players entails a degree of risk, but also the potential for reward. It is very open-ended.

However, remember how I said this wasn't Rust or Ark? The risk to yourself in this game really is limited to whatever cargo or loot you are currently carrying onboard your ship... and your own pride. Should you lose, and have your boat sink to an opponent, worry not, for you aren't going to be set back in progress, or have to re-purchase your boat and all its components through weeks of grinding with unfun mechanics. A new boat full of supplies will automatically spawn for you, the only thing that you will lose is chests or other loot you currently had on board at that time. All in all, this is fairly minor, but it makes the pvp exciting enough to feel like it matters, and isn't just for sport.

Ok, so PVP exists, but what about PVE you say?

Well, there's quite a bit of it! There are 3 main trading companies (+ 1 somewhat hidden one that unlocks after a certain amount of progression) that you can run voyages for. These voyages can involve sailing to islands to fight hordes of skeletons, to collect their skulls as trophys, treasure maps that force you to use your navigation skills to find buried treasure, riddles that have you look for clues and puzzles around the various islands to lead you to treasure hidden there, or cargo hauling activities which involve picking up/securing certain types of cargo and delivering them on-time to pre-set destinations, requiring you to look after things like valuable silk, delicate rum bottles, or hungry animals on board your ship.

Along the way, your journey will evolve from these basic mechanics. You may stumble across skeleton captains with their own hidden stashes or orders, leading you to new riches you had not originally planned. You may get attacked by various sea monsters. You may encounter a cursed skeleton ship that will try to sink your boat... or even an entire fleet of them. Loot is also strewn abound the various islands, awarding exploration and encouraging you to explore the environments. Some loot may even give you new quests which you can follow to their conclusion for even greater rewards.

The loot itself can even be interesting. There are cursed items that will force you to play around their negative effects, and if you are able to do so, can be sold for very high prices.

In addition to this basic gameplay loop, there is a 20-30 hour story mode built into the game. These are called Tall Tales and will take you all across the Sea of Thieves hunting ancient secrets and magical relics, all culminating in an epic journey to a hidden land of gold and riches. 

I highly recommend this game. It is best played with friends, but even if you can only scrounge together one other person to play with, you can have a great time. Keep your wits about you and keep your head on a swivel, and enjoy the journey.

Sea of Thieves is a fantastic sandbox game, and if you're looking for a fun pirate game to sink time into then you need not look any further! That said, there are a few things you need to know before you make the dive.

First, it'll take a bit of time before you get good at the game. As with most sandbox games, there's a bit of a learning curve, but nothing too brutal or time-consuming. Learning how to sail and fight comes naturally as you play, don't be afraid to seek out a challenge to put yourself to the test.

Second, this is a rather social game. I mean that in the sense that you'll have to deal with people sooner or later. It doesn't matter whether it's a random crew you've just joined, or someone sailing towards you looking for trouble or fleet mates. You will have to deal with people, for better or worse.

And third, adding onto the 2nd - This is, at its core, a PvP game. You aren't safe from other players. They can, and will, attack or disrupt your voyage across the seas. But likewise, so can you. 

If you can live with that, and accept that you won't be a god at the game within a week, this is a gem worth picking up, for sure! If you can't, then obviously, do not get this game. I had a bit talking about why PvE servers are a bad idea, but I think most people understand why so I won't bother with it.

Friendly warning: Joining any Open Crew is a risky thing, 90% of the time, you'll be paired with absolute smoothbrains. Don't let it ruin the game for you. Ideally you should get some friends to play with, or join the official discord and find people through there.
If you enjoy PVE/PVP than this is the game for you. If you are looking for a PVE game it is not that. Fun with friends or solo. Yarrr!
